title: 莊子
source: Chinese Text Project (ctext.org) - James Legge translation

passages.zh: 北冥有魚，其名為鯤。
passages.en: In the Northern Ocean there is a fish, the name of which is Kun - I do not know how many li in size.

passages.zh: 鯤之大，不知其幾千里也。
passages.en: It changes into a bird with the name of Peng, the back of which is (also) - I do not know how many li in extent.

passages.zh: 化而為鳥，其名為鵬。
passages.en: When this bird rouses itself and flies, its wings are like clouds all round the sky.

passages.zh: 鵬之背，不知其幾千里也；怒而飛，其翼若垂天之雲。
passages.en: When the sea is moved (so as to bear it along), it prepares to remove to the Southern Ocean.

passages.zh: 是鳥也，海運則將徙於南冥。
passages.en: The Southern Ocean is the Pool of Heaven.

passages.zh: 南冥者，天池也。
passages.en: There is the (book called) Qi Xie, a record of marvels.

passages.zh: 齊諧者，志怪者也。
passages.en: We have in it these words: 'When the peng is removing to the Southern Ocean it flaps (its wings) on the water for 3000 li.

passages.zh: 諧之言曰：「鵬之徙於南冥也，水擊三千里，摶扶搖而上者九萬里，去以六月息者也。」
passages.en: Then it ascends on a whirlwind 90,000 li, and it rests only at the end of six months.'

passages.zh: 野馬也，塵埃也，生物之以息相吹也。
passages.en: (But similar to this is the movement of the breezes which we call) the horses of the fields, of the dust (which quivers in the sunbeams), and of living things as they are blown against one another by the air.

passages.zh: 天之蒼蒼，其正色邪？
passages.en: Is its azure the proper colour of the sky?

passages.zh: 其遠而無所至極邪？
passages.en: Or is it occasioned by its distance and illimitable extent?

passages.zh: 其視下也亦若是，則已矣。
passages.en: If one were looking down (from above), the very same appearance would just meet his view.

passages.zh: 且夫水之積也不厚，則負大舟也無力。
passages.en: And moreover, (to speak of) the accumulation of water; if it be not great, it will not have strength to support a large boat.

passages.zh: 覆杯水於坳堂之上，則芥為之舟，置杯焉則膠，水淺而舟大也。
passages.en: Upset a cup of water in a cavity, and a straw will float on it as if it were a boat. Place a cup in it, and it will stick fast; the water is shallow and the boat is large.

passages.zh: 風之積也不厚，則其負大翼也無力。
passages.en: (So it is with) the accumulation of wind; if it be not great, it will not have strength to support great wings.

passages.zh: 故九萬里則風斯在下矣，而後乃今培風；背負青天而莫之夭閼者，而後乃今將圖南。
passages.en: Therefore (the peng ascended to) the height of 90,000 li, and there was such a mass of wind beneath it; thenceforth the accumulation of wind was sufficient. As it seemed to bear the blue sky on its back, and there was nothing to obstruct or arrest its course, it could pursue its way to the South.

passages.zh: 蜩與學鳩笑之曰：「我決起而飛，槍榆、枋，時則不至而控於地而已矣，奚以之九萬里而南為？」
passages.en: A cicada and a little dove laughed at it, saying, 'We make an effort and fly towards an elm or sapanwood tree; and sometimes before we reach it, we can do no more but drop to the ground. Of what use is it for this (creature) to rise 90,000 li, and make for the South?'

passages.zh: 適莽蒼者三湌而反，腹猶果然；適百里者宿舂糧；適千里者三月聚糧。
passages.en: He who goes to the grassy suburbs, returning to the third meal (of the day), will have his belly as full as when he set out; he who goes to a distance of 100 li will have to pound his grain where he stops for the night; he who goes a thousand li, will have to carry with him provisions for three months.

passages.zh: 之二蟲又何知！
passages.en: What should these two small creatures know about the matter?

passages.zh: 小知不及大知，小年不及大年。
passages.en: The knowledge of that which is small does not reach to that which is great; (the experience of) a few years does not reach to that of many.

passages.zh: 奚以知其然也？
passages.en: How do we know that it is so?

passages.zh: 朝菌不知晦朔，蟪蛄不知春秋，此小年也。
passages.en: The mushroom of a morning does not know (what takes place between) the beginning and end of a month; the short-lived cicada does not know (what takes place between) the spring and autumn. These are instances of a short term of life.

passages.zh: 楚之南有冥靈者，以五百歲為春，五百歲為秋；上古有大椿者，以八千歲為春，八千歲為秋。
passages.en: In the south of Chu there is the (tree) called Ming-ling, whose spring is 500 years, and its autumn the same; in high antiquity there was that called Da-chun, whose spring was 8000 years, and its autumn the same.

passages.zh: 而彭祖乃今以久特聞，眾人匹之，不亦悲乎！
passages.en: And Peng Zu is the one man renowned to the present day for his length of life: if all men were (to wish) to match him, would they not be miserable?

passages.zh: 湯之問棘也是已。
passages.en: In the questions put by Tang to Ji we have similar statements:

passages.zh: 窮髮之北，有冥海者，天池也。
passages.en: 'In the bare and barren north there is the dark and vast ocean - the Pool of Heaven.

passages.zh: 有魚焉，其廣數千里，未有知其脩者，其名為鯤。
passages.en: In it there is a fish, several thousand li in breadth, while no one knows its length. Its name is the kun.

passages.zh: 有鳥焉，其名為鵬，背若泰山，翼若垂天之雲，摶扶搖羊角而上者九萬里，絕雲氣，負青天，然後圖南，且適南冥也。
passages.en: There is (also) a bird named the peng; its back is like the Tai mountain, while its wings are like clouds all round the sky. On a whirlwind it mounts upwards as on the whorls of a goat's horn for 90,000 li, till, far removed from the cloudy vapours, it bears on its back the blue sky, and then it shapes its course for the South, and proceeds to the ocean there.'

passages.zh: 斥鴳笑之曰：「彼且奚適也？」
passages.en: A quail by the side of a marsh laughed at it, and said, 'Where is it going to?

passages.zh: 我騰躍而上，不過數仞而下，翱翔蓬蒿之間，此亦飛之至也。
passages.en: I spring up with a bound, and come down again when I have reached but a few fathoms, and then fly about among the brushwood and bushes; and this is the perfection of flying.

passages.zh: 而彼且奚適也？」
passages.en: Where is that creature going to?'

passages.zh: 此小大之辯也。
passages.en: This shows the difference between the small and the great.

passages.zh: 故夫知效一官，行比一鄉，德合一君而徵一國者，其自視也亦若此矣。
passages.en: Thus it is that men, whose wisdom is sufficient for the duties of some one office, or whose conduct will secure harmony in some one district, or whose virtue is befitting a ruler so that they could efficiently govern some one state, are sure to look on themselves in this manner (like the quail),

passages.zh: 而宋榮子猶然笑之。
passages.en: and yet Rongzi of Song would have smiled and laughed at them.

passages.zh: 且舉世而譽之而不加勸，舉世而非之而不加沮，定乎內外之分，辯乎榮辱之竟，斯已矣。
passages.en: (This Rongzi), though the whole world should have praised him, would not for that have stimulated himself to greater endeavour, and though the whole world should have condemned him, would not have exercised any more repression of his course; so fixed was he in the difference between the internal (judgment of himself) and the external (judgment of others), so distinctly had he marked out the bounding limit of glory and disgrace.

passages.zh: 彼其於世，未數數然也。
passages.en: Here, however, he stopped.

passages.zh: 雖然，猶有未樹也。
passages.en: His place in the world indeed had become indifferent to him, but still he had not planted himself firmly (in the right position).

passages.zh: 夫列子御風而行，泠然善也，旬有五日而後反。
passages.en: There was Liezi, who rode on the wind and pursued his way, with an admirable indifference (to all external things), returning, however, after fifteen days, (to his place).

passages.zh: 彼於致福者，未數數然也。
passages.en: In regard to the things that (are supposed to) contribute to happiness, he was free from all endeavours to obtain them;

passages.zh: 此雖免乎行，猶有所待者也。
passages.en: but though he had not to walk, there was still something for which he had to wait.

passages.zh: 若夫乘天地之正，而御六氣之辯，以遊無窮者，彼且惡乎待哉！
passages.en: But suppose one who mounts on (the ether of) heaven and earth in its normal operation, and drives along the six elemental energies of the changing (seasons), thus enjoying himself in the illimitable - what has he to wait for?

passages.zh: 故曰：至人無己，神人無功，聖人無名。
passages.en: Therefore it is said, 'The Perfect man has no (thought of) self; the Spirit-like man, none of merit; the Sagely-minded man, none of fame.'

passages.zh: 堯讓天下於許由，曰：「日月出矣，而爝火不息，其於光也，不亦難乎！
passages.en: Yao, proposing to resign the throne to Xu You, said, 'When the sun and moon have come forth, if the torches have not been put out, would it not be difficult for them to give light?

passages.zh: 時雨降矣，而猶浸灌，其於澤也，不亦勞乎！
passages.en: When the seasonal rains are coming down, if we still keep watering the ground, will not our toil be labour lost for all the good it will do?

passages.zh: 夫子立而天下治，而我猶尸之，吾自視缺然，請致天下。」
passages.en: Do you, Master, stand forth (as sovereign), and the kingdom will (at once) be well governed. If I still (continue to) preside over it, I must look on myself as vainly occupying the place - I beg to resign the throne to you.'

passages.zh: 許由曰：「子治天下，天下既已治也。
passages.en: Xu You said, 'You, Sir, govern the kingdom, and the kingdom is well governed.

passages.zh: 而我猶代子，吾將為名乎？
passages.en: If I in these circumstances take your place, shall I not be doing so for the sake of the name?

passages.zh: 名者，實之賓也，吾將為賓乎？
passages.en: But the name is but the guest of the reality; shall I be playing the part of the guest?

passages.zh: 鷦鷯巢於深林，不過一枝；偃鼠飲河，不過滿腹。
passages.en: The tailor-bird makes its nest in the deep forest, but only uses a single branch; the mole drinks from the He, but only takes what fills its belly.

passages.zh: 歸休乎君！
passages.en: Return and rest in being ruler -

passages.zh: 予無所用天下為。
passages.en: I will have nothing to do with the throne.

passages.zh: 庖人雖不治庖，尸祝不越樽俎而代之矣。」
passages.en: Though the cook were not attending to his kitchen, the representative of the dead and the officer of prayer would not leave their cups and stands to take his place.'

passages.zh: 肩吾問於連叔曰：「吾聞言於接輿，大而無當，往而不反。
passages.en: Jian Wu asked Lian Shu, saying, 'I heard Jie Yu talking words which were great, but had nothing corresponding to them (in reality); once gone, they could not be brought back.

passages.zh: 吾驚怖其言，猶河漢而無極也，大有逕庭，不近人情焉。」
passages.en: I was frightened by them; they were like the Milky Way which cannot be traced to its beginning or end. They had no connexion with one another, and were not akin to the experiences of men.'

passages.zh: 連叔曰：「其言謂何哉？」
passages.en: 'What were his words?' asked Lian Shu,

passages.zh: 曰：「藐姑射之山，有神人居焉，肌膚若冰雪，淖約若處子，不食五穀，吸風飲露。
passages.en: and the other replied, (He said) that 'Far away on the hill of Gu Ye there dwelt a Spirit-like man whose flesh and skin were (smooth) as ice and (white) as snow; that his manner was elegant and delicate as that of a virgin; that he did not eat any of the five grains, but inhaled the wind and drank the dew;

passages.zh: 乘雲氣，御飛龍，而遊乎四海之外。
passages.en: that he mounted on the clouds, drove along the flying dragons, rambling and enjoying himself beyond the four seas;

passages.zh: 其神凝，使物不疵癘而年穀熟。
passages.en: that by the concentration of his spirit-like powers he could save men from disease and pestilence, and secure every year a plentiful harvest.'

passages.zh: 吾以是狂而不信也。」
passages.en: These words appeared to me wild and incoherent and I did not believe them.

passages.zh: 連叔曰：「然，瞽者無以與乎文章之觀，聾者無以與乎鍾鼓之聲。
passages.en: 'So it is,' said Lian Shu. 'The blind have no perception of the beauty of elegant figures, nor the deaf of the sound of bells and drums.

passages.zh: 豈唯形骸有聾盲哉？
passages.en: But is it only the bodily senses of which deafness and blindness can be predicated?

passages.zh: 夫知亦有之。
passages.en: There is also a similar defect in the intelligence;

passages.zh: 是其言也，猶時女也。
passages.en: and of this your words supply an illustration in yourself.

passages.zh: 之人也，之德也，將旁礡萬物，以為一世蘄乎亂，孰弊弊焉以天下為事！
passages.en: That man, with those attributes, though all things were one mass of confusion, and he heard in that condition the whole world crying out to him to be rectified, would not have to address himself laboriously to the task, as if it were his business to rectify the world.

passages.zh: 之人也，物莫之傷，大浸稽天而不溺，大旱、金石流、土山焦而不熱。
passages.en: Nothing could hurt that man; the greatest floods, reaching to the sky, could not drown him, nor would he feel the fervour of the greatest heats melting metals and stones till they flowed, and scorching all the ground and hills.

passages.zh: 是其塵垢粃糠，將猶陶鑄堯、舜者也，孰肯以物為事！
passages.en: From the dust and chaff of himself, he could still mould and fashion Yaos and Shuns - how should he be willing to occupy himself with things?'

passages.zh: 宋人資章甫而適諸越，越人斷髮文身，無所用之。
passages.en: A man of Song, who dealt in the ceremonial caps (of Yin), went with them to Yue, the people of which cut off their hair and tattooed their bodies, so that they had no use for them.

passages.zh: 堯治天下之民，平海內之政，往見四子藐姑射之山，汾水之陽，窅然喪其天下焉。」
passages.en: Yao ruled the people of the kingdom, and maintained a perfect government within the four seas. Having gone to see the four (Perfect) Ones on the distant hill of Gu Ye, when (he returned to his capital) on the south of the Fen water, his throne appeared no more to his deep-sunk oblivious eyes.

passages.zh: 惠子謂莊子曰：「魏王貽我大瓠之種，我樹之成而實五石，以盛水漿，其堅不能自舉也。
passages.en: Huizi told Zhuangzi, saying, 'The king of Wei sent me some seeds of a large calabash, which I sowed. The fruit, when fully grown, could contain five piculs (of anything). I used it to contain water, but it was so heavy that I could not lift it by myself.

passages.zh: 剖之以為瓢，則瓠落無所容。
passages.en: I cut it in two to make the parts into drinking vessels; but the dried shells were too wide and unstable and would not hold (the liquor);

passages.zh: 非不呺然大也，吾為其無用而掊之。」
passages.en: nothing but large useless things! Because of their uselessness I knocked them to pieces.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「夫子固拙於用大矣。
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'You were indeed stupid, my master, in the use of what was large.

passages.zh: 宋人有善為不龜手之藥者，世世以洴澼絖為事。
passages.en: There was a man of Song who was skilful at making a salve which kept the hands from getting chapped; and (his family) for generations had made the bleaching of cocoon-silk their business.

passages.zh: 客聞之，請買其方百金。
passages.en: A stranger heard of it, and proposed to buy the art of the preparation for a hundred ounces of silver.

passages.zh: 聚族而謀曰：『我世世為洴澼絖，不過數金；今一朝而鬻技百金，請與之。』
passages.en: The kindred all came together, and considered the proposal. 'We have,' said they, 'been bleaching cocoon-silk for generations, and have only gained a little money. Now in one morning we can sell to this man our art for a hundred ounces - let him have it.'

passages.zh: 客得之，以說吳王。
passages.en: The stranger accordingly got it and went away with it to give counsel to the king of Wu, who was then engaged in hostilities with Yue.

passages.zh: 越有難，吳王使之將。
passages.en: The king gave him the command of his fleet,

passages.zh: 冬，與越人水戰，大敗越人，裂地而封之。
passages.en: and in the winter he had an engagement with that of Yue, on which he inflicted a great defeat, and was invested with a portion of territory taken from Yue.

passages.zh: 能不龜手一也，或以封，或不免於洴澼絖，則所用之異也。
passages.en: The keeping the hands from getting chapped was the same in both cases; but in the one case it led to the investiture (of the possessor of the salve), and in the other it had only enabled its owners to continue their bleaching. The difference of result was owing to the different use made of the art.

passages.zh: 今子有五石之瓠，何不慮以為大樽而浮乎江湖，而憂其瓠落無所容？
passages.en: Now you, Sir, had calabashes large enough to hold five piculs; why did you not think of making large bottle-gourds of them, by means of which you could have floated over rivers and lakes, instead of giving yourself the sorrow of finding that they were useless for holding anything.

passages.zh: 則夫子猶有蓬之心也夫！」
passages.en: Your mind, my master, would seem to have been closed against all intelligence!'

passages.zh: 惠子謂莊子曰：「吾有大樹，人謂之樗。
passages.en: Huizi said to Zhuangzi, 'I have a large tree, which men call the Ailantus.

passages.zh: 其大本擁腫而不中繩墨，其小枝卷曲而不中規矩，立之塗，匠者不顧。
passages.en: Its trunk swells out to a large size, but is not fit for a carpenter to apply his line to it; its smaller branches are knotted and crooked, so that the disk and square cannot be used on them.

passages.zh: 今子之言，大而無用，眾所同去也。」
passages.en: Though planted on the wayside, a builder would not turn his head to look at it. Now your words, Sir, are great, but of no use - all unite in putting them away from them.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「子獨不見狸狌乎？
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'Have you never seen a wildcat or a weasel?

passages.zh: 卑身而伏，以候敖者；東西跳梁，不避高下；中於機辟，死於罔罟。
passages.en: There it lies, crouching and low, till the wanderer approaches; east and west it leaps about, avoiding neither what is high nor what is low, till it is caught in a trap, or dies in a net.

passages.zh: 今夫斄牛，其大若垂天之雲。
passages.en: Again there is the Yak, so large that it is like a cloud hanging in the sky.

passages.zh: 此能為大矣，而不能執鼠。
passages.en: It is large indeed, but it cannot catch mice.

passages.zh: 今子有大樹，患其無用，何不樹之於無何有之鄉，廣莫之野，彷徨乎無為其側，逍遙乎寢臥其下？
passages.en: You, Sir, have a large tree and are troubled because it is of no use - why do you not plant it in a tract where there is nothing else, or in a wide and barren wild? There you might saunter idly by its side, or in the enjoyment of untroubled ease sleep beneath it.

passages.zh: 不夭斤斧，物無害者，無所可用，安所困苦哉！」
passages.en: Neither bill nor axe would shorten its existence; there would be nothing to injure it. What is there in its uselessness to cause you distress?'

passages.zh: 南郭子綦隱几而坐，仰天而噓，嗒焉似喪其耦。
passages.en: Nan-Guo Zi-Qi was seated, leaning forward on his stool. He was looking up to heaven and breathed gently, seeming to be in a trance, and to have lost all consciousness of any companion.

passages.zh: 顏成子游立侍乎前，曰：「何居乎？」
passages.en: (His disciple), Yan Cheng Zi-You, who was in attendance and standing before him, said, 'What is this?

passages.zh: 形固可使如槁木，而心固可使如死灰乎？
passages.en: Can the body be made to become thus like a withered tree, and the mind to become like slaked lime?

passages.zh: 今之隱几者，非昔之隱几者也。」
passages.en: His appearance as he leans forward on the stool to-day is such as I never saw him have before in the same position.'

passages.zh: 子綦曰：「偃，不亦善乎而問之也！
passages.en: Zi-Qi said, 'Yan, you do well to ask such a question,

passages.zh: 今者吾喪我，汝知之乎？
passages.en: I had just now lost myself; but how should you understand it?

passages.zh: 女聞人籟而未聞地籟，女聞地籟而未聞天籟夫！」
passages.en: You may have heard the notes of Man, but have not heard those of Earth; you may have heard the notes of Earth, but have not heard those of Heaven.'

passages.zh: 子游曰：「敢問其方。」
passages.en: Zi-You said, 'I venture to ask from you a description of all these.'

passages.zh: 子綦曰：「夫大塊噫氣，其名為風。
passages.en: The reply was, 'When the breath of the Great Mass (of nature) comes strongly, it is called Wind.

passages.zh: 是唯无作，作則萬竅怒呺。
passages.en: Sometimes it does not come so; but when it does, then from a myriad apertures there issues its excited noise;

passages.zh: 而獨不聞之翏翏乎？
passages.en: have you not heard it in a prolonged gale?

passages.zh: 山林之畏佳，大木百圍之竅穴，似鼻，似口，似耳，似枅，似圈，似臼，似洼者，似污者；激者，謞者，叱者，吸者，叫者，譹者，宎者，咬者，前者唱于而隨者唱喁。
passages.en: Take the projecting bluff of a mountain forest - in the great trees, a hundred spans round, the apertures and cavities are like the nostrils, or the mouth, or the ears; now square, now round like a cup or a mortar; here like a wet footprint, and there like a large puddle. (The sounds issuing from them are like) those of fretted water, of the arrowy whizz, of the stern command, of the inhaling of the breath, of the shout, of the gruff note, of the deep wail, of the sad and piping note.

passages.zh: 泠風則小和，飄風則大和，厲風濟則眾竅為虛。
passages.en: The first notes are slight, and those that follow deeper, but in harmony with them. Gentle winds produce a small response; violent winds a great one. When the fierce gusts have passed away, all the apertures are empty (and still) -

passages.zh: 而獨不見之調調、之刁刁乎？」
passages.en: have you not seen this in the bending and quivering of the branches and leaves?'

passages.zh: 子游曰：「地籟則眾竅是已，人籟則比竹是已。
passages.en: Zi-You said, 'The notes of Earth then are simply those which come from its myriad apertures; and the notes of Man may just be compared to those which (are brought from the tubes of) bamboo-

passages.zh: 敢問天籟。」
passages.en: allow me to ask about the notes of Heaven.'

passages.zh: 子綦曰：「夫吹萬不同，而使其自已也，咸其自取，怒者其誰邪！」
passages.en: Zi-Qi replied, 'Blowing the myriad differences, making them stop [proceed] of themselves, sealing their self-selecting - who is it that stirs it all up?'

passages.zh: 大知閑閑，小知閒閒；大言炎炎，小言詹詹。
passages.en: Great knowledge is wide and comprehensive; small knowledge is partial and restricted. Great speech is exact and complete; small speech is (merely) so much talk.

passages.zh: 其寐也魂交，其覺也形開，與接為構，日以心鬭。
passages.en: When we sleep, the soul communicates with (what is external to us); when we awake, the body is set free. Our intercourse with others then leads to various activity, and daily there is the striving of mind with mind.

passages.zh: 縵者，窖者，密者。
passages.en: There are hesitancies; deep difficulties; reservations; small apprehensions causing restless distress, and great apprehensions producing endless fears.

passages.zh: 小恐惴惴，大恐縵縵。
passages.en: Where their utterances are like arrows from a bow, we have those who feel it their charge to pronounce what is right and what is wrong;

passages.zh: 其發若機栝，其司是非之謂也；其留如詛盟，其守勝之謂也；其殺如秋冬，以言其日消也；其溺之所為之，不可使復之也；其厭也如緘，以言其老洫也；近死之心，莫使復陽也。
passages.en: where they are given out like the conditions of a covenant, we have those who maintain their views, determined to overcome. (The weakness of their arguments), like the decay (of things) in autumn and winter, shows the failing (of the minds of some) from day to day; or it is like their water which, once voided, cannot be gathered up again. Then their ideas seem as if fast bound with cords, showing that the mind is become like an old and dry moat, and that it is nigh to death, and cannot be restored to vigour and brightness.

passages.zh: 喜怒哀樂，慮嘆變慹，姚佚啟態；樂出虛，蒸成菌。
passages.en: Joy and anger, sadness and pleasure, anticipation and regret, fickleness and fixedness, vehemence and indolence, eagerness and tardiness;-- (all these moods), like music from an empty tube, or mushrooms from the warm moisture, day and night succeed to one another and come before us, and we do not know whence they sprout.

passages.zh: 日夜相代乎前，而莫知其所萌。
passages.en: Let us stop! Let us stop! Can we expect to find out suddenly how they are produced?

passages.zh: 已乎已乎！
passages.en: If there were not (the views of) another, I should not have mine;

passages.zh: 旦暮得此，其所由以生乎！
passages.en: if there were not I (with my views), his would be uncalled for:-- this is nearly a true statement of the case, but we do not know what it is that makes it be so.

passages.zh: 非彼無我，非我無所取。
passages.en: It might seem as if there would be a true Governor concerned in it, but we do not find any trace (of his presence and acting).

passages.zh: 是亦近矣，而不知其所為使。
passages.en: That such an One could act so I believe; but we do not see His form.

passages.zh: 若有真宰，而特不得其眹。
passages.en: He has affections, but He has no form.

passages.zh: 可行已信，而不見其形，有情而無形。
passages.en: Given the body, with its hundred parts, its nine openings, and its six viscera, all complete in their places, which do I love the most?

passages.zh: 百骸、九竅、六藏，賅而存焉，吾誰與為親？
passages.en: Do you love them all equally? or do you love some more than others?

passages.zh: 汝皆說之乎？
passages.en: Is it not the case that they all perform the part of your servants and waiting women?

passages.zh: 其有私焉？
passages.en: All of them being such, are they not incompetent to rule one another?

passages.zh: 如是皆有，為臣妾乎，其臣妾不足以相治乎。
passages.en: or do they take it in turns to be now ruler and now servants?

passages.zh: 其遞相為君臣乎，其有真君存焉。
passages.en: There must be a true Ruler (among them) whether by searching you can find out His character or not, there is neither advantage nor hurt, so far as the truth of His operation is concerned.

passages.zh: 如求得其情與不得，無益損乎其真。
passages.en: When once we have received the bodily form complete, its parts do not fail to perform their functions till the end comes.

passages.zh: 一受其成形，不亡以待盡。
passages.en: In conflict with things or in harmony with them, they pursue their course to the end, with the speed of a galloping horse which cannot be stopped - is it not sad?

passages.zh: 與物相刃相靡，其行盡如馳，而莫之能止，不亦悲乎！
passages.en: To be constantly toiling all one's lifetime, without seeing the fruit of one's labour, and to be weary and worn out with his labour, without knowing where he is going to - is it not a deplorable case?

passages.zh: 終身役役而不見其成功，苶然疲役而不知其所歸，可不哀邪！
passages.en: Men may say, 'But it is not death;' yet of what advantage is this?

passages.zh: 人謂之不死，奚益？
passages.en: When the body is decomposed, the mind will be the same along with it - must not the case be pronounced very deplorable?

passages.zh: 其形化，其心與之然，可不謂大哀乎？
passages.en: Is the life of man indeed enveloped in such darkness?

passages.zh: 人之生也，固若是芒乎！
passages.en: Is it I alone to whom it appears so?

passages.zh: 其我獨芒，而人亦有不芒者乎！
passages.en: And does it not appear to be so to other men?

passages.zh: 夫隨其成心而師之，誰獨且無師乎？
passages.en: If we were to follow the judgments of the predetermined mind, who would be left alone and without a teacher?

passages.zh: 奚必知代而心自取者有之？
passages.en: Not only would it be so with those who know the sequences (of knowledge and feeling) and make their own selection among them, but it would be so as well with the stupid and unthinking.

passages.zh: 愚者與有焉。
passages.en: For one who has not this determined mind, to have his affirmations and negations is like the case described in the saying, 'He went to Yue to-day, and arrived at it yesterday.'

passages.zh: 未成乎心而有是非，是今日適越而昔至也。
passages.en: It would be making what was not a fact to be a fact.

passages.zh: 是以無有為有。
passages.en: But even the spirit-like Yu could not have known how to do this, and how should one like me be able to do it?

passages.zh: 無有為有，雖有神禹，且不能知，吾獨且柰何哉！
passages.en: But speech is not like the blowing (of the wind); the speaker has (a meaning in) his words.

passages.zh: 夫言非吹也。
passages.en: If, however, what he says, be indeterminate (as from a mind not made up), does he then really speak or not?

passages.zh: 言者有言，其所言者特未定也。
passages.en: He thinks that his words are different from the chirpings of fledgelings; but is there any distinction between them or not?

passages.zh: 果有言邪？
passages.en: But how can the Dao be so obscured, that there should be 'a True' and 'a False' in it?

passages.zh: 其未嘗有言邪？
passages.en: How can speech be so obscured that there should be 'the Right' and 'the Wrong' about them?

passages.zh: 其以為異於鷇音，亦有辯乎，其無辯乎？
passages.en: Where shall the Dao go to that it will not be found?

passages.zh: 道惡乎隱而有真偽？
passages.en: Where shall speech be found that it will be inappropriate?

passages.zh: 言惡乎隱而有是非？
passages.en: Dao becomes obscured through the small comprehension (of the mind), and speech comes to be obscure through the vain-gloriousness (of the speaker).

passages.zh: 道惡乎往而不存？
passages.en: So it is that we have the contentions between the Literati and the Mohists, the one side affirming what the other denies, and vice versa.

passages.zh: 言惡乎存而不可？
passages.en: If we would decide on their several affirmations and denials, no plan is like bringing the (proper) light (of the mind) to bear on them.

passages.zh: 道隱於小成，言隱於榮華。
passages.en: There is no thing that is not 'that', and there is no thing that is not 'this'.

passages.zh: 故有儒、墨之是非，以是其所非，而非其所是。
passages.en: If I look at something from 'that', I do not see it; only if I look at it from knowing do I know it.

passages.zh: 欲是其所非而非其所是，則莫若以明。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'That view comes from this; and this view is a consequence of that:'-- which is the theory that that view and this (the opposite views) produce each the other.

passages.zh: 物無非彼，物無非是。
passages.en: Although it be so, there is affirmed now life and now death; now death and now life; now the admissibility of a thing and now its inadmissibility; now its inadmissibility and now its admissibility.

passages.zh: 自彼則不見，自知則知之。
passages.en: (The disputants) now affirm and now deny; now deny and now affirm.

passages.zh: 故曰：彼出於是，是亦因彼。
passages.en: Therefore the sagely man does not pursue this method, but views things in the light of (his) Heaven (-ly nature), and hence forms his judgment of what is right.

passages.zh: 彼是，方生之說也。
passages.en: This view is the same as that, and that view is the same as this.

passages.zh: 雖然，方生方死，方死方生；方可方不可，方不可方可；因是因非，因非因是。
passages.en: But that view involves both a right and a wrong; and this view involves also a right and a wrong - are there indeed the two views, that and this?

passages.zh: 是以聖人不由，而照之于天，亦因是也。
passages.en: Or are there not the two views, that and this?

passages.zh: 是亦彼也，彼亦是也。
passages.en: They have not found their point of correspondency which is called the pivot of the Dao.

passages.zh: 彼亦一是非，此亦一是非。
passages.en: As soon as one finds this pivot, he stands in the centre of the ring (of thought), where he can respond without end to the changing views; without end to those affirming, and without end to those denying.

passages.zh: 果且有彼是乎哉？
passages.en: Therefore I said, 'There is nothing like the proper light (of the mind).'

passages.zh: 果且無彼是乎哉？
passages.en: By means of a finger (of my own) to illustrate that the finger (of another) is not a finger is not so good a plan as to illustrate that it is not so by means of what is (acknowledged to be) not a finger;

passages.zh: 彼是莫得其偶，謂之道樞。
passages.en: and by means of (what I call) a horse to illustrate that (what another calls) a horse is not so, is not so good a plan as to illustrate that it is not a horse, by means of what is (acknowledged to be) not a horse.

passages.zh: 樞始得其環中，以應無窮。
passages.en: (All things in) heaven and earth may be (dealt with as) a finger; (each of) their myriads may be (dealt with as) a horse.

passages.zh: 是亦一無窮，非亦一無窮也。
passages.en: Does a thing seem so to me? (I say that) it is so. Does it seem not so to me? (I say that) it is not so.

passages.zh: 故曰「莫若以明」。
passages.en: A path is formed by (constant) treading on the ground.

passages.zh: 以指喻指之非指，不若以非指喻指之非指也；以馬喻馬之非馬，不若以非馬喻馬之非馬也。
passages.en: A thing is called by its name through the (constant) application of the name to it.

passages.zh: 天地，一指也；萬物，一馬也。
passages.en: How is it so? It is so because it is so. How is it not so? It is not so, because it is not so.

passages.zh: 可乎可，不可乎不可。
passages.en: Everything has its inherent character and its proper capability.

passages.zh: 道行之而成，物謂之而然。
passages.en: There is nothing which has not these.

passages.zh: 惡乎然？
passages.en: Therefore, this being so, if we take a stalk of grain and a (large) pillar, a loathsome (leper) and (a beauty like) Xi Shi, things large and things insecure, things crafty and things strange; they may in the light of the Dao all be reduced to the same category (of opinion about them).

passages.zh: 然於然。
passages.en: It was separation that led to completion; from completion ensued dissolution.

passages.zh: 惡乎不然？
passages.en: But all things, without regard to their completion and dissolution, may again be comprehended in their unity - it is only the far reaching in thought who know how to comprehend them in this unity.

passages.zh: 不然於不然。
passages.en: This being so, let us give up our devotion to our own views, and occupy ourselves with the ordinary views.

passages.zh: 物固有所然，物固有所可。
passages.en: These ordinary views are grounded on the use of things.

passages.zh: 無物不然，無物不可。
passages.en: (The study of that) use leads to the comprehensive judgment, and that judgment secures the success (of the inquiry).

passages.zh: 故為是舉莛與楹，厲與西施，恢恑憰怪，道通為一。
passages.en: That success gained, we are near (to the object of our search), and there we stop.

passages.zh: 其分也，成也；其成也，毀也。
passages.en: When we stop, and yet we do not know how it is so, we have what is called the Dao.

passages.zh: 凡物無成與毀，復通為一。
passages.en: When we toil our spirits and intelligence, obstinately determined (to establish our own view), and do not know the agreement (which underlies it and the views of others), we have what is called 'In the morning three.'

passages.zh: 唯達者知通為一，為是不用而寓諸庸。
passages.en: What is meant by that 'In the morning three?'

passages.zh: 庸也者，用也；用也者，通也；通也者，得也。
passages.en: A keeper of monkeys, in giving them out their acorns, (once) said, 'In the morning I will give you three (measures) and in the evening four.'

passages.zh: 適得而幾矣。
passages.en: This made them all angry, and he said, 'Very well. In the morning I will give you four and in the evening three.'

passages.zh: 因是已。
passages.en: The monkeys were all pleased.

passages.zh: 已而不知其然，謂之道。
passages.en: His two proposals were substantially the same, but the result of the one was to make the creatures angry, and of the other to make them pleased - an illustration of the point I am insisting on.

passages.zh: 勞神明為一，而不知其同也，謂之朝三。
passages.en: Therefore the sagely man brings together a dispute in its affirmations and denials, and rests in the equal fashioning of Heaven.

passages.zh: 何謂朝三？
passages.en: Both sides of the question are admissible.

passages.zh: 曰狙公賦芧，曰：「朝三而莫四。」
passages.en: Among the men of old their knowledge reached the extreme point.

passages.zh: 眾狙皆怒。
passages.en: What was that extreme point?

passages.zh: 曰：「然則朝四而莫三。」
passages.en: Some held that at first there was not anything.

passages.zh: 眾狙皆悅。
passages.en: This is the extreme point, the utmost point to which nothing can be added.

passages.zh: 名實未虧，而喜怒為用，亦因是也。
passages.en: A second class held that there was something, but without any responsive recognition of it (on the part of men).

passages.zh: 是以聖人和之以是非，而休乎天鈞，是之謂兩行。
passages.en: A third class held that there was such recognition, but there had not begun to be any expression of different opinions about it.

passages.zh: 古之人，其知有所至矣。
passages.en: It was through the definite expression of different opinions about it that there ensued injury to (the doctrine of) the Dao.

passages.zh: 惡乎至？
passages.en: It was this injury to the (doctrine of the) Dao which led to the formation of (partial) preferences.

passages.zh: 有以為未始有物者，至矣盡矣，不可以加矣。
passages.en: Was it indeed after such preferences were formed that the injury came? or did the injury precede the rise of such preferences?

passages.zh: 其次以為有物矣，而未始有封也。
passages.en: If the injury arose after their formation, Zhao's method of playing on the lute was natural.

passages.zh: 其次以為有封焉，而未始有是非也。
passages.en: If the injury arose before their formation, there would have been no such playing on the lute as Zhao's.

passages.zh: 是非之彰也，道之所以虧也。
passages.en: Zhao Wen's playing on the lute, Shi Kuang's indicating time with his staff, and Huizi's (giving his views), while leaning against a dryandra tree (were all extraordinary).

passages.zh: 道之所以虧，愛之所以成。
passages.en: The knowledge of the three men (in their several arts) was nearly perfect, and therefore they practised them to the end of their lives.

passages.zh: 果且有成與虧乎哉？
passages.en: They loved them because they were different from those of others.

passages.zh: 果且無成與虧乎哉？
passages.en: They loved them and wished to make them known to others.

passages.zh: 有成與虧，故昭氏之鼓琴也；無成與虧，故昭氏之不鼓琴也。
passages.en: But as they could not be made clear, though they tried to make them so, they ended with the obscure (discussions) about 'the hard' and 'the white.'

passages.zh: 昭文之鼓琴也，師曠之枝策也，惠子之據梧也，三子之知幾乎！
passages.en: And their sons, moreover, with all the threads of their fathers' compositions, yet to the end of their lives accomplished nothing.

passages.zh: 皆其盛者也，故載之末年。
passages.en: If they, proceeding in this way, could be said to have succeeded, then am I also successful; if they cannot be pronounced successful, neither I nor any other can succeed.

passages.zh: 唯其好之也，以異於彼，其好之也，欲以明之彼。
passages.en: Therefore the scintillations of light from the midst of confusion and perplexity are indeed valued by the sagely man;

passages.zh: 非所明而明之，故以堅白之昧終。
passages.en: but not to use one's own views and to take his position on the ordinary views is what is called using the (proper) light.

passages.zh: 而其子又以文之綸終，終身無成。
passages.en: But here now are some other sayings - I do not know whether they are of the same character as those which I have already given, or of a different character.

passages.zh: 若是而可謂成乎，雖我亦成也。
passages.en: Whether they be of the same character or not when looked at along with them, they have a character of their own, which cannot be distinguished from the others.

passages.zh: 若是而不可謂成乎，物與我無成也。
passages.en: But though this be the case, let me try to explain myself.

passages.zh: 是故滑疑之耀，聖人之所圖也。
passages.en: There was a beginning. There was a beginning before that beginning.

passages.zh: 為是不用而寓諸庸，此之謂以明。
passages.en: There was a beginning previous to that beginning before there was the beginning.

passages.zh: 今且有言於此，不知其與是類乎？
passages.en: There was existence; there had been no existence.

passages.zh: 其與是不類乎？
passages.en: There was no existence before the beginning of that no existence.

passages.zh: 類與不類，相與為類，則與彼無以異矣。
passages.en: There was no existence previous to the no existence before there was the beginning of the no existence.

passages.zh: 雖然，請嘗言之。
passages.en: If suddenly there was nonexistence, we do not know whether it was really anything existing, or really not existing.

passages.zh: 有始也者，有未始有始也者，有未始有夫未始有始也者。
passages.en: Now I have said what I have said, but I do not know whether what I have said be really anything to the point or not.

passages.zh: 有有也者，有無也者，有未始有無也者，有未始有夫未始有無也者。
passages.en: Under heaven there is nothing greater than the tip of an autumn down, and the Tai mountain is small.

passages.zh: 俄而有無矣，而未知有無之果孰有孰無也。
passages.en: There is no one more long-lived than a child which dies prematurely, and Peng Zu did not live out his time.

passages.zh: 今我則已有謂矣，而未知吾所謂之其果有謂乎，其果無謂乎？
passages.en: Heaven, Earth, and I were produced together, and all things and I are one.

passages.zh: 天下莫大於秋豪之末，而大山為小；莫壽乎殤子，而彭祖為夭。
passages.en: Since they are one, can there be speech about them?

passages.zh: 天地與我並生，而萬物與我為一。
passages.en: But since they are spoken of as one, must there not be room for speech?

passages.zh: 既已為一矣，且得有言乎？
passages.en: One and Speech are two; two and one are three.

passages.zh: 既已謂之一矣，且得無言乎？
passages.en: Going on from this (in our enumeration), the most skilful reckoner cannot reach (the end of the necessary numbers), and how much less can ordinary people do so!

passages.zh: 一與言為二，二與一為三。
passages.en: Therefore from non-existence we proceed to existence till we arrive at three; proceeding from existence to existence, to how many should we reach?

passages.zh: 自此以往，巧歷不能得，而況其凡乎！
passages.en: Let us abjure such procedure, and simply rest here.

passages.zh: 故自無適有，以至於三，而況自有適有乎！
passages.en: The Dao at first met with no responsive recognition.

passages.zh: 無適焉，因是已。
passages.en: Speech at first had no constant forms of expression.

passages.zh: 夫道未始有封，言未始有常，為是而有畛也。
passages.en: Because of this there came the demarcations (of different views).

passages.zh: 請言其畛：有左，有右，有倫，有義，有分，有辯，有競，有爭，此之謂八德。
passages.en: Let me describe those demarcations: they are the Left and the Right; the Relations and their Obligations; Classifications and their Distinctions; Emulations and Contentions. These are what are called 'the Eight Qualities.'

passages.zh: 六合之外，聖人存而不論；六合之內，聖人論而不議。
passages.en: Outside the limits of the world of men, the sage occupies his thoughts, but does not discuss about anything; inside those limits he occupies his thoughts, but does not pass any judgments.

passages.zh: 春秋經世，先王之志，聖人議而不辯。
passages.en: In the Chun Qiu, which embraces the history of the former kings, the sage indicates his judgments, but does not argue (in vindication of them).

passages.zh: 故分也者，有不分也；辯也者，有不辯也。
passages.en: Thus it is that he separates his characters from one another without appearing to do so, and argues without the form of argument.

passages.zh: 曰：何也？
passages.en: How does he do so?

passages.zh: 聖人懷之，眾人辯之以相示也。
passages.en: The sage cherishes his views in his own breast, while men generally state theirs argumentatively, to show them to others.

passages.zh: 故曰：辯也者，有不見也。
passages.en: Hence we have the saying, 'Disputation is a proof of not seeing clearly.'

passages.zh: 夫大道不稱，大辯不言，大仁不仁，大廉不嗛，大勇不忮。
passages.en: The Great Dao does not admit of being praised. The Great Argument does not require words. Great Benevolence is not (officiously) benevolent. Great Disinterestedness does not vaunt its humility. Great Courage is not seen in stubborn bravery.

passages.zh: 道昭而不道，言辯而不及，仁常而不成，廉清而不信，勇忮而不成。
passages.en: The Dao that is displayed is not the Dao. Words that are argumentative do not reach the point. Benevolence that is constantly exercised does not accomplish its object. Disinterestedness that vaunts its purity is not genuine. Courage that is most stubborn is ineffectual.

passages.zh: 五者园而幾向方矣。
passages.en: These five seem to be round (and complete), but they tend to become square (and immovable).

passages.zh: 故知止其所不知，至矣。
passages.en: Therefore the knowledge that stops at what it does not know is the greatest.

passages.zh: 孰知不言之辯，不道之道？
passages.en: Who knows the argument that needs no words, and the Way that is not to be trodden?

passages.zh: 若有能知，此之謂天府。
passages.en: He who is able to know this has what is called 'The Heavenly Treasure-house.'

passages.zh: 注焉而不滿，酌焉而不竭，而不知其所由來，此之謂葆光。
passages.en: He may pour into it without its being filled; he may pour from it without its being exhausted; and all the while he does not know whence (the supply) comes. This is what is called 'The Store of Light.'

passages.zh: 故昔者堯問於舜曰：「我欲伐宗、膾、胥敖，南面而不釋然。其故何也？」
passages.en: Therefore of old Yao asked Shun, saying, 'I wish to smite (the rulers of) Zong, Kuai, and Xu-Ao. Even when standing in my court, I cannot get them out of my mind. How is it so?'

passages.zh: 舜曰：「夫三子者，猶存乎蓬艾之間。若不釋然，何哉？昔者十日並出，萬物皆照，而況德之進乎日者乎！」
passages.en: Shun replied, 'Those three rulers live (in their little states) as if they were among the mugwort and other brushwood - how is it that you cannot get them out of your mind? Formerly, ten suns came out together, and all things were illuminated by them; how much should (your) virtue exceed (all) suns!'

passages.zh: 齧缺問乎王倪曰：「子知物之所同是乎？」
passages.en: Nie Que asked Wang Ni, saying, 'Do you know, Sir, what all creatures agree in approving and affirming?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾惡乎知之！」
passages.en: 'How should I know it?' was the reply.

passages.zh: 「子知子之所不知邪？」
passages.en: 'Do you know what it is that you do not know?' asked the other again,

passages.zh: 曰：「吾惡乎知之！」
passages.en: and he got the same reply.

passages.zh: 「然則物無知邪？」
passages.en: He asked a third time, 'Then are all creatures thus without knowledge?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾惡乎知之！雖然，嘗試言之。
passages.en: and Wang Ni answered as before, (adding however), 'Notwithstanding, I will try and explain my meaning.

passages.zh: 庸詎知吾所謂知之非不知邪？
passages.en: How do you know that when I say "I know it," I really (am showing that) I do not know it,

passages.zh: 庸詎知吾所謂不知之非知邪？
passages.en: and that when I say "I do not know it," I really am showing that I do know it.'

passages.zh: 且吾嘗試問乎女：民溼寢則腰疾偏死，鰌然乎哉？
passages.en: And let me ask you some questions: 'If a man sleep in a damp place, he will have a pain in his loins, and half his body will be as if it were dead; but will it be so with an eel?

passages.zh: 木處則惴慄恂懼，猨猴然乎哉？
passages.en: If he be living in a tree, he will be frightened and all in a tremble; but will it be so with a monkey?

passages.zh: 三者孰知正處？
passages.en: And does any one of the three know his right place?

passages.zh: 民食芻豢，麋鹿食薦，蝍且甘帶，鴟鴉耆鼠，四者孰知正味？
passages.en: Men eat animals that have been fed on grain and grass; deer feed on the thick-set grass; centipedes enjoy small snakes; owls and crows delight in mice; but does any one of the four know the right taste?

passages.zh: 猨，猵狙以為雌，麋與鹿交，鰌與魚游。
passages.en: The dog-headed monkey finds its mate in the female gibbon; the elk and the axis deer cohabit; and the eel enjoys itself with other fishes.

passages.zh: 毛嬙、麗姬，人之所美也，魚見之深入，鳥見之高飛，麋鹿見之決驟。
passages.en: Mao Qiang and Li Ji were accounted by men to be most beautiful, but when fishes saw them, they dived deep in the water from them; when birds, they flew from them aloft; and when deer saw them, they separated and fled away.

passages.zh: 四者孰知天下之正色哉？
passages.en: But did any of these four know which in the world is the right female attraction?

passages.zh: 自我觀之，仁義之端，是非之塗，樊然殽亂，吾惡能知其辯！」
passages.en: As I look at the matter, the first principles of benevolence and righteousness and the paths of approval and disapproval are inextricably mixed and confused together - how is it possible that I should know how to discriminate among them?'

passages.zh: 齧缺曰：「子不知利害，則至人固不知利害乎？」
passages.en: Nie Que said (further), 'Since you, Sir, do not know what is advantageous and what is hurtful, is the Perfect man also in the same way without the knowledge of them?'

passages.zh: 王倪曰：「至人神矣：大澤焚而不能熱，河、漢沍而不能寒，疾雷破山、風振海而不能驚。
passages.en: Wang Ni replied, 'The Perfect man is spirit-like. Great lakes might be boiling about him, and he would not feel their heat; the He and the Han might be frozen up, and he would not feel the cold; the hurrying thunderbolts might split the mountains, and the wind shake the ocean, without being able to make him afraid.

passages.zh: 若然者，乘雲氣，騎日月，而遊乎四海之外。
passages.en: Being such, he mounts on the clouds of the air, rides on the sun and moon, and rambles at ease beyond the four seas.

passages.zh: 死生无變於己，而況利害之端乎！」
passages.en: Neither death nor life makes any change in him, and how much less should the considerations of advantage and injury do so!'

passages.zh: 瞿鵲子問乎長梧子曰：「吾聞諸夫子，聖人不從事於務，不就利，不違害，不喜求，不緣道，无謂有謂，有謂无謂，而遊乎塵垢之外。
passages.en: Qu Quezi asked Chang Wuzi, saying, 'I heard the Master (speaking of such language as the following): "The sagely man does not occupy himself with worldly affairs. He does not put himself in the way of what is profitable, nor try to avoid what is hurtful; he has no pleasure in seeking (for anything from any one); he does not care to be found in (any established) Way; he speaks without speaking; he does not speak when he speaks; thus finding his enjoyment outside the dust and dirt (of the world)."'

passages.zh: 夫子以為孟浪之言，而我以為妙道之行也。
passages.en: The Master considered all this to be a shoreless flow of mere words, and I consider it to describe the course of the Mysterious Way - What do you, Sir, think of it?'

passages.zh: 吾子以為奚若？」
passages.en: Chang Wuzi replied, 'The hearing of such words would have perplexed even Huang Di, and how should Qiu be competent to understand them?

passages.zh: 長梧子曰：「是黃帝之所聽熒也，而丘也何足以知之！
passages.en: And you, moreover, are too hasty in forming your estimate (of their meaning).

passages.zh: 且女亦大早計，見卵而求時夜，見彈而求鴞炙。
passages.en: You see the egg, and (immediately) look out for the cock (that is to be hatched from it); you see the bow, and (immediately) look out for the dove (that is to be brought down by it) being roasted.

passages.zh: 予嘗為女妄言之，女以妄聽之，奚？
passages.en: I will try to explain the thing to you in a rough way; do you in the same way listen to me.

passages.zh: 旁日月，挾宇宙，為其脗合，置其滑涽，以隸相尊。
passages.en: How could any one stand by the side of the sun and moon, and hold under his arm all space and all time? (Such language only means that the sagely man) keeps his mouth shut, and puts aside questions that are uncertain and dark; making his inferior capacities unite with him in honouring (the One Lord).

passages.zh: 眾人役役，聖人愚芚，參萬歲而一成純。
passages.en: Men in general bustle about and toil; the sagely man seems stupid and to know nothing. He blends ten thousand years together in the one (conception of time); the myriad things all pursue their spontaneous course, and they are all before him as doing so.

passages.zh: 萬物盡然，而以是相蘊。
passages.en: How do I know that the love of life is not a delusion?

passages.zh: 予惡乎知說生之非惑邪！
passages.en: and that the dislike of death is not like a young person's losing his way, and not knowing that he is (really) going home?

passages.zh: 予惡乎知惡死之非弱喪而不知歸者邪！
passages.en: Li Ji was a daughter of the border Warden of Ai.

passages.zh: 麗之姬，艾封人之子也。
passages.en: When (the ruler of) the state of Jin first got possession of her, she wept till the tears wetted all the front of her dress.

passages.zh: 晉國之始得之也，涕泣沾襟；及其至於王所，與王同筐床，食芻豢，而後悔其泣也。
passages.en: But when she came to the place of the king, shared with him his luxurious couch, and ate his grain-and-grass-fed meat, then she regretted that she had wept.

passages.zh: 予惡乎知夫死者不悔其始之蘄生乎！
passages.en: How do I know that the dead do not repent of their former craving for life?

passages.zh: 夢飲酒者，旦而哭泣；夢哭泣者，旦而田獵。
passages.en: Those who dream of (the pleasures of) drinking may in the morning wail and weep; those who dream of wailing and weeping may in the morning be going out to hunt.

passages.zh: 方其夢也，不知其夢也。
passages.en: When they were dreaming they did not know it was a dream;

passages.zh: 夢之中又占其夢焉，覺而後知其夢也。
passages.en: in their dream they may even have tried to interpret it; but when they awoke they knew that it was a dream.

passages.zh: 且有大覺而後知此其大夢也，而愚者自以為覺，竊竊然知之。
passages.en: And there is the great awaking, after which we shall know that this life was a great dream. All the while, the stupid think they are awake, and with nice discrimination insist on their knowledge;

passages.zh: 君乎，牧乎，固哉！
passages.en: now playing the part of rulers, and now of grooms.

passages.zh: 丘也，與女皆夢也；予謂女夢，亦夢也。
passages.en: Bigoted was that Qiu! He and you are both dreaming. I who say that you are dreaming am dreaming myself.

passages.zh: 是其言也，其名為弔詭。
passages.en: These words seem very strange; but if after ten thousand ages we once meet with a great sage who knows how to explain them, it will be as if we met him (unexpectedly) some morning or evening.

passages.zh: 萬世之後，而一遇大聖知其解者，是旦暮遇之也。
passages.en: Since you made me enter into this discussion with you, if you have got the better of me and not I of you, are you indeed right, and I indeed wrong?

passages.zh: 既使我與若辯矣，若勝我，我不若勝，若果是也？
passages.en: If I have got the better of you and not you of me, am I indeed right and you indeed wrong?

passages.zh: 我果非也邪？
passages.en: Is the one of us right and the other wrong?

passages.zh: 我勝若，若不吾勝，我果是也？
passages.en: are we both right or both wrong?

passages.zh: 而果非也邪？
passages.en: Since we cannot come to a mutual and common understanding, men will certainly continue in darkness on the subject.

passages.zh: 其或是也，其或非也邪？
passages.en: Whom shall I employ to adjudicate in the matter?

passages.zh: 其俱是也，其俱非也邪？
passages.en: If I employ one who agrees with you, how can he, agreeing with you, do so correctly?

passages.zh: 我與若不能相知也，則人固受其黮闇。
passages.en: If I employ one who agrees with me, how can he, agreeing with me, do so correctly?

passages.zh: 吾誰使正之？
passages.en: If I employ one who disagrees with you and I, how can he, disagreeing with you and I, do so correctly?

passages.zh: 使同乎若者正之，既與若同矣，惡能正之！
passages.en: If I employ one who agrees with you and I, how can he, agreeing with you and I, do so correctly?

passages.zh: 使同乎我者正之，既同乎我矣，惡能正之！
passages.en: In this way I and you and those others would all not be able to come to a mutual understanding; and shall we then wait for that (great sage)?

passages.zh: 使異乎我與若者正之，既異乎我與若矣，惡能正之！
passages.en: (We need not do so.) To wait on others to learn how conflicting opinions are changed is simply like not so waiting at all.

passages.zh: 使同乎我與若者正之，既同乎我與若矣，惡能正之！
passages.en: The harmonising of them is to be found in the invisible operation of Heaven, and by following this on into the unlimited past.

passages.zh: 然則我與若與人俱不能相知也，而待彼也邪？
passages.en: It is by this method that we can complete our years (without our minds being disturbed).

passages.zh: 何化聲之相待，若其不相待。
passages.en: What is meant by harmonising (conflicting opinions) in the invisible operation of Heaven?

passages.zh: 和之以天倪，因之以曼衍，所以窮年也。
passages.en: There is the affirmation and the denial of it; and there is the assertion of an opinion and the rejection of it.

passages.zh: 謂和之以天倪？
passages.en: If the affirmation be according to the reality of the fact, it is certainly different from the denial of it - there can be no dispute about that.

passages.zh: 曰：是不是，然不然。
passages.en: If the assertion of an opinion be correct, it is certainly different from its rejection - neither can there be any dispute about that.

passages.zh: 是若果是也，則是之異乎不是也亦無辯；然若果然也，則然之異乎不然也亦無辯。
passages.en: Let us forget the lapse of time; let us forget the conflict of opinions.

passages.zh: 化聲之相待，若其不相待。
passages.en: Let us make our appeal to the Infinite, and take up our position there.'

passages.zh: 和之以天倪，因之以曼衍，所以窮年也。
passages.en: The Penumbra asked the Shadow, saying, 'Formerly you were walking on, and now you have stopped; formerly you were sitting, and now you have risen up - how is it that you are so without stability?'

passages.zh: 忘年忘義，振於無竟，故寓諸無竟。」
passages.en: The Shadow replied, 'I wait for the movements of something else to do what I do, and that something else on which I wait waits further on another to do as it does.

passages.zh: 罔兩問景曰：「曩子行，今子止，曩子坐，今子起，何其無特操與？」
passages.en: My waiting, is it for the scales of a snake, or the wings of a cicada? How should I know why I do one thing, or do not do another?

passages.zh: 景曰：「吾有待而然者邪！
passages.en: Formerly, I, Zhuang Zhou, dreamt that I was a butterfly, a butterfly flying about, feeling that it was enjoying itself.

passages.zh: 吾所待又有待而然者邪！
passages.en: I did not know that it was Zhou.

passages.zh: 吾待蛇蚹、蜩翼邪！
passages.en: Suddenly I awoke, and was myself again, the veritable Zhou.

passages.zh: 惡識所以然？
passages.en: I did not know whether it had formerly been Zhou dreaming that he was a butterfly, or it was now a butterfly dreaming that it was Zhou.

passages.zh: 惡識所以不然？」
passages.en: But between Zhou and a butterfly there must be a difference.

passages.zh: 昔者莊周夢為胡蝶，栩栩然胡蝶也，自喻適志與！
passages.en: This is a case of what is called the Transformation of Things.'

passages.zh: 不知周也。
俄然覺，則蘧蘧然周也。
不知周之夢為胡蝶與，胡蝶之夢為周與？
周與胡蝶，則必有分矣。
此之謂物化。
吾生也有涯，而知也无涯。
passages.en: There is a limit to our life, but to knowledge there is no limit.

passages.zh: 以有涯隨无涯，殆已；已而為知者，殆而已矣。
passages.en: With what is limited to pursue after what is unlimited is a perilous thing; and when, knowing this, we still seek the increase of our knowledge, the peril cannot be averted.

passages.zh: 為善无近名，為惡无近刑。
passages.en: There should not be the practice of what is good with any thought of the fame (which it will bring), nor of what is evil with any approximation to the punishment (which it will incur):

passages.zh: 緣督以為經，可以保身，可以全生，可以養親，可以盡年。
passages.en: an accordance with the Central Element (of our nature) is the regular way to preserve the body, to maintain the life, to nourish our parents, and to complete our term of years.

passages.zh: 庖丁為文惠君解牛，手之所觸，肩之所倚，足之所履，膝之所踦，砉然嚮然，奏刀騞然，莫不中音。
passages.en: His cook was cutting up an ox for the ruler Wen Hui. Whenever he applied his hand, leaned forward with his shoulder, planted his foot, and employed the pressure of his knee, in the audible ripping off of the skin, and slicing operation of the knife, the sounds were all in regular cadence.

passages.zh: 合於《桑林》之舞，乃中《經首》之會。
passages.en: Movements and sounds proceeded as in the dance of 'the Mulberry Forest' and the blended notes of the King Shou.'

passages.zh: 文惠君曰：「譆！善哉！技蓋至此乎？」
passages.en: The ruler said, 'Ah! Admirable! That your art should have become so perfect!'

passages.zh: 庖丁釋刀對曰：「臣之所好者道也，進乎技矣。
passages.en: (Having finished his operation), the cook laid down his knife, and replied to the remark, 'What your servant loves is the method of the Dao, something in advance of any art.

passages.zh: 始臣之解牛之時，所見无非牛者。
passages.en: When I first began to cut up an ox, I saw nothing but the (entire) carcase.

passages.zh: 三年之後，未嘗見全牛也。
passages.en: After three years I ceased to see it as a whole.

passages.zh: 方今之時，臣以神遇，而不以目視，官知止而神欲行。
passages.en: Now I deal with it in a spirit-like manner, and do not look at it with my eyes. The use of my senses is discarded, and my spirit acts as it wills.

passages.zh: 依乎天理，批大郤，導大窾，因其固然。
passages.en: Observing the natural lines, (my knife) slips through the great crevices and slides through the great cavities, taking advantage of the facilities thus presented.

passages.zh: 技經肯綮之未嘗，而況大軱乎！
passages.en: My art avoids the membranous ligatures, and much more the great bones.

passages.zh: 良庖歲更刀，割也；族庖月更刀，折也。
passages.en: A good cook changes his knife every year; (it may have been injured) in cutting - an ordinary cook changes his every month - (it may have been) broken.

passages.zh: 今臣之刀十九年矣，所解數千牛矣，而刀刃若新發於硎。
passages.en: Now my knife has been in use for nineteen years; it has cut up several thousand oxen, and yet its edge is as sharp as if it had newly come from the whetstone.

passages.zh: 彼節者有間，而刀刃者无厚，以无厚入有間，恢恢乎其於遊刃必有餘地矣，是以十九年而刀刃若新發於硎。
passages.en: There are the interstices of the joints, and the edge of the knife has no (appreciable) thickness; when that which is so thin enters where the interstice is, how easily it moves along! The blade has more than room enough.

passages.zh: 雖然，每至於族，吾見其難為，怵然為戒，視為止，行為遲。
passages.en: Nevertheless, whenever I come to a complicated joint, and see that there will be some difficulty, I proceed anxiously and with caution, not allowing my eyes to wander from the place, and moving my hand slowly.

passages.zh: 動刀甚微，謋然已解，如土委地。
passages.en: Then by a very slight movement of the knife, the part is quickly separated, and drops like (a clod of) earth to the ground.

passages.zh: 提刀而立，為之四顧，為之躊躇滿志，善刀而藏之。」
passages.en: Then standing up with the knife in my hand, I look all round, and in a leisurely manner, with an air of satisfaction, wipe it clean, and put it in its sheath.'

passages.zh: 文惠君曰：「善哉！吾聞庖丁之言，得養生焉。」
passages.en: The ruler Wen Hui said, 'Excellent! I have heard the words of my cook, and learned from them the nourishment of (our) life.'

passages.zh: 公文軒見右師而驚曰：「是何人也？」
passages.en: When Gong-wen Xian saw the Master of the Left, he was startled, and said, 'What sort of man is this?

passages.zh: 惡乎介也？
passages.en: How is it he has but one foot?

passages.zh: 天與，其人與？」
passages.en: Is it from Heaven? or from Man?'

passages.zh: 曰：「天也，非人也。
passages.en: Then he added, 'It must be from Heaven, and not from Man.

passages.zh: 天之生是使獨也，人之貌有與也。
passages.en: Heaven's making of this man caused him to have but one foot.

passages.zh: 以是知其天也，非人也。」
passages.en: In the person of man, each foot has its marrow. By this I know that his peculiarity is from Heaven, and not from Man.

passages.zh: 澤雉十步一啄，百步一飲，不蘄畜乎樊中。
passages.en: A pheasant of the marshes has to take ten steps to pick up a mouthful of food, and thirty steps to get a drink, but it does not seek to be nourished in a coop.

passages.zh: 神雖王，不善也。
passages.en: Though its spirit would (there) enjoy a royal abundance, it does not think (such confinement) good.'

passages.zh: 老聃死，秦失弔之，三號而出。
passages.en: When Lao Dan died, Qin Shi went to condole (with his son), but after crying out three times, he came out.

passages.zh: 弟子曰：「非夫子之友邪？」
passages.en: The disciples said to him, 'Were you not a friend of the Master?'
'I was,' he replied,

passages.zh: 「然則弔焉若此，可乎？」
passages.en: and they said, 'Is it proper then to offer your condolences merely as you have done?'

passages.zh: 曰：「然。始也，吾以為其人也，而今非也。
passages.en: He said, 'It is. At first I thought he was the man of men, and now I do not think so.

passages.zh: 向吾入而弔焉，有老者哭之，如哭其子；少者哭之，如哭其母。
passages.en: When I entered a little ago and expressed my condolences, there were the old men wailing as if they had lost a son, and the young men wailing as if they had lost their mother.

passages.zh: 彼其所以會之，必有不蘄言而言，不蘄哭而哭者。
passages.en: In his attracting and uniting them to himself in such a way there must have been that which made them involuntarily express their words (of condolence), and involuntarily wail, as they were doing.

passages.zh: 是遁天倍情，忘其所受，古者謂之遁天之刑。
passages.en: And this was a hiding from himself of his Heaven (-nature), and an excessive indulgence of his (human) feelings; a forgetting of what he had received (in being born); what the ancients called the punishment due to neglecting the Heaven (-nature).

passages.zh: 適來，夫子時也；適去，夫子順也。
passages.en: When the Master came, it was at the proper time; when he went away, it was the simple sequence (of his coming).

passages.zh: 安時而處順，哀樂不能入也，古者謂是帝之縣解。」
passages.en: Quiet acquiescence in what happens at its proper time, and quietly submitting (to its ceasing) afford no occasion for grief or for joy. The ancients described (death) as the loosening of the cord on which God suspended (the life).

passages.zh: 指窮於為薪，火傳也，不知其盡也。
passages.en: What we can point to are the faggots that have been consumed; but the fire is transmitted (elsewhere), and we know not that it is over and ended.

chapters.title: Man In The World Associated With

passages.zh: 顏回見仲尼請行。
passages.en: Yan Hui went to see Zhongni, and asked leave to take his departure.

passages.zh: 曰：「奚之？」
passages.en: 'Where are you going to?' asked the Master.

passages.zh: 曰：「將之衛。」
passages.en: 'I will go to Wei' was the reply.

passages.zh: 曰：「奚為焉？」
passages.en: 'And with what object?'

passages.zh: 曰：「回聞衛君，其年壯，其行獨，輕用其國，而不見其過，輕用民死，死者以國量乎澤，若蕉，民其无如矣。
passages.en: 'I have heard that the ruler of Wei is in the vigour of his years, and consults none but himself as to his course. He deals with his state as if it were a light matter, and has no perception of his errors. He thinks lightly of his people's dying; the dead are lying all over the country as if no smaller space could contain them; on the plains and about the marshes, they are as thick as heaps of fuel.

passages.zh: 回嘗聞之夫子曰：『治國去之，亂國就之，醫門多疾。』
passages.en: The people know not where to turn to. I have heard you, Master, say, "Leave the state that is well governed; go to the state where disorder prevails." At the door of a physician there are many who are ill.

passages.zh: 願以所聞思其則，庶幾其國有瘳乎！」
passages.en: I wish through what I have heard (from you) to think out some methods (of dealing with Wei), if peradventure the evils of the state may be cured.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「譆！若殆往而刑耳！
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'Alas! The risk is that you will go only to suffer in the punishment (of yourself)!

passages.zh: 夫道不欲雜，雜則多，多則擾，擾則憂，憂而不救。
passages.en: The right method (in such a case) will not admit of any admixture. With such admixture, the one method will become many methods. Their multiplication will embarrass you. That embarrassment will make you anxious. However anxious you may be, you will not save (yourself).

passages.zh: 古之至人，先存諸己，而後存諸人。
passages.en: The perfect men of old first had (what they wanted to do) in themselves, and afterwards they found (the response to it) in others.

passages.zh: 所存於己者未定，何暇至於暴人之所行！
passages.en: If what they wanted in themselves was not fixed, what leisure had they to go and interfere with the proceedings of any tyrannous man?

passages.zh: 且若亦知夫德之所蕩，而知之所為出乎哉？
passages.en: Moreover, do you know how virtue is liable to be dissipated, and how wisdom proceeds to display itself?

passages.zh: 德蕩乎名，知出乎爭。
passages.en: Virtue is dissipated in (the pursuit of) the name for it, and wisdom seeks to display itself in the striving with others.

passages.zh: 名也者，相軋也；知也者，爭之器也。
passages.en: In the pursuit of the name men overthrow one another; wisdom becomes a weapon of contention.

passages.zh: 二者凶器，非所以盡行也。
passages.en: Both these things are instruments of evil, and should not be allowed to have free course in one's conduct.

passages.zh: 且德厚信矼，未達人氣；名聞不爭，未達人心。
passages.en: Supposing one's virtue to be great and his sincerity firm, if he do not comprehend the spirit of those (whom he wishes to influence); and supposing he is free from the disposition to strive for reputation, if he do not comprehend their minds;--

passages.zh: 而彊以仁義繩墨之言術暴人之前者，是以人惡有其美也，命之曰菑人。
passages.en: when in such a case he forcibly insists on benevolence and righteousness, setting them forth in the strongest and most direct language, before the tyrant, then he, hating (his reprover's) possession of those excellences, will put him down as doing him injury.

passages.zh: 菑人者，人必反菑之，若殆為人菑夫！
passages.en: He who injures others is sure to be injured by them in return. You indeed will hardly escape being injured by the man (to whom you go)!

passages.zh: 且苟為悅賢而惡不肖，惡用而求有以異？
passages.en: Further, if perchance he takes pleasure in men of worth and hates those of an opposite character, what is the use of your seeking to make yourself out to be different (from such men about him)?

passages.zh: 若唯无詔，王公必將乘人而鬭其捷。
passages.en: Before you have begun to announce (your views), he, as king and ruler, will take advantage of you, and immediately contend with you for victory.

passages.zh: 而目將熒之，而色將平之，口將營之，容將形之，心且成之。
passages.en: Your eyes will be dazed and full of perplexity; you will try to look pleased with him; you will frame your words with care; your demeanour will be conformed to his; you will confirm him in his views.

passages.zh: 是以火救火，以水救水，名之曰益多，順始无窮。
passages.en: In this way you will be adding fire to fire, and water to water, increasing, as we may express it, the evils (which you deplore).

passages.zh: 若殆以不信厚言，必死於暴人之前矣。
passages.en: To these signs of deferring to him at the first there will be no end. You will be in danger, seeing he does not believe you, of making your words more strong, and you are sure to die at the hands of such a tyrant.

passages.zh: 且昔者桀殺關龍逢，紂殺王子比干，是皆脩其身以下傴拊人之民，以下拂其上者也，故其君因其脩以擠之。
passages.en: And formerly Jie killed Guan Long-feng, and Zhou killed the prince Bi-gan. Both of these cultivated their persons, bending down in sympathy with the lower people to comfort them suffering (as they did) from their oppressors, and on their account opposing their superiors. On this account, because they so ordered their conduct, their rulers compassed their destruction - such regard had they for their own fame.

passages.zh: 是好名者也。
passages.en: (Again), Yao anciently attacked (the states of) Cong-qi and Xu-ao, and Yu attacked the ruler of Hu.

passages.zh: 昔者堯攻叢枝、胥敖，禹攻有扈，國為虛厲，身為刑戮，其用兵不止，其求實无已。
passages.en: Those states were left empty, and with no one to continue their population, the people being exterminated. They had engaged in war without ceasing; their craving for whatever they could get was insatiable.

passages.zh: 是皆求名、實者也，而獨不聞之乎？
passages.en: And this (ruler of Wei) is, like them, one who craves after fame and greater substance - have you not heard it?

passages.zh: 名、實者，聖人之所不能勝也，而況若乎！
passages.en: Those sages were not able to overcome the thirst for fame and substance - how much less will you be able to do so!

passages.zh: 雖然，若必有以也，嘗以語我來！」
passages.en: Nevertheless you must have some ground (for the course which you wish to take); pray try and tell it to me.'

passages.zh: 顏回曰：「端而虛，勉而一，則可乎？」
passages.en: Yan Hui said, 'May I go, doing so in uprightness and humility, using also every endeavour to be uniform (in my plans of operation)?'

passages.zh: 曰：「惡！惡可？
passages.en: 'No, indeed!' was the reply. 'How can you do so?

passages.zh: 夫以陽為充孔揚，采色不定，常人之所不違，因案人之所感，以求容與其心。
passages.en: This man makes a display of being filled to overflowing (with virtue), and has great self-conceit. His feelings are not to be determined from his countenance. Ordinary men do not (venture to) oppose him, and he proceeds from the way in which he affects them to seek still more the satisfaction of his own mind.

passages.zh: 名之曰日漸之德不成，而況大德乎！
passages.en: He may be described as unaffected by the (small lessons of) virtue brought to bear on him from day to day; and how much less will he be so by your great lessons?

passages.zh: 將執而不化，外合而內不訾，其庸詎可乎！」
passages.en: He will be obstinate, and refuse to be converted. He may outwardly agree with you, but inwardly there will be no self-condemnation - how can you (go to him in this way and be successful)?'

passages.zh: 「然則我內直而外曲，成而上比。
passages.en: (Yan Hui) rejoined, 'Well then; while inwardly maintaining my straightforward intention, I will outwardly seem to bend to him. I will deliver (my lessons), and substantiate them by appealing to antiquity.

passages.zh: 內直者，與天為徒。
passages.en: Inwardly maintaining my straightforward intention, I shall be a co-worker with Heaven.

passages.zh: 與天為徒者，知天子之與己皆天之所子，而獨以己言蘄乎而人善之，蘄乎而人不善之邪？
passages.en: When I thus speak of being a co-worker with Heaven, it is because I know that (the sovereign, whom we style) the son of Heaven, and myself, are equally regarded by Heaven as Its sons. And should I then, as if my words were only my own, be seeking to find whether men approved of them, or disapproved of them?

passages.zh: 若然者，人謂之童子，是之謂與天為徒。
passages.en: In this way men will pronounce me a (sincere and simple) boy. This is what is called being a co-worker with Heaven.

passages.zh: 外曲者，與人之為徒也。
passages.en: Outwardly bending (to the ruler), I shall be a co-worker with other men.

passages.zh: 擎、跽、曲拳，人臣之禮也，人皆為之，吾敢不為邪！
passages.en: To carry (the memorandum tablet to court), to kneel, and to bend the body reverentially - these are the observances of ministers. They all employ them, and should I presume not to do so?

passages.zh: 為人之所為者，人亦无疵焉，是之謂與人為徒。
passages.en: Doing what other men do, they would have no occasion to blame me. This is what is called being a fellow-worker with other men.

passages.zh: 成而上比者，與古為徒。
passages.en: Fully declaring my sentiments and substantiating them by appealing to antiquity, I shall be a co-worker with the ancients.

passages.zh: 其言雖教，讁之實也。
passages.en: Although the words in which I convey my lessons may really be condemnatory (of the ruler), they will be those of antiquity, and not my own.

passages.zh: 古之有也，非吾有也。
passages.en: In this way, though straightforward, I shall be free from blame.

passages.zh: 若然者，雖直不為病，是之謂與古為徒。
passages.en: This is what is called being a co-worker with antiquity.

passages.zh: 若是，則可乎？」
passages.en: May I go to Wei in this way, and be successful?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「惡！惡可？
passages.en: 'No indeed!' said Zhongni. 'How can you do so?

passages.zh: 大多政，法而不諜，雖固，亦无罪。
passages.en: You have too many plans of proceeding, and have not spied out (the ruler's character).

passages.zh: 雖然，止是耳矣，夫胡可以及化！
passages.en: Though you firmly adhere to your plans, you may be held free from transgression, but this will be all the result.

passages.zh: 猶師心者也。」
passages.en: How can you (in this way) produce the transformation (which you desire)? All this only shows (in you) the mind of a teacher!'

passages.zh: 顏回曰：「吾无以進矣，敢問其方。」
passages.en: Yan Hui said, 'I can go no farther; I venture to ask the method from you.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「齋，吾將語若！
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'It is fasting, (as) I will tell you.

passages.zh: 有而為之，其易邪？
passages.en: (But) when you have the method, will you find it easy to practise it?

passages.zh: 易之者，皞天不宜。」
passages.en: He who thinks it easy will be disapproved of by the bright Heaven.'

passages.zh: 顏回曰：「回之家貧，唯不飲酒、不茹葷者數月矣。若此，則可以為齋乎？」
passages.en: Hui said, 'My family is poor. For months together we have no spirituous drink, nor do we taste the proscribed food or any strong-smelling vegetables;-- can this be regarded as fasting?'

passages.zh: 曰：「是祭祀之齋，非心齋也。」
passages.en: The reply was, 'It is the fasting appropriate to sacrificing, but it is not the fasting of the mind.'

passages.zh: 回曰：「敢問心齋。」
passages.en: 'I venture to ask what that fasting of the mind is,' said Hui,

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「若一志，无聽之以耳而聽之以心，无聽之以心而聽之以氣。
passages.en: and Zhongni answered, 'Maintain a perfect unity in every movement of your will, You will not wait for the hearing of your ears about it, but for the hearing of your mind. You will not wait even for the hearing of your mind, but for the hearing of the spirit.

passages.zh: 聽止於耳，心止於符。
passages.en: Let the hearing (of the ears) rest with the ears. Let the mind rest in the verification (of the rightness of what is in the will).

passages.zh: 氣也者，虛而待物者也。
passages.en: But the spirit is free from all pre-occupation and so waits for (the appearance of) things.

passages.zh: 唯道集虛。
passages.en: Where the (proper) course is, there is freedom from all pre-occupation;

passages.zh: 虛者，心齋也。」
passages.en: such freedom is the fasting of the mind.'

passages.zh: 顏回曰：「回之未始得使，實自回也；得使之也，未始有回也。可謂虛乎？」
passages.en: Hui said, 'Before it was possible for me to employ (this method), there I was, the Hui that I am; now, that I can employ it, the Hui that I was has passed away. Can I be said to have obtained this freedom from pre-occupation?'

passages.zh: 夫子曰：「盡矣。吾語若！
passages.en: The Master replied, 'Entirely. I tell you that you can enter and be at ease in the enclosure (where he is), and not come into collision with the reputation (which belongs to him).

passages.zh: 若能入遊其樊而无感其名，入則鳴，不入則止。
passages.en: If he listen to your counsels, let him hear your notes; if he will not listen, be silent.

passages.zh: 无門无毒，一宅而寓於不得已，則幾矣。
passages.en: Open no (other) door; employ no other medicine; dwell with him (as with a friend) in the same apartment, and as if you had no other option, and you will not be far from success in your object.

passages.zh: 絕迹易，无行地難。
passages.en: Not to move a step is easy; to walk without treading on the ground is difficult.

passages.zh: 為人使，易以偽；為天使，難以偽。
passages.en: In acting after the manner of men, it is easy to fall into hypocrisy; in acting after the manner of Heaven, it is difficult to play the hypocrite.

passages.zh: 聞以有翼飛者矣，未聞以无翼飛者也；聞以有知知者矣，未聞以无知知者也。
passages.en: I have heard of flying with wings; I have not heard of flying without them. I have heard of the knowledge of the wise; I have not heard of the knowledge of the unwise.

passages.zh: 瞻彼闋者，虛室生白，吉祥止止。
passages.en: Look at that aperture (left in the wall); the empty apartment is filled with light through it. Felicitous influences rest (in the mind thus emblemed), as in their proper resting place.

passages.zh: 夫且不止，是之謂坐馳。
passages.en: Even when they do not so rest, we have what is called (the body) seated and (the mind) galloping abroad.

passages.zh: 夫徇耳目內通而外於心知，鬼神將來舍，而況人乎！
passages.en: The information that comes through the ears and eyes is comprehended internally, and the knowledge of the mind becomes something external: (when this is the case), the spiritual intelligences will come, and take up their dwelling with us, and how much more will other men do so!

passages.zh: 是萬物之化也，禹、舜之所紐也，伏戲、几蘧之所行終，而況散焉者乎！」
passages.en: All things thus undergo a transforming influence. This was the hinge on which Yu and Shun moved; it was this which Fu-xi and Ji-qu practised all their lives: how much more should other men follow the same rule!'

passages.zh: 葉公子高將使於齊，問於仲尼曰：「王使諸梁也甚重，齊之待使者，蓋將甚敬而不急。
passages.en: Zi Gao, duke of She, being about to proceed on a mission to Qi, asked Zhongni, saying, 'The king is sending me, Zhu Liang, on a mission which is very important. Qi will probably treat me as his commissioner with great respect, but it will not be in a hurry (to attend to the business).

passages.zh: 匹夫猶未可動，而況諸侯乎！
passages.en: Even an ordinary man cannot be readily moved (to action), and how much less the prince of a state!

passages.zh: 吾甚慄之。
passages.en: I am very full of apprehension.

passages.zh: 子常語諸梁也，曰：『凡事若小若大，寡不道以懽成。
passages.en: You, Sir, once said to me that of all things, great or small, there were few which, if not conducted in the proper way, could be brought to a happy conclusion;

passages.zh: 事若不成，則必有人道之患；事若成，則必有陰陽之患。
passages.en: that, if the thing were not successful, there was sure to be the evil of being dealt with after the manner of men; that, if it were successful, there was sure to be the evil of constant anxiety;

passages.zh: 若成若不成而後無患者，唯有德者能之。』
passages.en: and that, whether it succeeded or not, it was only the virtuous man who could secure its not being followed by evil.

passages.zh: 吾食也，執粗而不臧，爨無欲清之人。
passages.en: In my diet I take what is coarse, and do not seek delicacies - a man whose cookery does not require him to be using cooling drinks.

passages.zh: 今吾朝受命而夕飲冰，我其內熱與！
passages.en: This morning I received my charge, and in the evening I am drinking iced water; am I not feeling the internal heat (and discomfort)?

passages.zh: 吾未至乎事之情，而既有陰陽之患矣；事若不成，必有人道之患。
passages.en: Such is my state before I have actually engaged in the affair; I am already suffering from conflicting anxieties. And if the thing do not succeed, (the king) is sure to deal with me after the manner of men.

passages.zh: 是兩也，為人臣者不足以任之，子其有以語我來！」
passages.en: The evil is twofold; as a minister, I am not able to bear the burden (of the mission). Can you, Sir, tell me something (to help me in the case)?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「天下有大戒二：其一，命也；其一，義也。
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'In all things under heaven there are two great cautionary considerations: the one is the requirement implanted (in the nature); the other is the conviction of what is right.

passages.zh: 子之愛親，命也，不可解於心；臣之事君，義也，無適而非君也，無所逃於天地之間。
passages.en: The love of a son for his parents is the implanted requirement, and can never be separated from his heart; the service of his ruler by a minister is what is right, and from its obligation there is no escaping anywhere between heaven and earth.

passages.zh: 是之謂大戒。
passages.en: These are what are called the great cautionary considerations.

passages.zh: 是以夫事其親者，不擇地而安之，孝之至也；夫事其君者，不擇事而安之，忠之盛也；自事其心者，哀樂不易施乎前，知其不可奈何而安之若命，德之至也。
passages.en: Therefore a son finds his rest in serving his parents without reference to or choice of place; and this is the height of filial duty. In the same way a subject finds his rest in serving his ruler, without reference to or choice of the business; and this is the fullest discharge of loyalty. When men are simply obeying (the dictates of) their hearts, the considerations of grief and joy are not readily set before them. They know that there is no alternative to their acting as they do, and rest in it as what is appointed; and this is the highest achievement of virtue.

passages.zh: 為人臣子者，固有所不得已，行事之情而忘其身，何暇至於悅生而惡死！
passages.en: He who is in the position of a minister or of a son has indeed to do what he cannot but do. Occupied with the details of the business (in hand), and forgetful of his own person, what leisure has he to think of his pleasure in living or his dislike of death?

passages.zh: 夫子其行可矣！
passages.en: You, my master, may well proceed on your mission.

passages.zh: 丘請復以所聞：凡交，近則必相靡以信，遠則必忠之以言，言必或傳之。
passages.en: But let me repeat to you what I have heard: In all intercourse (between states), if they are near to each other, there should be mutual friendliness, verified by deeds; if they are far apart, there must be sincere adherence to truth in their messages. Those messages will be transmitted by internuncios.

passages.zh: 夫傳兩喜兩怒之言，天下之難者也。
passages.en: But to convey messages which express the complacence or the dissatisfaction of the two parties is the most difficult thing in the world.

passages.zh: 夫兩喜必多溢美之言，兩怒必多溢惡之言。
passages.en: If they be those of mutual complacence, there is sure to be an overflow of expressions of satisfaction; if of mutual dissatisfaction, an overflow of expressions of dislike.

passages.zh: 凡溢之類妄，妄則其信之也莫，莫則傳言者殃。
passages.en: But all extravagance leads to reckless language, and such language fails to command belief. When this distrust arises, woe to the internuncio!

passages.zh: 故法言曰：『傳其常情，無傳其溢言，則幾乎全。』
passages.en: Hence the Rules for Speech say, "Transmit the message exactly as it stands; do not transmit it with any overflow of language; so is (the internuncio) likely to keep himself whole."

passages.zh: 且以巧鬥力者，始乎陽，常卒乎陰，大至則多奇巧；以禮飲酒者，始乎治，常卒乎亂，大至則多奇樂。
passages.en: Moreover, skilful wrestlers begin with open trials of strength, but always end with masked attempts (to gain the victory); as their excitement grows excessive, they display much wonderful dexterity.
