Parties drinking according to the rules at first observe good order, but always end with disorder; as their excitement grows excessive, their fun becomes uproarious.

passages.zh: 凡事亦然。
passages.en: In all things it is so.

passages.zh: 始乎諒，常卒乎鄙；其作始也簡，其將畢也必巨。
passages.en: People are at first sincere, but always end with becoming rude; at the commencement things are treated as trivial, but as the end draws near, they assume great proportions.

passages.zh: 夫言者，風波也；行者，實喪也。
passages.en: Words are (like) the waves acted on by the wind; the real point of the matters (discussed by them) is lost.

passages.zh: 風波易以動，實喪易以危。
passages.en: The wind and waves are easily set in motion; the success of the matter of which the real point is lost is easily put in peril.

passages.zh: 故忿設無由，巧言偏辭。
passages.en: Hence quarrels are occasioned by nothing so much as by artful words and one-sided speeches.

passages.zh: 獸死不擇音，氣息茀然，於是並生心厲。
passages.en: The breath comes angrily, as when a beast, driven to death, wildly bellows forth its rage. On this animosities arise on both sides.

passages.zh: 剋核大至，則必有不肖之心應之，而不知其然也。
passages.en: Hasty examination (of the case) eagerly proceeds, and revengeful thoughts arise in their minds; they do not know how.

passages.zh: 苟為不知其然也，孰知其所終！
passages.en: Since they do not know how such thoughts arise, who knows how they will end?

passages.zh: 故法言曰：『無遷令，無勸成。』
passages.en: Hence the Rules for Speech say, "Let not an internuncius depart from his instructions. Let him not urge on a settlement.

passages.zh: 過度，益也。
passages.en: If he go beyond the regular rules, he will complicate matters.

passages.zh: 遷令、勸成殆事，美成在久，惡成不及改，可不慎與！
passages.en: Departing from his instructions and urging on a settlement imperils negotiations. A good settlement is proved by its lasting long, and a bad settlement cannot be altered - ought he not to be careful?"

passages.zh: 且夫乘物以遊心，託不得已以養中，至矣。
passages.en: Further still, let your mind find its enjoyment in the circumstances of your position; nourish the central course which you pursue, by a reference to your unavoidable obligations. This is the highest object for you to pursue; what else can you do to fulfil the charge (of your father and ruler).

passages.zh: 何作為報也！
passages.en: The best thing you can do is to be prepared to sacrifice your life;

passages.zh: 莫若為致命。
passages.en: and this is the most difficult thing to do.'

passages.zh: 此其難者。」
passages.en: Yan He, being about to undertake the office of Teacher of the eldest son of duke Ling of Wei, consulted Qu Bo-yi.

passages.zh: 顏闔將傅衛靈公大子，而問於蘧伯玉曰：「有人於此，其德天殺。
passages.en: 'Here,' said he, 'is this (young) man, whose natural disposition is as bad as it could be.

passages.zh: 與之為無方，則危吾國；與之為有方，則危吾身。
passages.en: If I allow him to proceed in a bad way, it will be at the peril of our state; if I insist on his proceeding in a right way, it will be at the peril of my own person.

passages.zh: 其知適足以知人之過，而不知其所以過。
passages.en: His wisdom is just sufficient to know the errors of other men, but he does not know how he errs himself.

passages.zh: 若然者，吾奈之何？」
passages.en: What am I to do in such a case?'

passages.zh: 蘧伯玉曰：「善哉問乎！
passages.en: Qu Bo-yi replied, 'Good indeed is your question!

passages.zh: 戒之慎之，正汝身也哉！
passages.en: Be on your guard; be careful; see that you keep yourself correct!

passages.zh: 形莫若就，心莫若和。
passages.en: Your best plan will be, with your person to seek association with him, and with your mind to try to be in harmony with him;

passages.zh: 雖然，之二者有患。
passages.en: and yet there are dangers connected with both of these things.

passages.zh: 就不欲入，和不欲出。
passages.en: While seeking to keep near to him, do not enter into his pursuits; while cultivating a harmony of mind with him, do not show how superior you are to him.

passages.zh: 形就而入，且為顛為滅，為崩為蹶。
passages.en: If in your personal association you enter into his pursuits, you will fall with him and be ruined, you will tumble down with a crash.

passages.zh: 心和而出，且為聲為名，為妖為孽。
passages.en: If in maintaining a harmony with his mind, you show how different you are from him, he will think you do so for the reputation and the name, and regard you as a creature of evil omen.

passages.zh: 彼且為嬰兒，亦與之為嬰兒；彼且為無町畦，亦與之為無町畦；彼且為無崖，亦與之為無崖。
passages.en: If you find him to be a mere boy, be you with him as another boy; if you find him one of those who will not have their ground marked out in the ordinary way, do you humour him in this characteristic; if you find him to be free from lofty airs, show yourself to be the same - (ever) leading him on so as to keep him free from faults.

passages.zh: 達之，入於無疵。
passages.en: Do you not know (the fate of) the praying mantis?

passages.zh: 汝不知夫螳蜋乎？
passages.en: It angrily stretches out its arms, to arrest the progress of the carriage, unconscious of its inability for such a task, but showing how much it thinks of its own powers.

passages.zh: 怒其臂以當車轍，不知其不勝任也，是其才之美者也。
passages.en: Be on your guard; be careful.

passages.zh: 戒之慎之！
passages.en: If you cherish a boastful confidence in your own excellence, and place yourself in collision with him, you are likely to incur the fate (of the mantis).

passages.zh: 積伐而美者以犯之，幾矣。
passages.en: Do you not know how those who keep tigers proceed?

passages.zh: 汝不知夫養虎者乎？
passages.en: They do not dare to supply them with living creatures, because of the rage which their killing of them will excite;

passages.zh: 不敢以生物與之，為其殺之之怒也；不敢以全物與之，為其決之之怒也。
passages.en: they do not (even) dare to give them their food whole, because of the rage which their rending of it will excite.

passages.zh: 時其飢飽，達其怒心。
passages.en: They watch till their hunger is appeased, (dealing with them) from their knowledge of their natural ferocity.

passages.zh: 虎之與人異類而媚養己者，順也；故其殺者，逆也。
passages.en: Tigers are different from men, but they fawn on those who feed them, and do so in accordance with their nature. When any of these are killed by them, it is because they have gone against that nature.

passages.zh: 夫愛馬者，以筐盛矢，以蜄盛溺。
passages.en: Those again who are fond of horses preserve their dung in baskets, and their urine in jars.

passages.zh: 適有蚉虻僕緣，而拊之不時，則缺銜、毀首、碎胸。
passages.en: If musquitoes and gadflies light on them, and the grooms brush them suddenly away, the horses break their bits, injure (the ornaments on) their heads, and smash those on their breasts.

passages.zh: 意有所至，而愛有所亡，可不慎邪！」
passages.en: The more care that is taken of them, the more does their fondness (for their attendants) disappear. Ought not caution to be exercised (in the management of them)?'

passages.zh: 匠石之齊，至乎曲轅，見櫟社樹。
passages.en: A (master) mechanic, called Shi, on his way to Qi, came to Qu-yuan, where he saw an oak-tree, which was used as the altar for the spirits of the land.

passages.zh: 其大蔽數千牛，絜之百圍，其高臨山十仞而後有枝，其可以為舟者旁十數。
passages.en: It was so large that an ox standing behind it could not be seen. It measured a hundred spans round, and rose up eighty cubits on the hill before it threw out any branches, after which there were ten or so, from each of which a boat could be hollowed out.

passages.zh: 觀者如市，匠伯不顧，遂行不輟。
passages.en: People came to see it in crowds as in a market place, but the mechanic did not look round at it, but held on his way without stopping.

passages.zh: 弟子厭觀之，走及匠石，曰：「自吾執斧斤以隨夫子，未嘗見材如此其美也。
passages.en: One of his workmen, however, looked long and admiringly at it, and then ran on to his master, and said to him, 'Since I followed you with my axe and bill, I have never seen such a beautiful mass of timber as this.

passages.zh: 先生不肯視，行不輟，何邪？」
passages.en: Why would you, Sir, not look round at it, but went on without stopping?'

passages.zh: 曰：「已矣，勿言之矣！
passages.en: 'Have done,' said Mr. Shi, 'and do not speak about it.

passages.zh: 散木也，以為舟則沈，以為棺槨則速腐，以為器則速毀，以為門戶則液樠，以為柱則蠹。
passages.en: It is quite useless. A boat made from its wood would sink; a coffin or shell would quickly rot; an article of furniture would soon go to pieces; a door would be covered with the exuding sap; a pillar would be riddled by insects;

passages.zh: 是不材之木也，無所可用，故能若是之壽。」
passages.en: the material of it is good for nothing, and hence it is that it has attained to so great an age.'

passages.zh: 匠石歸，櫟社見夢曰：「女將惡乎比予哉？
passages.en: When Mr. Shi was returning, the altar-oak appeared to him in a dream, and said, 'What other tree will you compare with me?

passages.zh: 若將比予於文木邪？
passages.en: Will you compare me to one of your ornamental trees?

passages.zh: 夫柤、梨、橘、柚、果、蓏之屬，實熟則剝，剝則辱，大枝折，小枝泄。
passages.en: There are hawthorns, pear-trees, orange-trees, pummelo-trees, gourds and other low fruit-bearing plants. When their fruits are ripe, they are knocked down from them, and thrown among the dirt.

passages.zh: 此以其能苦其生者也，故不終其天年而中道夭，自掊擊於世俗者也。
passages.en: The large branches are broken, and the smaller are torn away. So it is that their productive ability makes their lives bitter to them; they do not complete their natural term of existence, but come to a premature end in the middle of their time, bringing on themselves the destructive treatment which they ordinarily receive.

passages.zh: 物莫不若是。
passages.en: It is so with all things.

passages.zh: 且予求無所可用久矣，幾死，乃今得之，為予大用。
passages.en: I have sought to discover how it was that I was so useless; I had long done so, till (the effort) nearly caused my death; and now I have learned it - it has been of the greatest use to me.

passages.zh: 使予也而有用，且得有此大也邪？
passages.en: Suppose that I had possessed useful properties, should I have become of the great size that I am?

passages.zh: 且也，若與予也皆物也，奈何哉其相物也？
passages.en: And moreover you and I are both things - how should one thing thus pass its judgment on another?

passages.zh: 而幾死之散人，又惡知散木！」
passages.en: how is it that you a useless man know all this about me a useless tree?'

passages.zh: 匠石覺而診其夢。
passages.en: When Mr. Shih awoke, he kept thinking about his dream,

passages.zh: 弟子曰：「趣取無用，則為社何邪？」
passages.en: but the workman said, 'Being so taken with its uselessness, how is it that it yet acts here as the altar for the spirits of the land?'

passages.zh: 曰：「密！若無言！
passages.en: 'Be still,' was the master's reply, 'and do not say a word.

passages.zh: 彼亦直寄焉，以為不知己者詬厲也。
passages.en: It simply happened to grow here; and thus those who do not know it do not speak ill of it as an evil thing.

passages.zh: 不為社者，且幾有翦乎！
passages.en: If it were not used as the altar, would it be in danger of being cut down?

passages.zh: 且也，彼其所保，與眾異，以義譽之，不亦遠乎！」
passages.en: Moreover, the reason of its being preserved is different from that of the preservation of things generally; is not your explaining it from the sentiment which you have expressed wide of the mark?'

passages.zh: 南伯子綦遊乎商之丘，見大木焉有異，結駟千乘，隱將芘其所藾。
passages.en: Nan-bo Zi-Qi in rambling about the Heights of Shang, saw a large and extraordinary tree. The teams of a thousand chariots might be sheltered under it, and its shade would cover them all!

passages.zh: 子綦曰：「此何木也哉？」
passages.en: Zi-Qi said, 'What a tree is this! It must contain an extraordinary amount of timber!'

passages.zh: 此必有異材夫！
passages.en: When he looked up, however, at its smaller branches, they were so twisted and crooked that they could not be made into rafters and beams;

passages.zh: 仰而視其細枝，則拳曲而不可以為棟梁；俯而見其大根，則軸解而不可為棺槨；咶其葉，則口爛而為傷；嗅之，則使人狂酲三日而不已。
passages.en: when he looked down to its root, its stem was divided into so many rounded portions that neither coffin nor shell could be made from them. He licked one of its leaves, and his mouth felt torn and wounded. The smell of it would make a man frantic, as if intoxicated, for more than three whole days together.

passages.zh: 子綦曰：「此果不材之木也，以至於此其大也。
passages.en: 'This, indeed,' said he, 'is a tree good for nothing, and it is thus that it has attained to such a size.

passages.zh: 嗟乎！神人以此不材！」
passages.en: Ah! and spirit-like men acknowledge this worthlessness (and its result).'

passages.zh: 宋有荊氏者，宜楸、柏、桑。
passages.en: In Song there is the district of Jing-shi, in which catalpae, cypresses, and mulberry trees grow well.

passages.zh: 其拱把而上者，求狙猴之杙者斬之；三圍四圍，求高名之麗者斬之；七圍八圍，貴人富商之家求樿傍者斬之。
passages.en: Those of them which are a span or two or rather more in circumference are cut down by persons who want to make posts to which to tie their monkeys; those which are three or four spans round are cut down by persons who want beams forr their lofty and famous houses; and those of seven or eight spans are cut down by noblemen and rich merchants who want single planks for the sides of their coffins.

passages.zh: 故未終其天年，而中道已夭於斧斤，此材之患也。
passages.en: The trees in consequence do not complete their natural term of life, and come to a premature end in the middle of their growth under the axe and bill;-- this is the evil that befalls them from their supplying good timber.

passages.zh: 故解之以牛之白顙者，與豚之亢鼻者，與人有痔病者，不可以適河。
passages.en: In the same way the Jie (book) specifies oxen that have white foreheads, pigs that have turned-up snouts, and men that are suffering from piles, and forbids their being sacrificed to the Ho.

passages.zh: 此皆巫祝以知之矣，所以為不祥也，此乃神人之所以為大祥也。
passages.en: The wizards know them by these peculiarities and consider them to be inauspicious, but spirit-like men consider them on this account to be very fortunate.

passages.zh: 支離疏者，頤隱於臍，肩高於頂，會撮指天，五管在上，兩髀為脅。
passages.en: There was the deformed object Shu. His chin seemed to hide his navel; his shoulders were higher than the crown of his head; the knot of his hair pointed to the sky; his five viscera were all compressed into the upper part of his body, and his two thigh bones were like ribs.

passages.zh: 挫鍼治繲，足以餬口；鼓筴播精，足以食十人。
passages.en: By sharpening needles and washing clothes he was able to make a living. By sifting rice and cleaning it, he was able to support ten individuals.

passages.zh: 上徵武士，則支離攘臂而遊於其間；上有大役，則支離以有常疾不受功；上與病者粟，則受三鐘與十束薪。
passages.en: When the government was calling out soldiers, this poor Shu would bare his arms among the others; when it had any great service to be undertaken, because of his constant ailments, none of the work was assigned to him; when it was giving out grain to the sick, he received three kung, and ten bundles of firewood.

passages.zh: 夫支離其形者，猶足以養其身，終其天年，又況支離其德者乎！」
passages.en: If this poor man, so deformed in body, was still able to support himself, and complete his term of life, how much more may they do so, whose deformity is that of their faculties!

passages.zh: 孔子適楚，楚狂接輿遊其門曰：「鳳兮鳳兮，何如德之衰也！
passages.en: When Confucius went to Chu, Jie-yu, the madman of Chu, as he was wandering about, passed by his door, and said, '0 Phoenix, 0 Phoenix, how is your virtue degenerated!

passages.zh: 來世不可待，往世不可追也。
passages.en: The future is not to be waited for; the past is not to be sought again!

passages.zh: 天下有道，聖人成焉；天下無道，聖人生焉。
passages.en: When good order prevails in the world, the sage tries to accomplish all his service; when disorder prevails, he may preserve his life;

passages.zh: 方今之時，僅免刑焉。
passages.en: at the present time, it is enough if he simply escape being punished.

passages.zh: 福輕乎羽，莫之知載；禍重乎地，莫之知避。
passages.en: Happiness is lighter than a feather, but no one knows how to support it; calamity is heavier than the earth, and yet no one knows how to avoid it.

passages.zh: 已乎已乎，臨人以德！
passages.en: Give over! give over approaching men with the lessons of your virtue!

passages.zh: 殆乎殆乎，畫地而趨！
passages.en: You are in peril! you are in peril, hurrying on where you have marked out the ground against your advance!

passages.zh: 迷陽迷陽，無傷吾行！
passages.en: I avoid publicity, I avoid publicity, that my path may not be injured.

passages.zh: 吾行卻曲，無傷吾足！」
passages.en: I pursue my course, now going backwards, now crookedly, that my feet may not be hurt.

passages.zh: 山木自寇也，膏火自煎也。
passages.en: The mountain by its trees weakens itself. The grease which ministers to the fire fries itself.

passages.zh: 桂可食，故伐之；漆可用，故割之。
passages.en: The cinnamon tree can be eaten, and therefore it is cut down. The varnish tree is useful, and therefore incisions are made in it.

passages.zh: 人皆知有用之用，而莫知無用之用也。
passages.en: All men know the advantage of being useful, but no one knows the advantage of being useless.

passages.zh: 魯有兀者王駘，從之遊者，與仲尼相若。
passages.en: In Lu there was a Wang Tai who had lost both his feet; while his disciples who followed and went about with him were as numerous as those of Zhongni.

passages.zh: 常季問於仲尼曰：「王駘，兀者也，從之遊者，與夫子中分魯。
passages.en: Chang Ji asked Zhongni about him, saying, 'Though Wang Tai is a cripple, the disciples who follow him about divide Lu equally with you, Master.

passages.zh: 立不教，坐不議，虛而往，實而歸。
passages.en: When he stands, he does not teach them; when he sits, he does not discourse to them. But they go to him empty, and come back full.

passages.zh: 固有不言之教，無形而心成者邪？
passages.en: Is there indeed such a thing as instruction without words? and while the body is imperfect, may the mind be complete?

passages.zh: 是何人也？」
passages.en: What sort of man is he?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「夫子，聖人也。
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'This master is a sage.

passages.zh: 丘也，直後而未往耳。
passages.en: I have only been too late in going to him.

passages.zh: 丘將以為師，而況不如丘者乎！
passages.en: I will make him my teacher; and how much more should those do so who are not equal to me!

passages.zh: 奚假魯國！
passages.en: Why should only the state of Lu follow him?

passages.zh: 丘將引天下而與從之。」
passages.en: I will lead on all under heaven with me to do so.'

passages.zh: 常季曰：「彼兀者也，而王先生，其與庸亦遠矣。
passages.en: Chang Ji rejoined, 'He is a man who has lost his feet, and yet he is known as the venerable Wang - he must be very different from ordinary men.

passages.zh: 若然者，其用心也，獨若之何？」
passages.en: What is the peculiar way in which he employs his mind?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「死生亦大矣，而不得與之變，雖天地覆墜，亦將不與之遺。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Death and life are great considerations, but they could work no change in him. Though heaven and earth were to be overturned and fall, they would occasion him no loss.

passages.zh: 審乎無假，而不與物遷，命物之化，而守其宗也。」
passages.en: His judgment is fixed regarding that in which there is no element of falsehood; and, while other things change, he changes not. The transformations of things are to him the developments prescribed for them, and he keeps fast hold of the author of them.'

passages.zh: 常季曰：「何謂也？」
passages.en: Chang Ji said, 'What do you mean?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「自其異者視之，肝膽楚越也；自其同者視之，萬物皆一也。
passages.en: 'When we look at things,' said Zhongni, 'as they differ, we see them to be different, (as for instance) the liver and the gall, or Chu and Yue; when we look at them, as they agree, we see them all to be a unity.

passages.zh: 夫若然者，且不知耳目之所宜，而游心於德之和，物視其所一，而不見其所喪，視喪其足，猶遺土也。」
passages.en: So it is with this (Wang Tai). He takes no knowledge of the things for which his ears and eyes are the appropriate organs, but his mind delights itself in the harmony of (all excellent) qualities. He looks at the unity which belongs to things, and does not perceive where they have suffered loss. He looks on the loss of his feet as only the loss of so much earth.'

passages.zh: 常季曰：「彼為己，以其知得其心，以其心得其常心，物何為最之哉？」
passages.en: Chang Ji said, 'He is entirely occupied with his (proper) self. By his knowledge he has discovered (the nature of) his mind, and to that he holds as what is unchangeable; but how is it that men make so much of him?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「人莫鑑於流水，而鑑於止水，唯止能止眾止。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Men do not look into running water as a mirror, but into still water - it is only the still water that can arrest them all, and keep them (in the contemplation of their real selves).

passages.zh: 受命於地，唯松柏獨也在，冬夏青青；受命於天，唯舜獨也正，幸能正生，以正眾生。
passages.en: Of things which are what they are by the influence of the earth, it is only the pine and cypress which are the best instances - in winter as in summer brightly green. Of those which were what they were by the influence of Heaven, the most correct examples were Yao and Shun; fortunate in (thus) maintaining their own life correct, and so as to correct the lives of others.

passages.zh: 夫保始之徵，不懼之實。
passages.en: As a verification of the (power of) the original endowment, when it has been preserved, take the result of fearlessness - how the heroic spirit of a single brave soldier has been thrown into an army of nine hosts.

passages.zh: 勇士一人，雄入於九軍。
passages.en: If a man only seeking for fame and able in this way to secure it can produce such an effect, how much more (may we look for a greater result) from one whose rule is over heaven and earth, and holds all things in his treasury, who simply has his lodging in the six members of his body, whom his ears and eyes serve but as conveying emblematic images of things, who comprehends all his knowledge in a unity, and whose mind never dies!

passages.zh: 將求名而能自要者，而猶若此，而況官天地，府萬物，直寓六骸，象耳目，一知之所知，而心未嘗死者乎！
passages.en: If such a man were to choose a day on which he would ascend far on high, men would (seek to) follow him there.

passages.zh: 彼且擇日而登假，人則從是也。
passages.en: But how should he be willing to occupy himself with other men?'

passages.zh: 彼且何肯以物為事乎！」
passages.en: But how should he be willing to occupy himself with other men?'

passages.zh: 申徒嘉，兀者也，而與鄭子產同師於伯昏無人。
passages.en: Shen-tu Jia was (another) man who had lost his feet. Along with Zi-chan of Zheng he studied under the master Bo-hun Wu-ren.

passages.zh: 子產謂申徒嘉曰：「我先出，則子止；子先出，則我止。」
passages.en: Zi-chan said to him (one day), 'If I go out first, do you remain behind; and if you go out first, I will remain behind.'

passages.zh: 其明日，又與合堂同席而坐。
passages.en: Next day they were again sitting together on the same mat in the hall, when Zi-chan said (again), 'If I go out first, do you remain behind; and if you go out first, I will remain behind.

passages.zh: 子產謂申徒嘉曰：「我先出，則子止；子先出，則我止。
passages.en: Now I am about to go out; will you stay behind or not?

passages.zh: 今我將出，子可以止乎，其未邪？
passages.en: Moreover, when you see one of official rank (like myself), you do not try to get out of his way - do you consider yourself equal to one of official rank?'

passages.zh: 且子見執政而不違，子齊執政乎？」
passages.en: Shen-tu Jia replied, 'In our Master's school is there indeed such recognition required of official rank?

passages.zh: 申徒嘉曰：「先生之門，固有執政焉如此哉？
passages.en: You are one, Sir, whose pleasure is in your official rank, and would therefore take precedence of other men.

passages.zh: 子而說子之執政而後人者也！
passages.en: I have heard that when a mirror is bright, the dust does not rest on it; when dust rests on it the mirror is not bright.

passages.zh: 聞之曰：『鑑明則塵垢不止，止則不明也。
passages.en: When one dwells long with a man of ability and virtue, he comes to be without error.

passages.zh: 久與賢人處，則無過。』
passages.en: There now is our teacher whom you have chosen to make you greater than you are; and when you still talk in this way, are you not in error?'

passages.zh: 今子之所取大者，先生也，而猶出言若是，不亦過乎！」
passages.en: Zi-chan rejoined, 'A (shattered) object as you are, you would still strive to make yourself out as good as Yao!

passages.zh: 子產曰：「子既若是矣，猶與堯爭善，計子之德不足以自反邪？」
passages.en: If I may form an estimate of your virtue, might it not be sufficient to lead you to the examination of yourself?'

passages.zh: 申徒嘉曰：「自狀其過以不當亡者眾，不狀其過以不當存者寡。
passages.en: The other said, 'Most criminals, in describing their offences, would make it out that they ought not to have lost (their feet) for them; few would describe them so as to make it appear that they should not have preserved their feet.

passages.zh: 知不可奈何而安之若命，惟有德者能之。
passages.en: They are only the virtuous who know that such a calamity was unavoidable, and therefore rest in it as what was appointed for them.

passages.zh: 遊於羿之彀中，中央者，中地也，然而不中者，命也。
passages.en: When men stand before (an archer like) Yi with his bent bow, if they are in the middle of his field, that is the place where they should be hit; and if they be not hit, that also was appointed.

passages.zh: 人以其全足笑吾不全足者多矣。
passages.en: There are many with their feet entire who laugh at me because I have lost my feet, which makes me feel vexed and angry.

passages.zh: 我怫然而怒，而適先生之所，則廢然而反。
passages.en: But when I go to our teacher, I throw off that feeling, and return (to a better mood) - he has washed, without my knowing it, the other from me by (his instructions in) what is good.

passages.zh: 不知先生之洗我以善邪！
passages.en: I have attended him now for nineteen years, and have not known that I am without my feet.

passages.zh: 吾與夫子遊十九年矣，而未嘗知吾兀者也。
passages.en: Now, you, Sir, and I have for the object of our study the (virtue) which is internal, and not an adjunct of the body, and yet you are continually directing your attention to my external body - are you not wrong in this?'

passages.zh: 今子與我遊於形骸之內，而子索我於形骸之外，不亦過乎！」
passages.en: Zi-chan felt uneasy, altered his manner and looks, and said, 'You need not, Sir, say anything more about it.'

passages.zh: 子產蹴然改容更貌曰：「子無乃稱！」
passages.en: Zi-chan felt uneasy, altered his manner and looks, and said, 'You need not, Sir, say anything more about it.'

passages.zh: 魯有兀者叔山無趾，踵見仲尼。
passages.en: In Lu there was a cripple, called Shu-shan the Toeless, who came on his heels to see Zhongni.

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「子不謹，前既犯患若是矣。
passages.en: Zhongni said to him, 'By your want of circumspection in the past, Sir, you have incurred such a calamity; of what use is your coming to me now?'

passages.zh: 雖今來，何及矣？」
passages.en: Toeless said, 'Through my ignorance of my proper business and taking too little care of my body, I came to lose my feet.

passages.zh: 無趾曰：「吾唯不知務而輕用吾身，吾是以亡足。
passages.en: But now I am come to you, still possessing what is more honourable than my feet, and which therefore I am anxious to preserve entire.

passages.zh: 今吾來也，猶有尊足者存，吾是以務全之也。
passages.en: There is nothing which Heaven does not cover, and nothing which Earth does not sustain; you, Master, were regarded by me as doing the part of Heaven and Earth - how could I know that you would receive me in such a way?'

passages.zh: 夫天無不覆，地無不載，吾以夫子為天地，安知夫子之猶若是也！」
passages.en: Confucius rejoined, 'I am but a poor creature. But why, my master, do you not come inside, where I will try to tell you what I have learned?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「丘則陋矣。
passages.en: When Toeless had gone out, Confucius said, 'Be stimulated to effort, my disciples.

passages.zh: 夫子胡不入乎？
passages.en: This toeless cripple is still anxious to learn to make up for the evil of his former conduct;-- how much more should those be so whose conduct has been unchallenged!'

passages.zh: 請講以所聞！」
passages.en: Mr. Toeless, however, told Lao Dan (of the interview), saying, 'Kong Qiu, I apprehend, has not yet attained to be a Perfect man.

passages.zh: 無趾出。
passages.en: What has he to do with keeping a crowd of disciples around him?

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「弟子勉之！
passages.en: He is seeking to have the reputation of being an extraordinary and marvellous man, and does not know that the Perfect man considers this to be as handcuffs and fetters to him.'

passages.zh: 夫無趾，兀者也，猶務學以復補前行之惡，而況全德之人乎！」
passages.en: Lao Dan said, 'Why did you not simply lead him to see the unity of life and death, and that the admissible and inadmissible belong to one category, so freeing him from his fetters?

passages.zh: 無趾語老聃曰：「孔丘之於至人，其未邪！
passages.en: Would this be possible?'

passages.zh: 彼何賓賓以學子為？
passages.en: Toeless said, 'It is the punishment inflicted on him by Heaven. How can he be freed from it?'

passages.zh: 彼且蘄以諔詭幻怪之名聞，不知至人之以是為己桎梏邪？」
passages.en: Duke Ai of Lu asked Zhongni, saying, 'There was an ugly man in Wei, called Ai-tai Tuo.

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「胡不直使彼以死生為一條，以可不可為一貫者，解其桎梏，其可乎？」
passages.en: His father-in-law, who lived with him, thought so much of him that he could not be away from him.

passages.zh: 無趾曰：「天刑之，安可解？」
passages.en: His wife, when she saw him (ugly as he was), represented to her parents, saying, "I had more than ten times rather be his concubine than the wife of any other man."

passages.zh: 魯哀公問於仲尼曰：「衛有惡人焉，曰哀駘它。
passages.en: He was never heard to take the lead in discussion, but always seemed to be of the same opinion with others.

passages.zh: 丈夫與之處者，思而不能去也。
passages.en: He had not the position of a ruler, so as to be able to save men from death.

passages.zh: 婦人見之，請於父母曰『與為人妻，寧為夫子妾』者，十數而未止也。
passages.en: He had no revenues, so as to be able to satisfy men's craving for food.

passages.zh: 未嘗有聞其唱者也，常和而已矣。
passages.en: He was ugly enough, moreover, to scare the whole world.

passages.zh: 無君人之位以濟乎人之死，無聚祿以望人之腹。
passages.en: He agreed with men instead of trying to lead them to adopt his views; his knowledge did not go beyond his immediate neighbourhood.

passages.zh: 又以惡駭天下，和而不唱，知不出乎四域，且而雌雄合乎前。
passages.en: And yet his father-in-law and his wife were of one mind about him in his presence (as I have said) - he must have been different from other men.

passages.zh: 是必有異乎人者也。
passages.en: I called him, and saw him.

passages.zh: 寡人召而觀之，果以惡駭天下。
passages.en: Certainly he was ugly enough to scare the whole world.

passages.zh: 與寡人處，不至以月數，而寡人有意乎其為人也；不至乎期年，而寡人信之。
passages.en: He had not lived with me, however, for many months, when I was drawn to the man; and before he had been with me a full year, I had confidence in him.

passages.zh: 國無宰，寡人傳國焉。
passages.en: The state being without a chief minister, I (was minded) to commit the government to him.

passages.zh: 悶然而後應，氾而若辭。
passages.en: He responded to my proposal sorrowfully, and looked undecided as if he would fain have declined it.

passages.zh: 寡人醜乎，卒授之國。
passages.en: I was ashamed of myself (as inferior to him), but finally gave the government into his hands.

passages.zh: 無幾何也，去寡人而行，寡人卹焉若有亡也，若無與樂是國也。
passages.en: In a little time, however, he left me and went away. I was sorry and felt that I had sustained a loss, and as if there were no other to share the pleasures of the kingdom with me.

passages.zh: 是何人者也？」
passages.en: What sort of man was he?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「丘也，嘗使於楚矣，適見㹠子食於其死母者，少焉眴若，皆棄之而走。
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'Once when I was sent on a mission to Qi, I saw some pigs sucking at their dead mother. After a little they looked with rapid glances, when they all left her, and ran away.

passages.zh: 不見己焉爾，不得類焉爾。
passages.en: They felt that she did not see them, and that she was no longer like themselves.

passages.zh: 所愛其母者，非愛其形也，愛使其形者也。
passages.en: What they had loved in their mother was not her bodily figure, but what had given animation to her figure.

passages.zh: 戰而死者，其人之葬也，不以翣資，刖者之屨，無為愛之，皆無其本矣。
passages.en: When a man dies in battle, they do not at his interment employ the usual appendages of plumes: as to supplying shoes to one who has lost his feet, there is no reason why he should care for them - in neither case is there the proper reason for their use.

passages.zh: 為天子之諸御，不爪翦，不穿耳；娶妻者止於外，不得復使。
passages.en: The members of the royal harem do not pare their nails nor pierce their ears; when a man is newly married, he remains (for a time) absent from his official duties, and unoccupied with them.

passages.zh: 形全猶足以為爾，而況全德之人乎！
passages.en: That their bodies might be perfect was sufficient to make them thus dealt with; how much greater results should be expected from men whose mental gifts are perfect!

passages.zh: 今哀駘它未言而信，無功而親，使人授己國，唯恐其不受也，是必才全而德不形者也。」
passages.en: This Ai-tai Tuo was believed by men, though he did not speak a word; and was loved by them, though he did no special service for them. He made men appoint him to the government of their states, afraid only that he would not accept the appointment. He must have been a man whose powers were perfect, though his realisation of them was not manifested in his person.

passages.zh: 哀公曰：「何謂才全？」
passages.en: Duke Ai said, 'What is meant by saying that his powers were complete?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「死生存亡，窮達貧富，賢與不肖，毀譽、饑渴、寒暑，是事之變，命之行也；日夜相代乎前，而知不能規乎其始者也。
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'Death and life, preservation and ruin, failure and success, poverty and wealth, superiority and inferiority, blame and praise, hunger and thirst, cold and heat; these are the changes of circumstances, the operation of our appointed lot. Day and night they succeed to one another before us, but there is no wisdom able to discover to what they owe their origination.

passages.zh: 故不足以滑和，不可入於靈府。
passages.en: They are not sufficient therefore to disturb the harmony (of the nature), and are not allowed to enter into the treasury of intelligence.

passages.zh: 使之和豫通而不失於兌，使日夜無郤而與物為春，是接而生時於心者也。
passages.en: To cause this harmony and satisfaction ever to be diffused, while the feeling of pleasure is not lost from the mind; to allow no break to arise in this state day or night, so that it is always spring-time in his relations with external things; in all his experiences to realise in his mind what is appropriate to each season (of the year): these are the characteristics of him whose powers are perfect.'

passages.zh: 是之謂才全。」
passages.en: 'And what do you mean by the realisation of these powers not being manifested in the person?' (pursued further the duke).

passages.zh: 「何謂德不形？」
passages.en: The reply was, 'There is nothing so level as the surface of a pool of still water.

passages.zh: 曰：「平者，水停之盛也。
passages.en: It may serve as an example of what I mean.

passages.zh: 其可以為法也，內保之而外不蕩也。
passages.en: All within its circuit is preserved (in peace), and there comes to it no agitation from without.

passages.zh: 德者，成和之修也。
passages.en: The virtuous efficacy is the perfect cultivation of the harmony (of the nature).

passages.zh: 德不形者，物不能離也。」
passages.en: Though the realisation of this be not manifested in the person, things cannot separate themselves (from its influence).'

passages.zh: 哀公異日以告閔子曰：「始也，吾以南面而君天下，執民之紀，而憂其死，吾自以為至通矣。
passages.en: Some days afterwards duke Ai told this conversation to Min-zi, saying, 'Formerly it seemed to me the work of the sovereign to stand in court with his face to the south, to rule the kingdom, and to pay good heed to the accounts of the people concerned, lest any should come to a (miserable) death - this I considered to be the sum (of his duty).

passages.zh: 今吾聞至人之言，恐吾無其實，輕用吾身而亡其國。
passages.en: Now that I have heard that description of the Perfect man, I fear that my idea is not the real one, and that, by employing myself too lightly, I may cause the ruin of my state.

passages.zh: 吾與孔丘，非君臣也，德友而已矣。」
passages.en: I and Kong Qiu are not on the footing of ruler and subject, but on that of a virtuous friendship.'

passages.zh: 闉跂支離無脤說衛靈公，靈公說之，而視全人，其脰肩肩。
passages.en: A person who had no lips, whose legs were bent so that he could only walk on his toes, and who was (otherwise) deformed, addressed his counsels to duke Ling of Wei, who was so pleased with him, that he looked on a perfectly formed man as having a lean and small neck in comparison with him.

passages.zh: 甕盎大癭說齊桓公，桓公說之，而視全人，其脰肩肩。
passages.en: Another who had a large goitre like an earthenware jar addressed his counsels to duke Huan of Qi, who was so pleased with him that he looked on a perfectly formed man as having a neck lean and small in comparison with him.

passages.zh: 故德有所長，而形有所忘，人不忘其所忘，而忘其所不忘，此謂誠忘。
passages.en: So it is that when one's virtue is extraordinary, (any deficiency in) his bodily form may be forgotten. When men do not forget what is (easily) forgotten, and forget what is not (easily) forgotten, we have a case of real oblivion.

passages.zh: 故聖人有所遊，而知為孽，約為膠，德為接，工為商。
passages.en: Therefore the sagely man has that in which his mind finds its enjoyment, and (looks on) wisdom as (but) the shoots from an old stump; agreements with others are to him but so much glue; kindnesses are (but the arts of) intercourse; and great skill is (but as) merchants' wares.

passages.zh: 聖人不謀，惡用知？
passages.en: The sagely man lays no plans; of what use would wisdom be to him?

passages.zh: 不斲，惡用膠？
passages.en: He has no cutting and hacking to do; of what use would glue be to him?

passages.zh: 無喪，惡用德？
passages.en: He has lost nothing; of what use would arts of intercourse be to him?

passages.zh: 不貨，惡用商？
passages.en: He has no goods to dispose of; what need has he to play the merchant?

passages.zh: 四者，天鬻也。
passages.en: (The want of) these four things are the nourishment of (his) Heavenly (nature); that nourishment is its Heavenly food.

passages.zh: 天鬻者，天食也。
passages.en: Since he receives this food from Heaven, what need has he for anything of man's (devising)?

passages.zh: 既受食於天，又惡用人？
passages.en: He has the bodily form of man, but not the passions and desires of (other) men.

passages.zh: 有人之形，無人之情。
passages.en: He has the form of man, and therefore he is a man.

passages.zh: 有人之形，故群於人；無人之情，故是非不得於身。
passages.en: Being without the passions and desires of men, their approvings and disapprovings are not to be found in him.

passages.zh: 眇乎小哉！
passages.en: How insignificant and small is (the body) by which he belongs to humanity!

passages.zh: 所以屬於人也。
passages.en: How grand and great is he in the unique perfection of his Heavenly (nature)!

passages.zh: 謷乎大哉！
passages.en: Huizi said to Zhuangzi, 'Can a man indeed be without desires and passions?'

passages.zh: 獨成其天。
passages.en: The reply was, 'He can.'

passages.zh: 惠子謂莊子曰：「人故無情乎？」
passages.en: 'But on what grounds do you call him a man, who is thus without passions and desires?'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「然。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi said, 'The Dao gives him his personal appearance (and powers); Heaven gives him his bodily form; how should we not call him a man?'

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「人而無情，何以謂之人？」
passages.en: Huizi rejoined, 'Since you call him a man, how can he be without passions and desires?'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「道與之貌，天與之形，惡得不謂之人？」
passages.en: The reply was, 'You are misunderstanding what I mean by passions and desires.

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「既謂之人，惡得無情？」
passages.en: What I mean when I say that he is without these is, that this man does not by his likings and dislikings do any inward harm to his body - he always pursues his course without effort, and does not (try to) increase his (store of) life.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「是非吾所謂情也。
passages.en: Huizi rejoined, 'If there were not that increasing of (the amount) of life, how would he get his body?'

passages.zh: 吾所謂無情者，言人之不以好惡內傷其身，常因自然而不益生也。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi said, 'The Dao gives him his personal appearance (and powers); Heaven gives him his bodily form; and he does not by his likings and dislikings do any internal harm to his body.

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「不益生，何以有其身？」
passages.en: But now you, Sir, deal with your spirit as if it were something external to you, and subject your vital powers to toil.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「道與之貌，天與之形，無以好惡內傷其身。
passages.en: You sing (your ditties), leaning against a tree; you go to sleep, grasping the stump of a rotten dryandra tree.

passages.zh: 今子外乎子之神，勞乎子之精，倚樹而吟，據槁梧而瞑。
passages.en: Heaven selected for you the bodily form (of a man), and you babble about what is strong and what is white.'

passages.zh: 天選子之形，子以堅白鳴！」
passages.en: Heaven selected for you the bodily form (of a man), and you babble about what is strong and what is white.'

passages.zh: 知天之所為，知人之所為者，至矣。
passages.en: He who knows the part which the Heavenly (in him) plays, and knows (also) that which the Human (in him ought to) play, has reached the perfection (of knowledge).

passages.zh: 知天之所為者，天而生也；知人之所為者，以其知之所知，以養其知之所不知，終其天年而不中道夭者，是知之盛也。
passages.en: He who knows the part which the Heavenly plays (knows) that it is naturally born with him; he who knows the part which the Human ought to play (proceeds) with the knowledge which he possesses to nourish it in the direction of what he does not (yet) know: to complete one's natural term of years and not come to an untimely end in the middle of his course is the fulness of knowledge.

passages.zh: 雖然，有患。
passages.en: Although it be so, there is an evil (attending this condition).

passages.zh: 夫知有所待而後當，其所待者特未定也。
passages.en: Such knowledge still awaits the confirmation of it as correct; it does so because it is not yet determined.

passages.zh: 庸詎知吾所謂天之非人乎？
passages.en: How do we know that what we call the Heavenly (in us) is not the Human?

passages.zh: 所謂人之非天乎？
passages.en: and that what we call the Human is not the Heavenly?

passages.zh: 且有真人，而後有真知。
passages.en: There must be the True man, and then there is the True knowledge.

passages.zh: 何謂真人？
passages.en: What is meant by 'the True Man?'

passages.zh: 古之真人，不逆寡，不雄成，不謨士。
passages.en: The True men of old did not reject (the views of) the few; they did not seek to accomplish (their ends) like heroes (before others); they did not lay plans to attain those ends.

passages.zh: 若然者，過而弗悔，當而不自得也。
passages.en: Being such, though they might make mistakes, they had no occasion for repentance; though they might succeed, they had no self-complacency.

passages.zh: 若然者，登高不慄，入水不濡，入火不熱。
passages.en: Being such, they could ascend the loftiest heights without fear; they could pass through water without being made wet by it; they could go into fire without being burnt.

passages.zh: 是知之能登假於道也若此。
passages.en: so it was that by their knowledge they ascended to and reached the Dao.

passages.zh: 古之真人，其寢不夢，其覺無憂，其食不甘，其息深深。
passages.en: The True men of old did not dream when they slept, had no anxiety when they awoke, and did not care that their food should be pleasant. Their breathing came deep and silently.

passages.zh: 真人之息以踵，眾人之息以喉。
passages.en: The breathing of the true man comes (even) from his heels, while men generally breathe (only) from their throats.

passages.zh: 屈服者，其嗌言若哇。
passages.en: When men are defeated in argument, their words come from their gullets as if they were vomiting.

passages.zh: 其耆欲深者，其天機淺。
passages.en: Where lusts and desires are deep, the springs of the Heavenly are shallow.

passages.zh: 古之真人，不知說生，不知惡死；其出不訢，其入不距；翛然而往，翛然而來而已矣。
passages.en: The True men of old knew nothing of the love of life or of the hatred of death. Entrance into life occasioned them no joy; the exit from it awakened no resistance. Composedly they went and came.

passages.zh: 不忘其所始，不求其所終；受而喜之，忘而復之。
passages.en: They did not forget what their beginning bad been, and they did not inquire into what their end would be. They accepted (their life) and rejoiced in it; they forgot (all fear of death), and returned (to their state before life).

passages.zh: 是之謂不以心捐道，不以人助天。
passages.en: Thus there was in them what is called the want of any mind to resist the Dao, and of all attempts by means of the Human to assist the Heavenly.

passages.zh: 是之謂真人。
passages.en: Such were they who are called the True men.

passages.zh: 若然者，其心志，其容寂，其顙頯，淒然似秋，煖然似春，喜怒通四時，與物有宜，而莫知其極。
passages.en: Being such, their minds were free from all thought; their demeanour was still and unmoved; their foreheads beamed simplicity. Whatever coldness came from them was like that of autumn; whatever warmth came from them was like that of spring. Their joy and anger assimilated to what we see in the four seasons. They did in regard to all things what was suitable, and no one could know how far their action would go.

passages.zh: 故聖人之用兵也，亡國而不失人心；利澤施於萬物，不為愛人。
passages.en: Therefore the sagely man might, in his conduct of war, destroy a state without losing the hearts of the people; his benefits and favours might extend to a myriad generations without his being a lover of men.

passages.zh: 故樂通物，非聖人也；有親，非仁也；天時，非賢也；利害不通，非君子也；行名失己，非士也；亡身不真，非役人也。
passages.en: Hence he who tries to share his joys with others is not a sagely man; he who manifests affection is not benevolent; he who observes times and seasons (to regulate his conduct) is not a man of wisdom; he to whom profit and injury are not the same is not a superior man; he who acts for the sake of the name of doing so, and loses his (proper) self is not the (right) scholar; and he who throws away his person in a way which is not the true (way) cannot command the service of others.

passages.zh: 若狐不偕、務光、伯夷、叔齊、箕子胥餘、紀他、申徒狄，是役人之役，適人之適，而不自適其適者也。
passages.en: Such men as Hu Bu-jie, Wu Guang, Bo-yi, Shu-Qi, the count of Ji, Xu-yu, Ji Ta, and Shen-tu Di, all did service for other men, and sought to secure for them what they desired, not seeking their own pleasure.

passages.zh: 古之真人，其狀義而不朋，若不足而不承，與乎其觚而不堅也，張乎其虛而不華也，邴邴乎其似喜乎！
passages.en: The True men of old presented the aspect of judging others aright, but without being partisans; of feeling their own insufficiency, but being without flattery or cringing. Their peculiarities were natural to them, but they were not obstinately attached to them; their humility was evident, but there was nothing of unreality or display about it. Their placidity and satisfaction had the appearance of joy; their every movement seemed to be a necessity to them.

passages.zh: 崔乎其不得已乎！
passages.en: Their accumulated attractiveness drew men's looks to them; their blandness fixed men's attachment to their virtue.

passages.zh: 滀乎進我色也，與乎止我德也，厲乎其似世乎！
passages.en: They seemed to accommodate themselves to the (manners of their age), but with a certain severity; their haughty indifference was beyond its control.

passages.zh: 謷乎其未可制也，連乎其似好閉也，悗乎忘其言也。
passages.en: Unceasing seemed their endeavours to keep (their mouths) shut; when they looked down, they had forgotten what they wished to say.

passages.zh: 以刑為體，以禮為翼，以知為時，以德為循。
passages.en: They considered punishments to be the substance (of government, and they never incurred it); ceremonies to be its supporting wings (and they always observed them); wisdom (to indicate) the time (for action, and they always selected it); and virtue to be accordance (with others), and they were all-accordant.

passages.zh: 以刑為體者，綽乎其殺也；以禮為翼者，所以行於世也；以知為時者，不得已於事也；以德為循者，言其與有足者至於丘也，而人真以為勤行者也。
passages.en: Considering punishments to be the substance (of government), yet their generosity appeared in the (manner of their) infliction of death. Considering ceremonies to be its supporting wings, they pursued by means of them their course in the world. Considering wisdom to indicate the time (for action), they felt it necessary to employ it in (the direction of) affairs. Considering virtue to be accordance (with others), they sought to ascend its height along with all who had feet (to climb it). (Such were they), and yet men really thought that they did what they did by earnest effort.

passages.zh: 故其好之也一，其弗好之也一。
passages.en: In this way they were one and the same in all their likings and dislikings. Where they liked, they were the same; where they did not like, they were the same.

passages.zh: 其一也一，其不一也一。
passages.en: In the former case where they liked, they were fellow-workers with the Heavenly (in them); in the latter where they disliked, they were co-workers with the Human in them.

passages.zh: 其一，與天為徒；其不一，與人為徒。
passages.en: The one of these elements (in their nature) did not overcome the other.

passages.zh: 天與人不相勝也，是之謂真人。
passages.en: Such were those who are called the True men.

passages.zh: 死生，命也，其有夜旦之常，天也。
passages.en: Death and life are ordained, just as we have the constant succession of night and day - in both cases from Heaven.

passages.zh: 人之有所不得與，皆物之情也。
passages.en: Men have no power to do anything in reference to them - such is the constitution of things.

passages.zh: 彼特以天為父，而身猶愛之，而況其卓乎！
passages.en: There are those who specially regard Heaven as their father, and they still love It (distant as It is); how much more should they love That which stands out (Superior and Alone)!

passages.zh: 人特以有君為愈乎己，而身猶死之，而況其真乎！
passages.en: Some specially regard their ruler as superior to themselves, and will give their bodies to die for him; how much more should they do so for That which is their true (Ruler)!

passages.zh: 泉涸，魚相與處於陸，相呴以溼，相濡以沫，不如相忘於江湖。
passages.en: When the springs are dried up, the fishes collect together on the land. Than that they should moisten one another there by the damp about them, and keep one another wet by their slime, it would be better for them to forget one another in the rivers and lakes.

passages.zh: 與其譽堯而非桀，不如兩忘而化其道。
passages.en: And when men praise Yao and condemn Jie, it would be better to forget them both, and seek the renovation of the Dao.

passages.zh: 夫大塊載我以形，勞我以生，佚我以老，息我以死。
passages.en: There is the great Mass (of nature) - I find the support of my body on it; my life is spent in toil on it; my old age seeks ease on it; at death I find rest in it - what makes my life a good makes my death also a good.

passages.zh: 故善吾生者，乃所以善吾死也。
passages.en: If you hide away a boat in the ravine of a hill, and hide away the hill in a lake, you will say that (the boat) is secure; but at midnight there shall come a strong man and carry it off on his back, while you in the dark know nothing about it.

passages.zh: 夫藏舟於壑，藏山於澤，謂之固矣。
passages.en: You may hide away anything, whether small or great, in the most suitable place, and yet it shall disappear from it.

passages.zh: 然而夜半有力者負之而走，昧者不知也。
passages.en: But if you could hide the world in the world, so that there was nowhere to which it could be removed, this would be the grand reality of the ever-during Thing.

passages.zh: 藏大小有宜，猶有所遯。
passages.en: When the body of man comes from its special mould, there is even then occasion for joy; but this body undergoes a myriad transformations, and does not immediately reach its perfection; does it not thus afford occasion for joys incalculable?

passages.zh: 若夫藏天下於天下，而不得所遯，是恆物之大情也。
passages.en: Therefore the sagely man enjoys himself in that from which there is no possibility of separation, and by which all things are preserved.

passages.zh: 特犯人之形而猶喜之，若人之形者，萬化而未始有極也，其為樂可勝計邪！
passages.en: He considers early death or old age, his beginning and his ending, all to be good, and in this other men imitate him; how much more will they do so in regard to That Itself on which all things depend, and from which every transformation arises!

passages.zh: 故聖人將遊於物之所不得遯而皆存。
passages.en: This is the Dao; there is in It emotion and sincerity, but It does nothing and has no bodily form.

passages.zh: 善妖善老，善始善終，人猶效之，又況萬物之所係，而一化之所待乎！
passages.en: It may be handed down (by the teacher), but may not be received (by his scholars). It may be apprehended (by the mind), but It cannot be seen.

passages.zh: 夫道，有情有信，無為無形；可傳而不可受，可得而不可見；自本自根，未有天地，自古以固存；神鬼神帝，生天生地；在太極之先而不為高，在六極之下而不為深；先天地生而不為久，長於上古而不為老。
passages.en: It has Its root and ground (of existence) in Itself. Before there were heaven and earth, from of old, there It was, securely existing. From It came the mysterious existences of spirits, from It the mysterious existence of God. It produced heaven; It produced earth. It was before the Tai-ji, and yet could not be considered high; It was below all space, and yet could not be considered deep. It was produced before heaven and earth, and yet could not be considered to have existed long; It was older than the highest antiquity, and yet could not be considered old.

passages.zh: 豨韋氏得之，以挈天地；伏犧氏得之，以襲氣母；維斗得之，終古不忒；日月得之，終古不息；堪坏得之，以襲崑崙；馮夷得之，以遊大川；肩吾得之，以處太山；黃帝得之，以登雲天；顓頊得之，以處玄宮；禺強得之，立乎北極；西王母得之，坐乎少廣，莫知其始，莫知其終；彭祖得之，上及有虞，下及五伯；傅說得之，以相武丁，奄有天下，乘東維，騎箕尾，而比於列星。
passages.en: Shi-wei got It, and by It adjusted heaven and earth. Fu-xi got It, and by It penetrated to the mystery of the maternity of the primary matter. The Wei-dou got It, and from all antiquity has made no eccentric movement. The Sun and Moon got It, and from all antiquity have not intermitted (their bright shining). Kan-pei got It, and by It became lord of Kun-lun. Feng-yi got It, and by It enjoyed himself in the Great River. Jian-wu got It, and by It dwelt on mount Tai. Huang-di got It, and by It ascended the cloudy sky. Zhuan-xu got It, and by It dwelt in the Dark Palace. Yu-jiang got It, and by It was set on the North Pole. Xi Wang-mu got It, and by It had her seat in (the palace of) Shao-guang. No one knows Its beginning; no one knows Its end. Peng Zu got It, and lived on from the time of the lord of Yu to that of the Five Chiefs. Fu Yue got It, and by It became chief minister to Wu-ding, (who thus) in a trice became master of the kingdom. (After his death), Fu Yue mounted to the eastern portion of the Milky Way, where, riding on Sagittarius and Scorpio, he took his place among the stars.

passages.zh: 南伯子葵問乎女偊曰：「子之年長矣，而色若孺子，何也？」
passages.en: Nan-bo Zi-kui asked Nu Yu, saying, 'You are old, Sir, while your complexion is like that of a child; how is it so?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾聞道矣。」
passages.en: The reply was, 'I have become acquainted with the Dao.'

passages.zh: 南伯子葵曰：「道可得學邪？」
passages.en: The other said, 'Can I learn the Dao?'

passages.zh: 曰：「惡！
passages.en: Nu Yu said, 'No. How can you?

passages.zh: 惡可！
passages.en: You, Sir, are not the man to do so.

passages.zh: 子非其人也。
passages.en: There was Bu-liang Yi who had the abilities of a sagely man, but not the Dao, while I had the Dao, but not the abilities.

passages.zh: 夫卜梁倚有聖人之才，而無聖人之道，我有聖人之道，而無聖人之才，吾欲以教之，庶幾其果為聖人乎！
passages.en: I wished, however, to teach him, if, peradventure, he might become the sagely man indeed.

passages.zh: 不然，以聖人之道告聖人之才，亦易矣。
passages.en: If he should not do so, it was easy (I thought) for one possessing the Dao of the sagely man to communicate it to another possessing his abilities.

passages.zh: 吾猶守而告之，參日而後能外天下；已外天下矣，吾又守之，七日而後能外物；已外物矣，吾又守之，九日而後能外生；已外生矣，而後能朝徹；朝徹，而後能見獨；見獨，而後能無古今；無古今，而後能入於不死不生。
passages.en: Accordingly, I proceeded to do so, but with deliberation. After three days, he was able to banish from his mind all worldly (matters). This accomplished, I continued my intercourse with him in the same way; and in seven days he was able to banish from his mind all thought of men and things. This accomplished, and my instructions continued, after nine days, he was able to count his life as foreign to himself. This accomplished, his mind was afterwards clear as the morning; and after this he was able to see his own individuality. That individuality perceived, he was able to banish all thought of Past or Present. Freed from this, he was able to penetrate to (the truth that there is no difference between) life and death - (how) the destruction of life is not dying, and the communication of other life is not living.

passages.zh: 殺生者不死，生生者不生。
passages.en: (The Dao) is a thing which accompanies all other things and meets them, which is present when they are overthrown and when they obtain their completion.

passages.zh: 其為物，無不將也，無不迎也；無不毀也，無不成也。
passages.en: Its name is Tranquillity amid all Disturbances, meaning that such Disturbances lead to Its Perfection.'

passages.zh: 其名為攖寧。
passages.en: 'And how did you, being alone (without any teacher), learn all this?'

passages.zh: 攖寧也者，攖而後成者也。」
passages.en: 'I learned it,' was the reply, 'from the son of Fu-mo; he learned it from the grandson of Luo-song; he learned it from Zhan-ming; he learned it from Nie-xu; he, from Xu-yu; he, from Ou; he, from Xuan-ming; he, from Shen-liao; and he learned it from Yi-shi.'

passages.zh: 南伯子葵曰：「子獨惡乎聞之？」
passages.en: Zi-si, Zi-yu, Zi-li, and Zi-lai, these four men, were talking together, when some one said, 'Who can suppose the head to be made from nothing, the spine from life, and the rump-bone from death?

passages.zh: 曰：「聞諸副墨之子，副墨之子聞諸洛誦之孫，洛誦之孫聞之瞻明，瞻明聞之聶許，聶許聞之需役，需役聞之於謳，於謳聞之玄冥，玄冥聞之參寥，參寥聞之疑始。」
passages.en: Who knows how death and birth, living on and disappearing, compose the one body? I would be friends with him.'

passages.zh: 子祀、子輿、子犁、子來四人相與語曰：「孰能以無為首，以生為脊，以死為尻，孰知生死存亡之一體者，吾與之友矣。」
passages.en: The four men looked at one another and laughed, but no one seized with his mind the drift of the questions. All, however, were friends together.

passages.zh: 四人相視而笑，莫逆於心，遂相與為友。
passages.en: Not long after Zi-yu fell ill, and Zi-si went to inquire for him.

passages.zh: 俄而子輿有病，子祀往問之。
passages.en: 'How great,' said (the sufferer), 'is the Creator! That He should have made me the deformed object that I am!'

passages.zh: 曰：「偉哉！
passages.en: He was a crooked hunchback; his five viscera were squeezed into the upper part of his body; his chin bent over his navel; his shoulder was higher than his crown; on his crown was an ulcer pointing to the sky; his breath came and went in gasps: yet he was easy in his mind, and made no trouble of his condition.

passages.zh: 夫造物者，將以予為此拘拘也！」
passages.en: He limped to a well, looked at himself in it, and said, 'Alas that the Creator should have made me the deformed object that I am!'

passages.zh: 曲僂發背，上有五管，頤隱於齊，肩高於頂，句贅指天。
passages.en: Si said, 'Do you dislike your condition?'

passages.zh: 陰陽之氣有沴，其心閒而無事，跰足而鑑於井，曰：「嗟乎！
passages.en: He replied, 'No, why should I dislike it?

passages.zh: 夫造物者，又將以予為此拘拘也！」
passages.en: If He were to transform my left arm into a cock, I should be watching with it the time of the night; if He were to transform my right arm into a cross-bow, I should then be looking for a Xiao to (bring down and) roast; if He were to transform my rump-bone into a wheel, and my spirit into a horse, I should then be mounting it, and would not change it for another steed.

passages.zh: 子祀曰：「汝惡之乎？」
passages.en: Moreover, when we have got (what we are to do), there is the time (of life) in which to do it; when we lose that (at death), submission (is what is required).

passages.zh: 曰：「亡，予何惡！
passages.en: When we rest in what the time requires, and manifest that submission, neither joy nor sorrow can find entrance (to the mind).

passages.zh: 浸假而化予之左臂以為雞，予因以求時夜；浸假而化予之右臂以為彈，予因以求鴞炙；浸假而化予之尻以為輪，以神為馬，予因以乘之，豈更駕哉！
passages.en: This would be what the ancients called loosing the cord by which (the life) is suspended.

passages.zh: 且夫得者時也，失者順也，安時而處順，哀樂不能入也。
passages.en: But one hung up cannot loose himself;-- he is held fast by his bonds.

passages.zh: 此古之所謂縣解也，而不能自解者，物有結之。
passages.en: And that creatures cannot overcome Heaven (the inevitable) is a long-acknowledged fact - why should I hate my condition?'

passages.zh: 且夫物不勝天久矣，吾又何惡焉？」
passages.en: Before long Zi-lai fell ill, and lay gasping at the point of death, while his wife and children stood around him wailing.

passages.zh: 俄而子來有病，喘喘然將死，其妻子環而泣之。
passages.en: Zi-li went to ask for him, and said to them, 'Hush! Get out of the way! Do not disturb him as he is passing through his change.'

passages.zh: 子犁往問之曰：「叱！
passages.en: Then, leaning against the door, he said (to the dying man), 'Great indeed is the Creator!

passages.zh: 避！
passages.en: What will He now make you to become?

passages.zh: 無怛化！」
passages.en: Where will He take you to?

passages.zh: 倚其戶與之語曰：「偉哉造物！
passages.en: Will He make you the liver of a rat, or the arm of an insect?'

passages.zh: 又將奚以汝為？
passages.en: Zi-lai replied, 'Wherever a parent tells a son to go, east, west, south, or north, he simply follows the command.

passages.zh: 將奚以汝適？
passages.en: The Yin and Yang are more to a man than his parents are.

passages.zh: 以汝為鼠肝乎？
passages.en: If they are hastening my death, and I do not quietly submit to them, I shall be obstinate and rebellious.

passages.zh: 以汝為蟲臂乎？」
passages.en: There is the great Mass (of nature);-- I find the support of my body in it; my life is spent in toil on it; my old age seeks ease on it; at death I find rest on it: what has made my life a good will make my death also a good.

passages.zh: 子來曰：「父母於子，東西南北，唯命之從。
passages.en: Here now is a great founder, casting his metal.

passages.zh: 陰陽於人，不翅於父母，彼近吾死而我不聽，我則悍矣，彼何罪焉！
passages.en: If the metal were to leap up (in the pot), and say, "I must be made into a (sword like the) Mo-ye," the great founder would be sure to regard it as uncanny.

passages.zh: 夫大塊載我以形，勞我以生，佚我以老，息我以死。
passages.en: So, again, when a form is being fashioned in the mould of the womb, if it were to say, "I must become a man; I must become a man," the Creator would be sure to regard it as uncanny.

passages.zh: 故善吾生者，乃所以善吾死也。
passages.en: When we once understand that heaven and earth are a great melting-pot, and the Creator a great founder, where can we have to go to that shall not be right for us?

passages.zh: 今之大冶鑄金，金踊躍曰『我且必為鏌鋣』，大冶必以為不祥之金。
passages.en: We are born as from a quiet sleep, and we die to a calm awaking.'

passages.zh: 今一犯人之形，而曰『人耳人耳』，夫造化者必以為不祥之人。
passages.en: Zi-sang Hu, Meng Zi-fan, and Zi-qin Zhang, these three men, were friends together.

passages.zh: 今一以天地為大鑪，以造化為大冶，惡乎往而不可哉！
passages.en: (One of them said), 'Who can associate together without any (thought of) such association, or act together without any (evidence of) such co-operation?

passages.zh: 成然寐，蘧然覺。」
passages.en: Who can mount up into the sky and enjoy himself amidst the mists, disporting beyond the utmost limits (of things), and forgetting all others as if this were living, and would have no end?'

passages.zh: 子桑戶、孟子反、子琴張三人相與友，曰：「孰能相與於無相與，相為於無相為？
passages.en: The three men looked at one another and laughed, not perceiving the drift of the questions; and they continued to associate together as friends.

passages.zh: 孰能登天遊霧，撓挑無極，相忘以生，無所終窮？」
passages.en: Suddenly, after a time, Zi-sang Hu died.

passages.zh: 三人相視而笑，莫逆於心，遂相與友。
passages.en: Before he was buried, Confucius heard of the event, and sent Zi-gong to go and see if he could render any assistance.

passages.zh: 莫然有閒，而子桑戶死，未葬。
passages.en: One of the survivors had composed a ditty, and the other was playing on his lute.

passages.zh: 孔子聞之，使子貢往侍事焉。
passages.en: Then they sang together in unison, 'Ah! come, Sang Hu! ah! come, Sang Hu! Your being true you've got again, While we, as men, still here remain Ohone!'

passages.zh: 或編曲，或鼓琴，相和而歌曰：「嗟來桑戶乎！
passages.en: Zi-gong hastened forward to them, and said, 'I venture to ask whether it be according to the rules to be singing thus in the presence of the corpse?'

passages.zh: 嗟來桑戶乎！
passages.en: The two men looked at each other, and laughed, saying, 'What does this man know about the idea that underlies (our) rules?'

passages.zh: 而已反其真，而我猶為人猗！」
passages.en: Zi-gong returned to Confucius, and reported to him, saying, 'What sort of men are those?

passages.zh: 子貢趨而進曰：「敢問臨尸而歌，禮乎？」
passages.en: They had made none of the usual preparations, and treated the body as a thing foreign to them.

passages.zh: 二人相視而笑，曰：「是惡知禮意！」
passages.en: They were singing in the presence of the corpse, and there was no change in their countenances.

passages.zh: 子貢反，以告孔子曰：「彼何人者邪？
passages.en: I cannot describe them; what sort of men are they?'

passages.zh: 修行無有，而外其形骸，臨尸而歌，顏色不變，無以命之。
passages.en: Confucius replied, 'Those men occupy and enjoy themselves in what is outside the (common) ways (of the world), while I occupy and enjoy myself in what lies within those ways.

passages.zh: 彼何人者邪？」
passages.en: There is no common ground for those of such different ways; and when I sent you to condole with those men, I was acting stupidly.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「彼遊方之外者也，而丘游方之內者也。
passages.en: They, moreover, make man to be the fellow of the Creator, and seek their enjoyment in the formless condition of heaven and earth.

passages.zh: 外內不相及，而丘使女往弔之，丘則陋矣。
passages.en: They consider life to be an appendage attached, an excrescence annexed to them, and death to be a separation of the appendage and a dispersion of the contents of the excrescence.

passages.zh: 彼方且與造物者為人，而遊乎天地之一氣。
passages.en: With these views, how should they know wherein death and life are to be found, or what is first and what is last?

passages.zh: 彼以生為附贅縣疣，以死為決𤴯潰癰。
passages.en: They borrow different substances, and pretend that the common form of the body is composed of them.

passages.zh: 夫若然者，又惡知死生先後之所在！
passages.en: They dismiss the thought of (its inward constituents like) the liver and gall, and (its outward constituents), the ears and eyes.

passages.zh: 假於異物，託於同體，忘其肝膽，遺其耳目，反覆終始，不知端倪，芒然彷徨乎塵垢之外，逍遙乎無為之業。
passages.en: Again and again they end and they begin, having no knowledge of first principles. They occupy themselves ignorantly and vaguely with what (they say) lies outside the dust and dirt (of the world), and seek their enjoyment in the business of doing nothing.

passages.zh: 彼又惡能憒憒然為世俗之禮，以觀眾人之耳目哉！」
passages.en: How should they confusedly address themselves to the ceremonies practised by the common people, and exhibit themselves as doing so to the ears and eyes of the multitude?'

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「然則夫子何方之依？」
passages.en: Zi-gong said, 'Yes, but why do you, Master, act according to the (common) ways (of the world)?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「丘，天之戮民也。
passages.en: The reply was, 'I am in this under the condemning sentence of Heaven.

passages.zh: 雖然，吾與汝共之。」
passages.en: Nevertheless, I will share with you (what I have attained to).'

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「敢問其方。」
passages.en: Zi-gong rejoined, 'I venture to ask the method which you pursue.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「魚相造乎水，人相造乎道。
passages.en: and Confucius said, 'Fishes breed and grow in the water; man developes in the Dao.

passages.zh: 相造乎水者，穿池而養給；相造乎道者，無事而生定。
passages.en: Growing in the water, the fishes cleave the pools, and their nourishment is supplied to them. Developing in the Dao, men do nothing, and the enjoyment of their life is secured.

passages.zh: 故曰：魚相忘乎江湖，人相忘乎道術。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, "Fishes forget one another in the rivers and lakes; men forget one another in the arts of the Dao."'

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「敢問畸人。」
passages.en: Zi-gong said, 'I venture to ask about the man who stands aloof from others.'

passages.zh: 曰：「畸人者，畸於人而侔於天。
passages.en: The reply was, 'He stands aloof from other men, but he is in accord with Heaven!

passages.zh: 故曰：天之小人，人之君子；人之君子，天之小人也。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, "The small man of Heaven is the superior man among men; the superior man among men is the small man of Heaven!"'

passages.zh: 顏回問仲尼曰：「孟孫才，其母死，哭泣無涕，中心不戚，居喪不哀。
passages.en: Yan Hui asked Zhongni, saying, 'When the mother of Meng-sun Cai died, in all his wailing for her he did not shed a tear; in the core of his heart he felt no distress; during all the mourning rites, he exhibited no sorrow.

passages.zh: 無是三者，以善處喪蓋魯國。
passages.en: Without these three things, he (was considered to have) discharged his mourning well; is it that in the state of Lu one who has not the reality may yet get the reputation of having it?

passages.zh: 固有無其實而得其名者乎？
passages.en: I think the matter very strange.'

passages.zh: 回壹怪之。」
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'That Meng-sun carried out (his views) to the utmost.

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「夫孟孫氏盡之矣，進於知矣。
passages.en: He was advanced in knowledge; but (in this case) it was not possible for him to appear to be negligent (in his ceremonial observances)', but he succeeded in being really so to himself.

passages.zh: 唯簡之而不得，夫已有所簡矣。
passages.en: Meng-sun does not know either what purposes life serves, or what death serves; he does not know which should be first sought, and which last.

passages.zh: 孟孫氏不知所以生，不知所以死，不知就先，不知就後，若化為物，以待其所不知之化已乎！
passages.en: If he is to be transformed into something else, he will simply await the transformation which he does not yet know. This is all he does.

passages.zh: 且方將化，惡知不化哉？
passages.en: And moreover, when one is about to undergo his change, how does he know that it has not taken place?

passages.zh: 方將不化，惡知已化哉？
passages.en: And when he is not about to undergo his change, how does he know that it has taken place?

passages.zh: 吾特與汝其夢未始覺者邪！
passages.en: Take the case of me and you: are we in a dream from which we have not begun to awake?

passages.zh: 且彼有駭形而無損心，有旦宅而無情死。
passages.en: Moreover, Meng-sun presented in his body the appearance of being agitated, but in his mind he was conscious of no loss.

passages.zh: 孟孫氏特覺，人哭亦哭，是自其所以乃。
passages.en: The death was to him like the issuing from one's dwelling at dawn, and no (more terrible) reality. He was more awake than others were. When they wailed, he also wailed, having in himself the reason why he did so.

passages.zh: 且也，相與吾之耳矣，庸詎知吾所謂吾之乎？
passages.en: And we all have our individuality which makes us what we are as compared together; but how do we know that we determine in any case correctly that individuality?

passages.zh: 且汝夢為鳥而厲乎天，夢為魚而沒於淵，不識今之言者，其覺者乎，夢者乎？
passages.en: Moreover you dream that you are a bird, and seem to be soaring to the sky; or that you are a fish, and seem to be diving in the deep. But you do not know whether we that are now speaking are awake or in a dream.

passages.zh: 造適不及笑，獻笑不及排，安排而去化，乃入於寥天一。」
passages.en: It is not the meeting with what is pleasurable that produces the smile; it is not the smile suddenly produced that produces the arrangement (of the person). When one rests in what has been arranged, and puts away all thought of the transformation, he is in unity with the mysterious Heaven.'

passages.zh: 意而子見許由，許由曰：「堯何以資汝？」
passages.en: Yi-er Zi having gone to see Xu You, the latter said to him, 'What benefit have you received from Yao?'

passages.zh: 意而子曰：「堯謂我：『汝必躬服仁義，而明言是非。』」
passages.en: The reply was, 'Yao says to me, You must yourself labour at benevolence and righteousness, and be able to tell clearly which is right and which wrong (in conflicting statements).'

passages.zh: 許由曰：「而奚為來軹？
passages.en: Xu You rejoined, 'Why then have you come to me?

passages.zh: 夫堯既已黥汝以仁義，而劓汝以是非矣，汝將何以遊夫遙蕩、恣睢、轉徙之途乎？」
passages.en: Since Yao has put on you the brand of his benevolence and righteousness, and cut off your nose with his right and wrong, how will you be able to wander in the way of aimless enjoyment, of unregulated contemplation, and the ever-changing forms (of dispute)?'

passages.zh: 意而子曰：「雖然，吾願遊於其藩。」
passages.en: Yi-er Zi said, 'That may be; but I should like to skirt along its hedges.'

passages.zh: 許由曰：「不然。
passages.en: 'But,' said the other, 'it cannot be.

passages.zh: 夫盲者無以與乎眉目顏色之好，瞽者無以與乎青黃黼黻之觀。」
passages.en: Eyes without pupils can see nothing of the beauty of the eyebrows, eyes, and other features; the blind have nothing to do with the green, yellow, and variegated colours of the sacrificial robes.'

passages.zh: 意而子曰：「夫無莊之失其美，據梁之失其力，黃帝之亡其知，皆在鑪捶之間耳。
passages.en: Yi-er Zi rejoined, 'Yet, when Wu-zhuang lost her beauty, Ju-liang his strength, and Huang-Di his wisdom, they all (recovered them) under the moulding (of your system) - how do you know that the Maker will not obliterate the marks of my branding, and supply my dismemberment, so that, again perfect in my form, I may follow you as my teacher?'

passages.zh: 庸詎知夫造物者之不息我黥而補我劓，使我乘成以隨先生邪？」
passages.en: Xu You said, 'Ah! that cannot yet be known.

passages.zh: 許由曰：「噫！
passages.en: I will tell you the rudiments.

passages.zh: 未可知也。
passages.en: O my Master!

passages.zh: 我為汝言其大略。
passages.en: O my Master!

passages.zh: 吾師乎！
passages.en: He gives to all things their blended qualities, and does not count it any righteousness; His favours reach to all generations, and He does not count it any benevolence; He is more ancient than the highest antiquity, and does not count Himself old; He overspreads heaven and supports the earth; He carves and fashions all bodily forms, and does not consider it any act of skill;-- this is He in whom I find my enjoyment.'

passages.zh: 吾師乎！
passages.en: Yan Hui said, 'I am making progress.'

passages.zh: 齏萬物而不為義，澤及萬世而不為仁，長於上古而不為老，覆載天地、刻彫眾形而不為巧。
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'What do you mean?'

passages.zh: 此所遊已。」
passages.en: 'I have ceased to think of benevolence and righteousness,' was the reply.

passages.zh: 顏回曰：「回益矣。」
passages.en: 'Very well; but that is not enough.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「何謂也？」
passages.en: Another day, Hui again saw Zhongni, and said, 'I am making progress.'

passages.zh: 曰：「回忘仁義矣。」
passages.en: 'What do you mean?'

passages.zh: 曰：「可矣，猶未也。」
passages.en: 'I have lost all thought of ceremonies and music.'

passages.zh: 他日復見，曰：「回益矣。」
passages.en: 'Very well, but that is not enough.'

passages.zh: 曰：「何謂也？」
passages.en: A third day, Hui again saw (the Master), and said, 'I am making progress.'

passages.zh: 曰：「回忘禮樂矣。」
passages.en: 'What do you mean?'

passages.zh: 曰：「可矣，猶未也。」
passages.en: 'I sit and forget everything.'

passages.zh: 他日復見，曰：「回益矣。」
passages.en: Zhongni changed countenance, and said, 'What do you mean by saying that you sit and forget (everything)?'

passages.zh: 曰：「何謂也？」
passages.en: Yan Hui replied, 'My connexion with the body and its parts is dissolved; my perceptive organs are discarded.

passages.zh: 曰：「回坐忘矣。」
passages.en: Thus leaving my material form, and bidding farewell to my knowledge, I am become one with the Great Pervader.

passages.zh: 仲尼蹴然曰：「何謂坐忘？」
passages.en: This I call sitting and forgetting all things.'

passages.zh: 顏回曰：「墮肢體，黜聰明，離形去知，同於大通，此謂坐忘。」
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'One (with that Pervader), you are free from all likings; so transformed, you are become impermanent.

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「同則無好也，化則無常也。
passages.en: You have, indeed, become superior to me!

passages.zh: 而果其賢乎！
passages.en: I must ask leave to follow in your steps.'

passages.zh: 丘也請從而後也。」
passages.en: Zi-yu and Zi-sang were friends.

passages.zh: 子輿與子桑友，而霖雨十日。
passages.en: (Once), when it had rained continuously for ten days, Zi-yu said, 'I fear that Zi-sang may be in distress.'

passages.zh: 子輿曰：「子桑殆病矣！」
passages.en: So he wrapped up some rice, and went to give it to him to eat.

passages.zh: 裹飯而往食之。
passages.en: When he came to Zi-sang's door, there issued from it sounds between singing and wailing; a lute was struck, and there came the words, '0 Father!

passages.zh: 至子桑之門，則若歌若哭，鼓琴曰：「父邪母邪！
passages.en: 0 Mother!

passages.zh: 天乎人乎！」
passages.en: 0 Heaven! 0 Men!'

passages.zh: 有不任其聲，而趨舉其詩焉。
passages.en: The voice could not sustain itself, and the line was hurriedly pronounced.

passages.zh: 子輿入，曰：「子之歌詩，何故若是？」
passages.en: Zi-yu entered and said, 'Why are you singing, Sir, this line of poetry in such a way?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾思乎使我至此極者而弗得也。
passages.en: The other replied, 'I was thinking, and thinking in vain, how it was that I was brought to such extremity.

passages.zh: 父母豈欲吾貧哉？
passages.en: Would my parents have wished me to be so poor?

passages.zh: 天無私覆，地無私載，天地豈私貧我哉？
passages.en: Heaven overspreads all without any partial feeling, and so does Earth sustain all; Would Heaven and Earth make me so poor with any unkindly feeling?

passages.zh: 求其為之者而不得也。
passages.en: I was trying to find out who had done it, and I could not do so.

passages.zh: 然而至此極者，命也夫！」
passages.en: But here I am in this extremity - it is what was appointed for me!'

chapters.title: Normal Course For Rulers And Kings

passages.zh: 齧缺問於王倪，四問而四不知。
passages.en: Nie Que put four questions to Wang Ni, not one of which did he know (how to answer).

passages.zh: 齧缺因躍而大喜，行以告蒲衣子。
passages.en: On this Nie Que leaped up, and in great delight walked away and informed Yu-yi Zi of it, who said to him, 'Do you (only) now know it?'

passages.zh: 蒲衣子曰：「而乃今知之乎？
passages.en: He of the line of Yu was not equal to him of the line of Tai.

passages.zh: 有虞氏不及泰氏。
passages.en: He of Yu still kept in himself (the idea of) benevolence by which to constrain (the submission of) men; and he did win men, but he had not begun to proceed by what did not belong to him as a man.

passages.zh: 有虞氏，其猶藏仁以要人，亦得人矣，而未始出於非人。
passages.en: He of the line of Tai would sleep tranquilly, and awake in contented simplicity.

passages.zh: 泰氏，其臥徐徐，其覺于于，一以己為馬，一以己為牛，其知情信，其德甚真，而未始入於非人。」
passages.en: He would consider himself now (merely) as a horse, and now (merely) as an ox. His knowledge was real and untroubled by doubts; and his virtue was very true: he had not begun to proceed by what belonged to him as a man.

passages.zh: 肩吾見狂接輿。
passages.en: Jian Wu went to see the mad (recluse), Jie-yu, who said to him, 'What did Ri-Zhong Shi tell you?'

passages.zh: 狂接輿曰：「日中始何以語女？」
passages.en: The reply was, 'He told me that when rulers gave forth their regulations according to their own views and enacted righteous measures, no one would venture not to obey them, and all would be transformed.'

passages.zh: 肩吾曰：「告我：君人者，以己出經式義度，人孰敢不聽而化諸！」
passages.en: Jie-yu said, 'That is but the hypocrisy of virtue.

passages.zh: 狂接輿曰：「是欺德也。
passages.en: For the right ordering of the world it would be like trying to wade through the sea and dig through the He, or employing a mosquito to carry a mountain on its back.

passages.zh: 其於治天下也，猶涉海鑿河，而使蚉負山也。
passages.en: And when a sage is governing, does he govern men's outward actions?

passages.zh: 夫聖人之治也，治外乎？
passages.en: He is (himself) correct, and so (his government) goes on; this is the simple and certain way by which he secures the success of his affairs.

passages.zh: 正而後行，確乎能其事者而已矣。
passages.en: Think of the bird which flies high, to avoid being hurt by the dart on the string of the archer, and the little mouse which makes its hole deep under Shen-qiu to avoid the danger of being smoked or dug out; are (rulers) less knowing than these two little creatures?'

passages.zh: 且鳥高飛以避矰弋之害，鼷鼠深穴乎神丘之下，以避熏鑿之患，而曾二蟲之無知！」
passages.en: Tian Gen, rambling on the south of (mount) Yin, came to the neighbourhood of the Liao-water.

passages.zh: 天根遊於殷陽，至蓼水之上，適遭無名人而問焉，曰：「請問為天下。」
passages.en: Happening there to meet with the man whose name is not known, he put a question to him, saying, 'I beg to ask what should be done in order to (carry on) the government of the world.'

passages.zh: 無名人曰：「去！
passages.en: The nameless man said, 'Go away; you are a rude borderer.

passages.zh: 汝鄙人也，何問之不豫也！
passages.en: Why do you put to me a question for which you are unprepared?

passages.zh: 予方將與造物者為人，厭則又乘夫莽眇之鳥，以出六極之外，而遊無何有之鄉，以處壙埌之野。
passages.en: I would simply play the part of the Maker of (all) things. When wearied, I would mount on the bird of the light and empty air, proceed beyond the six cardinal points, and wander in the region of nonentity, to dwell in the wilderness of desert space.

passages.zh: 汝又何帠以治天下感予之心為？」
passages.en: What method have you, moreover, for the government of the world that you (thus) agitate my mind?'

passages.zh: 又復問。
passages.en: (Tian Gen), however, again asked the question, and the nameless man said, 'Let your mind find its enjoyment in pure simplicity; blend yourself with (the primary) ether in idle indifference; allow all things to take their natural course; and admit no personal or selfish consideration - do this and the world will be governed.'

passages.zh: 無名人曰：「汝遊心於淡，合氣於漠，順物自然，而無容私焉，而天下治矣。」
passages.en: Yang Zi-ju, having an interview with Lao Dan, said to him, 'Here is a man, alert and vigorous in responding to all matters, clearsighted and widely intelligent, and an unwearied student of the Dao - can he be compared to one of the intelligent kings?'

passages.zh: 陽子居見老聃曰：「有人於此，嚮疾強梁，物徹疏明，學道不倦。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Such a man is to one of the intelligent kings but as the bustling underling of a court who toils his body and distresses his mind with his various contrivances.

passages.zh: 如是者，可比明王乎？」
passages.en: And moreover, it is the beauty of the skins of the tiger and leopard which makes men hunt them; the agility of the monkey, or (the sagacity of) the dog that catches the yak, which make men lead them in strings; but can one similarly endowed be compared to the intelligent kings?'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「是於聖人也，胥易技係，勞形怵心者也。
passages.en: Yang Zi-ju looked discomposed and said, 'I venture to ask you what the government of the intelligent kings is.'

passages.zh: 且也虎豹之文來田，猿狙之便、執嫠之狗來藉。
passages.en: Lao Dan replied, 'In the governing of the intelligent kings, their services overspread all under the sky, but they did not seem to consider it as proceeding from themselves; their transforming influence reached to all things, but the people did not refer it to them with hope.

passages.zh: 如是者，可比明王乎？」
passages.en: No one could tell the name of their agency, but they made men and things be joyful in themselves.

passages.zh: 陽子居蹴然曰：「敢問明王之治。」
passages.en: Where they took their stand could not be fathomed, and they found their enjoyment in (the realm of) nonentity.'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「明王之治，功蓋天下而似不自己，化貸萬物而民弗恃，有莫舉名，使物自喜，立乎不測，而遊於無有者也。」
passages.en: In Zheng there was a mysterious wizard called Ji-xian.

passages.zh: 鄭有神巫曰季咸，知人之生死存亡，禍福壽夭，期以歲月旬日，若神。
passages.en: He knew all about the deaths and births of men, their preservation and ruin, their misery and happiness, and whether their lives would be long or short, foretelling the year, the month, the decade and the day like a spirit.

passages.zh: 鄭人見之，皆棄而走。
passages.en: When the people of Kang saw him, they all ran out of his way.

passages.zh: 列子見之而心醉，歸以告壺子，曰：「始吾以夫子之道為至矣，則又有至焉者矣。」
passages.en: Liezi went to see him, and was fascinated by him. Returning, he told Hu-zi of his interview, and said, 'I considered your doctrine, my master, to be perfect, but I have found another which is superior to it.'
