passages.zh: 壺子曰：「吾與汝既其文，未既其實，而固得道與？」
passages.en: Hu-zi replied, 'I have communicated to you but the outward letter of my doctrine, and have not communicated its reality and spirit; and do you think that you are in possession of it?

passages.zh: 眾雌而無雄，而又奚卵焉！
passages.en: However many hens there be, if there be not the cock among them, how should they lay (real) eggs?

passages.zh: 而以道與世亢必信，夫故使人得而相女。
passages.en: When you confront the world with your doctrine, you are sure to show in your countenance (all that is in your mind), and so enable (this) man to succeed in interpreting your physiognomy.

passages.zh: 嘗試與來，以予示之。」
passages.en: Try and come to me with him, that I may show myself to him.'

passages.zh: 明日，列子與之見壺子。
passages.en: On the morrow, accordingly, Liezi came with the man and saw Hu-zi.

passages.zh: 出而謂列子曰：「嘻！
passages.en: When they went out, the wizard said, 'Alas!

passages.zh: 子之先生死矣，弗活矣，不以旬數矣！
passages.en: your master is a dead man. He will not live;-- not for ten days more!

passages.zh: 吾見怪焉，見溼灰焉。」
passages.en: I saw something strange about him - I saw the ashes (of his life) all slaked with water!'

passages.zh: 列子入，泣涕沾襟，以告壺子。
passages.en: When Liezi reentered, he wept till the front of his jacket was wet with his tears, and told Hu-zi what the man had said.

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「鄉吾示之以地文，萌乎不震不正。
passages.en: Hu-zi said, 'I showed myself to him with the forms of (vegetation beneath) the earth.

passages.zh: 是殆見吾杜德機也。
passages.en: There were the sprouts indeed, but without (any appearance of) growth or regularity:-- he seemed to see me with the springs of my (vital) power closed up.

passages.zh: 嘗又與來。」
passages.en: Try and come to me with him again.'

passages.zh: 明日，又與之見壺子。
passages.en: Next day, accordingly, Liezi brought the man again and saw Hu-zi.

passages.zh: 出而謂列子曰：「幸矣！
passages.en: When they went out, the man said, 'It is a fortunate thing for your master that he met with me.

passages.zh: 子之先生遇我也。
passages.en: He will get better; he has all the signs of living!

passages.zh: 有瘳矣，全然有生矣。
passages.en: I saw the balance (of the springs of life) that had been stopped (inclining in his favour).'

passages.zh: 吾見其杜權矣。」
passages.en: Liezi went in, and reported these words to his master, who said, 'I showed myself to him after the pattern of the earth (beneath the) sky.

passages.zh: 列子入，以告壺子。
passages.en: Neither semblance nor reality entered (into my exhibition), but the springs (of life) were issuing from beneath my feet;-- he seemed to see me with the springs of vigorous action in full play.

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「鄉吾示之以天壤，名實不入，而機發於踵。
passages.en: Try and come with him again.'

passages.zh: 是殆見吾善者機也。
passages.en: Next day Liezi came with the man again, and again saw Hu-zi with him.

passages.zh: 嘗又與來。」
passages.en: When they went out, the wizard said, 'Your master is never the same.

passages.zh: 明日，又與之見壺子。
passages.en: I cannot understand his physiognomy.

passages.zh: 出而謂列子曰：「子之先生不齊，吾無得而相焉。
passages.en: Let him try to steady himself, and I will again view him.'

passages.zh: 試齊，且復相之。」
passages.en: Liezi went in and reported this to Hu-zi, who said, 'This time I showed myself to him after the pattern of the grand harmony (of the two elemental forces), with the superiority inclining to neither.

passages.zh: 列子入，以告壺子。
passages.en: He seemed to see me with the springs of (vital) power in equal balance.

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「吾鄉示之以太沖莫勝。
passages.en: Where the water wheels about from (the movements of) a dugong, there is an abyss; where it does so from the arresting (of its course), there is an abyss; where it does so, and the water keeps flowing on, there is an abyss.

passages.zh: 是殆見吾衡氣機也。
passages.en: There are nine abysses with their several names, and I have only exhibited three of them.

passages.zh: 鯢桓之審為淵，止水之審為淵，流水之審為淵。
passages.en: Try and come with him again.'

passages.zh: 淵有九名，此處三焉。
passages.en: Next day they came, and they again saw Hu-zi.

passages.zh: 嘗又與來。」
passages.en: But before he had settled himself in his position, the wizard lost himself and ran away.

passages.zh: 明日，又與之見壺子。
passages.en: 'Pursue him,' said Hu-zi, and Liezi did so, but could not come up with him.

passages.zh: 立未定，自失而走。
passages.en: He returned, and told Hu-zi, saying, 'There is an end of him; he is lost; I could not find him.'

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「追之！」
passages.en: Hu-zi rejoined, 'I was showing him myself after the pattern of what was before I began to come from my author.

passages.zh: 列子追之不及，反以報壺子，曰：「已滅矣，已失矣，吾弗及也。」
passages.en: I confronted him with pure vacancy, and an easy indifference.

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「鄉吾示之以未始出吾宗。
passages.en: He did not know what I meant to represent.

passages.zh: 吾與之虛而委蛇，不知其誰何，因以為弟靡，因以為波流，故逃也。」
passages.en: Now he thought it was the idea of exhausted strength, and now that of an onward flow, and therefore he ran away.'

passages.zh: 然後列子自以為未始學而歸，三年不出。
passages.en: After this, Liezi considered that he had not yet begun to learn (his master's doctrine). He returned to his house, and for three years did not go out.

passages.zh: 為其妻爨，食豕如食人。
passages.en: He did the cooking for his wife. He fed the pigs as if he were feeding men.

passages.zh: 於事無與親，彫琢復朴，塊然獨以其形立。
passages.en: He took no part or interest in occurring affairs. He put away the carving and sculpture about him, and returned to pure simplicity. Like a clod of earth he stood there in his bodily presence.

passages.zh: 紛而封哉，一以是終。
passages.en: Amid all distractions he was (silent) and shut up in himself. And in this way he continued to the end of his life.

passages.zh: 無為名尸，無為謀府，無為事任，無為知主。
passages.en: Non-action (makes its exemplifier) the lord of all fame; non-action (serves him as) the treasury of all plans; non-action (fits him for) the burden of all offices; non-action (makes him) the lord of all wisdom.

passages.zh: 體盡無窮，而遊無朕，盡其所受於天，而無見得，亦虛而已。
passages.en: The range of his action is inexhaustible, but there is nowhere any trace of his presence. He fulfils all that he has received from Heaven, but he does not see that he was the recipient of anything. A pure vacancy (of all purpose) is what characterises him.

passages.zh: 至人之用心若鏡，不將不迎，應而不藏，故能勝物而不傷。
passages.en: When the perfect man employs his mind, it is a mirror. It conducts nothing and anticipates nothing; it responds to (what is before it), but does not retain it. Thus he is able to deal successfully with all things, and injures none.

passages.zh: 南海之帝為儵，北海之帝為忽，中央之帝為渾沌。
passages.en: The Ruler of the Southern Ocean was Shu, the Ruler of the Northern Ocean was Hu, and the Ruler of the Centre was Chaos.

passages.zh: 儵與忽時相與遇於渾沌之地，渾沌待之甚善。
passages.en: Shu and Hu were continually meeting in the land of Chaos, who treated them very well.

passages.zh: 儵與忽謀報渾沌之德，曰：「人皆有七竅，以視聽食息，此獨無有，嘗試鑿之。」
passages.en: They consulted together how they might repay his kindness, and said, 'Men all have seven orifices for the purpose of seeing, hearing, eating, and breathing, while this (poor) Ruler alone has not one. Let us try and make them for him.'

passages.zh: 日鑿一竅，七日而渾沌死。
passages.en: Accordingly they dug one orifice in him every day; and at the end of seven days Chaos died.

passages.zh: 駢拇枝指，出乎性哉！
passages.en: A ligament uniting the big toe with the other toes and an extra finger may be natural growths, but they are more than is good for use.

passages.zh: 而侈於德。
passages.en: Excrescences on the person and hanging tumours are growths from the body, but they are unnatural additions to it.

passages.zh: 附贅縣疣，出乎形哉！
passages.en: There are many arts of benevolence and righteousness, and the exercise of them is distributed among the five viscera; but this is not the correct method according to the characteristics of the Dao.

passages.zh: 而侈於性。
passages.en: Thus it is that the addition to the foot is but the attachment to it of so much useless flesh, and the addition to the hand is but the planting on it of a useless finger.

passages.zh: 多方乎仁義而用之者，列於五藏哉！
passages.en: (So it is that) the connecting (the virtues) with the five viscera renders, by excess or restraint, the action of benevolence and righteousness bad, and leads to many arts as in the employment of (great) powers of hearing or of vision.

passages.zh: 而非道德之正也。
passages.en: Therefore an extraordinary power of vision leads to the confusion of the five colours and an excessive use of ornament.

passages.zh: 是故駢於足者，連無用之肉也；枝於手者，樹無用之指也；多方駢枝於五藏之情者，淫僻於仁義之行，而多方於聰明之用也。
passages.en: (Its possessor), in the resplendence of his green and yellow, white and black, black and green, will not stop till he has become a Li Zhu.

passages.zh: 是故駢於明者，亂五色，淫文章，青黃黼黻之煌煌非乎？
passages.en: An extraordinary power of hearing leads to a confusion of the five notes, and an excessive use of the six musical accords.

passages.zh: 而離朱是已。
passages.en: (Its possessor), in bringing out the tones from the instruments of metal, stone, silk, and bamboo, aided by the Huang-zhong and Da-lu (tubes), will not stop till he has become a Shi Kuang.

passages.zh: 多於聰者，亂五聲，淫六律，金石、絲竹，黃鐘、大呂之聲非乎？
passages.en: (So), excessive benevolence eagerly brings out virtues and restrains its (proper) nature, that (its possessor) may acquire a famous reputation, and cause all the organs and drums in the world to celebrate an unattainable condition; and he will not stop till he has become a Zeng (Shen) or a Shi (Qiu).

passages.zh: 而師曠是已。
passages.en: An extraordinary faculty in debating leads to the piling up of arguments like a builder with his bricks, or a netmaker with his string.

passages.zh: 枝於仁者，擢德塞性以收名聲，使天下簧鼓以奉不及之法非乎？
passages.en: (Its possessor) cunningly contrives his sentences and enjoys himself in discussing what hardness is and what whiteness is, where views agree and where they differ, and pressing on, though weary, with short steps, with (a multitude of) useless words to make good his opinion; nor will he stop till he has become a Yang (Zhu) or Mo (Di).

passages.zh: 而曾、史是已。
passages.en: But in all these cases the parties, with their redundant and divergent methods, do not proceed by that which is the correct path for all under the sky.

passages.zh: 駢於辯者，纍瓦結繩竄句，遊心於堅白同異之間，而敝跬譽無用之言非乎？
passages.en: That which is the perfectly correct path is not to lose the real character of the nature with which we are endowed.

passages.zh: 而楊、墨是已。
passages.en: Hence the union (of parts) should not be considered redundance, nor their divergence superfluity; what is long should not be considered too long, nor what is short too short.

passages.zh: 故此皆多駢旁枝之道，非天下之至正也。
passages.en: A duck's legs, for instance, are short, but if we try to lengthen them, it occasions pain; and a crane's legs are long, but if we try to cut off a portion of them, it produces grief.

passages.zh: 彼正正者，不失其性命之情。
passages.en: Where a part is by nature long, we are not to amputate, or where it is by nature short, we are not to lengthen it.

passages.zh: 故合者不為駢，而枝者不為跂；長者不為有餘，短者不為不足。
passages.en: There is no occasion to try to remove any trouble that it may cause.

passages.zh: 是故鳧脛雖短，續之則憂；鶴脛雖長，斷之則悲。
passages.en: The presumption is that benevolence and righteousness are not constituents of humanity; for to how much anxiety does the exercise of them give rise!

passages.zh: 故性長非所斷，性短非所續，無所去憂也。
passages.en: Moreover when another toe is united to the great toe, to divide the membrane makes you weep; and when there is an extra finger, to gnaw it off makes you cry out.

passages.zh: 意仁義其非人情乎！
passages.en: In the one case there is a member too many, and in the other a member too few; but the anxiety and pain which they cause is the same.

passages.zh: 彼仁人何其多憂也？
passages.en: The benevolent men of the present age look at the evils of the world, as with eyes full of dust, and are filled with sorrow by them, while those who are not benevolent, having violently altered the character of their proper nature, greedily pursue after riches and honours.

passages.zh: 且夫駢於拇者，決之則泣；枝於手者，齕之則啼。
passages.en: The presumption therefore is that benevolence and righteousness are contrary to the nature of man - how full of trouble and contention has the world been ever since the three dynasties began!

passages.zh: 二者或有餘於數，或不足於數，其於憂一也。
passages.en: And moreover, in employing the hook and line, the compass and square, to give things their correct form you must cut away portions of what naturally belongs to them; in employing strings and fastenings, glue and varnish to make things firm, you must violently interfere with their qualities.

passages.zh: 今世之仁人，蒿目而憂世之患；不仁之人，決性命之情而饕富貴。
passages.en: The bendings and stoppings in ceremonies and music, and the factitious expression in the countenance of benevolence and righteousness, in order to comfort the minds of men - these all show a failure in observing the regular principles (of the human constitution).

passages.zh: 故意仁義其非人情乎！
passages.en: All men are furnished with such regular principles; and according to them what is bent is not made so by the hook, nor what is straight by the line, nor what is round by the compass, nor what is square by the carpenter's square.

passages.zh: 自三代以下者，天下何其囂囂也？
passages.en: Nor is adhesion effected by the use of glue and varnish, nor are things bound together by means of strings and bands.

passages.zh: 且夫待鉤繩規矩而正者，是削其性；待繩約膠漆而固者，是侵其德也；屈折禮樂，呴俞仁義，以慰天下之心者，此失其常然也。
passages.en: Thus it is that all in the world are produced what they are by a certain guidance, while they do not know how they are produced so; and they equally attain their several ends while they do not know how it is that they do so.

passages.zh: 天下有常然。
passages.en: Anciently it was so, and it is so now; and this constitution of things should not be made of none effect.

passages.zh: 常然者，曲者不以鉤，直者不以繩，圓者不以規，方者不以矩，附離不以膠漆，約束不以纆索。
passages.en: Why then should benevolence and righteousness be employed as connecting (links), or as glue and varnish, strings and bands, and the enjoyment arising from the Dao and its characteristics be attributed to them?

passages.zh: 故天下誘然皆生，而不知其所以生；同焉皆得，而不知其所以得。
passages.en: It is a deception practised upon the world.

passages.zh: 古今不二，不可虧也。
passages.en: Where the deception is small, there will be a change in the direction (of the objects pursued); where it is great, there will be a change of the nature itself.

passages.zh: 則仁義又奚連連如膠漆纆索，而遊乎道德之間為哉？
passages.en: How do I know that it is so?

passages.zh: 使天下惑也！
passages.en: Since he of the line of Yu called in his benevolence and righteousness to distort and vex the world, the world has not ceased to hurry about to execute their commands - has not this been by means of benevolence and righteousness to change (men's views) of their nature?

passages.zh: 夫小惑易方，大惑易性。
passages.en: I will therefore try and discuss this matter.

passages.zh: 何以知其然邪？
passages.en: From the commencement of the three dynasties downwards, nowhere has there been a man who has not under (the influence of external) things altered (the course of) his nature.

passages.zh: 自虞氏招仁義以撓天下也，天下莫不奔命於仁義，是非以仁義易其性與？
passages.en: Small men for the sake of gain have sacrificed their persons; scholars for the sake of fame have done so; great officers, for the sake of their families; and sagely men, for the sake of the kingdom.

passages.zh: 故嘗試論之，自三代以下者，天下莫不以物易其性矣。
passages.en: These several classes, with different occupations, and different reputations, have agreed in doing injury to their nature and sacrificing their persons.

passages.zh: 小人則以身殉利，士則以身殉名，大夫則以身殉家，聖人則以身殉天下。
passages.en: Take the case of a male and female slave; they have to feed the sheep together, but they both lose their sheep.

passages.zh: 故此數子者，事業不同，名聲異號，其於傷性以身為殉，一也。
passages.en: Ask the one what he was doing, and you will find that he was holding his bamboo tablets and reading.

passages.zh: 臧與穀，二人相與牧羊，而俱亡其羊。
passages.en: Ask the other, and you will find that she was amusing herself with some game.

passages.zh: 問臧奚事，則挾筴讀書；問穀奚事，則博塞以遊。
passages.en: They were differently occupied, but they equally lose their sheep.

passages.zh: 二人者，事業不同，其於亡羊均也。
passages.en: (So), Bo-yi died at the foot of Shou-yang to maintain his fame, and the robber Zhi died on the top of Dong-ling in his eagerness for gain.

passages.zh: 伯夷死名於首陽之下，盜跖死利於東陵之上。
passages.en: Their deaths were occasioned by different causes, but they equally shortened their lives and did violence to their nature; why must we approve of Bo-yi, and condemn the robber Zhi?

passages.zh: 二人者，所死不同，其於殘生傷性均也，奚必伯夷之是而盜跖之非乎？
passages.en: In cases of such sacrifice all over the world, when one makes it for the sake of benevolence and righteousness, the common people style him 'a superior man,' but when another does it for the sake of goods and riches, they style him 'a small man.'

passages.zh: 天下盡殉也。
passages.en: The action of sacrificing is the same, and yet we have 'the superior man' and 'the small man!'

passages.zh: 彼其所殉仁義也，則俗謂之君子；其所殉貨財也，則俗謂之小人。
passages.en: In the matter of destroying his life, and doing injury to his nature, the robber Zhi simply did the same as Bo-yi - why must we make the distinction of 'superior man' and 'small man' between them?

passages.zh: 其殉一也，則有君子焉，有小人焉；若其殘生損性，則盜跖亦伯夷已，又惡取君子小人於其間哉？
passages.en: Moreover, those who devote their nature to (the pursuit) of benevolence and righteousness, though they should attain to be like Zeng (Shen) and Shi (Qiu), I do not pronounce to be good; those who devote it to (the study of) the five flavours, though they attain to be like Shu-er, I do not pronounce to be good; those who devote it to the (discrimination of the) five notes, though they attain to be like Shi Kuang, I do not pronounce to be quick of hearing; those who devote it to the (appreciation of the) five colours, though they attain to be like Li Zhu, I do not pronounce to be clear of vision.

passages.zh: 且夫屬其性乎仁義者，雖通如曾、史，非吾所謂臧也；屬其性於五味，雖通如俞兒，非吾所謂臧也；屬其性乎五聲，雖通如師曠，非吾所謂聰也；屬其性乎五色，雖通如離朱，非吾所謂明也。
passages.en: When I pronounce men to be good, I am not speaking of their benevolence and righteousness; the goodness is simply (their possession of) the qualities (of the Dao).

passages.zh: 吾所謂臧者，非仁義之謂也，臧於其德而已矣；吾所謂臧者，非所謂仁義之謂也，任其性命之情而已矣；吾所謂聰者，非謂其聞彼也，自聞而已矣；吾所謂明者，非謂其見彼也，自見而已矣。
passages.en: When I pronounce them to be good, I am not speaking of what are called benevolence and righteousness; but simply of their allowing the nature with which they are endowed to have its free course. When I pronounce men to be quick of hearing, I do not mean that they hearken to anything else, but that they hearken to themselves; when I pronounce them to be clear of vision, I do not mean that they look to anything else, but that they look to themselves.

passages.zh: 夫不自見而見彼，不自得而得彼者，是得人之得而不自得其得者也，適人之適而不自適其適者也。
passages.en: Now those who do not see themselves but see other things, who do not get possession of themselves but get possession of other things, get possession of what belongs to others, and not of what is their own; and they reach forth to what attracts others, and not to that in themselves which should attract them.

passages.zh: 夫適人之適而不自適其適，雖盜跖與伯夷，是同為淫僻也。
passages.en: But thus reaching forth to what attracts others and not to what should attract them in themselves, be they like the robber Zhi or like Bo-yi, they equally err in the way of excess or of perversity.

passages.zh: 余愧乎道德，是以上不敢為仁義之操，而下不敢為淫僻之行也。
passages.en: What I am ashamed of is erring in the characteristics of the Dao, and therefore, in the higher sphere, I do not dare to insist on the practice of benevolence and righteousness, and, in the lower, I do not dare to allow myself either in the exercise of excess or perversity.

passages.zh: 馬，蹄可以踐霜雪，毛可以禦風寒，齕草飲水，翹足而陸。
passages.en: Horses can with their hoofs tread on the hoarfrost and snow, and with their hair withstand the wind and cold; they feed on the grass and drink water; they prance with their legs and leap:

passages.zh: 此馬之真性也。
passages.en: this is the true nature of horses.

passages.zh: 雖有義臺、路寢，無所用之。
passages.en: Though there were made for them grand towers and large dormitories, they would prefer not to use them.

passages.zh: 及至伯樂，曰：「我善治馬。」
passages.en: But when Bo-le (arose and) said, 'I know well how to manage horses,'

passages.zh: 燒之剔之，刻之雒之，連之以羈馽，編之以皁棧，馬之死者十二三矣；
passages.en: (men proceeded) to singe and mark them, to clip their hair, to pare their hoofs, to halter their heads, to bridle them and hobble them, and to confine them in stables and corrals. (When subjected to this treatment), two or three in every ten of them died.

passages.zh: 飢之渴之，馳之驟之，整之齊之，前有橛飾之患，而後有鞭筴之威，而馬之死者已過半矣。
passages.en: (Men proceeded further) to subject them to hunger and thirst, to gallop them and race them, and to make them go together in regular order. In front were the evils of the bit and ornamented breastbands, and behind were the terrors of the whip and switch. (When so treated), more than half of them died.

passages.zh: 陶者曰：「我善治埴，圓者中規，方者中矩。」
passages.en: The (first) potter said, 'I know well how to deal with clay;' and (men proceeded) to mould it into circles as exact as if made by the compass, and into squares as exact as if formed by the measuring square.

passages.zh: 匠人曰：「我善治木，曲者中鉤，直者應繩。」
passages.en: The (first) carpenter said, 'I know well how to deal with wood;' and (men proceeded) to make it bent as if by the application of the hook, and straight as if by the application of the plumb-line.

passages.zh: 夫埴、木之性，豈欲中規矩鉤繩哉？
passages.en: But is it the nature of clay and wood to require the application of the compass and square, of the hook and line?

passages.zh: 然且世世稱之曰：「伯樂善治馬，而陶、匠善治埴木。」
passages.en: And yet age after age men have praised Bo-le, saying, 'He knew well how to manage horses,' and also the (first) potter and carpenter, saying, 'They knew well how to deal with clay and wood.'

passages.zh: 此亦治天下者之過也。
passages.en: This is just the error committed by the governors of the world.

passages.zh: 吾意善治天下者不然。
passages.en: According to my idea, those who knew well to govern mankind would not act so.

passages.zh: 彼民有常性，織而衣，耕而食，是謂同德；
passages.en: The people had their regular and constant nature: they wove and made themselves clothes; they tilled the ground and got food. This was their common faculty.

passages.zh: 一而不黨，命曰天放。
passages.en: They were all one in this, and did not form themselves into separate classes; so were they constituted and left to their natural tendencies.

passages.zh: 故至德之世，其行填填，其視顛顛。
passages.en: Therefore in the age of perfect virtue men walked along with slow and grave step, and with their looks steadily directed forwards.

passages.zh: 當是時也，山無蹊隧，澤無舟梁；
passages.en: At that time, on the hills there were no foot-paths, nor excavated passages; on the lakes there were no boats nor dams;

passages.zh: 萬物群生，連屬其鄉；
passages.en: all creatures lived in companies; and the places of their settlement were made close to one another.

passages.zh: 禽獸成群，草木遂長。
passages.en: Birds and beasts multiplied to flocks and herds; the grass and trees grew luxuriant and long.

passages.zh: 是故禽獸可係羈而遊，烏鵲之巢可攀援而闚。
passages.en: In this condition the birds and beasts might be led about without feeling the constraint; the nest of the magpie might be climbed to, and peeped into.

passages.zh: 夫至德之世，同與禽獸居，族與萬物並，惡乎知君子小人哉！
passages.en: Yes, in the age of perfect virtue, men lived in common with birds and beasts, and were on terms of equality with all creatures, as forming one family - how could they know among themselves the distinctions of superior men and small men?

passages.zh: 同乎無知，其德不離；
passages.en: Equally without knowledge, they did not leave (the path of) their natural virtue;

passages.zh: 同乎無欲，是謂素樸。
passages.en: equally free from desires, they were in the state of pure simplicity.

passages.zh: 素樸而民性得矣。
passages.en: In that state of pure simplicity, the nature of the people was what it ought to be.

passages.zh: 及至聖人，蹩躠為仁，踶跂為義，而天下始疑矣；
passages.en: But when the sagely men appeared, limping and wheeling about in (the exercise of) benevolence, pressing along and standing on tiptoe in the doing of righteousness, then men universally began to be perplexed.

passages.zh: 澶漫為樂，摘僻為禮，而天下始分矣。
passages.en: (Those sages also) went to excess in their performances of music, and in their gesticulations in the practice of ceremonies, and then men began to be separated from one another.

passages.zh: 故純樸不殘，孰為犧尊！
passages.en: If the raw materials had not been cut and hacked, who could have made a sacrificial vase from them?

passages.zh: 白玉不毀，孰為珪璋！
passages.en: If the natural jade had not been broken and injured, who could have made the handles for the libation-cups from it?

passages.zh: 道德不廢，安取仁義！
passages.en: If the attributes of the Dao had not been disallowed, how should they have preferred benevolence and righteousness?

passages.zh: 性情不離，安用禮樂！
passages.en: If the instincts of the nature had not been departed from, how should ceremonies and music have come into use?

passages.zh: 五色不亂，孰為文采！
passages.en: If the five colours had not been confused, how should the ornamental figures have been formed?

passages.zh: 五聲不亂，孰應六律！
passages.en: If the five notes had not been confused, how should they have supplemented them by the musical accords?

passages.zh: 夫殘樸以為器，工匠之罪也；
passages.en: The cutting and hacking of the raw materials to form vessels was the crime of the skilful workman;

passages.zh: 毀道德以為仁義，聖人之過也。
passages.en: the injury done to the characteristics of the Dao in order to the practice of benevolence and righteousness was the error of the sagely men.

passages.zh: 夫馬，陸居則食草飲水，喜則交頸相靡，怒則分背相踶。
passages.en: Horses, when living in the open country, eat the grass, and drink water; when pleased, they intertwine their necks and rub one another; when enraged, they turn back to back and kick one another -

passages.zh: 馬知已此矣。
passages.en: this is all that they know to do.

passages.zh: 夫加之以衡扼，齊之以月題，而馬知介倪、闉扼、鷙曼、詭銜、竊轡。
passages.en: But if we put the yoke on their necks, with the moonlike frontlet displayed on all their foreheads, then they know to look slily askance, to curve their necks, to rush viciously, trying to get the bit out of their mouths, and to filch the reins (from their driver);

passages.zh: 故馬之知而態至盜者，伯樂之罪也。
passages.en: this knowledge of the horse and its ability thus to act the part of a thief is the crime of Bo-le.

passages.zh: 夫赫胥氏之時，民居不知所為，行不知所之，含哺而熙，鼓腹而遊，民能以此矣。
passages.en: In the time of (the Di) He-xu, the people occupied their dwellings without knowing what they were doing, and walked out without knowing where they were going. They filled their mouths with food and were glad; they slapped their stomachs to express their satisfaction. This was all the ability which they possessed.

passages.zh: 及至聖人，屈折禮樂以匡天下之形，縣跂仁義以慰天下之心，而民乃始踶跂好知，爭歸於利，不可止也。
passages.en: But when the sagely men appeared, with their bendings and stoppings in ceremonies and music to adjust the persons of all, and hanging up their benevolence and righteousness to excite the endeavours of all to reach them, in order to comfort their minds, then the people began to stump and limp about in their love of knowledge, and strove with one another in their pursuit of gain, so that there was no stopping them:

passages.zh: 此亦聖人之過也。
passages.en: this was the error of those sagely men.

passages.zh: 將為胠篋、探囊、發匱之盜而為守備，則必攝緘、縢，固扃、鐍，此世俗之所謂知也。
passages.en: In taking precautions against thieves who cut open satchels, search bags, and break open boxes, people are sure to cord and fasten them well, and to employ strong bonds and clasps; and in this they are ordinarily said to show their wisdom.

passages.zh: 然而巨盜至，則負匱、揭篋、擔囊而趨，唯恐緘、縢、扃、鐍之不固也。
passages.en: When a great thief comes, however, he shoulders the box, lifts up the satchel, carries off the bag, and runs away with them, afraid only that the cords, bonds, and clasps may not be secure;

passages.zh: 然則鄉之所謂知者，不乃為大盜積者也？
passages.en: and in this case what was called the wisdom (of the owners) proves to be nothing but a collecting of the things for the great thief.

passages.zh: 故嘗試論之，世俗之所謂知者，有不為大盜積者乎？
passages.en: Let me try and set this matter forth. Do not those who are vulgarly called wise prove to be collectors for the great thieves?

passages.zh: 所謂聖者，有不為大盜守者乎？
passages.en: And do not those who are called sages prove to be but guardians in the interest of the great thieves?

passages.zh: 何以知其然邪？
passages.en: How do I know that the case is so?

passages.zh: 昔者齊國鄰邑相望，雞狗之音相聞，罔罟之所布，耒耨之所刺，方二千餘里。
passages.en: Formerly, in the state of Qi, the neighbouring towns could see one another; their cocks and dogs never ceased to answer the crowing and barking of other cocks and dogs (between them). The nets were set (in the water and on the land); and the ploughs and hoes were employed over more than a space of two thousand li square.

passages.zh: 闔四竟之內，所以立宗廟社稷，治邑、屋、州、閭、鄉曲者，曷嘗不法聖人哉！
passages.en: All within its four boundaries, the establishment of the ancestral temples and of the altars of the land and grain, and the ordering of the hamlets and houses, and of every corner in the districts, large, medium, and small, were in all particulars according to the rules of the sages.

passages.zh: 然而田成子一旦殺齊君而盜其國。
passages.en: So it was; but yet one morning, Tian Cheng-zi killed the ruler of Qi, and stole his state.

passages.zh: 所盜者豈獨其國邪？
passages.en: And was it only the state that he stole?

passages.zh: 並與其聖知之法而盜之。
passages.en: Along with it he stole also the regulations of the sages and wise men (observed in it).

passages.zh: 故田成子有乎盜賊之名，而身處堯、舜之安，小國不敢非，大國不敢誅，十二世有齊國。
passages.en: And so, though he got the name of being a thief and a robber, yet he himself continued to live as securely as Yao and Shun had done. Small states did not dare to find fault with him; great states did not dare to take him off; for twelve generations (his descendants) have possessed the state of Qi.

passages.zh: 則是不乃竊齊國，並與其聖知之法，以守其盜賊之身乎？
passages.en: Thus do we not have a case in which not only did (the party) steal the state of Qi, but at the same time the regulations of its sages and wise men, which thereby served to guard the person of him, thief and robber as he was?

passages.zh: 嘗試論之，世俗之所謂至知者，有不為大盜積者乎？
passages.en: Let me try to set forth this subject (still further). Have not there been among those vulgarly styled the wisest, such as have collected (their wealth) for the great chief?

passages.zh: 所謂至聖者，有不為大盜守者乎？
passages.en: And among those styled the most sage such as have guarded it for him?

passages.zh: 何以知其然邪？
passages.en: How do I know that it has been so?

passages.zh: 昔者龍逢斬，比干剖，萇弘胣，子胥靡，故四子之賢而身不免乎戮。
passages.en: Formerly, Long-feng was beheaded; Bi-gan had his heart torn out; Chang Hong was ripped open; and Zi-xu was reduced to pulp (in the Chang). Worthy as those four men were, they did not escape such dreadful deaths.

passages.zh: 故盜跖之徒問於跖曰：「盜亦有道乎？」
passages.en: The followers of the robber Zhi asked him, saying, 'Has the robber also any method or principle (in his proceedings)?'

passages.zh: 跖曰：「何適而無有道邪？」
passages.en: He replied, 'What profession is there which has not its principles?'

passages.zh: 夫妄意室中之藏，聖也；
passages.en: That the robber in his recklessness comes to the conclusion that there are valuable deposits in an apartment shows his sageness;

passages.zh: 入先，勇也；
passages.en: that he is the first to enter it shows his bravery;

passages.zh: 出後，義也；
passages.en: that he is the last to quit it shows his righteousness;

passages.zh: 知可否，知也；
passages.en: that he knows whether (the robbery) may be attempted or not shows his wisdom;

passages.zh: 分均，仁也。
passages.en: and that he makes an equal division of the plunder shows his benevolence.

passages.zh: 五者不備而能成大盜者，天下未之有也。」
passages.en: Without all these five qualities no one in the world has ever attained to become a great robber.

passages.zh: 由是觀之，善人不得聖人之道不立，跖不得聖人之道不行；
passages.en: Looking at the subject in this way, we see that good men do not arise without having the principles of the sages, and that Zhi could not have pursued his course without the same principles.

passages.zh: 天下之善人少而不善人多，則聖人之利天下也少而害天下也多。
passages.en: But the good men in the world are few, and those who are not good are many - it follows that the sages benefit the world in a few instances and injure it in many.

passages.zh: 故曰：「脣竭則齒寒，魯酒薄而邯鄲圍，聖人生而大盜起。」
passages.en: Hence it is that we have the sayings, 'When the lips are gone the teeth are cold;' 'The poor wine of Lu gave occasion to the siege of Han-dan;' 'When sages are born great robbers arise.'

passages.zh: 掊擊聖人，縱舍盜賊，而天下始治矣。
passages.en: Only when you destroy the sages and pardon all the thieves and robbers can the world begin to be ordered.

passages.zh: 夫川竭而谷虛，丘夷而淵實。
passages.en: When the stream is dried, the valley is empty; when the mound is levelled, the deep pool (beside it) is filled up.

passages.zh: 聖人已死，則大盜不起，天下平而無故矣。
passages.en: When the sages have died, the great robbers will not arise; the world would be at peace, and there would be no more troubles.

passages.zh: 聖人不死，大盜不止。
passages.en: While the sagely men have not died, great robbers will not cease to appear.

passages.zh: 雖重聖人而治天下，則是重利盜跖也。
passages.en: The more right that is attached to (the views of) the sagely men for the government of the world, the more advantage will accrue to (such men as) the robber Kih.

passages.zh: 為之斗斛以量之，則並與斗斛而竊之；
passages.en: If we make for men pecks and bushels to measure (their wares), even by means of those pecks and bushels should we be teaching them to steal;

passages.zh: 為之權衡以稱之，則並與權衡而竊之；
passages.en: if we make for them weights and steelyards to weigh (their wares), even by means of those weights and steelyards shall we be teaching them to steal.

passages.zh: 為之符璽以信之，則並與符璽而竊之；
passages.en: If we make for them tallies and seals to secure their good faith, even by means of those tallies and seals shall we be teaching them to steal.

passages.zh: 為之仁義以矯之，則並與仁義而竊之。
passages.en: If we make for them benevolence and righteousness to make their doings correct, even by means of benevolence and righteousness shall we be teaching them to steal.

passages.zh: 何以知其然邪？
passages.en: How do I know that it is so?

passages.zh: 彼竊鉤者誅，竊國者為諸侯，諸侯之門，而仁義存焉，則是非竊仁義聖知邪？
passages.en: Here is one who steals a hook (for his girdle) - he is put to death for it: here is another who steals a state - he becomes its prince. But it is at the gates of the princes that we find benevolence and righteousness (most strongly) professed - is not this stealing benevolence and righteousness, sageness and wisdom?

passages.zh: 故逐於大盜，揭諸侯，竊仁義並斗斛、權衡、符璽之利者，雖有軒冕之賞弗能勸，斧鉞之威弗能禁。
passages.en: Thus they hasten to become great robbers, carry off princedoms, and steal benevolence and righteousness, with all the gains springing from the use of pecks and bushels, weights and steelyards, tallies and seals: even the rewards of carriages and coronets have no power to influence (to a different course), and the terrors of the axe have no power to restrain in such cases.

passages.zh: 此重利盜跖而使不可禁者，是乃聖人之過也。
passages.en: The giving of so great gain to robbers (like) Zhi, and making it impossible to restrain them - this is the error committed by the sages.

passages.zh: 故曰：「魚不可脫於淵，國之利器不可以示人。」
passages.en: In accordance with this it is said, 'Fish should not be taken from (the protection of) the deep waters; the agencies for the profit of a state should not be shown to men.'

passages.zh: 彼聖人者，天下之利器也，非所以明天下也。
passages.en: But those sages (and their teachings) are the agencies for the profit of the world, and should not be exhibited to it.

passages.zh: 故絕聖棄知，大盜乃止；
passages.en: Therefore if an end were put to sageness and wisdom put away, the great robbers would cease to arise.

passages.zh: 擿玉毀珠，小盜不起；
passages.en: If jade were put away and pearls broken to bits, the small thieves would not appear.

passages.zh: 焚符破璽，而民朴鄙；
passages.en: If tallies were burned and seals broken in pieces, the people would become simple and unsophisticated.

passages.zh: 掊斗折衡，而民不爭；
passages.en: If pecks were destroyed and steelyards snapped in two, the people would have no wrangling.

passages.zh: 殫殘天下之聖法，而民始可與論議。
passages.en: If the rules of the sages were entirely set aside in the world, a beginning might be made of reasoning with the people.

passages.zh: 擢亂六律，鑠絕竽瑟，塞瞽曠之耳，而天下始人含其聰矣；
passages.en: If the six musical accords were reduced to a state of utter confusion, organs and lutes all burned, and the ears of the (musicians like the) blind Khwang stopped up, all men would begin to possess and employ their (natural) power of hearing.

passages.zh: 滅文章，散五采，膠離朱之目，而天下始人含其明矣；
passages.en: If elegant ornaments were abolished, the five embellishing colours disused and the eyes of (men like) Li Zhu glued up, all men would begin to possess and employ their (natural) power of vision.

passages.zh: 毀絕鉤繩而棄規矩，攦工倕之指，而天下始人有其巧矣。
passages.en: If the hook and line were destroyed, the compass and square thrown away, and the fingers of men (like) the artful Khui smashed, all men would begin to possess and employ their (natural) skill -

passages.zh: 故曰：「大巧若拙。」
passages.en: as it is said, 'The greatest art is like stupidity.'

passages.zh: 削曾、史之行，鉗楊、墨之口，攘棄仁義，而天下之德始玄同矣。
passages.en: If conduct such as that of Zeng (Shen) and Shi (Qiu) were discarded, the mouths of Yang (Zhu) and Mo (Di) gagged, and benevolence and righteousness seized and thrown aside, the virtue of all men would begin to display its mysterious excellence.

passages.zh: 彼人含其明，則天下不鑠矣；
passages.en: When men possessed and employed their (natural) power of vision, there would be no distortion in the world.

passages.zh: 人含其聰，則天下不累矣；
passages.en: When they possessed and employed their (natural) power of hearing, there would be no distractions in the world.

passages.zh: 人含其知，則天下不惑矣；
passages.en: When they possessed and employed their (natural) faculty of knowledge, there would be no delusions in the world.

passages.zh: 人含其德，則天下不僻矣。
passages.en: When they possessed and employed their (natural) virtue, there would be no depravity in the world.

passages.zh: 彼曾、史、楊、墨、師曠、工倕、離朱，皆外立其德，而以爚亂天下者也，法之所無用也。
passages.en: Men like Zeng (Shen), Shi (Qiu), Yang (Zhu), Mo (Di), Shi Kuang (the musician), the artist Khui, and Li Zhu, all display their qualities outwardly, and set the world in a blaze (of admiration) and confound it - a method which is of no use!

passages.zh: 子獨不知至德之世乎？
passages.en: Are you, Sir, unacquainted with the age of perfect virtue?

passages.zh: 昔者容成氏、大庭氏、伯皇氏、中央氏、栗陸氏、驪畜氏、軒轅氏、赫胥氏、尊盧氏、祝融氏、伏羲氏、神農氏，當是時也，民結繩而用之，甘其食，美其服，樂其俗，安其居，鄰國相望，雞狗之音相聞，民至老死而不相往來。
passages.en: Anciently there were Rong-cheng, Da-ting, Bo-huang, Zhong-yang, Li-lu, Li-Chu, Xian-yuan, He-xu, Zun-lu, Zhu-rong, Fu-xi, and Shen-nong. In their times the people made knots on cords in carrying on their affairs. They thought their (simple) food pleasant, and their (plain) clothing beautiful. They were happy in their (simple) manners, and felt at rest in their (poor) dwellings. (The people of) neighbouring states might be able to descry one another; the voices of their cocks and dogs might be heard (all the way) from one to the other; they might not die till they were old; and yet all their life they would have no communication together.

passages.zh: 若此之時，則至治已。
passages.en: In those times perfect good order prevailed.

passages.zh: 今遂至使民延頸舉踵曰「某所有賢者」，贏糧而趣之，則內棄其親而外去其主之事，足跡接乎諸侯之境，車軌結乎千里之外，則是上好知之過也。
passages.en: Now-a-days, however, such is the state of things that you shall see the people stretching out their necks, and standing on tiptoe, while they say, 'In such and such a place there is a wise and able man.' Then they carry with them whatever dry provisions they may have left, and hurry towards it, abandoning their parents in their homes, and neglecting the service of their rulers abroad. Their footsteps may be traced in lines from one state to another, and the ruts of their chariot-wheels also for more than a thousand li. This is owing to the error of their superiors in their (inordinate) fondness for knowledge.

passages.zh: 上誠好知而無道，則天下大亂矣。
passages.en: When those superiors do really love knowledge, but do not follow the (proper) course, the whole world is thrown into great confusion.

passages.zh: 何以知其然邪？
passages.en: How do I know that the case is so?

passages.zh: 夫弓、弩、畢、弋、機變之知多，則鳥亂於上矣；
passages.en: The knowledge shown in the (making of) bows, cross-bows, band-nets, stringed arrows, and contrivances with springs is great, but the birds are troubled by them above;

passages.zh: 鉤餌、罔、罟罾笱之知多，則魚亂於水矣；
passages.en: the knowledge shown in the hooks, baits, various kinds of nets, and bamboo traps is great, but the fishes are disturbed by them in the waters;

passages.zh: 削格、羅落、罝罘之知多，則獸亂於澤矣；
passages.en: the knowledge shown in the arrangements for setting nets, and the nets and snares themselves, is great, but the animals are disturbed by them in the marshy grounds.

passages.zh: 知詐漸毒、頡滑堅白、解垢同異之變多，則俗惑於辯矣。
passages.en: (So), the versatility shown in artful deceptions becoming more and more pernicious, in ingenious discussions as to what is hard and what is white, and in attempts to disperse the dust and reconcile different views, is great, but the common people are perplexed by all the sophistry.

passages.zh: 故天下每每大亂，罪在於好知。
passages.en: Hence there is great disorder continually in the world, and the guilt of it is due to that fondness for knowledge.

passages.zh: 故天下皆知求其所不知而莫知求其所已知者，皆知非其所不善而莫知非其所已善者，是以大亂。
passages.en: Thus it is that all men know to seek for the knowledge that they have not attained to; and do not know to seek for that which they already have (in themselves); and that they know to condemn what they do not approve (in others), and do not know to condemn what they have allowed in themselves - it is this which occasions the great confusion and disorder.

passages.zh: 故上悖日月之明，下爍山川之精，中墮四時之施，惴耎之蟲，肖翹之物，莫不失其性。
passages.en: It is just as if, above, the brightness of the sun and moon were darkened; as if, beneath, the productive vigour of the hills and streams were dried up; and as if, between, the operation of the four seasons were brought to an end: in which case there would not be a single weak and wriggling insect, nor any plant that grows up, which would not lose its proper nature.

passages.zh: 甚矣夫好知之亂天下也！
passages.en: Great indeed is the disorder produced in the world by the love of knowledge.

passages.zh: 自三代以下者是已。
passages.en: From the time of the three dynasties downwards it has been so.

passages.zh: 舍夫種種之民而悅夫役役之佞，釋夫恬淡無為而悅夫啍啍之意，啍啍已亂天下矣。
passages.en: The plain and honest-minded people are neglected, and the plausible representations of restless spirits received with pleasure; the quiet and unexciting method of non-action is put away, and pleasure taken in ideas garrulously expressed. It is this garrulity of speech which puts the world in disorder.

passages.zh: 聞在宥天下，不聞治天下也。
passages.en: I have heard of letting the world be, and exercising forbearance; I have not heard of governing the world.

passages.zh: 在之也者，恐天下之淫其性也；
passages.en: Letting be is from the fear that men, (when interfered with), will carry their nature beyond its normal condition;

passages.zh: 宥之也者，恐天下之遷其德也。
passages.en: exercising forbearance is from the fear that men, (when not so dealt with), will alter the characteristics of their nature.

passages.zh: 天下不淫其性，不遷其德，有治天下者哉！
passages.en: When all men do not carry their nature beyond its normal condition, nor alter its characteristics, the good government of the world is secured.

passages.zh: 昔堯之治天下也，使天下欣欣焉人樂其性，是不恬也；
passages.en: Formerly, Yao's government of the world made men look joyful; but when they have this joy in their nature, there is a want of its (proper) placidity.

passages.zh: 桀之治天下也，使天下瘁瘁焉人苦其性，是不愉也。
passages.en: The government of the world by Jie, (on the contrary), made men look distressed; but when their nature shows the symptoms of distress, there is a want of its (proper) contentment.

passages.zh: 夫不恬不愉，非德也。
passages.en: The want of placidity and the want of contentment are contrary to the character (of the nature);

passages.zh: 非德也而可長久者，天下無之。
passages.en: and where this obtains, it is impossible that any man or state should anywhere abide long.

passages.zh: 人大喜邪，毗於陽。
passages.en: Are men exceedingly joyful? The Yang or element of expansion in them is too much developed.

passages.zh: 大怒邪，毗於陰。
passages.en: Are they exceedingly irritated? The Yin or opposite element is too much developed.

passages.zh: 陰陽並毗，四時不至，寒暑之和不成，其反傷人之形乎！
passages.en: When those elements thus predominate in men, (it is as if) the four seasons were not to come (at their proper times), and the harmony of cold and heat were not to be maintained - would there not result injury to the bodies of men?

passages.zh: 使人喜怒失位，居處無常，思慮不自得，中道不成章，於是乎天下始喬詰、卓鷙，而後有盜跖、曾、史之行。
passages.en: Men's joy and dissatisfaction are made to arise where they ought not to do so; their movements are all uncertain; they lose the mastery of their thoughts; they stop short midway, and do not finish what they have begun. In this state of things the world begins to have lofty aims, and jealous dislikes, ambitious courses, and fierce animosities, and then we have actions like those of the robber Zhi, or of Zeng (Shen) and Shi (Qiu).

passages.zh: 故舉天下以賞其善者不足，舉天下以罰其惡者不給，故天下之大不足以賞罰。
passages.en: If now the whole world were taken to reward the good it would not suffice, nor would it be possible with it to punish the bad. Thus the world, great as it is, not sufficing for rewards and punishments,

passages.zh: 自三代以下者，匈匈焉終以賞罰為事，彼何暇安其性命之情哉！
passages.en: from the time of the three dynasties downwards, there has been nothing but bustle and excitement. Always occupied with rewards and punishments, what leisure have men had to rest in the instincts of the nature with which they are endowed?

passages.zh: 而且說明邪，是淫於色也；
passages.en: Moreover, delight in the power of vision leads to excess in the pursuit of (ornamental) colours;

passages.zh: 說聰邪，是淫於聲也；
passages.en: delight in the power of hearing, to excess in seeking (the pleasures of) sound;

passages.zh: 說仁邪，是亂於德也；
passages.en: delight in benevolence tends to disorder that virtue (as proper to the nature);

passages.zh: 說義邪，是悖於理也；
passages.en: delight in righteousness sets the man in opposition to what is right in reason;

passages.zh: 說禮邪，是相於技也；
passages.en: delight in (the practice of) ceremonies is helpful to artful forms;

passages.zh: 說樂邪，是相於淫也；
passages.en: delight in music leads to voluptuous airs;

passages.zh: 說聖邪，是相於藝也；
passages.en: delight in sageness is helpful to ingenious contrivances;

passages.zh: 說知邪，是相於疵也。
passages.en: delight in knowledge contributes to fault-finding.

passages.zh: 天下將安其性命之情，之八者，存可也；亡可也；
passages.en: If all men were to rest in the instincts of their nature, to keep or to extinguish these eight delights might be a matter of indifference;

passages.zh: 天下將不安其性命之情，之八者，乃始臠卷、獊囊而亂天下也。
passages.en: but if they will not rest in those instincts, then those eight delights begin to be imperfectly and unevenly developed or violently suppressed, and the world is thrown into disorder.

passages.zh: 而天下乃始尊之惜之，甚矣天下之惑也！
passages.en: But when men begin to honour them, and to long for them, how great is the deception practised on the world!

passages.zh: 豈直過也而去之邪！
passages.en: And not only, when (a performance of them) is once over, do they not have done with them,

passages.zh: 乃齊戒以言之，跪坐以進之，鼓歌以儛之，吾若是何哉！
passages.en: but they prepare themselves (as) with fasting to describe them, they seem to kneel reverentially when they bring them forward, and they go through them with the excitements of music and singing; and then what can be done (to remedy the evil of them)?

passages.zh: 故君子不得已而臨邪天下，莫若無為。
passages.en: Therefore the superior man, who feels himself constrained to engage in the administration of the world will find it his best way to do nothing.

passages.zh: 無為也，而後安其性命之情。
passages.en: In (that policy of) doing nothing, he can rest in the instincts of the nature with which he is endowed.

passages.zh: 故貴以身於為天下，則可以託天下；
passages.en: Hence he who will administer (the government of) the world honouring it as he honours his own person, may have that government committed to him,

passages.zh: 愛以身於為天下，則可以寄天下。
passages.en: and he who will administer it loving it as he loves his own person, may have it entrusted to him.

passages.zh: 故君子苟能無解其五藏，無擢其聰明，尸居而龍見，淵默而雷聲，神動而天隨，從容無為而萬物炊累焉。
passages.en: Therefore, if the superior man will keep (the faculties lodged in) his five viscera unemployed, and not display his powers of seeing and hearing, while he is motionless as a representative of the dead, his dragon-like presence will be seen; while he is profoundly silent, the thunder (of his words) will resound; while his movements are (unseen) like those of a spirit, all heavenly influences will follow them; while he is (thus) unconcerned and does nothing, his genial influence will attract and gather all things round him:

passages.zh: 吾又何暇治天下哉！
passages.en: what leisure has he to do anything more for the government of the world?

passages.zh: 崔瞿問於老聃曰：「不治天下，安藏人心？」
passages.en: Cui Ji asked Lao Dan, saying, 'If you do not govern the world, how can you make men's minds good?'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「汝慎無攖人心。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Take care how you meddle with and disturb men's minds.

passages.zh: 人心排下而進上，上下囚殺，淖約柔乎剛強。
passages.en: The mind, if pushed about, gets depressed; if helped forward, it gets exalted. Now exalted, now depressed, here it appears as a prisoner, and there as a wrathful fury.

passages.zh: 廉劌彫琢，其熱焦火，其寒凝冰。
passages.en: (At one time) it becomes pliable and soft, yielding to what is hard and strong; (at another), it is sharp as the sharpest corner, fit to carve or chisel (stone or jade). Now it is hot as a scorching fire, and anon it is cold as ice.

passages.zh: 其疾俛仰之間，而再撫四海之外，其居也淵而靜，其動也縣而天。
passages.en: It is so swift that while one is bending down and lifting up his head, it shall twice have put forth a soothing hand beyond the four seas. Resting, it is still as a deep abyss; moving, it is like one of the bodies in the sky;

passages.zh: 僨驕而不可係者，其唯人心乎！
passages.en: in its resolute haughtiness, it refuses to be bound - such is the mind of man!

passages.zh: 昔者黃帝始以仁義攖人之心，堯、舜於是乎股無胈，脛無毛，以養天下之形，愁其五藏以為仁義，矜其血氣以規法度。
passages.en: Anciently, Huang-Di was the first to meddle with and disturb the mind of man with his benevolence and righteousness. After him, Yao and Shun wore their thighs bare and the hair off the calves of their legs, in their labours to nourish the bodies of the people. They toiled painfully with all the powers in their five viscera at the practice of their benevolence and righteousness; they tasked their blood and breath to make out a code of laws -

passages.zh: 然猶有不勝也。
passages.en: and after all they were unsuccessful.

passages.zh: 堯於是放讙兜於崇山，投三苗於三峗，流共工於幽都，此不勝天下也夫！
passages.en: On this Yao sent away Huan Dou to Chong hill, and (the Chiefs of) the Three Miao to San-wei, and banished the Minister of Works to the Dark Capital; so unequal had they been to cope with the world.

passages.zh: 施及三王而天下大駭矣。
passages.en: Then we are carried on to the kings of the Three (dynasties), when the world was in a state of great distraction.

passages.zh: 下有桀、跖，上有曾、史，而儒、墨畢起。
passages.en: Of the lowest type of character there were Jie and Zhi; of a higher type there were Zeng (Shen) and Shi (Qiu). At the same time there arose the classes of the Literati and the Mohists.

passages.zh: 於是乎喜怒相疑，愚知相欺，善否相非，誕信相譏，而天下衰矣；
passages.en: Hereupon, complacency in, and hatred of, one another produced mutual suspicions; the stupid and the wise imposed on one another; the good and the bad condemned one another; the boastful and the sincere interchanged their recriminations - and the world fell into decay.

passages.zh: 大德不同，而性命爛漫矣；
passages.en: Views as to what was greatly virtuous did not agree, and the nature with its endowments became as if shrivelled by fire or carried away by a flood.

passages.zh: 天下好知，而百姓求竭矣。
passages.en: All were eager for knowledge, and the people were exhausted with their searchings (after what was good).

passages.zh: 於是乎釿鋸制焉，繩墨殺焉，椎鑿決焉。
passages.en: On this the axe and the saw were brought into play; guilt was determined as by the plumb-line and death inflicted; the hammer and gouge did their work.

passages.zh: 天下脊脊大亂，罪在攖人心。
passages.en: The world fell into great disorder, and presented the appearance of a jagged mountain ridge. The crime to which all was due was the meddling with and disturbing men's minds.

passages.zh: 故賢者伏處大山嵁巖之下，而萬乘之君憂慄乎廟堂之上。
passages.en: The effect was that men of ability and worth lay concealed at the foot of the crags of mount Tai, and princes of ten thousand chariots were anxious and terrified in their ancestral temples.

passages.zh: 今世殊死者相枕也，桁楊者相推也，刑戮者相望也，而儒、墨乃始離跂攘臂乎桎梏之間。
passages.en: In the present age those who have been put to death in various ways lie thick as if pillowed on each other; those who are wearing the cangue press on each other (on the roads); those who are suffering the bastinado can see each other (all over the land). And now the Literati and the Mohists begin to stand, on tiptoe and with bare arms, among the fettered and manacled crowd!

passages.zh: 意！甚矣哉！其無愧而不知恥也甚矣！
passages.en: Ah! extreme is their shamelessness, and their failure to see the disgrace!

passages.zh: 吾未知聖知之不為桁楊椄槢也，仁義之不為桎梏、鑿枘也，焉知曾、史之不為桀、跖嚆矢也！
passages.en: Strange that we should be slow to recognise their sageness and wisdom in the bars of the cangue, and their benevolence and righteousness in the rivets of the fetters and handcuffs! How do we know that Zeng and Shi are not the whizzing arrows of Jie and Zhi?

passages.zh: 故曰：『絕聖棄知而天下大治。』」
passages.en: Therefore it is said, 'Abolish sageness and cast away knowledge, and the world will be brought to a state of great order.'

passages.zh: 黃帝立為天子十九年，令行天下，聞廣成子在於空同之上，故往見之，曰：「我聞吾子達於至道，敢問至道之精。
passages.en: Huang-Di had been on the throne for nineteen years, and his ordinances were in operation all through the kingdom, when he heard that Guang Cheng-zi was living on the summit of Kong-tong, and went to see him. 'I have heard,' he said, 'that you, Sir, are well acquainted with the perfect Dao. I venture to ask you what is the essential thing in it.

passages.zh: 吾欲取天地之精，以佐五穀，以養民人；
passages.en: I wish to take the subtlest influences of heaven and earth, and assist with them the (growth of the) five cereals for the (better) nourishment of the people.

passages.zh: 吾又欲官陰陽，以遂群生。
passages.en: I also wish to direct the (operation of the) Yin and Yang, so as to secure the comfort of all living beings.

passages.zh: 為之奈何？」
passages.en: How shall I proceed to accomplish those objects?'

passages.zh: 廣成子曰：「而所欲問者，物之質也；而所欲官者，物之殘也。
passages.en: Kong Tong-zi replied, 'What you wish to ask about is the original substance of all things; what you wish to have the direction of is that substance as it was shattered and divided.

passages.zh: 自而治天下，雲氣不待族而雨，草木不待黃而落，日月之光益以荒矣。
passages.en: According to your government of the world, the vapours of the clouds, before they were collected, would descend in rain; the herbs and trees would shed their leaves before they became yellow; and the light of the sun and moon would hasten to extinction.

passages.zh: 而佞人之心翦翦者，又奚足以語至道！」
passages.en: Your mind is that of a flatterer with his plausible words - it is not fit that I should tell you the perfect Dao.'

passages.zh: 黃帝退，捐天下，築特室，席白茅，閒居三月，復往邀之。
passages.en: Huang-Di withdrew, gave up (his government of) the kingdom, built himself a solitary apartment, spread in it a mat of the white mao grass, dwelt in it unoccupied for three months, and then went again to seek an interview with (the recluse).

passages.zh: 廣成子南首而臥，黃帝順下風膝行而進，再拜稽首而問曰：「聞吾子達於至道，敢問治身奈何而可以長久？」
passages.en: Kong Tong-zi was then lying down with his head to the south. Huang-Di, with an air of deferential submission, went forward on his knees, twice bowed low with his face to the ground, and asked him, saying, 'I have heard that you, Sir, are well acquainted with the perfect Dao - I venture to ask how I should rule my body, in order that it may continue for a long time.'

passages.zh: 廣成子蹶然而起，曰：「善哉問乎！
passages.en: Kong Tong-zi hastily rose, and said, 'A good question!

passages.zh: 來！吾語女至道。
passages.en: Come and I will tell you the perfect Dao.

passages.zh: 至道之精，窈窈冥冥；至道之極，昏昏默默。
passages.en: Its essence is (surrounded with) the deepest obscurity; its highest reach is in darkness and silence.

passages.zh: 無視無聽，抱神以靜，形將自正。
passages.en: There is nothing to be seen; nothing to be heard. When it holds the spirit in its arms in stillness, then the bodily form of itself will become correct.

passages.zh: 必靜必清，無勞女形，無搖女精，乃可以長生。
passages.en: You must be still; you must be pure; not subjecting your body to toil, not agitating your vital force - then you may live for long.

passages.zh: 目無所見，耳無所聞，心無所知，女神將守形，形乃長生。
passages.en: When your eyes see nothing, your ears hear nothing, and your mind knows nothing, your spirit will keep your body, and the body will live long.

passages.zh: 慎女內，閉女外，多知為敗。
passages.en: Watch over what is within you, shut up the avenues that connect you with what is external - much knowledge is pernicious.

passages.zh: 我為女遂於大明之上矣，至彼至陽之原也；為女入於窈冥之門矣，至彼至陰之原也。
passages.en: I (will) proceed with you to the summit of the Grand Brilliance, where we come to the source of the bright and expanding (element); I will enter with you the gate of the Deepest Obscurity, where we come to the source of the dark and repressing (element).

passages.zh: 天地有官，陰陽有藏，慎守女身，物將自壯。
passages.en: There heaven and earth have their controllers; there the Yin and Yang have their Repositories. Watch over and keep your body, and all things will of themselves give it vigour.

passages.zh: 我守其一，以處其和，故我修身千二百歲矣，吾形未嘗衰。」
passages.en: I maintain the (original) unity (of these elements), and dwell in the harmony of them. In this way I have cultivated myself for one thousand and two hundred years, and my bodily form has undergone no decay.'

passages.zh: 黃帝再拜稽首曰：「廣成子之謂天矣！」
passages.en: Huang-Di twice bowed low with his head to the ground, and said, 'In Kong Tong-zi we have an example of what is called Heaven.'

passages.zh: 廣成子曰：「來！吾語女。
passages.en: The other said, 'Come, and I will tell you:

passages.zh: 彼其物無窮，而人皆以為有終；彼其物無測，而人皆以為有極。
passages.en: (The perfect Dao) is something inexhaustible, and yet men all think it has an end; it is something unfathomable, and yet men all think its extreme limit can be reached.

passages.zh: 得吾道者，上為皇而下為王；失吾道者，上見光而下為土。
passages.en: He who attains to my Dao, if he be in a high position, will be one of the August ones, and in a low position, will be a king. He who fails in attaining it, in his highest attainment will see the light, but will descend and be of the Earth.

passages.zh: 今夫百昌，皆生於土而反於土，故余將去女，入無窮之門，以遊無極之野。
passages.en: At present all things are produced from the Earth and return to the Earth. Therefore I will leave you, and enter the gate of the Unending, to enjoy myself in the fields of the Illimitable.

passages.zh: 吾與日月參光，吾與天地為常。
passages.en: I will blend my light with that of the sun and moon, and will endure while heaven and earth endure.

passages.zh: 當我，緡乎！遠我，昏乎！人其盡死，而我獨存乎！」
passages.en: If men agree with my views, I will be unconscious of it; if they keep far apart from them, I will be unconscious of it; they may all die, and I will abide alone!'

passages.zh: 雲將東遊，過扶搖之枝，而適遭鴻蒙。
passages.en: Yun Jiang, rambling to the east, having been borne along on a gentle breeze, suddenly encountered Hong Mang, who was rambling about, slapping his buttocks and hopping like a bird.

passages.zh: 鴻蒙方將拊髀雀躍而遊。
passages.en: Amazed at the sight, Yun Jiang stood reverentially,

passages.zh: 雲將見之，倘然止，贄然立，曰：「叟何人邪？叟何為此？」
passages.en: and said to the other, 'Venerable Sir, who are you? and why are you doing this?'

passages.zh: 鴻蒙拊髀雀躍不輟，對雲將曰：「遊。」
passages.en: Hong Mang went on slapping his buttocks and hopping like a bird, but replied, 'I am enjoying myself.'

passages.zh: 雲將曰：「朕願有問也。」
passages.en: Yun Jiang said, 'I wish to ask you a question.'

passages.zh: 鴻蒙仰而視雲將曰：「吁！」
passages.en: Hong Mang lifted up his head, looked at the stranger, and said, 'Pooh!'

passages.zh: 雲將曰：「天氣不合，地氣鬱結，六氣不調，四時不節。
passages.en: Yun Jiang, however, continued, 'The breath of heaven is out of harmony; the breath of earth is bound up; the six elemental influences do not act in concord; the four seasons do not observe their proper times.

passages.zh: 今我願合六氣之精，以育群生，為之奈何？」
passages.en: Now I wish to blend together the essential qualities of those six influences in order to nourish all living things - how shall I go about it?'

passages.zh: 鴻蒙拊髀雀躍掉頭曰：「吾弗知，吾弗知。」
passages.en: Hong Mang slapped his buttocks, hopped about, and shook his head, saying, 'I do not know; I do not know!'

passages.zh: 雲將不得問。
passages.en: Yun Jiang could not pursue his question;

passages.zh: 又三年，東遊，過有宋之野，而適遭鴻蒙。
passages.en: but three years afterwards, when (again) rambling in the east, as he was passing by the wild of Sung, he happened to meet Hong Mang.

passages.zh: 雲將大喜，行趨而進曰：「天忘朕邪？天忘朕邪？」
passages.en: Delighted with the rencontre, he hastened to him, and said, 'Have you forgotten me, O Heaven? Have you forgotten me, O Heaven?'

passages.zh: 再拜稽首，願聞於鴻蒙。
passages.en: At the same time, he bowed twice with his head to the ground, wishing to receive his instructions.

passages.zh: 鴻蒙曰：「浮游不知所求，猖狂不知所往，遊者鞅掌，以觀無妄，朕又何知！」
passages.en: Hong Mang said, 'Wandering listlessly about, I know not what I seek; carried on by a wild impulse, I know not where I am going. I wander about in the strange manner (which you have seen), and see that nothing proceeds without method and order - what more should I know?'

passages.zh: 雲將曰：「朕也自以為猖狂，而百姓隨予所往；朕也不得已於民，今則民之放也。願聞一言。」
passages.en: Yun Jiang replied, 'I also seem carried on by an aimless influence, and yet the people follow me wherever I go. I cannot help their doing so. But now as they thus imitate me, I wish to hear a word from you (in the case).'

passages.zh: 鴻蒙曰：「亂天之經，逆物之情，玄天弗成；解獸之群，而鳥皆夜鳴；災及草木，禍及止蟲。意！治人之過也！」
passages.en: The other said, 'What disturbs the regular method of Heaven, comes into collision with the nature of things, prevents the accomplishment of the mysterious (operation of) Heaven, scatters the herds of animals, makes the birds all sing at night, is calamitous to vegetation, and disastrous to all insects - all this is owing, I conceive, to the error of governing men.'

passages.zh: 雲將曰：「然則吾奈何？」
passages.en: 'What then,' said Yun Jiang, 'shall I do?'

passages.zh: 鴻蒙曰：「意！毒哉！僊僊乎歸矣！」
passages.en: 'Ah,' said the other, 'you will only injure them! I will leave you in my dancing way, and return to my place.'

passages.zh: 雲將曰：「吾遇天難，願聞一言。」
passages.en: Yun Jiang rejoined, 'It has been a difficult thing to get this meeting with you, O Heaven! I should like to hear from you a word (more).'

passages.zh: 鴻蒙曰：「意！心養。
passages.en: Hong Mang said, 'Ah! your mind (needs to be) nourished.

passages.zh: 汝徒處無為，而物自化。
passages.en: Do you only take the position of doing nothing, and things will of themselves become transformed.

passages.zh: 墮爾形體，吐爾聰明；倫與物忘，大同乎涬溟；解心釋神，莫然無魂。
passages.en: Neglect your body; cast out from you your power of hearing and sight; forget what you have in common with things; cultivate a grand similarity with the chaos of the plastic ether; unloose your mind; set your spirit free; be still as if you had no soul.

passages.zh: 萬物云云，各復其根，各復其根而不知。
passages.en: Of all the multitude of things every one returns to its root. Every one returns to its root, and does not know (that it is doing so).

passages.zh: 渾渾沌沌，終身不離；若彼知之，乃是離之。
passages.en: They all are as in the state of chaos, and during all their existence they do not leave it. If they knew (that they were returning to their root), they would be (consciously) leaving it.

passages.zh: 無問其名，無闚其情，物故自生。」
passages.en: They do not ask its name; they do not seek to spy out their nature; and thus it is that things come to life of themselves.'

passages.zh: 雲將曰：「天降朕以德，示朕以默，躬身求之，乃今也得。」
passages.en: Yun Jiang said, 'Heaven, you have conferred on me (the knowledge of) your operation, and revealed to me the mystery of it. All my life I had been seeking for it, and now I have obtained it.'

passages.zh: 再拜稽首，起辭而行。
passages.en: He then bowed twice, with his head to the ground, arose, took his leave, and walked away.

passages.zh: 世俗之人，皆喜人之同乎己，而惡人之異於己也。
passages.en: The ordinary men of the world all rejoice in men's agreeing with themselves, and dislike men's being different from themselves.

passages.zh: 同於己而欲之、異於己而不欲者，以出乎眾為心也。
passages.en: This rejoicing and this dislike arise from their being bent on making themselves distinguished above all others.

passages.zh: 夫以出於眾為心者，曷嘗出乎眾哉！
passages.en: But have they who have this object at heart so risen out above all others?

passages.zh: 因眾以寧所聞，不如眾技眾矣。
passages.en: They depend on them to rest quietly (in the position which they desire), and their knowledge is not equal to the multitude of the arts of all those others!

passages.zh: 而欲為人之國者，此攬乎三王之利，而不見其患者也。
passages.en: When they wish again to administer a state for its ruler, they proceed to employ all the methods which the kings of the three dynasties considered profitable without seeing the evils of such a course.

passages.zh: 此以人之國僥倖也，幾何僥倖而不喪人之國乎！
passages.en: This is to make the state depend on the peradventure of their luck. But how seldom it is that that peradventure does not issue in the ruin of the state!

passages.zh: 其存人之國也，無萬分之一；而喪人之國也，一不成而萬有餘喪矣。
passages.en: Not once in ten thousand instances will such men preserve a state. Not once will they succeed, and in more than ten thousand cases will they ruin it.

passages.zh: 悲夫！有土者之不知也！
passages.en: Alas that the possessors of territory (the rulers of states) should not know the danger (of employing such men)!

passages.zh: 夫有土者，有大物也。
passages.en: Now the possessors of territory possess the greatest of (all) things.

passages.zh: 有大物者，不可以物物；而不物，故能物物。
passages.en: Possessing the greatest of all things (possessing, that is, men) they should not try to deal with them as (simply) things. And it is he who is not a thing (himself) that is therefore able to deal with (all) things as they severally require.

passages.zh: 明乎物物者之非物也，豈獨治天下百姓而已哉！
passages.en: When (a ruler) clearly understands that he who should so deal with all things is not a thing himself, will he only rule the kingdom?

passages.zh: 出入六合，遊乎九州，獨往獨來，是謂獨有。
passages.en: He will go out and in throughout the universe (at his pleasure); he will roam over the nine regions, alone in going, alone in coming.

passages.zh: 獨有之人，是謂至貴。
passages.en: Him we call the sole possessor (of this ability); and the sole possessor (of this ability) is what is called the noblest of all.

passages.zh: 大人之教，若形之於影，聲之於響。
passages.en: The teaching of (this) great man goes forth as the shadow from the substance, as the echo responds to the sound.

passages.zh: 有問而應之，盡其所懷，為天下配。
passages.en: When questioned, he responds, exhausting (from his own stores) all that is in the (enquirer's) mind, as if front to front with all under heaven.

passages.zh: 處乎無響，行乎無方。
passages.en: His resting-place gives forth no sound; his sphere of activity has no restriction of place.

passages.zh: 挈汝適復之撓撓，以遊無端，出入無旁，與日無始，頌論形軀，合乎大同，大同而無己。
passages.en: He conducts every one to his proper goal, proceeding to it and bringing him back to it as by his own movement. His movements have no trace; his going forth and his re-enterings have no deviation; his course is like that of the sun without beginning (or ending). If you would praise or discourse about his personality, he is united with the great community of existences. He belongs to that great community, and has no individual self.

passages.zh: 無己，惡乎得有有！
passages.en: Having no individual self, how should he have anything that can be called his?

passages.zh: 睹有者，昔之君子；睹無者，天地之友。
passages.en: If you look at those who have what they call their own, they are the superior men of former times; if you look at him who has nothing of the kind, he is the friend of heaven and earth.

passages.zh: 賤而不可不任者，物也；卑而不可不因者，民也；匿而不可不為者，事也；麤而不可不陳者，法也；遠而不可不居者，義也；親而不可不廣者，仁也；節而不可不積者，禮也；中而不可不高者，德也；一而不可不易者，道也；神而不可不為者，天也。
passages.en: Mean, and yet demanding to be allowed their free course - such are Things. Low, and yet requiring to be relied on - such are the People. Hidden (as to their issues), and yet requiring to be done - such are Affairs. Coarse, and yet necessary to be set forth - such are Laws. Remote, and yet necessary to have dwelling (in one's self) - such is Righteousness. Near, and yet necessary to be widely extended - such is Benevolence. Restrictive, and yet necessary to be multiplied - such are Ceremonies. Lodged in the centre, and yet requiring to be exalted - such is Virtue. Always One, and yet requiring to be modified - such is the Dao. Spiritlike, and yet requiring to be exercised - such is Heaven.

passages.zh: 故聖人觀於天而不助，成於德而不累，出於道而不謀，會於仁而不恃，薄於義而不積，應於禮而不諱，接於事而不辭，齊於法而不亂，恃於民而不輕，因於物而不去。
passages.en: Therefore the sages contemplated Heaven, but did not assist It. They tried to perfect their virtue, but did not allow it to embarrass them. They proceeded according to the Dao, but did not lay any plans. They associated benevolence (with all their doings), but did not rely on it. They pursued righteousness extensively, but did not try to accumulate it. They responded to ceremonies, but did not conceal (their opinion as to the troublesomeness of them). They engaged in affairs as they occurred, and did not decline them. They strove to render their laws uniform, but (feared that confusion) might arise from them. They relied upon the people, and did not set light by them. They depended on things as their instruments, and did not discard them.

passages.zh: 物者莫足為也，而不可不為。
passages.en: They did not think things equal to what they employed them for, but yet they did not see that they could do without employing them.

passages.zh: 不明於天者，不純於德；不通於道者，無自而可。
passages.en: Those who do not understand Heaven are not pure in their virtue. Those who do not comprehend the Dao have no course which they can pursue successfully.

passages.zh: 不明於道者，悲夫！
passages.en: Alas for them who do not clearly understand the Dao!

passages.zh: 何謂道？
passages.en: What is it that we call the Dao?

passages.zh: 有天道，有人道。
passages.en: There is the Dao, or Way of Heaven; and there is the Dao, or Way of Man.

passages.zh: 無為而尊者，天道也；有為而累者，人道也。
passages.en: Doing nothing and yet attracting all honour is the Way of Heaven; Doing and being embarrassed thereby is the Way of Man.

passages.zh: 主者，天道也；臣者，人道也。
passages.en: It is the Way of Heaven that plays the part of the Lord; it is the Way of Man that plays the part of the Servant.

passages.zh: 天道之與人道也，相去遠矣，不可不察也。
passages.en: The Way of Heaven and the Way of Man are far apart. They should be clearly distinguished from each other.

passages.zh: 天地雖大，其化均也；萬物雖多，其治一也；人卒雖眾，其主君也。
passages.en: Notwithstanding the greatness of heaven and earth, their transforming power proceeds from one lathe; notwithstanding the number of the myriad things, the government of them is one and the same; notwithstanding the multitude of mankind, the lord of them is their (one) ruler.

passages.zh: 君原於德而成於天，故曰：玄古之君天下，無為也，天德而已矣。
passages.en: The ruler's (course) should proceed from the qualities (of the Dao) and be perfected by Heaven, when it is so, it is called 'Mysterious and Sublime.' The ancients ruled the world by doing nothing - simply by this attribute of Heaven.

passages.zh: 以道觀言而天下之君正，以道觀分而君臣之義明，以道觀能而天下之官治，以道汎觀而萬物之應備。
passages.en: If we look at their words in the light of the Dao, (we see that) the appellation for the ruler of the world was correctly assigned; if we look in the same light at the distinctions which they instituted, (we see that) the separation of ruler and ministers was right; if we look at the abilities which they called forth in the same light, (we see that the duties of) all the offices were well performed; and if we look generally in the same way at all things, (we see that) their response (to this rule) was complete.

passages.zh: 故通於天地者，德也；行於萬物者，道也；上治人者，事也；能有所藝者，技也。
passages.en: Therefore that which pervades (the action of) Heaven and Earth is (this one) attribute; that which operates in all things is (this one) course; that by which their superiors govern the people is the business (of the various departments); and that by which aptitude is given to ability is skill.

passages.zh: 技兼於事，事兼於義，義兼於德，德兼於道，道兼於天。
passages.en: The skill was manifested in all the (departments of) business; those departments were all administered in righteousness; the righteousness was (the outflow of) the natural virtue; the virtue was manifested according to the Dao; and the Dao was according to (the pattern of) Heaven.

passages.zh: 故曰：「古之畜天下者，無欲而天下足，無為而萬物化，淵靜而百姓定。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'The ancients who had the nourishment of the world wished for nothing and the world had enough; they did nothing and all things were transformed; their stillness was abysmal, and the people were all composed.'

passages.zh: 記曰：「通於一而萬事畢，無心得而鬼神服。」
passages.en: The Record says, 'When the one (Dao) pervades it, all business is completed. When the mind gets to be free from all aim, even the Spirits submit.'

passages.zh: 夫子曰：「夫道，覆載萬物者也，洋洋乎大哉！
passages.en: The Master said, 'It is the Dao that overspreads and sustains all things. How great It is in Its overflowing influence!

passages.zh: 君子不可以不刳心焉。
passages.en: The Superior man ought by all means to remove from his mind (all that is contrary to It).

passages.zh: 無為為之之謂天，無為言之之謂德，愛人利物之謂仁，不同同之之謂大，行不崖異之謂寬，有萬不同之謂富。
passages.en: Acting without action is what is called Heaven(-like). Speech coming forth of itself is what is called (a mark of) the (true) Virtue. Loving men and benefiting things is what is called Benevolence. Seeing wherein things that are different yet agree is what is called being Great. Conduct free from the ambition of being distinguished above others is what is called being Generous. The possession in himself of a myriad points of difference is what is called being Rich.

passages.zh: 故執德之謂紀，德成之謂立，循於道之謂備，不以物挫志之謂完。
passages.en: Therefore to hold fast the natural attributes is what is called the Guiding Line (of government); the perfecting of those attributes is what is called its Establishment; accordance with the Dao is what is called being Complete; and not allowing anything external to affect the will is what is called being Perfect.

passages.zh: 君子明於此十者，則韜乎其事心之大也，沛乎其為萬物逝也。
passages.en: When the Superior man understands these ten things, he keeps all matters as it were sheathed in himself, showing the greatness of his mind; and through the outflow of his doings, all things move (and come to him).

passages.zh: 若然者，藏金於山，藏珠於淵；不利貨財，不近貴富；不樂壽，不哀夭；不榮通，不醜窮；
passages.en: Being such, he lets the gold lie hid in the hill, and the pearls in the deep; he considers not property or money to be any gain; he keeps aloof from riches and honours; he rejoices not in long life, and grieves not for early death; he does not account prosperity a glory, nor is ashamed of indigence;

passages.zh: 壽夭俱忘，窮通不足言矣。
passages.en: he would not grasp at the gain of the whole world to be held as his own private portion; he would not desire to rule over the whole world as his own private distinction.

passages.zh: 不拘一世之利以為己私分，不以王天下為己處顯。
passages.en: His distinction is in understanding that all things belong to the one treasury, and that death and life should be viewed in the same way.

passages.zh: 顯則明，萬物一府，死生同狀。」
passages.en: His distinction is in understanding that all things belong to the one treasury, and that death and life should be viewed in the same way.

passages.zh: 夫子曰：「夫道，淵乎其居也，漻乎其清也。
passages.en: The Master said, 'How still and deep is the place where the Dao resides! How limpid is its purity!

passages.zh: 金石不得，無以鳴。
passages.en: Metal and stone without It would give forth no sound.

passages.zh: 故金石有聲，不考不鳴。
passages.en: They have indeed the (power of) sound (in them), but if they be not struck, they do not emit it.

passages.zh: 萬物孰能定之！
passages.en: Who can determine (the qualities that are in) all things?

passages.zh: 夫王德之人，素逝而恥通於事，立之本原而知通於神。
passages.en: The man of kingly qualities holds on his way unoccupied, and is ashamed to busy himself with (the conduct of) affairs. He establishes himself in (what is) the root and source (of his capacity), and his wisdom grows to be spirit-like.

passages.zh: 故其德廣，其心之出，有物採之。
passages.en: In this way his attributes become more and more great, and when his mind goes forth, whatever things come in his way, it lays hold of them (and deals with them).

passages.zh: 故形非道不生，生非德不明。
passages.en: Thus, if there were not the Dao, the bodily form would not have life, and its life, without the attributes (of the Dao), would not be manifested.

passages.zh: 存形窮生，立德明道，非王德者邪！
passages.en: Is not he who preserves the body and gives the fullest development to the life, who establishes the attributes of the Dao and clearly displays It, possessed of kingly qualities?

passages.zh: 蕩蕩乎！忽然出，勃然動，而萬物從之乎！
passages.en: How majestic is he in his sudden issuings forth, and in his unexpected movements, when all things follow him!

passages.zh: 此謂王德之人。
passages.en: This we call the man whose qualities fit him to rule.

passages.zh: 視乎冥冥，聽乎無聲。
passages.en: He sees where there is the deepest obscurity; he hears where there is no sound.

passages.zh: 冥冥之中，獨見曉焉；無聲之中，獨聞和焉。
passages.en: In the midst of the deepest obscurity, he alone sees and can distinguish (various objects); in the midst of a soundless (abyss), he alone can hear a harmony (of notes).

passages.zh: 故深之又深，而能物焉；神之又神，而能精焉。
passages.en: Therefore where one deep is succeeded by a greater, he can people all with things; where one mysterious range is followed by another that is more so, he can lay hold of the subtlest character of each.

passages.zh: 故其與萬物接也，至無而供其求，時騁而要其宿，大小、長短、修遠。」
passages.en: In this way in his intercourse with all things, while he is farthest from having anything, he can yet give to them what they seek; while he is always hurrying forth, he yet returns to his resting-place; now large, now small; now long, now short; now distant, now near.'

passages.zh: 黃帝遊乎赤水之北，登乎崑崙之丘而南望，還歸，遺其玄珠，使知索之而不得，使離朱索之而不得，使喫詬索之而不得也。
passages.en: Huang-Di, enjoying himself on the north of the Red-water, ascended to the height of the Kun-lun (mountain), and having looked towards the south, was returning home, when he lost his dark-coloured pearl. He employed Wisdom to search for it, but he could not find it. He employed (the clear-sighted) Li Zhu to search for it, but he could not find it. He employed (the vehement debater) Chi Gou to search for it, but he could not find it.

passages.zh: 乃使象罔，象罔得之。
passages.en: He then employed Purposeless, who found it;

passages.zh: 黃帝曰：「異哉！象罔乃可以得之乎？」
passages.en: on which Huang-Di said, 'How strange that it was Purposeless who was able to find it!'

passages.zh: 堯之師曰許由，許由之師曰齧缺，齧缺之師曰王倪，王倪之師曰被衣。
passages.en: The teacher of Yao was Xu You; of Xu You, Nie Que; of Nie Que, Wang Ni; of Wang Ni, Bei-yi.

passages.zh: 堯問於許由曰：「齧缺可以配天乎？吾藉王倪以要之。」
passages.en: Yao asked Xu You, saying, 'Is Nie Que fit to be the correlate of Heaven? (If you think he is), I will avail myself of the services of Wang Ni to constrain him (to take my place).'

passages.zh: 許由曰：「殆哉圾乎天下！
passages.en: Xu You replied, 'Such a measure would be hazardous, and full of peril to the kingdom!

passages.zh: 齧缺之為人也，聰明叡知，給數以敏，其性過人，而又乃以人受天。
passages.en: The character of Nie Que is this - he is acute, perspicacious, shrewd and knowing, ready in reply, sharp in retort, and hasty; his natural (endowments) surpass those of other men, but by his human qualities he seeks to obtain the Heavenly gift;

passages.zh: 彼審乎禁過，而不知過之所由生。
passages.en: he exercises his discrimination in suppressing his errors, but he does not know what is the source from which his errors arise.

passages.zh: 與之配天乎？
passages.en: Make him the correlate of Heaven!

passages.zh: 彼且乘人而無天，方且本身而異形，方且尊知而火馳，方且為緒使，方且為物絯，方且四顧而物應，方且應眾宜，方且與物化而未始有恒。
