passages.en: He would employ the human qualities, so that no regard would be paid to the Heavenly gift. Moreover, he would assign different functions to the different parts of the one person. Moreover, honour would be given to knowledge, and he would have his plans take effect with the speed of fire. Moreover, he would be the slave of everything he initiated. Moreover, he would be embarrassed by things. Moreover, he would be looking all round for the response of things (to his measures). Moreover, he would be responding to the opinion of the multitude as to what was right. Moreover, he would be changing as things changed, and would not begin to have any principle of constancy.

passages.zh: 夫何足以配天乎？
passages.en: How can such a man be fit to be the correlate of Heaven?

passages.zh: 雖然，有族有祖，可以為眾父，而不可以為眾父父。
passages.en: Nevertheless, as there are the smaller branches of a family and the common ancestor of all its branches, he might be the father of a branch, but not the father of the fathers of all the branches.

passages.zh: 治亂之率也，北面之禍也，南面之賊也。」
passages.en: Such government (as he would conduct) would lead to disorder. It would be calamity in one in the position of a minister, and ruin if he were in the position of the sovereign.'

passages.zh: 堯觀乎華。
passages.en: Yao was looking about him at Hua,

passages.zh: 華封人曰：「嘻！聖人！請祝聖人：使聖人壽。」
passages.en: the border-warden of which said, 'Ha! the sage! Let me ask blessings on the sage! May he live long!'

passages.zh: 堯曰：「辭。」
passages.en: Yao said, 'Hush!'

passages.zh: 「使聖人富」。
passages.en: but the other went on, 'May the sage become rich!'

passages.zh: 堯曰：「辭。」
passages.en: Yao (again) said, 'Hush!'

passages.zh: 「使聖人多男子」。
passages.en: but (the warden) continued, 'May the sage have many sons!'

passages.zh: 堯曰：「辭。」
passages.en: When Yao repeated his 'Hush,'

passages.zh: 封人曰：「壽、富、多男子，人之所欲也。女獨不欲，何邪？」
passages.en: the warden said, 'Long life, riches, and many sons are what men wish for - how is it that you alone do not wish for them?'

passages.zh: 堯曰：「多男子則多懼，富則多事，壽則多辱。
passages.en: Yao replied, 'Many sons bring many fears; riches bring many troubles; and long life gives rise to many obloquies.

passages.zh: 是三者，非所以養德也，故辭。」
passages.en: These three things do not help to nourish virtue; and therefore I wish to decline them.'

passages.zh: 封人曰：「始也我以女為聖人邪，今然君子也。
passages.en: The warden rejoined, 'At first I considered you to be a sage; now I see in you only a Superior man.

passages.zh: 天生萬民，必授之職，多男子而授之職，則何懼之有！
passages.en: Heaven, in producing the myriads of the people, is sure to have appointed for them their several offices. If you had many sons, and gave them (all their) offices, what would you have to fear?

passages.zh: 富而使人分之，則何事之有！
passages.en: If you had riches, and made other men share them with you, what trouble would you have?

passages.zh: 夫聖人鶉居而鷇食，鳥行而無彰；
passages.en: The sage finds his dwelling like the quail (without any choice of its own), and is fed like the fledgling; he is like the bird which passes on (through the air), and leaves no trace (of its flight).

passages.zh: 天下有道則與物皆昌，天下無道則修德就閒；
passages.en: When good order prevails in the world, he shares in the general prosperity. When there is no such order, he cultivates his virtue, and seeks to be unoccupied.

passages.zh: 千歲厭世，去而上僊，乘彼白雲，至於帝鄉。
passages.en: After a thousand years, tired of the world, he leaves it, and ascends among the immortals. He mounts on the white clouds, and arrives at the place of God.

passages.zh: 三患莫至，身常無殃，則何辱之有！」
passages.en: The three forms of evil do not reach him, his person is always free from misfortune - what obloquy has he to incur?'

passages.zh: 封人去之，堯隨之，曰：「請問。」
passages.en: With this the border-warden left him. Yao followed him, saying, 'I beg to ask--;'

passages.zh: 封人曰：「退已！」
passages.en: but the other said, 'Begone!'

passages.zh: 堯治天下，伯成子高立為諸侯。
passages.en: When Yao was ruling the world, Bo-cheng Zi-Gao was appointed by him prince of one of the states.

passages.zh: 堯授舜，舜授禹，伯成子高辭為諸侯而耕。
passages.en: From Yao (afterwards) the throne passed to Shun, and from Shun (again) to Yu; and (then) Bo-cheng Zi-Gao resigned his principality and began to cultivate the ground.

passages.zh: 禹往見之，則耕在野。
passages.en: Yu went to see him, and found him ploughing in the open country.

passages.zh: 禹趨就下風，立而問焉，曰：「昔堯治天下，吾子立為諸侯；堯授舜，舜授予，而吾子辭為諸侯而耕。敢問其故何也？」
passages.en: Hurrying to him, and bowing low in acknowledgment of his superiority, Yu then stood up, and asked him, saying, 'Formerly, when Yao was ruling the world, you, Sir, were appointed prince of a state. He gave his sovereignty to Shun, and Shun gave his to me, when you, Sir, resigned your dignity, and are (now) ploughing (here) - I venture to ask the reason of your conduct.'

passages.zh: 子高曰：「昔堯治天下，不賞而民勸，不罰而民畏。
passages.en: Zi-Gao said, 'When Yao ruled the world, the people stimulated one another (to what was right) without his offering them rewards, and stood in awe (of doing wrong) without his threatening them with punishments.

passages.zh: 今子賞罰而民且不仁，德自此衰，刑自此立，後世之亂自此始矣。
passages.en: Now you employ both rewards and punishments, and the people notwithstanding are not good. Their virtue will from this time decay; punishments will from this time prevail; the disorder of future ages will from this time begin.

passages.zh: 夫子闔行邪？無落吾事！」
passages.en: Why do you, my master, not go away, and not interrupt my work?'

passages.zh: 俋俋乎耕而不顧。
passages.en: With this he resumed his ploughing with his head bent down, and did not (again) look round.

passages.zh: 泰初有無，無有無名，一之所起，有一而未形。
passages.en: In the Grand Beginning (of all things) there was nothing in all the vacancy of space; there was nothing that could be named. It was in this state that there arose the first existence - the first existence, but still without bodily shape.

passages.zh: 物得以生，謂之德；
passages.en: From this things could then be produced, (receiving) what we call their proper character.

passages.zh: 未形者有分，且然無間，謂之命；
passages.en: That which had no bodily shape was divided; and then without intermission there was what we call the process of conferring.

passages.zh: 留動而生物，物成生理，謂之形；
passages.en: (The two processes) continuing in operation, things were produced. As things were completed, there were produced the distinguishing lines of each, which we call the bodily shape.

passages.zh: 形體保神，各有儀則，謂之性。
passages.en: That shape was the body preserving in it the spirit, and each had its peculiar manifestation, which we call its Nature.

passages.zh: 性修反德，德至同於初。
passages.en: When the Nature has been cultivated, it returns to its proper character; and when that has been fully reached, there is the same condition as at the Beginning.

passages.zh: 同乃虛，虛乃大。
passages.en: That sameness is pure vacancy, and the vacancy is great.

passages.zh: 合喙鳴，喙鳴合，與天地為合。
passages.en: It is like the closing of the beak and silencing the singing (of a bird). That closing and silencing is like the union of heaven and earth (at the beginning).

passages.zh: 其合緡緡，若愚若昏，是謂玄德，同乎大順。
passages.en: The union, effected, as it is, might seem to indicate stupidity or darkness, but it is what we call the 'mysterious quality' (existing at the beginning); it is the same as the Grand Submission (to the Natural Course).

passages.zh: 夫子問於老聃曰：「有人治道若相放，可不可，然不然。
passages.en: The Master asked Lao Dan, saying, 'Some men regulate the Dao (as by a law), which they have only to follow - (a thing, they say,) is admissible or it is inadmissible; it is so, or it is not so.

passages.zh: 辯者有言曰：『離堅白若縣宇。』
passages.en: (They are like) the sophists who say that they can distinguish what is hard and what is white as clearly as if the objects were houses suspended in the sky.

passages.zh: 若是，則可謂聖人乎？」
passages.en: Can such men be said to be sages?'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「是胥易技係，勞形怵心者也。
passages.en: The reply was, 'They are like the busy underlings of a court, who toil their bodies and distress their minds with their various artifices -

passages.zh: 執留之狗成思，猿狙之便自山林來。
passages.en: dogs, (employed) to their sorrow to catch the yak, or monkeys that are brought from their forests (for their tricksiness).

passages.zh: 丘！予告若，而所不能聞與而所不能言。
passages.en: Qiu, I tell you this - it is what you cannot hear, and what you cannot speak of:

passages.zh: 凡有首、有趾、無心、無耳者眾，有形者與無形無狀而皆存者盡無。
passages.en: Of those who have their heads and feet, and yet have neither minds nor ears, there are multitudes; while of those who have their bodies, and at the same time preserve that which has no bodily form or shape, there are really none.

passages.zh: 其動，止也；其死，生也；其廢，起也。此又非其所以也。
passages.en: It is not in their movements or stoppages, their dying or living, their falling and rising again, that this is to be found.

passages.zh: 有治在人，忘乎物，忘乎天，其名為忘己。
passages.en: The regulation of the course lies in (their dealing with) the human element in them. When they have forgotten external things, and have also forgotten the heavenly element in them, they may be named men who have forgotten themselves.

passages.zh: 忘己之人，是之謂入於天。」
passages.en: The man who has forgotten himself is he of whom it is said that he has become identified with Heaven.'

passages.zh: 將閭葂見季徹曰：「魯君謂葂也曰：『請受教。』辭不獲命，既已告矣，未知中否，請嘗薦之。
passages.en: At an interview with Ji Che, Jiang-li Wan said to him, 'Our ruler of Lu asked to receive my instructions. I declined, on the ground that I had not received any message for him. Afterwards, however, I told him (my thoughts). I do not know whether (what I said) was right or not, and I beg to repeat it to you.

passages.zh: 吾謂魯君曰：『必服恭儉，拔出公忠之屬，而無阿私，民孰敢不輯！』」
passages.en: I said to him, "You must strive to be courteous and to exercise self-restraint; you must distinguish the public-spirited and loyal, and repress the cringing and selfish - who among the people will in that case dare not to be in harmony with you?"'

passages.zh: 季徹局局然笑曰：「若夫子之言，於帝王之德，猶螳蜋之怒臂以當車軼，則必不勝任矣。
passages.en: Ji Che laughed quietly and said, 'Your words, my master, as a description of the right course for a Di or King, were like the threatening movement of its arms by a mantis which would thereby stop the advance of a carriage - inadequate to accomplish your object.

passages.zh: 且若是，則其自為處危，其觀臺多物，將往投跡者眾。」
passages.en: And moreover, if he guided himself by your directions, it would be as if he were to increase the dangerous height of his towers and add to the number of his valuables collected in them - the multitudes (of the people) would leave their (old) ways, and bend their steps in the same direction.'

passages.zh: 將閭葂覤覤然驚曰：「葂也汒若於夫子之所言矣。雖然，願先生之言其風也。」
passages.en: Jiang-li Wan was awe-struck, and said in his fright, 'I am startled by your words, Master, Nevertheless, I should like to hear you describe the influence (which a ruler should exert).'

passages.zh: 季徹曰：「大聖之治天下也，搖蕩民心，使之成教易俗，舉滅其賊心而皆進其獨志，若性之自為，而民不知其所由然。
passages.en: The other said, 'If a great sage ruled the kingdom, he would stimulate the minds of the people, and cause them to carry out his instructions fully, and change their manners; he would take their minds which had become evil and violent and extinguish them, carrying them all forward to act in accordance with the (good) will belonging to them as individuals, as if they did it of themselves from their nature, while they knew not what it was that made them do so.

passages.zh: 若然者，豈兄堯、舜之教民，溟滓然弟之哉？欲同乎德而心居矣。」
passages.en: Would such an one be willing to lookup to Yao and Shun in their instruction of the people as his elder brothers? He would treat them as his juniors, belonging himself to the period of the original plastic ether. His wish would be that all should agree with the virtue (of that early period), and quietly rest in it.'

passages.zh: 子貢南遊於楚，反於晉，過漢陰，見一丈人方將為圃畦，鑿隧而入井，抱甕而出灌，搰搰然用力甚多而見功寡。
passages.en: Zi-gong had been rambling in the south in Chu, and was returning to Jin. As he passed (a place) on the north of the Han, he saw an old man who was going to work on his vegetable garden. He had dug his channels, gone to the well, and was bringing from it in his arms a jar of water to pour into them. Toiling away, he expended a great deal of strength, but the result which he accomplished was very small.

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「有械於此，一日浸百畦，用力甚寡而見功多，夫子不欲乎？」
passages.en: Zi-gong said to him, 'There is a contrivance here, by means of which a hundred plots of ground may be irrigated in one day. With the expenditure of a very little strength, the result accomplished is great. Would you, Master, not like (to try it)?'

passages.zh: 為圃者卬而視之曰：「奈何？」
passages.en: The gardener looked up at him, and said, 'How does it work?'

passages.zh: 曰：「鑿木為機，後重前輕，挈水若抽，數如泆湯，其名為槔。」
passages.en: Zi-gong said, 'It is a lever made of wood, heavy behind, and light in front. It raises the water as quickly as you could do with your hand, or as it bubbles over from a boiler. Its name is a shadoof.'

passages.zh: 為圃者忿然作色而笑曰：「吾聞之吾師：『有機械者必有機事，有機事者必有機心。』
passages.en: The gardener put on an angry look, laughed, and said, 'I have heard from my teacher that, where there are ingenious contrivances, there are sure to be subtle doings; and that, where there are subtle doings, there is sure to be a scheming mind.

passages.zh: 機心存於胸中，則純白不備；純白不備，則神生不定；神生不定者，道之所不載也。
passages.en: But, when there is a scheming mind in the breast, its pure simplicity is impaired. When this pure simplicity is impaired, the spirit becomes unsettled, and the unsettled spirit is not the proper residence of the Dao.

passages.zh: 吾非不知，羞而不為也。」
passages.en: It is not that I do not know (the contrivance which you mention), but I should be ashamed to use it.'

passages.zh: 子貢瞞然慙，俯而不對。
passages.en: (At these words) Zi-gong looked blank and ashamed; he hung down his head, and made no reply.

passages.zh: 有間，為圃者曰：「子奚為者邪？」
passages.en: After an interval, the gardener said to him, 'Who are you, Sir?'

passages.zh: 曰：「孔丘之徒也。」
passages.en: 'A disciple of Kong Qiu,' was the reply.

passages.zh: 為圃者曰：「子非夫博學以擬聖，於于以蓋眾，獨弦哀歌以賣名聲於天下者乎？
passages.en: The other continued, 'Are you not the scholar whose great learning makes you comparable to a sage, who make it your boast that you surpass all others, who sing melancholy ditties all by yourself, thus purchasing a famous reputation throughout the kingdom?

passages.zh: 汝方將忘汝神氣，墮汝形骸，而庶幾乎！
passages.en: If you would (only) forget the energy of your spirit, and neglect the care of your body, you might approximate (to the Dao).

passages.zh: 而身之不能治，而何暇治天下乎？子往矣，無乏吾事！
passages.en: But while you cannot regulate yourself, what leisure have you to be regulating the world? Go on your way, Sir, and do not interrupt my work.'

passages.zh: 子貢卑陬失色，頊頊然不自得，行三十里而後愈。
passages.en: Zi-gong shrunk back abashed, and turned pale. He was perturbed, and lost his self-possession, nor did he recover it, till he had walked a distance of thirty li.

passages.zh: 其弟子曰：「向之人何為者邪？夫子何故見之變容失色，終日不自反邪？」
passages.en: His disciples then said, 'Who was that man? Why, Master, when you saw him, did you change your bearing, and become pale, so that you have been all day without returning to yourself?'

passages.zh: 曰：「始以為天下一人耳，不知復有夫人也。
passages.en: He replied to them, 'Formerly I thought that there was but one man in the world, and did not know that there was this man.

passages.zh: 吾聞之夫子：『事求可、功求成、用力少、見功多者，聖人之道。』
passages.en: I have heard the Master say that to seek for the means of conducting his undertakings so that his success in carrying them out may be complete, and how by the employment of a little strength great results may be obtained, is the way of the sage.

passages.zh: 今徒不然。
passages.en: Now (I perceive that) it is not so at all.

passages.zh: 執道者德全，德全者形全，形全者神全。
passages.en: They who hold fast and cleave to the Dao are complete in the qualities belonging to it. Complete in those qualities, they are complete in their bodies. Complete in their bodies, they are complete in their spirits.

passages.zh: 神全者，聖人之道也。
passages.en: To be complete in spirit is the way of the sage.

passages.zh: 託生與民並行，而不知其所之，汒乎淳備哉！
passages.en: (Such men) live in the world in closest union with the people, going along with them, but they do not know where they are going. Vast and complete is their simplicity!

passages.zh: 功利、機巧，必忘夫人之心。
passages.en: Success, gain, and ingenious contrivances, and artful cleverness, indicate (in their opinion) a forgetfulness of the (proper) mind of man.

passages.zh: 若夫人者，非其志不之，非其心不為。
passages.en: These men will not go where their mind does not carry them, and will do nothing of which their mind does not approve.

passages.zh: 雖以天下譽之，得其所謂，謷然不顧；以天下非之，失其所謂，儻然不受。
passages.en: Though all the world should praise them, they would (only) get what they think should be loftily disregarded; and though all the world should blame them, they would but lose (what they think) fortuitous and not to be received -

passages.zh: 天下之非譽，無益損焉，是謂全德之人哉！
passages.en: the world's blame and praise can do them neither benefit nor injury. Such men may be described as possessing all the attributes (of the Dao),

passages.zh: 我之謂風波之民。」
passages.en: while I can only be called one of those who are like the waves carried about by the wind.'

passages.zh: 反於魯，以告孔子。
passages.en: When he returned to Lu, (Zi-gong) reported the interview and conversation to Confucius,

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「彼假修渾沌氏之術者也：識其一，不知其二；治其內，而不治其外。
passages.en: who said, 'The man makes a pretence of cultivating the arts of the Embryonic Age. He knows the first thing, but not the sequel to it. He regulates what is internal in himself, but not what is external to himself.

passages.zh: 夫明白入素，無為復朴，體性抱神，以遊世俗之間者，汝將固驚邪？
passages.en: If he had intelligence enough to be entirely unsophisticated, and by doing nothing to seek to return to the normal simplicity, embodying (the instincts of) his nature, and keeping his spirit (as it were) in his arms, so enjoying himself in the common ways, you might then indeed be afraid of him!

passages.zh: 且渾沌氏之術，予與汝何足以識之哉！」
passages.en: But what should you and I find in the arts of the embryonic time, worth our knowing?'

passages.zh: 諄芒將東之大壑，適遇苑風於東海之濱。
passages.en: Zhun Mang, on his way to the ocean, met with Yuan Feng on the shore of the eastern sea, and was asked by him where he was going.

passages.zh: 苑風曰：「子將奚之？」
passages.en: 'I am going,' he replied, 'to the ocean;'

passages.zh: 曰：「將之大壑。」
passages.en: and the other again asked, 'What for?'

passages.zh: 曰：「奚為焉？」
passages.en: Zhun Mang said,

passages.zh: 曰：「夫大壑之為物也，注焉而不滿，酌焉而不竭，吾將遊焉。」
passages.en: 'Such is the nature of the ocean that the waters which flow into it can never fill it, nor those which flow from it exhaust it. I will enjoy myself, rambling by it.'

passages.zh: 苑風曰：「夫子無意於橫目之民乎？願聞聖治。」
passages.en: Yuan Feng replied, 'Have you no thoughts about mankind? I should like to hear from you about sagely government.'

passages.zh: 諄芒曰：「聖治乎，官施而不失其宜，拔舉而不失其能，畢見其情事而行其所為，行言自為而天下化，手撓顧指，四方之民莫不俱至，此之謂聖治。」
passages.en: Zhun Mang said, 'Under the government of sages, all offices are distributed according to the fitness of their nature; all appointments are made according to the ability of the men; whatever is done is after a complete survey of all circumstances; actions and words proceed from the inner impulse, and the whole world is transformed. Wherever their hands are pointed and their looks directed, from all quarters the people are all sure to come (to do what they desire): this is what is called government by sages.'

passages.zh: 「願聞德人。」
passages.en: 'I should like to hear about (the government of) the kindly, virtuous men,' (continued Yuan Feng).

passages.zh: 曰：「德人者，居無思，行無慮，不藏是非美惡。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Under the government of the virtuous, when quietly occupying (their place), they have no thought, and, when they act, they have no anxiety; they do not keep stored (in their minds) what is right and what is wrong, what is good and what is bad.

passages.zh: 四海之內，共利之之謂悅，共給之之謂安；
passages.en: They share their benefits among all within the four seas, and this produces what is called (the state of) satisfaction; they dispense their gifts to all, and this produces what is called (the state of) rest.

passages.zh: 怊乎若嬰兒之失其母也，儻乎若行而失其道也。
passages.en: (The people) grieve (on their death) like babies who have lost their mothers, and are perplexed like travellers who have lost their way.

passages.zh: 財用有餘而不知其所自來，飲食取足而不知其所從。
passages.en: They have a superabundance of wealth and all necessaries, and they know not whence it comes; they have a sufficiency of food and drink, and they know not from whom they get it:

passages.zh: 此謂德人之容。」
passages.en: such are the appearances (under the government) of the kindly and virtuous.'

passages.zh: 「願聞神人。」
passages.en: 'I should like to hear about (the government of) the spirit-like men,' (continued Yuan Feng once more).

passages.zh: 曰：「上神乘光，與形滅亡，此謂照曠。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Men of the highest spirit-like qualities mount up on the light, and (the limitations of) the body vanish. This we call being bright and ethereal.

passages.zh: 天地樂而萬事銷亡，萬物復情，此之謂混冥。」
passages.en: They carry out to the utmost the powers with which they are endowed, and have not a single attribute unexhausted. Their joy is that of heaven and earth, and all embarrassments of affairs melt away and disappear; all things return to their proper nature: and this is what is called (the state of) chaotic obscurity.'

passages.zh: 門無鬼與赤張滿稽，觀於武王之師。
passages.en: Men Wu-gui and Chi-zhang Man-ji had been looking at the army of king Wu,

passages.zh: 赤張滿稽曰：「不及有虞氏乎！故離此患也。」
passages.en: when the latter said, 'It is because he was not born in the time of the Lord of Yu, that therefore he is involved in this trouble (of war).'

passages.zh: 門無鬼曰：「天下均治而有虞氏治之邪，其亂而後治之與？」
passages.en: Men Wu-gui replied, 'Was it when the kingdom was in good order, that the Lord of Yu governed it? Or was it after it had become disordered that he governed it?'

passages.zh: 赤張滿稽曰：「天下均治之為願，而何計以有虞氏為？
passages.en: The other said, 'That the kingdom be in a condition of good order, is what (all) desire, and (in that case) what necessity would there be to say anything about the Lord of Yu?

passages.zh: 有虞氏之藥瘍也，禿而施髢，病而求醫。
passages.en: He had medicine for sores; false hair for the bald; and healing for those who were ill:

passages.zh: 孝子操藥以修慈父，其色燋然，聖人羞之。
passages.en: he was like the filial son carrying in the medicine to cure his kind father, with every sign of distress in his countenance. A sage would be ashamed (of such a thing).

passages.zh: 至德之世，不尚賢，不使能；上如標枝，民如野鹿；
passages.en: In the age of perfect virtue they attached no value to wisdom, nor employed men of ability. Superiors were (but) as the higher branches of a tree; and the people were like the deer of the wild.

passages.zh: 端正而不知以為義，相愛而不知以為仁；實而不知以為忠，當而不知以為信；
passages.en: They were upright and correct, without knowing that to be so was Righteousness; they loved one another, without knowing that to do so was Benevolence; they were honest and leal-hearted, without knowing that it was Loyalty; they fulfilled their engagements, without knowing that to do so was Good Faith;

passages.zh: 蠢動而相使，不以為賜。
passages.en: in their simple movements they employed the services of one another, without thinking that they were conferring or receiving any gift.

passages.zh: 是故行而無迹，事而無傳。」
passages.en: Therefore their actions left no trace, and there was no record of their affairs.'

passages.zh: 孝子不諛其親，忠臣不諂其君，臣子之盛也。
passages.en: The filial son who does not flatter his father, and the loyal minister who does not fawn on his ruler, are the highest examples of a minister and a son.

passages.zh: 親之所言而然，所行而善，則世俗謂之不肖子；
passages.en: When a son assents to all that his father says, and approves of all that his father does, common opinion pronounces him an unworthy son;

passages.zh: 君之所言而然，所行而善，則世俗謂之不肖臣。
passages.en: when a minister assents to all that his ruler says, and approves of all that his ruler does, common opinion pronounces him an unworthy minister.

passages.zh: 而未知此其必然邪！
passages.en: Nor does any one reflect that this view is necessarily correct.

passages.zh: 世俗之所謂然而然之，所謂善而善之，則不謂之道諛之人也。
passages.en: But when common opinion (itself) affirms anything and men therefore assent to it, or counts anything good and men also approve of it, then it is not said that they are mere consenters and flatterers -

passages.zh: 然則俗固嚴於親而尊於君邪！
passages.en: is common opinion then more authoritative than a father, or more to be honoured than a ruler?

passages.zh: 謂己道人，則勃然作色；謂己諛人，則怫然作色。
passages.en: Tell a man that he is merely following (the opinions) of another, and at once he flushes with anger. Tell a man that he is flatterer of others, and immediately he flushes with anger.

passages.zh: 而終身道人也，終身諛人也，合譬飾辭聚眾也，是始終本末不相坐。
passages.en: And yet all his life he is merely following others, and flattering them. His illustrations are made to agree with theirs; his phrases are glossed: to win the approbation of the multitudes. From first to last, from beginning to end, he finds no fault with their views.

passages.zh: 垂衣裳，設采色，動容貌，以媚一世，而不自謂道諛，與夫人之為徒，通是非，而不自謂眾人，愚之至也。
passages.en: He will let his robes hang down, display the colours on them, and arrange his movements and bearing, so as to win the favour of his age, and yet not call himself a flatterer. He is but a follower of those others, approving and disapproving as they do, and yet he will not say that he is one of them. This is the height of stupidity.

passages.zh: 知其愚者，非大愚也；知其惑者，非大惑也。
passages.en: He who knows his stupidity is not very stupid; he who knows that he is under a delusion is not greatly deluded.

passages.zh: 大惑者，終身不解；大愚者，終身不靈。
passages.en: He who is greatly deluded will never shake the delusion off; he who is very stupid will all his life not become intelligent.

passages.zh: 三人行而一人惑，所適者猶可致也，惑者少也；二人惑則勞而不至，惑者勝也。
passages.en: If three men be walking together, and (only) one of them be under a delusion (as to their way), they may yet reach their goal, the deluded being the fewer; but if two of them be under the delusion, they will not do so, the deluded being the majority.

passages.zh: 而今也以天下惑，予雖有祈嚮，不可得也。不亦悲乎！
passages.en: At the present time, when the whole world is under a delusion, though I pray men to go in the right direction, I cannot make them do so - is it not a sad case?

passages.zh: 大聲不入於里耳，《折楊》、《皇荂》，則嗑然而笑。
passages.en: Grand music does not penetrate the ears of villagers; but if they hear 'The Breaking of the Willow,' or 'The Bright Flowers,' they will roar with laughter.

passages.zh: 是故高言不止於眾人之心，至言不出，俗言勝也。
passages.en: So it is that lofty words do not remain in the minds of the multitude, and that perfect words are not heard, because the vulgar words predominate.

passages.zh: 以二缶鍾惑，而所適不得矣。
passages.en: By two earthenware instruments the (music of) a bell will be confused, and the pleasure that it would afford cannot be obtained.

passages.zh: 而今也以天下惑，予雖有祈嚮，其庸可得邪？
passages.en: At the present time the whole world is under a delusion, and though I wish to go in a certain direction, how can I succeed in doing so?

passages.zh: 知其不可得也而強之，又一惑也，故莫若釋之而不推。
passages.en: Knowing that I cannot do so, if I were to try to force my way, that would be another delusion. Therefore my best course is to let my purpose go, and no more pursue it.

passages.zh: 不推，誰其比憂！
passages.en: If I do not pursue it, whom shall I have to share in my sorrow?

passages.zh: 厲之人夜半生其子，遽取火而視之，汲汲然惟恐其似己也。
passages.en: If an ugly man have a son born to him at midnight, he hastens with a light to look at it. Very eagerly he does so, only afraid that it may be like himself.

passages.zh: 百年之木，破為犧尊，青黃而文之，其斷在溝中。
passages.en: From a tree a hundred years old a portion shall be cut and fashioned into a sacrificial vase, with the bull figured on it, which is ornamented further with green and yellow, while the rest (of that portion) is cut away and thrown into a ditch.

passages.zh: 比犧尊於溝中之斷，則美惡有間矣，其於失性一也。
passages.en: If now we compare the sacrificial vase with what was thrown into the ditch, there will be a difference between them as respects their beauty and ugliness; but they both agree in having lost the (proper) nature of the wood.

passages.zh: 跖與曾、史，行義有間矣，然其失性均也。
passages.en: So in respect of their practice of righteousness there is a difference between (the robber) Zhi on the one hand, and Zeng (Shen) or Shi (Qiu) on the other; but they all agree in having lost (the proper qualities of) their nature.

passages.zh: 且夫失性有五：一曰五色亂目，使目不明；
passages.en: Now there are five things which produce (in men) the loss of their (proper) nature. The first is (their fondness for) the five colours which disorder the eye, and take from it its (proper) clearness of vision;

passages.zh: 二曰五聲亂耳，使耳不聰；
passages.en: the second is (their fondness for) the five notes (of music), which disorder the ear and take from it its (proper) power of hearing;

passages.zh: 三曰五臭薰鼻，困惾中顙；
passages.en: the third is (their fondness for) the five odours which penetrate the nostrils, and produce a feeling of distress all over the forehead;

passages.zh: 四曰五味濁口，使口厲爽；
passages.en: the fourth is (their fondness for) the five flavours, which deaden the mouth, and pervert its sense of taste;

passages.zh: 五曰趣舍滑心，使性飛揚。
passages.en: the fifth is their preferences and dislikes, which unsettle the mind, and cause the nature to go flying about.

passages.zh: 此五者，皆生之害也。
passages.en: These five things are all injurious to the life;

passages.zh: 而楊、墨乃始離跂自以為得，非吾所謂得也。
passages.en: and now Yang and Mo begin to stretch forward from their different standpoints, each thinking that he has hit on (the proper course for men). But the courses they have hit on are not what I call the proper course.

passages.zh: 夫得者困，可以為得乎？則鳩鴞之在於籠也，亦可以為得矣。
passages.en: What they have hit on (only) leads to distress - can they have hit on what is the right thing? If they have, we may say that the dove in a cage has found the right thing for it.

passages.zh: 且夫趣舍聲色以柴其內，皮弁、鷸冠、搢笏、紳修以約其外，內支盈於柴柵，外重纆繳，睆睆然在纆繳之中而自以為得，則是罪人交臂、歷指，而虎豹在於囊檻，亦可以為得矣。
passages.en: Moreover, those preferences and dislikes, that (fondness for) music and colours, serve but to pile up fuel (in their breasts); while their caps of leather, the bonnet with kingfishers' plumes, the memorandum tablets which they carry, and their long girdles, serve but as restraints on their persons. Thus inwardly stuffed full as a hole for fuel, and outwardly fast bound with cords, when they look quietly round from out of their bondage, and think they have got all they could desire, they are no better than criminals whose arms are tied together, and their fingers subjected to the screw, or than tigers and leopards in sacks or cages, and yet thinking that they have got (all they could wish).

passages.zh: 天道運而無所積，故萬物成；帝道運而無所積，故天下歸；聖道運而無所積，故海內服。
passages.en: The Way of Heaven operates (unceasingly), and leaves no accumulation (of its influence) in any particular place, so that all things are brought to perfection by it; so does the Way of the Dis operate, and all under the sky turn to them (as their directors); so also does the Way of the Sages operate, and all within the seas submit to them.

passages.zh: 明於天，通於聖，六通四辟於帝王之德者，其自為也，昧然無不靜者矣。
passages.en: Those who clearly understand (the Way of) Heaven, who are in sympathy with (that of) the sages, and familiar through the universe and in the four quarters (of the earth) with the work of the Dis and the kings, yet act spontaneously from themselves: with the appearance of being ignorant they are yet entirely still.

passages.zh: 聖人之靜也，非曰靜也善，故靜也，萬物無足以鐃心者，故靜也。
passages.en: The stillness of the sages does not belong to them as a consequence of their skilful ability; all things are not able to disturb their minds - it is on this account that they are still.

passages.zh: 水靜則明燭鬚眉，平中準，大匠取法焉。
passages.en: When water is still, its clearness shows the beard and eyebrows (of him who looks into it). It is a perfect Level, and the greatest artificer takes his rule from it.

passages.zh: 水靜猶明，而況精神！
passages.en: Such is the clearness of still water, and how much greater is that of the human Spirit!

passages.zh: 聖人之心靜乎，天地之鑑也，萬物之鏡也。
passages.en: The still mind of the sage is the mirror of heaven and earth, the glass of all things.

passages.zh: 夫虛靜恬淡，寂漠無為者，天地之平而道德之至，故帝王聖人休焉。
passages.en: Vacancy, stillness, placidity, tastelessness, quietude, silence, and non-action - this is the Level of heaven and earth, and the perfection of the Dao and its characteristics. Therefore the Dis, Kings, and Sages found in this their resting-place.

passages.zh: 休則虛，虛則實，實者倫矣。
passages.en: Resting here, they were vacant; from their vacancy came fullness; from their fullness came the nice distinctions (of things).

passages.zh: 虛則靜，靜則動，動則得矣。
passages.en: From their vacancy came stillness; that stillness was followed by movement; their movements were successful.

passages.zh: 靜則無為，無為也，則任事者責矣。
passages.en: From their stillness came their non-action. Doing-nothing, they devolved the cares of office on their employes.

passages.zh: 無為則俞俞，俞俞者憂患不能處，年壽長矣。
passages.en: Doing-nothing was accompanied by the feeling of satisfaction. Where there is that feeling of satisfaction, anxieties and troubles find no place; and the years of life are many.

passages.zh: 夫虛靜恬淡，寂寞無為者，萬物之本也。
passages.en: Vacancy, stillness, placidity, tastelessness, quietude, silence, and doing-nothing are the root of all things.

passages.zh: 明此以南鄉，堯之為君也；明此以北面，舜之為臣也。
passages.en: When this is understood, we find such a ruler on the throne as Yao, and such a minister as Shun.

passages.zh: 以此處上，帝王天子之德也；以此處下，玄聖素王之道也。
passages.en: When with this a high position is occupied, we find the attributes of the Dis and kings,-- the sons of Heaven; with this in a low position, we find the mysterious sages, the uncrowned kings, with their ways.

passages.zh: 以此退居而閒游，江海山林之士服；以此進為而撫世，則功大名顯而天下一也。
passages.en: With this retiring (from public life), and enjoying themselves at leisure, we find the scholars who dwell by the rivers and seas, among the hills and forests, all submissive to it; with this coming forward to active life and comforting their age, their merit is great, and their fame is distinguished - and all the world becomes united in one.

passages.zh: 靜而聖，動而王，無為也而尊，樸素而天下莫能與之爭美。
passages.en: (Such men) by their stillness become sages; and by their movement, kings. Doing-nothing, they are honoured; in their plain simplicity, no one in the world can strive with them (for the palm of) excellence.

passages.zh: 夫明白於天地之德者，此之謂大本大宗，與天和者也；所以均調天下，與人和者也。
passages.en: The clear understanding of the virtue of Heaven and Earth is what is called 'The Great Root,' and 'The Great Origin;' - they who have it are in harmony with Heaven, and so they produce all equable arrangements in the world - they are those who are in harmony with men.

passages.zh: 與人和者，謂之人樂；與天和者，謂之天樂。
passages.en: Being in harmony with men is called the joy of men; being in harmony with Heaven is called the joy of Heaven.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「吾師乎！吾師乎！
passages.en: Zhuangzi said, 'My Master! my Master!

passages.zh: 虀萬物而不為戾，澤及萬世而不為仁，長於上古而不為壽，覆載天地、刻雕眾形而不為朽，此之謂天樂。
passages.en: He shall hash and blend all things in mass without being cruel; he shall dispense his favours to all ages without being benevolent. He is older than the highest antiquity, and yet is not old. He overspreads the heavens and sustains the earth; from him is the carving of all forms without any artful skill! This is what is called the Joy of Heaven.

passages.zh: 故曰：知天樂者，其生也天行，其死也物化；靜而與陰同德，動而與陽同波。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'Those who know the joy of Heaven during their life, act like Heaven, and at death undergo transformation like (other) things; in their stillness they possess the quality of the Yin, and in their movement they flow abroad as the Yang.

passages.zh: 故知天樂者，無天怨，無人非，無物累，無鬼責。
passages.en: Therefore he who knows the Joy of Heaven has no murmuring against Heaven, nor any fault-finding with men; and suffers no embarrassment from things, nor any reproof from ghosts.

passages.zh: 故曰：其動也天，其靜也地，一心定而王天下；其鬼不祟，其魂不疲，一心定而萬物服。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'His movements are those of Heaven; his stillness is that of Earth; his whole mind is fixed, and he rules over the world. The spirits of his dead do not come to scare him; he is not worn out by their souls.

passages.zh: 言以虛靜推於天地，通於萬物，此之謂天樂。
passages.en: His words proceeding from his vacancy and stillness, yet reach to heaven and earth, and show a communication with all things: this is what is called the Joy of Heaven.

passages.zh: 天樂者，聖人之心，以蓄天下也。」
passages.en: This Joy of Heaven forms the mind of the sage whereby he nurtures all under the sky.'

passages.zh: 夫帝王之德，以天地為宗，以道德為主，以無為為常。
passages.en: It was the Way of the Dis and Kings to regard Heaven and Earth as their Author, the Dao and its characteristics as their Lord, and Doing-nothing as their constant rule.

passages.zh: 無為也，則用天下而有餘；有為也，則為天下用而不足。
passages.en: Doing-nothing, they could use the whole world in their service and might have done more; acting, they were not sufficient for the service required of them by the world.

passages.zh: 故古之人貴夫無為也。
passages.en: Hence the men of old held non-inaction in honour.

passages.zh: 上無為也，下亦無為也，是下與上同德，下與上同德則不臣；下有為也，上亦有為也，是上與下同道，上與下同道則不主。
passages.en: When superiors do nothing and their inferiors also do nothing, inferiors and superiors possess the same virtue; and when inferiors and superiors possess the same virtue, there are none to act as ministers. When inferiors act, and their superiors also act, then superiors and inferiors possess the same Dao; and when superiors and inferiors possess the same Dao, there is none to preside as Lord.

passages.zh: 上必無為而用天下，下必有為為天下用，此不易之道也。
passages.en: But that the superiors do nothing and yet thereby use the world in their service, and that the inferiors, while acting, be employed in the service of the world, is an unchangeable principle.

passages.zh: 故古之王天下者，知雖落天地，不自慮也；辯雖彫萬物，不自說也；能雖窮海內，不自為也。
passages.en: Therefore the ancient kings who presided over the world, though their knowledge embraced (all the operations of) Heaven and Earth, took no thought of their own about them; though their nice discrimination appreciated the fine fashioning of all things, they said not a word about it; though their power comprehended all within the seas, they did nothing themselves.

passages.zh: 天不產而萬物化，地不長而萬物育，帝王無為而天下功。
passages.en: Heaven produces nothing, yet all things experience their transformations; Earth effects no growth, yet all things receive their nurture; the Dis and Kings did nothing, yet all the world testified their effective services.

passages.zh: 故曰：莫神於天，莫富於地，莫大於帝王。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'There is nothing more spiritlike than Heaven; there is nothing richer than Earth; there are none greater than the Dis and Kings.'

passages.zh: 故曰：帝王之德配天地。
passages.en: Hence it is said (further), 'The attributes of the Dis and kings corresponded to those of Heaven and Earth.'

passages.zh: 此乘天地，馳萬物，而用人群之道也。
passages.en: It was thus that they availed themselves of (the operations of) Heaven and Earth, carried all things on unceasingly (in their courses), and employed the various classes of men in their service.

passages.zh: 本在於上，末在於下；要在於主，詳在於臣。
passages.en: Originating belongs to those in the higher position; details (of work) to those who are in the lower. The compendious decision belongs to the lord; the minutiae of execution, to his ministers.

passages.zh: 三軍、五兵之運，德之末也；賞罰利害，五刑之辟，教之末也；禮法度數，形名比詳，治之末也；鐘鼓之音，羽毛之容，樂之末也；哭泣衰絰，隆殺之服，哀之末也。
passages.en: The direction of the three hosts and their men with the five weapons is but a trifling quality; rewards and penalties with their advantages and sufferings, and the inflictions of the five punishments are but trivial elements of instruction; ceremonies, laws, measures, and numbers, with all the minutiae of jurisprudence, are small matters in government; the notes of bells and drums, and the display of plumes and flags are the slightest things in music, and the various grades of the mourning garments are the most unimportant manifestations of grief.

passages.zh: 此五末者，須精神之運，心術之動，然後從之者也。
passages.en: These five unimportant adjuncts required the operation of the excited spirit and the employment of the arts of the mind, to bring them into use.

passages.zh: 末學者，古人有之，而非所以先也。
passages.en: The men of old had them indeed, but they did not give them the first place.

passages.zh: 君先而臣從，父先而子從，兄先而弟從，長先而少從，男先而女從，夫先而婦從。
passages.en: The ruler precedes, and the minister follows; the father precedes, and the son follows; the elder brother precedes, and the younger follows; the senior precedes, and the junior follows; the male precedes, and the female follows; the husband precedes, and the wife follows.

passages.zh: 夫尊卑先後，天地之行也，故聖人取象焉。
passages.en: This precedence of the more honourable and sequence of the meaner is seen in the (relative) action of heaven and earth, and hence the sages took them as their pattern.

passages.zh: 天尊地卑，神明之位也；春夏先，秋冬後，四時之序也。
passages.en: The more honourable position of heaven and the lower one of earth are equivalent to a designation of their spirit-like and intelligent qualities. The precedence of spring and summer and the sequence of autumn and winter mark the order of the four seasons.

passages.zh: 萬物化作，萌區有狀，盛衰之殺，變化之流也。
passages.en: In the transformations and growth of all things, every bud and feature has its proper form; and in this we have their gradual maturing and decay, the constant flow of transformation and change.

passages.zh: 夫天地至神，而有尊卑先後之序，而況人道乎！
passages.en: Thus since Heaven and Earth, which are most spirit-like, are distinguished as more honourable and less, and by precedence and sequence, how much more must we look for this in the ways of men!

passages.zh: 宗廟尚親，朝廷尚尊，鄉黨尚齒，行事尚賢，大道之序也。
passages.en: In the ancestral temple it is to kinship that honour is given; in court, to rank; in the neighbourhoods and districts, to age; in the conduct of affairs, to wisdom; such is the order in those great ways.

passages.zh: 語道而非其序者，非其道也；語道而非其道者，安取道！
passages.en: If we speak of the course (to be pursued in them), and do not observe their order, we violate their course. If we speak of the course, and do not observe it, why do we apply that name to it?

passages.zh: 是故古之明大道者，先明天而道德次之，道德已明而仁義次之，仁義已明而分守次之，分守已明而形名次之，形名已明而因任次之，因任已明而原省次之，原省已明而是非次之，是非已明而賞罰次之。
passages.en: Therefore the ancients who clearly understood the great Dao first sought to apprehend what was meant by Heaven, and the Dao and its characteristics came next. When this was apprehended, then came Benevolence and Righteousness. When these were apprehended, then came the Distinction of duties and the observance of them. This accomplished, there came objects and their names. After objects and their names, came the employment of men according to their qualities: on this there followed the examination of the men and of their work. This led to the approval or disapproval of them, which again was succeeded by the apportioning of rewards and penalties.

passages.zh: 賞罰已明而愚知處宜，貴賤履位，仁賢不肖襲情，必分其能，必由其名。
passages.en: After this the stupid and the intelligent understood what was required of them, and the honourable and the mean occupied their several positions. The good and the able, and those inferior to them, sincerely did their best. Their ability was distributed; the duties implied in their official names were fulfilled.

passages.zh: 以此事上，以此畜下，以此治物，以此修身，知謀不用，必歸其天，此之謂太平，治之至也。
passages.en: In this way did they serve their superiors, nourish their inferiors, regulate things, and cultivate their persons. They did not call their knowledge and schemes into requisition; they were required to fall back upon (the method of) Heaven: this was what is called the Perfection of the Rule of Great Peace.

passages.zh: 故《書》曰：「有形有名。」
passages.en: Hence it is said in the Book, 'There are objects and there are their names.'

passages.zh: 形名者，古人有之，而非所以先也。
passages.en: Objects and their names the ancients had; but they did not put them in the foremost place.

passages.zh: 古之語大道者，五變而形名可舉，九變而賞罰可言也。
passages.en: When the ancients spoke of the Great Dao, it was only after four other steps that they gave a place to 'Objects and their Names,' and after eight steps that they gave a place to 'Rewards and Penalties.'

passages.zh: 驟而語形名，不知其本也；驟而語賞罰，不知其始也。
passages.en: If they had all at once spoken of 'Objects and their Names,' they would have shown an ignorance of what is the Root (of government); if they had all at once spoken of 'Rewards and Penalties,' they would have shown an ignorance of the first steps of it.

passages.zh: 倒道而言，迕道而說者，人之所治也，安能治人！
passages.en: Those whose words are thus an inversion of the (proper) course, or in opposition to it, are (only fit to be) ruled by others - how can they rule others?

passages.zh: 驟而語形名賞罰，此有知治之具，非知治之道；可用於天下，不足以用天下。
passages.en: To speak all at once of 'Objects and their Names,' and of 'Rewards and Penalties,' only shows that the speaker knows the instruments of government, but does not know the method of it, is fit to be used as an instrument in the world, but not fit to use others as his instruments: he is what we call a mere sophist, a man of one small idea.

passages.zh: 此之謂辯士，一曲之人也。
passages.en: Ceremonies, laws, numbers, measures, with all the minutiae of jurisprudence, the ancients had; but it is by these that inferiors serve their superiors; it is not by them that those superiors nourish the world.

passages.zh: 禮法度數，形名比詳，古人有之，此下之所以事上，非上之所以畜下也。
passages.en: Anciently, Shun asked Yao, saying, 'In what way does your Majesty by the Grace of Heaven exercise your mind?'

passages.zh: 昔者舜問於堯曰：「天王之用心何如？」
passages.en: The reply was, 'I simply show no arrogance towards the helpless; I do not neglect the poor people; I grieve for those who die; I love their infant children; and I compassionate their widows.'

passages.zh: 堯曰：「吾不敖無告，不廢窮民，苦死者，嘉孺子而哀婦人。此吾所以用心也。」
passages.en: Shun rejoined, 'Admirable, as far as it goes; but it is not what is Great.'

passages.zh: 舜曰：「美則美矣，而未大也。」
passages.en: 'How then,' asked Yao, 'do you think I should do?'

passages.zh: 堯曰：「然則何如？」
passages.en: Shun replied, 'When (a sovereign) possesses the virtue of Heaven, then when he shows himself in action, it is in stillness.

passages.zh: 舜曰：「天德而出寧，日月照而四時行，若晝夜之有經，雲行而雨施矣。」
passages.en: The sun and moon (simply) shine, and the four seasons pursue their courses. So it is with the regular phenomena of day and night, and with the movement of the clouds by which the rain is distributed.'

passages.zh: 堯曰：「膠膠擾擾乎！子，天之合也；我，人之合也。」
passages.en: Yao said, 'Then I have only been persistently troubling myself! What you wish is to be in harmony with Heaven, while I wish to be in harmony with men.'

passages.zh: 夫天地者，古之所大也，而黃帝、堯、舜之所共美也。
passages.en: Now (the Way of) Heaven and Earth was much thought of of old, and Huang-Di, Yao, and Shun united in admiring it.

passages.zh: 故古之王天下者，奚為哉？天地而已矣。
passages.en: Hence the kings of the world of old did nothing, but tried to imitate that Way.

passages.zh: 孔子西藏書於周室，子路謀曰：「由聞周之徵藏史有老聃者，免而歸居。夫子欲藏書，則試往因焉。」
passages.en: Confucius went to the west to deposit (some) writings in the library of Zhou, when Zi-lu counselled him, saying, 'I have heard that the officer in charge of this Zheng Repository of Zhou was one Lao Dan, who has given up his office, and is living in his own house. As you, Master, wish to deposit these writings here, why not go to him, and obtain his help (to accomplish your object).'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「善。」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'Good;' and he went and saw Lao Dan, who refused his assistance.

passages.zh: 往見老聃，而老聃不許，於是繙十二經以說。
passages.en: On this he proceeded to give an abstract of the Twelve Classics to bring the other over to his views.

passages.zh: 老聃中其說，曰：「大謾，願聞其要。」
passages.en: Lao Dan, however, interrupted him while he was speaking, and said, 'This is too vague; let me hear the substance of them in brief.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「要在仁義。」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'The substance of them is occupied with Benevolence and Righteousness.'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「請問：仁義，人之性邪？」
passages.en: The other said, 'Let me ask whether you consider Benevolence and Righteousness to constitute the nature of man?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「然。君子不仁則不成，不義則不生。仁義，真人之性也，又將奚為矣？」
passages.en: 'I do,' was the answer. 'If the superior man be not benevolent, he will not fulfil his character; if he be not righteous, he might as well not have been born. Benevolence and Righteousness are truly the nature of man.'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「請問何謂仁義？」
passages.en: Lao Dan continued, 'Let me ask you what you mean by Benevolence and Righteousness.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「中心物愷，兼愛無私，此仁義之情也。」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'To be in one's inmost heart in kindly sympathy with all things; to love all men; and to allow no selfish thoughts - this is the nature of Benevolence and Righteousness.'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「意！幾乎後言！夫兼愛，不亦迂乎！無私焉，乃私也。
passages.en: Lao Dan exclaimed, 'Ah! you almost show your inferiority by such words! "To love all men!" is not that vague and extravagant? "To be seeking to allow no selfish thoughts!" - that is selfishness!

passages.zh: 夫子若欲使天下無失其牧乎？則天地固有常矣，日月固有明矣，星辰固有列矣，禽獸固有群矣，樹木固有立矣。
passages.en: If you, Master, wish men not to be without their (proper) shepherding, think of Heaven and Earth, which certainly pursue their invariable course; think of the sun and moon, which surely maintain their brightness; think of the stars in the zodiac, which preserve their order and courses; think of birds and beasts, which do not fail to collect together in their flocks and herds; and think of the trees, which do not fail to stand up (in their places).

passages.zh: 夫子亦放德而行，循道而趨，已至矣，又何偈偈乎揭仁義，若擊鼓而求亡子焉？意！夫子亂人之性也！」
passages.en: Do you, Master, imitate this way and carry it into practice; hurry on, following this course, and you will reach your end. Why must you further be vehement in putting forward your Benevolence and Righteousness, as if you were beating a drum, and seeking a fugitive son, (only making him run away the more)? Ah! Master, you are introducing disorder into the nature of man!'

passages.zh: 士成綺見老子而問曰：「吾聞夫子聖人也，吾固不辭遠道而來，願見，百舍重趼而不敢息。今吾觀子，非聖人也。
passages.en: Shi-cheng Qi, having an interview with Laozi, asked him, saying, 'I heard, Master, that you were a sage, and I came here, wishing to see you, without grudging the length of the journey. During the stages of the hundred days, the soles of my feet became quite callous, but I did not dare to stop and rest. Now I perceive that you are not a sage.

passages.zh: 鼠壤有餘蔬，而棄妹之者，不仁也；生熟不盡於前，而積歛無崖。」
passages.en: Because there was some rice left about the holes of the rats, you sent away your younger sister, which was unkind; when your food, whether raw or cooked, remains before you not all consumed, you keep on hoarding it up to any extent.'

passages.zh: 老子漠然不應。
passages.en: Laozi looked indifferent, and gave him no answer.

passages.zh: 士成綺明日復見，曰：「昔者吾有刺於子，今吾心正卻矣，何故也？」
passages.en: Next day Qi again saw Laozi, and said, 'Yesterday I taunted you; but to-day I have gone back to a better mood of mind. What is the cause (of the change)?'

passages.zh: 老子曰：「夫巧知神聖之人，吾自以為脫焉。昔者子呼我牛也而謂之牛，呼我馬也而謂之馬。
passages.en: Laozi replied, 'I consider that I have freed myself from the trammels of claiming to be artfully knowing, spirit-like, and sage. Yesterday if you had called me an ox, you might have done so; or if you had called me a horse, you might have done so.

passages.zh: 苟有其實，人與之名而弗受，再受其殃。
passages.en: If there be a reality (corresponding to men's ideas), and men give it a name, which another will not receive, he will in the sequel suffer the more.

passages.zh: 吾服也恒服，吾非以服有服。」
passages.en: My manner was what I constantly observe - I did not put it on for the occasion.'

passages.zh: 士成綺雁行避影，履行，遂進而問：「修身若何？」
passages.en: Shi-cheng Qi sidled away out of Lao's shadow; then he retraced his steps, advanced forward, and asked how he should cultivate himself.

passages.zh: 老子曰：「而容崖然，而目衝然，而顙頯然，而口闞然，而狀義然，似繫馬而止也。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Your demeanour is repelling; you stare with your eyes; your forehead is broad and yet tapering; you bark and growl with your mouth; your appearance is severe and pretentious; you are like a horse held by its tether, you would move, but are restrained, and (if let go) would start off like an arrow from a bow;

passages.zh: 動而持，發也機，察而審，知巧而睹於泰，凡以為不信。
passages.en: you examine all the minutiae of a thing; your wisdom is artful, and yet you try to look at ease. All these are to be considered proofs of your want of sincerity.

passages.zh: 邊竟有人焉，其名為竊。」
passages.en: If on the borders one were to be found with them, he would be named a Thief.'

passages.zh: 夫子曰：「夫道，於大不終，於小不遺，故萬物備。
passages.en: The Master said, 'The Dao does not exhaust itself in what is greatest, nor is it ever absent from what is least; and therefore it is to be found complete and diffused in all things.

passages.zh: 廣廣乎其無不容也，淵乎其不可測也。
passages.en: How wide is its universal comprehension! How deep is its unfathomableness!

passages.zh: 形德仁義，神之末也，非至人孰能定之！
passages.en: The embodiment of its attributes in benevolence and righteousness is but a small result of its spirit-like (working); but it is only the perfect man who can determine this.

passages.zh: 夫至人有世，不亦大乎！而不足以為之累。
passages.en: The perfect man has (the charge of) the world - is not the charge great? and yet it is not sufficient to embarrass him.

passages.zh: 天下奮柄而不與之偕，審乎無假而不與利遷，極物之真，能守其本，故外天地，遺萬物，而神未嘗有所困也。
passages.en: He wields the handle of power over the whole world, and yet it is nothing to him. His discrimination detects everything false, and no consideration of gain moves him. He penetrates to the truth of things, and can guard that which is fundamental. So it is that heaven and earth are external to him, and he views all things with indifference, and his spirit is never straitened by them.

passages.zh: 通乎道，合乎德，退仁義，賓禮樂，至人之心有所定矣。」
passages.en: He has comprehended the Dao, and is in harmony with its characteristics; he pushes back benevolence and righteousness (into their proper place), and deals with ceremonies and music as (simply) guests: yes, the mind of the perfect man determines all things aright.'

passages.zh: 世之所貴道者，書也，書不過語，語有貴也。
passages.en: What the world thinks the most valuable exhibition of the Dao is to be found in books. But books are only a collection of words. Words have what is valuable in them - what is valuable in words is the ideas they convey.

passages.zh: 語之所貴者，意也，意有所隨。
passages.en: But those ideas are a sequence of something else - and what that something else is cannot be conveyed by words.

passages.zh: 意之所隨者，不可以言傳也，而世因貴言傳書。
passages.en: When the world, because of the value which it attaches to words, commits them to books, that for which it so values them may not deserve to be valued - because that which it values is not what is really valuable.

passages.zh: 世雖貴之，我猶不足貴也，為其貴非其貴也。
passages.en: Thus it is that what we look at and can see is (only) the outward form and colour, and what we listen to and can hear is (only) names and sounds.

passages.zh: 故視而可見者，形與色也；聽而可聞者，名與聲也。
passages.en: Alas! that men of the world should think that form and colour, name and sound, should be sufficient to give them the real nature of the Dao.

passages.zh: 悲夫！世人以形色名聲為足以得彼之情！
passages.en: The form and colour, the name and sound, are certainly not sufficient to convey its real nature; and so it is that 'the wise do not speak and those who do speak are not wise.'

passages.zh: 夫形色名聲果不足以得彼之情，則知者不言，言者不知，而世豈識之哉！
passages.en: How should the world know that real nature?

passages.zh: 桓公讀書於堂上，輪扁斲輪於堂下，釋椎鑿而上，問桓公曰：「敢問公之所讀者何言邪？」
passages.en: Duke Huan, seated above in his hall, was (once) reading a book, and the wheelwright Bian was making a wheel below it. Laying aside his hammer and chisel, Bian went up the steps, and said, 'I venture to ask your Grace what words you are reading?'

passages.zh: 公曰：「聖人之言也。」
passages.en: The duke said, 'The words of the sages.'

passages.zh: 曰：「聖人在乎？」
passages.en: 'Are those sages alive?' Bian continued.

passages.zh: 公曰：「已死矣。」
passages.en: 'They are dead,' was the reply.

passages.zh: 曰：「然則君之所讀者，古人之糟魄已夫！」
passages.en: 'Then,' said the other, 'what you, my Ruler, are reading are only the dregs and sediments of those old men.'

passages.zh: 桓公曰：「寡人讀書，輪人安得議乎！有說則可，無說則死。」
passages.en: The duke said, 'How should you, a wheelwright, have anything to say about the book which I am reading? If you can explain yourself, very well; if you cannot, you shall die!'

passages.zh: 輪扁曰：「臣也，以臣之事觀之。斲輪，徐則甘而不固，疾則苦而不入。
passages.en: The wheelwright said, 'Your servant will look at the thing from the point of view of his own art. In making a wheel, if I proceed gently, that is pleasant enough, but the workmanship is not strong; if I proceed violently, that is toilsome and the joinings do not fit.

passages.zh: 不徐不疾，得之於手而應於心，口不能言，有數存焉於其間。
passages.en: If the movements of my hand are neither (too) gentle nor (too) violent, the idea in my mind is realised. But I cannot tell (how to do this) by word of mouth; there is a knack in it.

passages.zh: 臣不能以喻臣之子，臣之子亦不能受之於臣，是以行年七十而老斲輪。
passages.en: I cannot teach the knack to my son, nor can my son learn it from me. Thus it is that I am in my seventieth year, and am (still) making wheels in my old age.

passages.zh: 古之人與其不可傳也死矣，然則君之所讀者，古人之糟魄已夫。」
passages.en: But these ancients, and what it was not possible for them to convey, are dead and gone: so then what you, my Ruler, are reading is but their dregs and sediments!'

passages.zh: 天其運乎？地其處乎？日月其爭於所乎？
passages.en: How (ceaselessly) heaven revolves! How (constantly) earth abides at rest! And do the sun and moon contend about their (respective) places?

passages.zh: 孰主張是？孰維綱是？孰居無事推而行是？
passages.en: Who presides over and directs these (things)? Who binds and connects them together? Who is it that, without trouble or exertion on his part, causes and maintains them?

passages.zh: 意者其有機緘而不得已邪？意者其運轉而不能自止邪？
passages.en: Is it, perhaps, that there is some secret spring, in consequence of which they cannot be but as they are? Or is it, perhaps, that they move and turn as they do, and cannot stop of themselves?

passages.zh: 雲者為雨乎？雨者為雲乎？孰隆施是？孰居無事淫樂而勸是？
passages.en: (Then) how the clouds become rain! And how the rain again forms the clouds! Who diffuses them so abundantly? Who is it that, without trouble or exertion on his part, produces this elemental enjoyment, and seems to stimulate it?

passages.zh: 風起北方，一西一東，有上彷徨，孰噓吸是？孰居無事而披拂是？敢問何故？
passages.en: The winds rise in the north; one blows to the west, and another to the east; while some rise upwards, uncertain in their direction. By whose breathing are they produced? Who is it that, without any trouble and exertion of his own, effects all their undulations? I venture to ask their cause.

passages.zh: 巫咸袑曰：「來！吾語女。天有六極五常，帝王順之則治，逆之則凶。
passages.en: Wu-xian Shao said, 'Come, and I will tell you. To heaven there belong the six Extreme Points, and the five Elements. When the Dis and Kings acted in accordance with them, there was good government; when they acted contrary to them, there was evil.

passages.zh: 九洛之事，治成德備，監照下土，天下戴之，此謂上皇。」
passages.en: Observing the things (described) in the nine divisions (of the writing) of Luo, their government was perfected and their virtue was complete. They inspected and enlightened the kingdom beneath them, and all under the sky acknowledged and sustained them. Such was the condition under the august (sovereigns) and those before them.'

passages.zh: 商太宰蕩問仁於莊子。
passages.en: Tang, the chief administrator of Shang, asked Zhuangzi about Benevolence.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「虎狼，仁也。」
passages.en: The answer was, 'Wolves and tigers are benevolent.'

passages.zh: 曰：「何謂也？」
passages.en: 'What do you mean?' said Tang.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「父子相親，何為不仁？」
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'Father and son (among them) are affectionate to one another. Why should they be considered as not benevolent?'

passages.zh: 曰：「請問至仁。」
passages.en: 'Allow me to ask about perfect benevolence,' pursued the other.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「至仁無親。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi said, 'Perfect benevolence does not admit (the feeling) of affection.'

passages.zh: 太宰曰：「蕩聞之：無親則不愛，不愛則不孝。謂至仁不孝，可乎？」
passages.en: The minister said, 'I have heard that, without (the feeling of) affection there is no love, and without love there is not filial duty - is it permissible to say that the perfectly benevolent are not filial?'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「不然。夫至仁尚矣，孝固不足以言之。此非過孝之言也，不及孝之言也。
passages.en: Zhuangzi rejoined, 'That is not the way to put the case. Perfect Benevolence is the very highest thing - filial duty is by no means sufficient to describe it. The saying which you quote is not to the effect that (such benevolence) transcends filial duty - it does not refer to such duty at all.

passages.zh: 夫南行者至於郢，北面而不見冥山，是何也？則去之遠也。
passages.en: One, travelling to the south, comes (at last) to Ying, and there, standing with his face to the north, he does not see mount Ming. Why does he not see it? Because he is so far from it.

passages.zh: 故曰：以敬孝易，以愛孝難；以愛孝易，以忘親難；忘親易，使親忘我難；使親忘我易，兼忘天下難；兼忘天下易，使天下兼忘我難。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'Filial duty as a part of reverence is easy, but filial duty as a part of love is difficult. If it be easy as a part of love, yet it is difficult to forget one's parents. It may be easy for me to forget my parents, but it is difficult to make my parents forget me. If it were easy to make my parents forget me, it is difficult for me to forget all men in the world. If it were easy to forget all men in the world, it is difficult to make them all forget me.'

passages.zh: 夫德遺堯、舜而不為也，利澤施於萬世，天下莫知也，豈直太息而言仁孝乎哉！
passages.en: This virtue might make one think light of Yao and Shun, and not wish to be they. The profit and beneficial influences of it extend to a myriad ages, and no one in the world knows whence they come. How can you simply heave a great sigh, and speak (as you do) of benevolence and filial duty?

passages.zh: 夫孝悌仁義，忠信貞廉，此皆自勉以役其德者也，不足多也。
passages.en: Filial duty, fraternal respect, benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, sincerity, firmness, and purity - all these may be pressed into the service of this virtue, but they are far from sufficient to come up to it.

passages.zh: 故曰：至貴，國爵并焉；至富，國財并焉；至願，名譽并焉。是以道不渝。」
passages.en: Therefore it is said, 'To him who has what is most noble, all the dignities of a state are as nothing; to him who has what is the greatest riches, all the wealth of a state is as nothing; to him who has all that he could wish, fame and praise are as nothing.' It is thus that the Dao admits of no substitute.

passages.zh: 北門成問於黃帝曰：帝張咸池之樂於洞庭之野，吾始聞之懼，復聞之怠，卒聞之而惑，蕩蕩默默，乃不自得。」
passages.en: Bei-men Cheng asked Huang-Di, saying, 'You were celebrating, O Di, a performance of the music of the Xian-chi, in the open country near the Dong-ting lake. When I heard the first part of it, I was afraid; the next made me weary; and the last perplexed me. I became agitated and unable to speak, and lost my self-possession.'

passages.zh: 帝曰：「女殆其然哉！吾奏之以人，徵之以天，行之以禮義，建之以太清。
passages.en: The Di said, 'It was likely that it should so affect you! It was performed with (the instruments of) men, and all attuned according to (the influences of) Heaven. It proceeded according to (the principles of) propriety and righteousness, and was pervaded by (the idea of) the Grand Purity.

passages.zh: 夫至樂者，先應之以人事，順之以天理，行之以五德，應之以自然，然後調理四時，太和萬物。
passages.en: The Perfect Music first had its response in the affairs of men, and was conformed to the principles of Heaven; it indicated the action of the five virtues, and corresponded to the spontaneity (apparent in nature). After this it showed the blended distinctions of the four seasons, and the grand harmony of all things.

passages.zh: 四時迭起，萬物循生；一盛一衰，文武倫經；一清一濁，陰陽調和，流光其聲；蟄蟲始作，吾驚之以雷霆；其卒無尾，其始無首；一死一生，一僨一起；所常無窮，而一不可待。
passages.en: The succession of those seasons one after another, and the production of things in their proper order. Now it swelled, and now it died away, its peaceful and military strains clearly distinguished and given forth. Now it was clear, and now rough, as if the contracting and expanding of the elemental processes blended harmoniously (in its notes). Those notes then flowed away in waves of light, till, as when the hibernating insects first begin to move, I commanded the terrifying crash of thunder. Its end was marked by no formal conclusion, and it began again without any prelude. It seemed to die away, and then it burst into life; it came to a close, and then it rose again.

passages.zh: 女故懼也。
passages.en: So it went on regularly and inexhaustibly, and without the intervention of any pause: it was this which made you afraid.

passages.zh: 吾又奏之以陰陽之和，燭之以日月之明；其聲能短能長，能柔能剛；變化齊一，不主故常；在谷滿谷，在阬滿阬；塗郤守神，以物為量。
passages.en: In the second part (of the performance), I made it describe the harmony of the Yin and Yang, and threw round it the brilliance of the sun and moon. Its notes were now short and now long, now soft and now hard. Their changes, however, were marked by an unbroken unity, though not dominated by a fixed regularity. They filled every valley and ravine; you might shut up every crevice, and guard your spirit (against their entrance), yet there was nothing but gave admission to them.

passages.zh: 其聲揮綽，其名高明。是故鬼神守其幽，日月星辰行其紀。
passages.en: Yea, those notes resounded slowly, and might have been pronounced high and clear. Hence the shades of the dead kept in their obscurity; the sun and moon, and all the stars of the zodiac, pursued their several courses.

passages.zh: 吾止之於有窮，流之於無止。予欲慮之而不能知也，望之而不能見也，逐之而不能及也，儻然立於四虛之道，倚於槁梧而吟。
passages.en: I made (my instruments) leave off, when (the performance) came to an end, and their (echoes) flowed on without stopping. You thought anxiously about it, and were not able to understand it; you looked for it, and were not able to see it; you pursued it, and were not able to reach it. All-amazed, you stood in the way all open around you, and then you leant against an old rotten dryandra-tree and hummed.

passages.zh: 目知窮乎所欲見，力屈乎所欲逐，吾既不及已夫！形充空虛，乃至委蛇。汝委蛇，故怠。
passages.en: The power of your eyes was exhausted by what you wished to see; your strength failed in your desire to pursue it, while I myself could not reach it. Your body was but so much empty vacancy while you endeavoured to retain your self-possession: it was that endeavour which made you weary.

passages.zh: 吾又奏之以無怠之聲，調之以自然之命，故若混逐叢生，林樂而無形；布揮而不曳，幽昏而無聲。
passages.en: In the last part (of the performance), I employed notes which did not have that wearying effect. I blended them together as at the command of spontaneity. Hence they came as if following one another in confusion, like a clump of plants springing from one root, or like the music of a forest produced by no visible form. They spread themselves all around without leaving a trace (of their cause); and seemed to issue from deep obscurity where there was no sound.

passages.zh: 動於無方，居於窈冥；或謂之死，或謂之生；或謂之實，或謂之榮；行流散徙，不主常聲。
passages.en: Their movements came from nowhere; their home was in the deep darkness - conditions which some would call death, and some would call life; some would call the fruit, and some would call (merely) the flower. Those notes, moving and flowing on, separating and shifting, and not following any regular sounds.

passages.zh: 世疑之，稽於聖人。聖也者，達於情而遂於命也。
passages.en: The world might well have doubts about them, and refer them to the judgment of a sage, for the sages understand the nature of this music, and judge in accordance with the prescribed (spontaneity).

passages.zh: 天機不張而五官皆備，此之謂天樂，無言而心說。
passages.en: While the spring of that spontaneity has not been touched, and yet the regulators of the five notes are all prepared - this is what is called the music of Heaven, delighting the mind without the use of words.

passages.zh: 故有焱氏為之頌曰：『聽之不聞其聲，視之不見其形，充滿天地，苞裏六極。』
passages.en: Hence it is said in the eulogy of the Lord of Yan, 'You listen for it, and do not hear its sound; you look for it, and do not perceive its form; it fills heaven and earth; it envelopes all within the universe.'

passages.zh: 汝欲聽之而無接焉，而故惑也。
passages.en: You wished to hear it, but could not take it in; and therefore you were perplexed.

passages.zh: 樂也者，始於懼，懼故祟；吾又次之以怠，怠故遁；卒之於惑，惑故愚；愚故道，道可載而與之俱也。」
passages.en: I performed first the music calculated to awe; and you were frightened as if by a ghostly visitation. I followed it with that calculated to weary; and in your weariness you would have withdrawn. I concluded with that calculated to perplex; and in your perplexity you felt your stupidity. But that stupidity is akin to the Dao; you may with it convey the Dao in your person, and have it (ever) with you.'

passages.zh: 孔子西遊於衛。
passages.en: When Confucius was travelling in the west in Wei, Yan Yuan asked the music-master Jin.

passages.zh: 顏淵問師金，曰：「以夫子之行為奚如？」
passages.en: 'How is it, do you think, with the course of the Master?'

passages.zh: 師金曰：「惜乎，而夫子其窮哉！」
passages.en: The music-master replied, 'Alas! it is all over with your Master!'

passages.zh: 顏淵曰：「何也？」
passages.en: 'How so?' asked Yan Yuan.

passages.zh: 師金曰：「夫芻狗之未陳也，盛以篋衍，巾以文繡，尸祝齊戒以將之；及其已陳也，行者踐其首脊，蘇者取而爨之而已。
passages.en: The music-master said, 'Before the grass-dogs are set forth (at the sacrifice), they are deposited in a box or basket, and wrapt up with elegantly embroidered cloths, while the representative of the dead and the officer of prayer prepare themselves by fasting to present them. After they have been set forth, however, passers-by trample on their heads and backs, and the grass-cutters take and burn them in cooking. That is all they are good for.

passages.zh: 將復取而盛以篋衍，巾以文繡，遊居寢臥其下，彼不得夢，必且數眯焉。
passages.en: If one should again take them, replace them in the box or basket, wrap them up with embroidered cloths, and then in rambling, or abiding at the spot, should go to sleep under them, if he do not get (evil) dreams, he is sure to be often troubled with the nightmare.

passages.zh: 今而夫子，亦取先王已陳芻狗，聚弟子游居寢臥其下。
passages.en: Now here is your Master in the same way taking the grass-dogs, presented by the ancient kings, and leading his disciples to wander or abide and sleep under them.

passages.zh: 故伐樹於宋，削跡於衛，窮於商、周，是非其夢邪？
passages.en: Owing to this, the tree (beneath which they were practising ceremonies) in Sung was cut down; he was obliged to leave Wei; he was reduced to extremities in Shang and Zhou: were not those experiences like having (evil) dreams?

passages.zh: 圍於陳、蔡之間，七日不火食，死生相與鄰，是非其眯邪？
passages.en: He was kept in a state of siege between Chen and Cai, so that for seven days he had no cooked food to eat, and was in a situation between life and death: were not those experiences like the nightmare?

passages.zh: 夫水行莫如用舟，而陸行莫如用車。
passages.en: If you are travelling by water, your best plan is to use a boat; if by land, a carriage.

passages.zh: 以舟之可行於水也而求推之於陸，則沒世不行尋常。
passages.en: Take a boat, which will go (easily) along on the water, and try to push it along on the land, and all your lifetime it will not go so much as a fathom or two.

passages.zh: 古今非水陸與？周、魯非舟車與？今蘄行周於魯，是猶推舟於陸也，勞而無功，身必有殃。
passages.en: Are not ancient time and the present time like the water and the dry land? and are not Zhou and Lu like the boat and the carriage? To seek now to practise (the old ways of) Zhou in Lu is like pushing along a boat on the dry land. It is only a toilsome labour, and has no success; he who does so is sure to meet with calamity.

passages.zh: 彼未知夫無方之傳，應物而不窮者也。
passages.en: He has not learned that in handing down the arts (of one time) he is sure to be reduced to extremity in endeavouring to adapt them to the conditions (of another).

passages.zh: 且子獨不見夫桔槔者乎？引之則俯，舍之則仰。彼，人之所引，非引人也，故俯仰而不得罪於人。
passages.en: And have you not seen the working of a shadoof? When (the rope of) it is pulled, it bends down; and when it is let go, it rises up. It is pulled by a man, and does not pull the man; and so, whether it bends down or rises up, it commits no offence against the man.

passages.zh: 故夫三皇、五帝之禮義法度，不矜於同而矜於治。
passages.en: In the same way the rules of propriety, righteousness, laws, and measures of the three Huangs and five Dis derived their excellence, not from their being the same as those of the present day, but from their (aptitude for) government.

passages.zh: 故譬三皇、五帝之禮義法度，其猶柤梨橘柚邪！其味相反，而皆可於口。
passages.en: We may compare them to haws, pears, oranges, and pummeloes, which are different in flavour, but all suitable to be eaten.

passages.zh: 故禮義法度者，應時而變者也。
passages.en: Just so it is that the rules of propriety, righteousness, laws, and measures, change according to the time.

passages.zh: 今取猨狙而衣以周公之服，彼必齕齧挽裂，盡去而後慊。觀古今之異，猶猨狙之異乎周公也。
passages.en: If now you take a monkey, and dress it in the robes of the duke of Zhou, it will bite and tear them, and will not be satisfied till it has got rid of them altogether. And if you look at the difference between antiquity and the present time it is as great as that between the monkey and the duke of Zhou.

passages.zh: 故西施病心而矉其里，其里之醜人見而美之，歸亦捧心而矉其里。
passages.en: In the same way, when Xi Shi was troubled in mind, she would knit her brows and frown on all in her neighbourhood. An ugly woman of the neighbourhood, seeing and admiring her beauty, went home, and also laying her hands on her heart proceeded to stare and frown on all around her.

passages.zh: 其里之富人見之，堅閉門而不出；貧人見之，挈妻子而去之走。彼知矉美而不知矉之所以美。
passages.en: When the rich people of the village saw her, they shut fast their doors and would not go out; when the poor people saw her, they took their wives and children and ran away from her. The woman knew how to admire the frowning beauty, but she did not know how it was that she, though frowning, was beautiful.

passages.zh: 惜乎！而夫子其窮哉！」
passages.en: Alas! it is indeed all over with your Master!'

passages.zh: 孔子行年五十有一而不聞道，乃南之沛，見老聃。
passages.en: When Confucius was in his fifty-first year, he had not heard of the Dao, and went south to Pei to see Lao Dan.

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「子來乎？吾聞子北方之賢者也，子亦得道乎？」
passages.en: Lao Dan said to him, 'You have come, Sir; have you? I have heard that you are the wisest man of the North; have you also got the Dao?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「未得也。」
passages.en: 'Not yet,' was the reply.

passages.zh: 老子曰：「子惡乎求之哉？」
passages.en: And the other went on, 'How have you sought it?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾求之於度數，五年而未得也。」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'I sought it in measures and numbers, and after five years I had not got it.'

passages.zh: 老子曰：「子又惡乎求之哉？」
passages.en: 'And how then did you seek it?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾求之於陰陽，十有二年而未得。」
passages.en: 'I sought it in the Yin and Yang, and after twelve years I have not found it.'

passages.zh: 老子曰：「然。使道而可獻，則人莫不獻之於其君；使道而可進，則人莫不進之於其親；使道而可以告人，則人莫不告其兄弟；使道而可以與人，則人莫不與其子孫。
passages.en: Laozi said, 'Just so! If the Dao could be presented (to another), men would all present it to their rulers; if it could be served up (to others), men would all serve it up to their parents; if it could be told (to others), men would all tell it to their brothers; if it could be given to others, men would all give it to their sons and grandsons.

passages.zh: 然而不可者，無佗也，中無主而不止，外無正而不行。
passages.en: The reason why it cannot be transmitted is no other but this - that if, within, there be not the presiding principle, it will not remain there, and if, outwardly, there be not the correct obedience, it will not be carried out.

passages.zh: 由中出者，不受於外，聖人不出；由外入者，無主於中，聖人不隱。
passages.en: When that which is given out from the mind (in possession of it) is not received by the mind without, the sage will not give it out; and when, entering in from without, there is no power in the receiving mind to entertain it, the sage will not permit it to lie hid there.

passages.zh: 名，公器也，不可多取。
passages.en: Fame is a possession common to all; we should not seek to have much of it.

passages.zh: 仁義，先王之蘧廬也，止可以一宿而不可以久處，覯而多責。
passages.en: Benevolence and righteousness were as the lodging-houses of the former kings; we should only rest in them for a night, and not occupy them for long. If men see us doing so, they will have much to say against us.

passages.zh: 古之至人，假道於仁，託宿於義，以遊逍遙之虛，食於苟簡之田，立於不貸之圃。
passages.en: The perfect men of old trod the path of benevolence as a path which they borrowed for the occasion, and dwelt in Righteousness as in a lodging which they used for a night. Thus they rambled in the vacancy of Untroubled Ease, found their food in the fields of Indifference, and stood in the gardens which they had not borrowed.

passages.zh: 逍遙，無為也；苟簡，易養也；不貸，無出也。古者謂是采真之遊。
passages.en: Untroubled Ease requires the doing of nothing; Indifference is easily supplied with nourishment; not borrowing needs no outlay. The ancients called this the Enjoyment that Collects the True.

passages.zh: 以富為是者，不能讓祿；以顯為是者，不能讓名；親權者，不能與人柄。
passages.en: Those who think that wealth is the proper thing for them cannot give up their revenues; those who seek distinction cannot give up the thought of fame; those who cleave to power cannot give the handle of it to others.

passages.zh: 操之則慄，舍之則悲，而一無所鑒，以闚其所不休者，是天之戮民也。
passages.en: While they hold their grasp of those things, they are afraid (of losing them). When they let them go, they are grieved; and they will not look at a single example, from which they might perceive the (folly) of their restless pursuits: such men are under the doom of Heaven.

passages.zh: 怨、恩、取、與、諫、教、生、殺，八者，正之器也，唯循大變無所湮者，為能用之。
passages.en: Hatred and kindness; taking and giving; reproof and instruction; death and life: these eight things are instruments of rectification, but only those are able to use them who do not obstinately refuse to comply with their great changes.

passages.zh: 故曰：正者，正也。其心以為不然者，天門弗開矣。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'Correction is Rectification.' When the minds of some do not acknowledge this, it is because the gate of Heaven (in them) has not been opened.'

passages.zh: 孔子見老聃而語仁義。
passages.en: At an interview with Lao Dan, Confucius spoke to him of benevolence and righteousness.

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「夫播穅眯目，則天地四方易位矣；蚊虻噆膚，則通昔不寐矣。
passages.en: Lao Dan said, 'If you winnow chaff, and the dust gets into your eyes, then the places of heaven and earth and of the four cardinal points are all changed to you. If musquitoes or gadflies puncture your skin, it will keep you all the night from sleeping.

passages.zh: 夫仁義憯然，乃憤吾心，亂莫大焉。
passages.en: But this painful iteration of benevolence and righteousness excites my mind and produces in it the greatest confusion.

passages.zh: 吾子使天下無失其朴，吾子亦放風而動，總德而立矣，又奚傑然若負建鼓而求亡子者邪？
passages.en: If you, Sir, would cause men not to lose their natural simplicity, and if you would also imitate the wind in its (unconstrained) movements, and stand forth in all the natural attributes belonging to you!-- why must you use so much energy, and carry a great drum to seek for the son whom you have lost?

passages.zh: 夫鵠不日浴而白，烏不日黔而黑。黑白之朴，不足以為辯；名譽之觀，不足以為廣。
passages.en: The snow-goose does not bathe every day to make itself white, nor the crow blacken itself every day to make itself black. The natural simplicity of their black and white does not afford any ground for controversy; and the fame and praise which men like to contemplate do not make them greater than they naturally are.

passages.zh: 泉涸，魚相與處於陸，相呴以溼，相濡以沫，不若相忘於江湖。」
passages.en: When the springs (supplying the pools) are dried up, the fishes huddle together on the dry land. Than that they should moisten one another there by their gasping, and keep one another wet by their milt, it would be better for them to forget one another in the rivers and lakes.'

passages.zh: 孔子見老聃歸，三日不談。
passages.en: From this interview with Lao Dan, Confucius returned home, and for three days did not speak.

passages.zh: 弟子問曰：「夫子見老聃，亦將何歸哉？」
passages.en: His disciples (then) asked him, saying, 'Master, you have seen Lao Dan; in what way might you admonish and correct him?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「吾乃今於是乎見龍。龍合而成體，散而成章，乘乎雲氣而養乎陰陽。予口張而不能嗋，予又何規老聃哉！」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'In him (I may say) that I have now seen the dragon. The dragon coils itself up, and there is its body; it unfolds itself and becomes the dragon complete. It rides on the cloudy air, and is nourished by the Yin and Yang. I kept my mouth open, and was unable to shut it - how could I admonish and correct Lao Dan?'
