passages.zh: 子貢曰：「然則人固有尸居而龍見，雷聲而淵默，發動如天地者乎？賜亦可得而觀乎？」
passages.en: Zi-gong said, 'So then, can (this) man indeed sit still as a representative of the dead, and then appear as the dragon? Can his voice resound as thunder, when he is profoundly still? Can he exhibit himself in his movements like heaven and earth? May I, Ci, also get to see him?'

passages.zh: 遂以孔子聲見老聃。
passages.en: Accordingly with a message from Confucius he went to see Lao Dan.

passages.zh: 老聃方將倨堂而應微曰：「予年運而往矣，子將何以戒我乎？」
passages.en: Lao Dan was then about to answer (his salutation) haughtily in the hall, but he said in a low voice, 'My years have rolled on and are passing away, what do you, Sir, wish to admonish me about?'

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「夫三王、五帝之治天下不同，其係聲名一也。而先生獨以為非聖人，如何哉？」
passages.en: Zi-gong replied, 'The Three Kings and Five Dis ruled the world not in the same way, but the fame that has accrued to them is the same. How is it that you alone consider that they were not sages?'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「小子少進！子何以謂不同？」
passages.en: 'Come forward a little, my son. Why do you say that (their government) was not the same?'

passages.zh: 對曰：「堯授舜，舜授禹，禹用力而湯用兵，文王順紂而不敢逆，武王逆紂而不肯順，故曰不同。」
passages.en: 'Yao,' was the reply, 'gave the kingdom to Shun, and Shun gave it to Yu. Yu had recourse to his strength, and Tang to the force of arms. King Wen was obedient to Zhou (-xin), and did not dare to rebel; king Wu rebelled against Zhou, and would not submit to him. And I say that their methods were not the same.'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「小子少進！余語汝三皇、五帝之治天下。
passages.en: Lao Dan said, 'Come a little more forward, my son, and I will tell you how the Three Huangs and the Five Dis ruled the world.

passages.zh: 黃帝之治天下，使民心一，民有其親死不哭而民不非也。
passages.en: Huang-Di ruled it, so as to make the minds of the people all conformed to the One (simplicity). If the parents of one of them died, and he did not wail, no one blamed him.

passages.zh: 堯之治天下，使民心親，民有為其親殺其殺而民不非也。
passages.en: Yao ruled it so as to cause the hearts of the people to cherish relative affection. If any, however, made the observances on the death of other members of their kindred less than those for their parents, no one blamed them.

passages.zh: 舜之治天下，使民心競，民孕婦十月生子，子生五月而能言，不至乎孩而始誰，則人始有夭矣。
passages.en: Shun ruled it, so as to produce a feeling of rivalry in the minds of the people. Their wives gave birth to their children in the tenth month of their pregnancy, but those children could speak at five months; and before they were three years old, they began to call people by their surnames and names. Then it was that men began to die prematurely.

passages.zh: 禹之治天下，使民心變，人有心而兵有順，殺盜非殺，人自為種而天下耳，是以天下大駭，儒、墨皆起。
passages.en: Yu ruled it, so as to cause the minds of the people to become changed. Men's minds became scheming, and they used their weapons as if they might legitimately do so, (saying that they were) killing thieves and not killing other men. The people formed themselves into different combinations - so it was throughout the kingdom. Everywhere there was great consternation, and then arose the Literati and (the followers of) Mo (Di).

passages.zh: 其作始有倫，而今乎婦女，何言哉！
passages.en: From them came first the doctrine of the relationships (of society); and what can be said of the now prevailing customs (in the marrying of) wives and daughters?

passages.zh: 余語汝：三皇、五帝之治天下，名曰治之，而亂莫甚焉。
passages.en: I tell you that the rule of the Three Kings and Five Dis may be called by that name, but nothing can be greater than the disorder which it produced.

passages.zh: 三皇之知，上悖日月之明，下睽山川之精，中墮四時之施。其知憯於蠣蠆之尾，鮮規之獸，莫得安其性命之情者，而猶自以為聖人，不可恥乎？其無恥也！」
passages.en: The wisdom of the Three Kings was opposed to the brightness of the sun and moon above, contrary to the exquisite purity of the hills and streams below, and subversive of the beneficent gifts of the four seasons between. Their wisdom has been more fatal than the sting of a scorpion or the bite of a dangerous beast. Unable to rest in the true attributes of their nature and constitution, they still regarded themselves as sages: was it not a thing to be ashamed of? But they were shameless.'

passages.zh: 子貢蹴蹴然立不安。
passages.en: Zi-gong stood quite disconcerted and ill at ease.

passages.zh: 孔子謂老聃曰：「丘治《詩》、《書》、《禮》、《樂》、《易》、《春秋》六經，自以為久矣，孰知其故矣，以奸者七十二君，論先王之道而明周、召之跡，一君無所鉤用。甚矣夫！人之難說也，道之難明邪！」
passages.en: Confucius said to Lao Dan, 'I have occupied myself with the Shi, the Shu, the Li, the Yue, the Yi, and the Chun Qiu, those six Books, for what I myself consider a long time, and am thoroughly acquainted with their contents. With seventy-two rulers, all offenders against the right, I have discoursed about the ways of the former kings, and set forth the examples (of the dukes of Zhou and Shao); and not one of them has adopted (my views) and put them in practice: how very difficult it is to prevail on such men, and to make clear the path to be pursued!'

passages.zh: 老子曰：「幸矣，子之不遇治世之君也！
passages.en: Laozi replied, 'It is fortunate that you have not met with a ruler fitted to rule the age.

passages.zh: 夫六經，先王之陳跡也，豈其所以跡哉！今子之所言，猶迹也。
passages.en: Those six writings are a description of the vestiges left by the former kings, but do not tell how they made such vestiges; and what you, Sir, speak about are still only the vestiges.

passages.zh: 夫迹，履之所出，而迹豈履哉！
passages.en: But vestiges are the prints left by the shoes - are they the shoes that produced them?

passages.zh: 夫白鶂之相視，眸子不運而風化；蟲，雄鳴於上風，雌應於下風而風化。類自為雌雄，故風化。
passages.en: A pair of white herons look at each other with pupils that do not move, and impregnation takes place; the male insect emits its buzzing sound in the air above, and the female responds from the air below, and impregnation takes place; the creatures called lei are both male and female, and each individual breeds of itself.

passages.zh: 性不可易，命不可變，時不可止，道不可壅。
passages.en: The nature cannot be altered; the conferred constitution cannot be changed; the march of the seasons cannot be arrested; the Dao cannot be stopped.

passages.zh: 苟得其道，無自而不可；失焉者，無自而可。」
passages.en: If you get the Dao, there is no effect that cannot be produced; if you miss it, there is no effect that can.'

passages.zh: 孔子不出三月，復見，曰：「丘得之矣。烏鵲孺，魚傅沫，細要者化，有弟而兄啼。
passages.en: Confucius (after this) did not go out, till at the end of three months he went again to see Lao Dan, and said, 'I have got it. Ravens produce their young by hatching; fishes by the communication of their milt; the small-waisted wasp by transformation; when a younger brother comes, the elder weeps.

passages.zh: 久矣夫，丘不與化為人！不與化為人，安能化人！」
passages.en: Long is it that I have not played my part in harmony with these processes of transformation. But as I did not play my part in harmony with such transformation, how could I transform men?'

passages.zh: 老子曰：「可。丘得之矣。」
passages.en: Laozi said, 'You will do. Qiu, you have found the Dao.'

passages.zh: 刻意尚行，離世異俗，高論怨誹，為亢而已矣，此山谷之士，非世之人，枯槁赴淵者之所好也。
passages.en: Ingrained ideas and a high estimate of their own conduct; leaving the world, and pursuing uncommon ways; talking loftily and in resentful disparagement of others - all this is simply symptomatic of arrogance. This is what scholars who betake themselves to the hills and valleys, who are always blaming the world, and who stand aloof like withered trees, or throw themselves into deep pools, are fond of.

passages.zh: 語仁義忠信，恭儉推讓，為修而已矣，此平世之士，教誨之人，遊居學者之所好也。
passages.en: Discoursing of benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and good faith; being humble and frugal, self-forgetful and courteous - all this is simply symptomatic of (self-)cultivation. This is what scholars who wish to tranquillise the world, teachers and instructors, men who pursue their studies at home and abroad, are fond of.

passages.zh: 語大功，立大名，禮君臣，正上下，為治而已矣，此朝廷之士，尊主強國之人，致功并兼者之所好也。
passages.en: Discoursing of their great merit and making a great name for themselves; insisting on the ceremonies between ruler and minister; and rectifying the relations between high and low - all this shows their one object to be the promotion of government. This is what officers of the court, men who honour their lord and would strengthen the state and who would do their utmost to incorporate other states with their own, are fond of.

passages.zh: 就藪澤，處閒曠，釣魚閒處，無為而已矣，此江海之士，避世之人，閒暇者之所好也。
passages.en: Resorting to marshes and lakes; dwelling in solitary places; occupying themselves with angling and living at ease - all this shows their one object to be to do nothing. This is what gentlemen of the rivers and seas, men who avoid the society of the world and desire to live at leisure, are fond of.

passages.zh: 吹呴呼吸，吐故納新，熊經鳥申，為壽而已矣，此道引之士，養形之人，彭祖壽考者之所好也。
passages.en: Blowing and breathing with open mouth; inhaling and exhaling the breath; expelling the old breath and taking in new; passing their time like the (dormant) bear, and stretching and twisting (the neck) like a bird - all this simply shows the desire for longevity. This is what the scholars who manipulate their breath, and the men who nourish the body and wish to live as long as Peng Zu are fond of.

passages.zh: 若夫不刻意而高，無仁義而修，無功名而治，無江海而閒，不道引而壽，無不忘也，無不有也，澹然無極而眾美從之，此天地之道，聖人之德也。
passages.en: As to those who have a lofty character without any ingrained ideas; who pursue the path of self-cultivation without benevolence and righteousness; who succeed in government without great services or fame; who enjoy their ease without resorting to the rivers and seas; who attain to longevity without the management (of the breath); who forget all things and yet possess all things; whose placidity is unlimited, while all things to be valued attend them: such men pursue the way of heaven and earth, and display the characteristics of the sages.

passages.zh: 故曰：夫恬惔寂寞，虛無無為，此天地之平而道德之質也。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'Placidity, indifference, silence, quietude, absolute vacancy, and non-action: these are the qualities which maintain the level of heaven and earth and are the substance of the Dao and its characteristics.'

passages.zh: 故曰：聖人休，休焉則平易矣，平易則恬惔矣。
passages.en: In accordance with this it is said, 'The sage is entirely restful, and so (his mind) is evenly balanced and at ease. This even balance and ease appears in his placidity and indifference.

passages.zh: 平易恬惔，則憂患不能入，邪氣不能襲，故其德全而神不虧。
passages.en: In this state of even balance and ease, of placidity and indifference, anxieties and evils do not find access to him, no depraving influence can take him by surprise; his virtue is complete, and his spirit continues unimpaired.'

passages.zh: 故曰：聖人之生也天行，其死也物化；靜而與陰同德，動而與陽同波；不為福先，不為禍始；感而後應，迫而後動，不得已而後起。
passages.en: Therefore it is (also) said, 'The life of the sage is (like) the action of Heaven; and his death is the transformation common to (all) things. In his stillness his virtue is the same as that of the Yin, and in movement his diffusiveness is like that of the Yang. He does not take the initiative in producing either happiness or calamity. He responds to the influence acting on him, and moves as he feels the pressure. He rises to act only when he is obliged to do so.

passages.zh: 去知與故，循天之理，故無天災，無物累，無人非，無鬼責。
passages.en: He discards wisdom and the memories of the past; he follows the lines of his Heaven (-given nature); and therefore he suffers no calamity from Heaven, no involvement from things, no blame from men, and no reproof from the spirits of the dead.

passages.zh: 其生若浮，其死若休；不思慮，不豫謀；光矣而不耀，信矣而不期；其寢不夢，其覺無憂；其神純粹，其魂不罷。
passages.en: His life seems to float along; his death seems to be a resting. He does not indulge any anxious doubts; he does not lay plans beforehand. His light is without display; his good faith is without previous arrangement. His sleep is untroubled by dreams; his waking is followed by no sorrows. His spirit is guileless and pure; his soul is not subject to weariness.

passages.zh: 虛無恬惔，乃合天德。
passages.en: Vacant and without self-assertion, placid and indifferent, he agrees with the virtue of Heaven.'

passages.zh: 故曰：悲樂者，德之邪；喜怒者，道之過；好惡者，德之失。
passages.en: Therefore it is said (further), 'Sadness and pleasure show a depraving element in the virtue (of those who feel them); joy and anger show some error in their course; love and hatred show a failure of their virtue.

passages.zh: 故心不憂樂，德之至也；一而不變，靜之至也；無所於忤，虛之至也；不與物交，惔之至也；無所於逆，粹之至也。
passages.en: Hence for the mind to be free from sorrow and pleasure is the perfection of virtue; to be of one mind that does not change is the perfection of quietude; to be conscious of no opposition is the perfection of vacancy; to have no intercourse with (external) things is the perfection of indifference; and to have no rebellious dissatisfactions is the perfection of purity.'

passages.zh: 故曰：形勞而不休則弊，精用而不已則勞，勞則竭。
passages.en: Therefore it is said (still further), 'If the body be toiled, and does not rest, it becomes worn out; if the spirit be used without cessation, it becomes toiled; and when toiled, it becomes exhausted.

passages.zh: 水之性，不雜則清，莫動則平，鬱閉而不流，亦不能清，天德之象也。
passages.en: It is the nature of water, when free from admixture, to be clear, and, when not agitated, to be level; while if obstructed and not allowed to flow, it cannot preserve its clearness - being an image of the virtue of Heaven.'

passages.zh: 故曰：純粹而不雜，靜一而不變，惔而無為，動而以天行，此養神之道也。
passages.en: Hence it is said (once again), 'To be guileless and pure, and free from all admixture; to be still and uniform, without undergoing any change; to be indifferent and do nothing; to move and yet to act like Heaven: this is the way to nourish the spirit.'

passages.zh: 夫有干、越之劍者，柙而藏之，不敢用也，寶之至也。
passages.en: Now he who possesses a sword made at Gan-Yue preserves it carefully in a box, and does not dare to use it - it is considered the perfection of valuable swords.

passages.zh: 精神四達並流，無所不極，上際於天，下蟠於地，化育萬物，不可為象，其名為同帝。
passages.en: But the human spirit goes forth in all directions, flowing on without limit, reaching to heaven above, and wreathing round the earth beneath. It transforms and nourishes all things, and cannot be represented by any form. Its name is 'the Divinity (in man).'

passages.zh: 純素之道，惟神是守，守而勿失，與神為一，一之精通，合於天倫。
passages.en: It is only the path of pure simplicity which guards and preserves the Spirit. When this path is preserved and not lost, it becomes one with the Spirit; and in this ethereal amalgamation, it acts in harmony with the orderly operation of Heaven.

passages.zh: 野語有之曰：「眾人重利，廉士重名，賢人尚志，聖人貴精。」
passages.en: There is the vulgar saying, 'The multitude of men consider gain to be the most important thing; pure scholars, fame; those who are wise and able value their ambition; the sage prizes essential purity.'

passages.zh: 故素也者，謂其無所與雜也；純也者，謂其不虧其神也。
passages.en: Therefore simplicity is the denomination of that in which there is no admixture; purity of that in which the spirit is not impaired.

passages.zh: 能體純素，謂之真人。
passages.en: It is he who can embody simplicity and purity whom we call the True Man.

passages.zh: 繕性於俗，俗學以求復其初，滑欲於俗，思以求致其明，謂之蔽蒙之民。
passages.en: Those who would correct their nature by means of the vulgar learning, seeking to restore it to its original condition, and those who would regulate their desires, by the vulgar ways of thinking, seeking thereby to carry their intelligence to perfection, must be pronounced to be deluded and ignorant people.

passages.zh: 古之治道者，以恬養知；知生而無以知為也，謂之以知養恬。
passages.en: The ancients who regulated the Dao nourished their faculty of knowledge by their placidity, and all through life abstained from employing that faculty in action - they must be pronounced to have (thus also) nourished their placidity by their knowledge.

passages.zh: 知與恬交相養，而和理出其性。
passages.en: When the faculty of knowledge and the placidity (thus) blend together, and they nourish each other, then from the nature there come forth harmony and orderly method.

passages.zh: 夫德，和也；道，理也。
passages.en: The attributes (of the Dao) constitute the harmony; the Dao (itself) secures the orderly method.

passages.zh: 德無不容，仁也；道無不理，義也；義明而物親，忠也；中純實而反乎情，樂也；信行容體而順乎文，禮也。
passages.en: When the attributes appear in a universal practice of forbearance, we have Benevolence; when the path is all marked by orderly method, we have Righteousness; when the righteousness is clearly manifested, and (all) things are regarded with affection, we have Leal-heartedness; when the (heart's) core is thus (pure) and real, and carried back to its (proper) qualities, we have Music; when this sincerity appears in all the range of the capacity, and its demonstrations are in accordance with what is elegant, we have Ceremony.

passages.zh: 禮樂遍行，則天下亂矣。
passages.en: If ceremonies and Music are carried out in an imperfect and one-sided manner, the world is thrown into confusion.

passages.zh: 彼正而蒙己德，德則不冒，冒則物必失其性也。
passages.en: When men would rectify others, and their own virtue is beclouded, it is not sufficient to extend itself to them. If an attempt be made so to extend it, they also will lose their (proper) nature.

passages.zh: 古之人在混芒之中，與一世而得澹漠焉。
passages.en: The men of old, while the chaotic condition was yet undeveloped, shared the placid tranquillity which belonged to the whole world.

passages.zh: 當是時也，陰陽和靜，鬼神不擾，四時得節，萬物不傷，群生不夭，人雖有知，無所用之，此之謂至一。
passages.en: At that time the Yin and Yang were harmonious and still; their resting and movement proceeded without any disturbance; the four seasons had their definite times; not a single thing received any injury, and no living being came to a premature end. Men might be possessed of (the faculty of) knowledge, but they had no occasion for its use. This was what is called the state of Perfect Unity.

passages.zh: 當是時也，莫之為而常自然。
passages.en: At this time, there was no action on the part of any one, but a constant manifestation of spontaneity.

passages.zh: 逮德下衰，及燧人、伏羲始為天下，是故順而不一。
passages.en: This condition (of excellence) deteriorated and decayed, till Sui-ren and Fu-xi arose and commenced their administration of the world; on which came a compliance (with their methods), but the state of unity was lost.

passages.zh: 德又下衰，及神農、黃帝始為天下，是故安而不順。
passages.en: The condition going on to deteriorate and decay, Shen Nong and Huang-Di arose, and took the administration of the world, on which (the people) rested (in their methods), but did not themselves comply with them.

passages.zh: 德又下衰，及唐、虞始為天下，興治化之流，澆淳散朴，離道以善，險德以行，然後去性而從於心。
passages.en: Still the deterioration and decay continued till the lords of Tang and Yu began to administer the world. These introduced the method of governing by transformation, resorting to the stream (instead of to the spring), thus vitiating the purity and destroying the simplicity (of the nature). They left the Dao, and substituted the Good for it, and pursued the course of Haphazard Virtue. After this they forsook their nature and followed (the promptings of) their minds.

passages.zh: 心與心識知而不足以定天下，然後附之以文，益之以博。
passages.en: One mind and another associated their knowledge, but were unable to give rest to the world. Then they added to this knowledge (external and) elegant forms, and went on to make these more and more numerous.

passages.zh: 文滅質，博溺心，然後民始惑亂，無以反其性情而復其初。
passages.en: The forms extinguished the (primal) simplicity, till the mind was drowned by their multiplicity. After this the people began to be perplexed and disordered, and had no way by which they might return to their true nature, and bring back their original condition.

passages.zh: 由是觀之，世喪道矣，道喪世矣。
passages.en: Looking at the subject from this point of view, we see how the world lost the (proper) course, and how the course (which it took) only led it further astray.

passages.zh: 世與道交相喪也。
passages.en: The world and the Way, when they came together, being (thus) lost to each other.

passages.zh: 道之人何由興乎世，世亦何由興乎道哉！
passages.en: How could the men of the Way make themselves conspicuous in the world? and how could the world rise to an appreciation of the Way?

passages.zh: 道無以興乎世，世無以興乎道，雖聖人不在山林之中，其德隱矣。
passages.en: Since the Way had no means to make itself conspicuous in the world, and the world had no means of rising to an appreciation of the Way, though sagely men might not keep among the hills and forests, their virtue was hidden - hidden, but not because they themselves sought to hide it.

passages.zh: 隱，故不自隱。
passages.en: Those whom the ancients called 'Retired Scholars' did not conceal their persons, and not allow themselves to be seen.

passages.zh: 古之所謂隱士者，非伏其身而弗見也，非閉其言而不出也，非藏其知而不發也，時命大謬也。
passages.en: They did not shut up their words, and refuse to give utterance to them; they did not hide away their knowledge, and refuse to bring it forth. The conditions laid on them by the times were very much awry.

passages.zh: 當時命而大行乎天下，則反一無跡；不當時命而大窮乎天下，則深根寧極而待。
passages.en: If the conditions of the times had allowed them to act in the world on a great scale, they would have brought back the state of unity without any trace being perceived (of how they did so), When those conditions shut them up entirely from such action, they struck their roots deeper (in themselves), were perfectly still and waited.

passages.zh: 此存身之道也。
passages.en: It was thus that they preserved (the Way in) their own persons.

passages.zh: 古之行身者，不以辯飾知，不以知窮天下，不以知窮德，危然處其所而反其性，己又何為哉！
passages.en: The ancients who preserved (the Way in) their own persons did not try by sophistical reasonings to gloss over their knowledge; they did not seek to embrace (everything in) the world in their knowledge, nor to comprehend all the virtues in it. Solitary and trembling they remained where they were, and sought the restoration of their nature.

passages.zh: 道固不小行，德固不小識。
passages.en: What had they to do with any further action? The Way indeed is not to be pursued, nor (all) its characteristics to be known on a small scale.

passages.zh: 小識傷德，小行傷道。
passages.en: A little knowledge is injurious to those characteristics; small doings are injurious to the Way.

passages.zh: 故曰：正己而已矣。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'They simply rectified themselves.'

passages.zh: 樂全之謂得志。
passages.en: Complete enjoyment is what is meant by 'the Attainment of the Aim.'

passages.zh: 古之所謂得志者，非軒冕之謂也，謂其無以益其樂而已矣。
passages.en: What was anciently called 'the Attainment of the Aim' did not mean the getting of carriages and coronets; it simply meant that nothing more was needed for their enjoyment.

passages.zh: 今之所謂得志者，軒冕之謂也。
passages.en: Now-a-days what is called 'the Attainment of the Aim' means the getting of carriages and coronets.

passages.zh: 軒冕在身，非性命也，物之儻來，寄者也。
passages.en: But carriages and coronets belong to the body; they do not affect the nature as it is constituted. When such things happen to come, it is but for a time; being but for a time, their coming cannot be obstructed and their going cannot be stopped.

passages.zh: 寄之，其來不可圉，其去不可止。
passages.en: Therefore we should not because of carriages and coronets indulge our aims, nor because of distress and straitness resort to the vulgar (learning and thinking).

passages.zh: 故不為軒冕肆志，不為窮約趨俗，其樂彼與此同，故無憂而已矣。
passages.en: The one of these conditions and the other may equally conduce to our enjoyment, which is simply to be free from anxiety.

passages.zh: 今寄去則不樂，由是觀之，雖樂，未嘗不荒也。
passages.en: If now the departure of what is transient takes away one's enjoyment, this view shows that what enjoyment it had given was worthless.

passages.zh: 故曰：喪己於物，失性於俗者，謂之倒置之民。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'They who lose themselves in their pursuit of things, and lose their nature in their study of what is vulgar, must be pronounced people who turn things upside down.'

passages.zh: 秋水時至，百川灌河，涇流之大，兩涘渚崖之間，不辯牛馬。
passages.en: The time of the autumnal floods was come, and the hundred streams were all discharging themselves into the He. Its current was greatly swollen, so that across its channel from bank to bank one could not distinguish an ox from a horse.

passages.zh: 於是焉河伯欣然自喜，以天下之美為盡在己。
passages.en: On this the (Spirit-) earl of the He laughed with delight, thinking that all the beauty of the world was to be found in his charge.

passages.zh: 順流而東行，至於北海，東面而視，不見水端，於是焉河伯始旋其面目，望洋向若而歎，曰：「野語有之曰『聞道百，以為莫己若』者，我之謂也。
passages.en: Along the course of the river he walked east till he came to the North Sea, over which he looked, with his face to the east, without being able to see where its waters began. Then he began to turn his face round, looked across the expanse, (as if he were) confronting Ruo, and said with a sigh, 'What the vulgar saying expresses about him who has learned a hundred points (of the Dao), and thinks that there is no one equal to himself, was surely spoken of me.

passages.zh: 且夫我嘗聞少仲尼之聞而輕伯夷之義者，始吾弗信，今我睹子之難窮也，吾非至於子之門則殆矣，吾長見笑於大方之家。」
passages.en: And moreover, I have heard parties making little of the knowledge of Zhongni and the righteousness of Bo-yi, and at first I did not believe them. Now I behold the all-but-boundless extent (of your realms). If I had not come to your gate, I should have been in danger (of continuing in my ignorance), and been laughed at for long in the schools of our great System.'

passages.zh: 北海若曰：「井蛙不可以語於海者，拘於虛也；夏蟲不可以語於冰者，篤於時也；曲士不可以語於道者，束於教也。
passages.en: Ruo, (the Spirit-lord) of the Northern Sea, said, 'A frog in a well cannot be talked with about the sea - he is confined to the limits of his hole. An insect of the summer cannot be talked with about ice - it knows nothing beyond its own season. A scholar of limited views cannot be talked with about the Dao - he is bound by the teaching (which he has received).

passages.zh: 今爾出於崖涘，觀於大海，乃知爾醜，爾將可與語大理矣。
passages.en: Now you have come forth from between your banks, and beheld the great sea. You have come to know your own ignorance and inferiority, and are in the way of being fitted to be talked with about great principles.

passages.zh: 天下之水，莫大於海，萬川歸之，不知何時止而不盈；尾閭泄之，不知何時已而不虛；春秋不變，水旱不知。
passages.en: Of all the waters under heaven there are none so great as the sea. A myriad streams flow into it without ceasing, and yet it is not filled; and afterwards it discharges them (also) without ceasing, and yet it is not emptied. In spring and in autumn it undergoes no change; it takes no notice of floods or of drought.

passages.zh: 此其過江河之流，不可為量數。
passages.en: Its superiority over such streams even as the Jiang and the He cannot be told by measures or numbers.

passages.zh: 而吾未嘗以此自多者，自以比形於天地而受氣於陰陽，吾在天地之間，猶小石小木之在大山也，方存乎見少，又奚以自多！
passages.en: And that I have never, notwithstanding this, made much of myself, is because I compare my own bodily form with (the greatness of) heaven and earth, and (remember that) I have received my breath from the Yin and Yang. Between heaven and earth I am but as a small stone or a small tree on a great hill. So long as I see myself to be thus small, how should I make much of myself?

passages.zh: 計四海之在天地之間也，不似礨空之在大澤乎？
passages.en: I estimate all within the four seas, compared with the space between heaven and earth, to be not so large as that occupied by a pile of stones in a large marsh!

passages.zh: 計中國之在海內，不似稊米之在大倉乎？
passages.en: I estimate our Middle States, compared with the space between the four seas, to be smaller than a single little grain of rice in a great granary!

passages.zh: 號物之數謂之萬，人處一焉；人卒九州，穀食之所生，舟車之所通，人處一焉。
passages.en: When we would set forth the number of things (in existence), we speak of them as myriads; and man is only one of them. Men occupy all the nine provinces; but of all whose life is maintained by grain-food, wherever boats and carriages reach, men form only one portion.

passages.zh: 此其比萬物也，不似豪末之在於馬體乎？
passages.en: Thus compared with the myriads of things, they are not equal to a single fine hair on the body of a horse.

passages.zh: 五帝之所連，三王之所爭，仁人之所憂，任士之所勞，盡此矣。
passages.en: Within this range are comprehended all (the territories) which the five Dis received in succession from one another; all which the royal founders of the three dynasties contended for; all which excited the anxiety of Benevolent men; and all which men in office have toiled for.

passages.zh: 伯夷辭之以為名，仲尼語之以為博，此其自多也，不似爾向之自多於水乎？」
passages.en: Bo-yi was accounted famous for declining (to share in its government), and Zhongni was accounted great because of the lessons which he addressed to it. They acted as they did, making much of themselves - therein like you who a little time ago did so of yourself because of your (volume of) water!'

passages.zh: 河伯曰：「然則吾大天地而小毫末可乎？」
passages.en: The earl of the He said, 'Well then, may I consider heaven and earth as (the ideal of) what is great, and the point of a hair as that of what is small?'

passages.zh: 北海若曰：「否。
passages.en: Ruo of the Northern Sea replied, 'No.

passages.zh: 夫物，量無窮，時無止，分無常，終始無故。
passages.en: The (different) capacities of things are illimitable; time never stops, (but is always moving on); man's lot is ever changing; the end and the beginning of things never occur (twice) in the same way.

passages.zh: 是故大知觀於遠近，故小而不寡，大而不多，知量無窮；證曏今故，故遙而不悶，掇而不跂，知時無止；察乎盈虛，故得而不喜，失而不憂，知分之無常也；明乎坦塗，故生而不說，死而不禍，知終始之不可故也。
passages.en: Therefore men of great wisdom, looking at things far off or near at hand, do not think them insignificant for being small, nor much of them for being great: knowing how capacities differ illimitably. They appeal with intelligence to things of ancient and recent occurrence, without being troubled by the remoteness of the former, or standing on tiptoe to lay hold of the latter: knowing that time never stops in its course. They examine with discrimination (cases of) fulness and of want, not overjoyed by success, nor disheartened by failure: knowing the inconstancy of man's lot. They know the plain and quiet path (in which things proceed), therefore they are not overjoyed to live, nor count it a calamity to die: the end and the beginning of things never occurring (twice) in the same way.

passages.zh: 計人之所知，不若其所不知；其生之時，不若未生之時。
passages.en: We must reckon that what men know is not so much as what they do not know, and that the time since they were born is not so long as that which elapsed before they were born.

passages.zh: 以其至小，求窮其至大之域，是故迷亂而不能自得也。
passages.en: When they take that which is most small and try to fill with it the dimensions of what is most great, this leads to error and confusion, and they cannot attain their end.

passages.zh: 由此觀之，又何以知毫末之足以定至細之倪！
passages.en: Looking at the subject in this way, how can you know that the point of a hair is sufficient to determine the minuteness of what is most small, or that heaven and earth are sufficient to complete the dimensions of what is most large?'

passages.zh: 又何以知天地之足以窮至大之域！」
河伯曰：「世之議者皆曰：『至精無形，至大不可圍。』是信情乎？」
passages.en: The earl of the He said, 'The disputers of the world all say, "That which is most minute has no bodily form; and that which is most great cannot be encompassed" - is this really the truth?'

passages.zh: 北海若曰：「夫自細視大者不盡，自大視細者不明。
passages.en: Ruo of the Northern Sea replied, 'When from the standpoint of what is small we look at what is great, we do not take it all in; when from the standpoint of what is great we look at what is small, we do not see it clearly.

passages.zh: 夫精，小之微也，垺，大之殷也，故異便。
passages.en: Now the subtile essence is smallness in its extreme degree; and the vast mass is greatness in its largest form. Different as they are, each has its suitability - according to their several conditions.

passages.zh: 此勢之有也。
夫精粗者，期於有形者也；無形者，數之所不能分也；不可圍者，數之所不能窮也。
passages.en: But the subtile and the gross both presuppose that they have a bodily form. Where there is no bodily form, there is no longer a possibility of numerical division; where it is not possible to encompass a mass, there is no longer a possibility of numerical estimate.

passages.zh: 可以言論者，物之粗也；可以意致者，物之精也；言之所不能論，意之所不能察致者，不期精粗焉。
passages.en: What can be discoursed about in words is the grossness of things; what can be reached in idea is the subtilty of things. What cannot be discoursed about in words, and what cannot be reached by nice discrimination of thought, has nothing to do either with subtilty or grossness.

passages.zh: 是故大人之行，不出乎害人，不多仁恩；動不為利，不賤門隸；貨財弗爭，不多辭讓；事焉不惜人，不多食乎力，不賤貪污；行殊乎俗，不多辟異；為在從眾，不賤佞諂；世之爵祿不足以為勸，戮恥不足以為辱；知是非之不可為分，細大之不可為倪。
passages.en: Therefore while the actions of the Great Man are not directed to injure men, he does not plume himself on his benevolence and kindness; while his movements are not made with a view to gain, he does not consider the menials of a family as mean; while he does not strive after property and wealth, he does not plume himself on declining them; while he does not borrow the help of others to accomplish his affairs, he does not plume himself on supporting himself by his own strength, nor does he despise those who in their greed do what is mean; while he differs in his conduct from the vulgar, he does not plume himself on being so different from them; while it is his desire to follow the multitude, he does not despise the glib-tongued flatterers. The rank and emoluments of the world furnish no stimulus to him, nor does he reckon its punishments and shame to be a disgrace. He knows that the right and the wrong can (often) not be distinguished, and that what is small and what is great can (often) not be defined.

passages.zh: 聞曰：『道人不聞，至德不得，大人無己，約分之至也。」
passages.en: I have heard it said, 'The Man of Dao does not become distinguished; the greatest virtue is unsuccessful; the Great Man has no thought of self' - to so great a degree may the lot be restricted.'

passages.zh: 河伯曰：「若物之外，若物之內，惡至而倪貴賤？
passages.en: The earl of the He said, 'Whether the subject be what is external in things, or what is internal, how do we come to make a distinction between them as noble and mean, and as great or small?'

passages.zh: 惡至而倪小大？」
北海若曰：「以道觀之，物無貴賤；以物觀之，自貴而相賤：以俗觀之，貴賤不在己。
passages.en: Ruo of the Northern Sea replied, 'When we look at them in the light of the Dao, they are neither noble nor mean. Looking at them in themselves, each thinks itself noble, and despises others. Looking at them in the light of common opinion, their being noble or mean does not depend on themselves.

passages.zh: 以差觀之，因其所大而大之，則萬物莫不大；因其所小而小之，則萬物莫不小。
passages.en: Looking at them in their differences from one another, if we call those great which are greater than others, there is nothing that is not great, and in the same way there is nothing that is not small.

passages.zh: 知天地之為稊米也，知豪末之為丘山也，則差數等矣。
passages.en: We shall (thus) know that heaven and earth is but (as) a grain of the smallest rice, and that the point of a hair is (as) a mound or a mountain - such is the view given of them by their relative size.

passages.zh: 以功觀之，因其所有而有之，則萬物莫不有；因其所無而無之，則萬物莫不無。
passages.en: Looking at them from the services they render, allowing to everything the service which it does, there is not one which is not serviceable; and, extending the consideration to what it does not do, there is not one which is not unserviceable.

passages.zh: 知東西之相反，而不可以相無，則功分定矣。
passages.en: We know (for instance) that East and West are opposed to each other, and yet that the one cannot be without (suggesting the idea of) the other - (thus) their share of mutual service is determined.

passages.zh: 以趣觀之，因其所然而然之，則萬物莫不然；因其所非而非之，則萬物莫不非。
passages.en: Looking at them with respect to their tendencies, if we approve of what they approve, then there is no one who may not be approved of; and, if we condemn what they condemn, there is no one who may not be condemned.

passages.zh: 知堯、桀之自然而相非，則趣操睹矣。
passages.en: There are the cases of Yao and Jie, each of whom approved of his own course, and condemned the other - such is the view arising from the consideration of tendency and aim.

passages.zh: 昔者堯、舜讓而帝，之、噲讓而絕；湯、武爭而王，白公爭而滅。
passages.en: Formerly Yao and Shun resigned (their thrones), and yet each continued to be Di; Zhi-kuai resigned (his marquisate) which led to his ruin. Tang and Wu contended (for the sovereignty), and each became king; the duke a contended (for Qi), which led to his extinction.

passages.zh: 由此觀之，爭讓之禮，堯、桀之行，貴賤有時，未可以為常也。
passages.en: Looking at the subject from these examples of striving by force and of resigning, and from the conduct of Yao (on the one hand) and of Jie (on the other), we see that there is a time for noble acting, and a time for mean - these characteristics are subject to no regular rule.

passages.zh: 梁麗可以衝城，而不可以窒穴，言殊器也；騏驥驊騮，一日而馳千里，捕鼠不如狸狌，言殊技也；鴟鵂夜撮蚤，察毫末，晝出瞋目而不見丘山，言殊性也。
passages.en: A battering ram may be used against the wall of a city, but it cannot be employed to stop up a hole - the uses of implements are different. The (horses) Qi-ji and Hua-liu could in one day gallop 1000 li, but for catching rats they were not equal to a wild dog or a weasel - the gifts of creatures are different. The white horned owl collects its fleas in the night-time, and can discern the point of a hair, but in bright day it stares with its eyes and cannot see a mound or a hill - the natures of creatures are different.

passages.zh: 故曰：蓋師是而無非，師治而無亂乎？
passages.en: Hence the sayings, 'Shall we not follow and honour the right, and have nothing to do with the wrong? shall we not follow and honour those who secure good government, and have nothing to do with those who produce disorder?'

passages.zh: 是未明天地之理，萬物之情者也。
passages.en: show a want of acquaintance with the principles of Heaven and Earth, and with the different qualities of things.

passages.zh: 是猶師天而無地，師陰而無陽，其不可行明矣。
passages.en: It is like following and honouring Heaven and taking no account of Earth; it is like following and honouring the Yin and taking no account of the Yang. It is clear that such a course cannot be pursued.

passages.zh: 然且語而不舍，非愚則誣也。
passages.en: Yet notwithstanding they go on talking so: if they are not stupid, they are visionaries.

passages.zh: 帝王殊禪，三代殊繼。
passages.en: The Di sovereigns resigned their thrones to others in one way, and the rulers of the three dynasties transmitted their thrones to their successors in another.

passages.zh: 差其時，逆其俗者，謂之篡夫；當其時，順其俗者，謂之義徒。
passages.en: He who acts differently from the requirements of his time and contrary to its custom is called an usurper; he who complies with the time and follows the common practice is said to be righteous.

passages.zh: 默默乎河伯！
passages.en: Hold your peace, 0 earl of the He.

passages.zh: 女惡知貴賤之門，大小之家！」
passages.en: How should you know what constitutes being noble and being mean, or who are the small and who the great?'

passages.zh: 河伯曰：「然則我何為乎？
passages.en: The earl of the He said, 'Very well. But what am I to do? and what am I not to do?

passages.zh: 何不為乎？
吾辭受趣舍，吾終奈何？」
passages.en: How am I to be guided after all in regard to what I accept or reject, and what I pursue or put away from me?'

passages.zh: 北海若曰：「以道觀之，何貴何賤，是謂反衍，無拘而志，與道大蹇。
passages.en: Ruo of the Northern Sea replied, 'From the standpoint of the Dao, what is noble? and what is mean? These expressions are but the different extremes of the average level. Do not keep pertinaciously to your own ideas, which put you in such opposition to the Dao.

passages.zh: 何少何多，是謂謝施，無一而行，與道參差。
passages.en: What are few? and what are many? These are denominations which we employ in thanking (donors) and dispensing gifts. Do not study to be uniform in doing so - it only shows how different you are from the Dao.

passages.zh: 嚴乎若國之有君，其無私德；繇繇乎若祭之有社，其無私福；泛泛乎其若四方之無窮，其無所畛域。
passages.en: Be severe and strict, like the ruler of a state who does not selfishly bestow his favours. Be scrupulous, yet gentle, like the tutelary spirit of the land, when sacrifice is offered to him who does not bestow his blessing selfishly. Be large-minded like space, whose four terminating points are illimitable, and form no particular enclosures.

passages.zh: 兼懷萬物，其孰承翼？
passages.en: Hold all things in your love, favouring and supporting none specially.

passages.zh: 是謂無方。
passages.en: This is called being without any local or partial regard; all things are equally regarded; there is no long or short among them.

passages.zh: 萬物一齊，孰短孰長？
道無終始，物有死生，不恃其成；一虛一滿，不位乎其形。
passages.en: There is no end or beginning to the Dao. Things indeed die and are born, not reaching a perfect state which can be relied on. Now there is emptiness, and now fulness - they do not continue in one form.

passages.zh: 年不可舉，時不可止；消息盈虛，終則有始。
passages.en: The years cannot be reproduced; time cannot be arrested. Decay and growth, fulness and emptiness, when they end, begin again.

passages.zh: 是所以語大義之方，論萬物之理也。
passages.en: It is thus that we describe the method of great righteousness, and discourse about the principle pervading all things.

passages.zh: 物之生也若驟若馳，無動而不變，無時而不移。
passages.en: The life of things is like the hurrying and galloping along of a horse. With every movement there is a change; with every moment there is an alteration.

passages.zh: 何為乎？
passages.en: What should you be doing? what should you not be doing?

passages.zh: 何不為乎？
夫固將自化。」
passages.en: You have only to be allowing this course of natural transformation to be going on.'

passages.zh: 河伯曰：「然則何貴於道邪？」
passages.en: The earl of the He said, 'What then is there so valuable in the Dao?'

passages.zh: 北海若曰：「知道者必達於理，達於理者必明於權，明於權者不以物害己。
passages.en: Ruo of the Northern Sea replied, 'He who knows the Dao is sure to be well acquainted with the principles (that appear in the procedures of things). Acquainted with (those) principles, he is sure to understand how to regulate his conduct in all varying circumstances. Having that understanding, he will not allow things to injure himself.

passages.zh: 至德者，火弗能熱，水弗能溺，寒暑弗能害，禽獸弗能賊。
passages.en: Fire cannot burn him who is (so) perfect in virtue, nor water drown him; neither cold nor heat can affect him injuriously; neither bird nor beast can hurt him.

passages.zh: 非謂其薄之也，言察乎安危，寧於禍福，謹於去就，莫之能害也。
passages.en: This does not mean that he is indifferent to these things; it means that he discriminates between where he may safely rest and where he will be in peril; that he is tranquil equally in calamity and happiness; that he is careful what he avoids and what he approaches - so that nothing can injure him.

passages.zh: 故曰：天在內，人在外，德在乎天。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'What is heavenly is internal; what is human is external.' The virtue (of man) is in what is Heavenly.

passages.zh: 知天人之行，本乎天，位乎得。
passages.en: If you know the operation of what is Heavenly and what is Human, you will have your root in what is Heavenly and your position in Virtue.

passages.zh: 蹢䠱而屈伸，反要而語極。」
passages.en: You will bend or stretch (only) after the (necessary) hesitation; you will have returned to the essential, and may be pronounced to have reached perfection.'

passages.zh: 曰：「何謂天？
passages.en: 'What do you mean,' pursued the earl, 'by the Heavenly, and by the Human?'

passages.zh: 何謂人？」
北海若曰：「牛馬四足，是謂天；落馬首，穿牛鼻，是謂人。
passages.en: Ruo replied, 'Oxen and horses have four feet - that is what I call their Heavenly (constitution). When horses' heads are haltered, and the noses of oxen are pierced, that is what I call (the doing of) Man.

passages.zh: 故曰：無以人滅天，無以故滅命，無以得殉名。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'Do not by the Human (doing) extinguish the Heavenly (constitution); do not for your (Human) purpose extinguish the appointment (of Heaven); do not bury your (proper) fame in (such) a pursuit of it.

passages.zh: 謹守而勿失，是謂反其真。」
passages.en: Carefully guard (the Way) and do not lose it: this is what I call reverting to your True (Nature).'"'

passages.zh: 夔憐蚿，蚿憐蛇，蛇憐風，風憐目，目憐心。
passages.en: The kui desires to be like the millipede; the millipede to be like the serpent; the serpent like the wind; the wind to be like the eye; and the eye to be like the mind.

passages.zh: 夔謂蚿曰：「吾以一足趻踔而行，予無如矣。
passages.en: The kui said to the millipede, 'With my one leg I hop about, and can hardly manage to go along.

passages.zh: 今子之使萬足，獨奈何？」
passages.en: Now you have a myriad feet which you can employ; how is it that you are so abundantly furnished?'

passages.zh: 蚿曰：「不然。
passages.en: The millipede said, 'It is not so.

passages.zh: 子不見夫唾者乎？
passages.en: Have you not seen one ejecting saliva?

passages.zh: 噴則大者如珠，小者如霧，雜而下者不可勝數也。
passages.en: The largest portion of it is like a pearl, while the smaller portions fall down like a shower of mist in innumerable drops.

passages.zh: 今予動吾天機，而不知其所以然。」
passages.en: Now I put in motion the springs set in me by Heaven, without knowing how I do so.'

passages.zh: 蚿謂蛇曰：「吾以眾足行，而不及子之無足，何也？」
passages.en: The millipede said to the serpent, 'I go along by means of my multitude of feet; and yet how is it that I do not go so fast as you who have no feet at all?'

passages.zh: 蛇曰：「夫天機之所動，何可易邪？
passages.en: The serpent replied, 'How can the method of moving by the springs set in us by Heaven be changed?

passages.zh: 吾安用足哉！」
passages.en: How could I make use of feet?'

passages.zh: 蛇謂風曰：「予動吾脊脅而行，則有似也。
passages.en: The serpent said to the wind, 'I get along by moving my backbone and ribs, thus appearing to have some (bodily) means of progression.

passages.zh: 今子蓬蓬然起於北海，蓬蓬然入於南海，而似無有，何也？」
passages.en: But now you, Sir, rise with a blustering force in the North Sea, and go on in the same way to the South Sea - seemingly without any such means. How does it take place?'

passages.zh: 風曰：「然。
passages.en: The wind said, 'Yes.

passages.zh: 予蓬蓬然起於北海而入於南海也，然而指我則勝我，䠓我亦勝我。
passages.en: With such a blustering force I rise in the North Sea and go on to the South Sea. But you can point to me, and therein are superior to me, as you are also in treading on me.

passages.zh: 雖然，夫折大木，蜚大屋者，唯我能也，故以眾小不勝為大勝也。
passages.en: Yet notwithstanding, it is only I who can break great trees, and blow down great houses. Therefore he whom all that are small cannot overcome is a great overcomer.

passages.zh: 為大勝者，唯聖人能之。」
passages.en: But it is only he who is the sagely man that is the Great Conqueror (of all).'

passages.zh: 孔子遊於匡，宋人圍之數匝，而絃歌不惙。
passages.en: When Confucius was travelling in Kuang, some people of Song (once) surrounded him (with a hostile intention) several ranks deep; but he kept singing to his lute without stopping.

passages.zh: 子路入見，曰：「何夫子之娛也？」
passages.en: Zi-lu came in, and saw him, and said, 'How is it, Master, that you are so pleased?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「來！
passages.en: Confucius said, 'Come here, and I will tell you.

passages.zh: 吾語女。
我諱窮久矣，而不免，命也；求通久矣，而不得，時也。
passages.en: I have tried to avoid being reduced to such a strait for a long time; and that I have not escaped shows that it was so appointed for me. I have sought to find a ruler that would employ me for a long time, and that I have not found one, shows the character of the time.

passages.zh: 當堯、舜而天下無窮人，非知得也，當桀，紂而天下無通人，非知失也，時勢適然。
passages.en: Under Yao and Shun there was no one in the kingdom reduced to straits like mine; and it was not by their sagacity that men succeeded as they did. Under Jie and Zhou no (good and able man) in the kingdom found his way to employment; and it was not for (want of) sagacity that they failed to do so. It was simply owing to the times and their character.

passages.zh: 夫水行不避蛟龍者，漁父之勇也；陸行不避兕虎者，獵夫之勇也；白刃交於前，視死若生者，烈士之勇也；知窮之有命，知通之有時，臨大難而不懼者，聖人之勇也。
passages.en: People that do business on the water do not shrink from meeting iguanodons and dragons - that is the courage of fishermen. Those who do business on land do not shrink from meeting rhinoceroses and tigers - that is the courage of hunters. When men see the sharp weapons crossed before them, and look on death as going home - that is the courage of the determined soldier. When he knows that his strait is determined for him, and that the employment of him by a ruler depends on the character of the time, and then meeting with great distress is yet not afraid - that is the courage of the sagely man.

passages.zh: 由處矣！
passages.en: Wait, my good You, and you will see what there is determined for me in my lot.'

passages.zh: 吾命有所制矣。」
無幾何，將甲者進，辭曰：「以為陽虎也，故圍之；今非也，請辭而退。」
passages.en: A little afterwards, the leader of the armed men approached and took his leave, saying, 'We thought you were Yang Hu, and therefore surrounded you. Now we see our mistake.' (With this) he begged to take his leave, and withdrew.

passages.zh: 公孫龍問於魏牟曰：「龍少學先生之道，長而明仁義之行，合同異，雜堅白，然不然，可不可，困百家之知，窮眾口之辯，吾自以為至達已。
passages.en: Gong-sun Long asked Mou of Wei, saying, 'When I was young, I learned the teachings of the former kings; and when I was grown up, I became proficient in the practice of benevolence and righteousness. I brought together the views that agreed and disagreed; I considered the questions about hardness and whiteness; I set forth what was to be affirmed and what was not, and what was allowable and what was not; I studied painfully the various schools of thought, and made myself master of the reasonings of all their masters. I thought that I had reached a good understanding of every subject.

passages.zh: 今吾聞莊子之言，汒焉異之，不知論之不及與，知之弗若與？
passages.en: But now that I have heard the words of Zhuangzi, they throw me into a flutter of surprise. I do not know whether it be that I do not come up to him in the power of discussion, or that my knowledge is not equal to his.

passages.zh: 今吾無所開吾喙，敢問其方。」
passages.en: But now I do not feel able to open my mouth, and venture to ask you what course I should pursue.'

passages.zh: 公子牟隱机太息，仰天而笑曰：「子獨不聞夫埳井之鼃乎？
passages.en: Gong-sun Mou leant forward on his stool, drew a long breath, looked up to heaven, smiled, and said, 'Have you not heard of the frog of the dilapidated well, and how it said to the turtle of the Eastern Sea.

passages.zh: 謂東海之鱉曰：『吾樂與！
passages.en: "How I enjoy myself?

passages.zh: 出跳梁乎井幹之上，入休乎缺甃之崖，赴水則接腋持頤，蹶泥則沒足滅跗，還虷蟹與科斗，莫吾能若也。
passages.en: I leap upon the parapet of this well. I enter, and having by means of the projections formed by the fragments of the broken tiles of the lining proceeded to the water, I draw my legs together, keep my chin up, (and strike out). When I have got to the mud, I dive till my feet are lost in it. Then turning round, I see that of the shrimps, crabs, and tadpoles there is not one that can do like me.

passages.zh: 且夫擅一壑之水，而跨跱埳井之樂，此亦至矣，夫子奚不時來入觀乎？』
passages.en: Moreover, when one has entire command of all the water in the gully, and hesitates to go forward, it is the greatest pleasure to enjoy one's self here in this dilapidated well - why do not you, Master, often come and enter, and see it for yourself?"

passages.zh: 東海之鱉左足未入，而右膝已縶矣。
passages.en: The turtle of the Eastern Sea (was then proceeding to go forward), but before he had put in his left foot, he found his right knee caught and held fast.

passages.zh: 於是逡巡而卻，告之海曰：『夫千里之遠，不足以舉其大；千仞之高，不足以極其深。
passages.en: On this he hesitated, drew back, and told (the frog) all about the sea, saying, "A distance of a thousand li is not sufficient to express its extent, nor would (a line of) eight thousand cubits be equal to sound its depth.

passages.zh: 禹之時，十年九潦，而水弗為加益；湯之時，八年七旱，而崖不為加損。
passages.en: In the time of Yu, for nine years out of ten the flooded land (all drained into it), and its water was not sensibly increased; and in the time of Thang for seven years out of eight there was a drought, but the rocks on the shore (saw) no diminution of the water because of it.

passages.zh: 夫不為頃久推移，不以多少進退者，此亦東海之大樂也。』
passages.en: Thus it is that no change is produced in its waters by any cause operating for a short time or a long, and that they do not advance nor recede for any addition or subtraction, whether great or small; and this is the great pleasure afforded by the Eastern Sea."

passages.zh: 於是埳井之鼃聞之，適適然驚，規規然自失也。
passages.en: When the frog of the dilapidated well heard this, he was amazed and terror-struck, and lost himself in surprise.

passages.zh: 且夫知不知是非之竟，而猶欲觀於莊子之言，是猶使蚊負山，商蚷馳河也，必不勝任矣。
passages.en: And moreover, when you, who have not wisdom enough to know where the discussions about what is right and what is wrong should end, still desire to see through the words of Zhuangzi, that is like employing a mosquito to carry a mountain on its back, or a millipede to gallop as fast as the Ho runs - tasks to which both the insects are sure to be unequal.

passages.zh: 且夫知不知論極妙之言，而自適一時之利者，是非埳井之鼃與？
passages.en: Still further, when you, who have not wisdom enough to know the words employed in discussing very mysterious subjects, yet hasten to show your sharpness of speech on any occasion that may occur, is not this being like the frog of the dilapidated well?

passages.zh: 且彼方跐黃泉而登大皇，無南無北，奭然四解，淪於不測；無東無西，始於玄冥，反於大通。
passages.en: And that (Zhuangzi) now plants his foot on the Yellow Springs (below the earth), and anon rises to the height of the Empyrean. Without any regard to south and north, with freedom he launches out in every direction, and is lost in the unfathomable. Without any regard to east and west, starting from what is abysmally obscure, he comes back to what is grandly intelligible.

passages.zh: 子乃規規然而求之以察，索之以辯，是直用管窺天，用錐指地也，不亦小乎！
passages.en: (All the while), you, Sir, in amazement, search for his views to examine them, and grope among them for matter for discussion - this is just like peeping at the heavens through a tube, or aiming at the earth with an awl; are not both the implements too small for the purpose?

passages.zh: 子往矣！
passages.en: Go your ways, Sir.

passages.zh: 且子獨不聞壽陵餘子之學行於邯鄲與？
passages.en: And have you not heard of the young learners of Shou-ling, and how they did in Han-dan?

passages.zh: 未得國能，又失其故行矣，直匍匐而歸耳。
passages.en: Before they had acquired what they might have done in that capital, they had forgotten what they had learned to do in their old city, and were marched back to it on their hands and knees.

passages.zh: 今子不去，將忘子之故，失子之業。」
passages.en: If now you do not go away, you will forget your old acquirements, and fail in your profession.'

passages.zh: 公孫龍口呿而不合，舌舉而不下，乃逸而走。
passages.en: Gong-sun Long gaped on the speaker, and could not shut his mouth, and his tongue clave to its roof. He slank away and ran off.

passages.zh: 莊子釣於濮水，楚王使大夫二人往先焉，曰：「願以境內累矣！」
passages.en: Zhuangzi was (once) fishing in the river Pu, when the king of Chu sent two great officers to him, with the message, 'I wish to trouble you with the charge of all within my territories.'

passages.zh: 莊子持竿不顧，曰：「吾聞楚有神龜，死已三千歲矣，王巾笥而藏之廟堂之上。
passages.en: Zhuangzi kept on holding his rod without looking round, and said, 'I have heard that in Chu there is a spirit-like tortoise-shell, the wearer of which died 3000 years ago, and which the king keeps, in his ancestral temple, in a hamper covered with a cloth.

passages.zh: 此龜者，寧其死為留骨而貴乎，寧其生而曳尾於塗中乎？」
passages.en: Was it better for the tortoise to die, and leave its shell to be thus honoured? Or would it have been better for it to live, and keep on dragging its tail through the mud?'

passages.zh: 二大夫曰：「寧生而曳尾塗中。」
passages.en: The two officers said, 'It would have been better for it to live, and draw its tail after it over the mud.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「往矣！
passages.en: 'Go your ways.

passages.zh: 吾將曳尾於塗中。」
passages.en: I will keep on drawing my tail after me through the mud.'

passages.zh: 惠子相梁，莊子往見之。
passages.en: Huizi being a minister of state in Liang, Zhuangzi went to see him.

passages.zh: 或謂惠子曰：「莊子來，欲代子相。」
passages.en: Some one had told Huizi that Zhuangzi was come with a wish to supersede him in his office, on which he was afraid, and instituted a search for the stranger all over the kingdom for three days and three nights.

passages.zh: 於是惠子恐，搜於國中三日三夜。
莊子往見之，曰：「南方有鳥，其名為鵷鶵，子知之乎？
passages.en: (After this) Zhuangzi went and saw him, and said, 'There is in the south a bird, called "the Young Phoenix" - do you know it?

passages.zh: 夫鵷鶵發於南海而飛於北海，非梧桐不止，非練實不食，非醴泉不飲。
passages.en: Starting from the South Sea, it flies to the Northern; never resting but on the bignonia, never eating but the fruit of the melia azederach, and never drinking but from the purest springs.

passages.zh: 於是鴟得腐鼠，鵷鶵過之，仰而視之曰：『嚇！』
passages.en: An owl, which had got a putrid rat, (once), when a phoenix went passing overhead, looked up to it and gave an angry scream.

passages.zh: 今子欲以子之梁國而嚇我邪？」
passages.en: Do you wish now, in your possession of the kingdom of Liang, to frighten me with a similar scream?'

passages.zh: 莊子與惠子遊於濠梁之上。
passages.en: Zhuangzi and Huizi were walking on the dam over the Hao.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「儵魚出遊從容，是魚樂也。」
passages.en: The former said, 'These thryssas come out, and play about at their ease - that is the enjoyment of fishes.'

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「子非魚，安知魚之樂？」
passages.en: The other said, 'You are not a fish; how do you know what constitutes the enjoyment of fishes?'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「子非我，安知我不知魚之樂？」
passages.en: Zhuangzi rejoined, 'You are not I. How do you know that I do not know what constitutes the enjoyment of fishes?'

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「我非子，固不知子矣；子固非魚也，子之不知魚之樂全矣。」
passages.en: Huizi said, 'I am not you; and though indeed I do not fully know you, you certainly are not a fish, and (the argument) is complete against your knowing what constitutes the happiness of fishes.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「請循其本。
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'Let us keep to your original question.

passages.zh: 子曰『汝安知魚樂』云者，既已知吾知之而問我，我知之濠上也。」
passages.en: You said to me, "How do you know what constitutes the enjoyment of fishes?" You knew that I knew it, and yet you put your question to me - well, I know it (from our enjoying ourselves together) over the Hao.'

passages.zh: 天下有至樂無有哉？
passages.en: Under the sky is perfect enjoyment to be found or not?

passages.zh: 有可以活身者無有哉？
passages.en: Are there any who can preserve themselves alive or not?

passages.zh: 今奚為奚據？
passages.en: If there be, what do they do? What do they maintain?

passages.zh: 奚避奚處？
passages.en: What do they avoid? What do they attend to?

passages.zh: 奚就奚去？
passages.en: Where do they resort to? Where do they keep from?

passages.zh: 奚樂奚惡？
passages.en: What do they delight in? What do they dislike?

passages.zh: 夫天下之所尊者，富貴壽善也；所樂者，身安、厚味、美服、好色、音聲也；所下者，貧賤夭惡也；所苦者，身不得安逸，口不得厚味，形不得美服，目不得好色，耳不得音聲；若不得者，則大憂以懼。
passages.en: What the world honours is riches, dignities, lonevity, and being deemed able. What it delights in is rest for the body, rich flavours, fine garments, beautiful colours, and pleasant music. What it looks down on are poverty and mean condition, short life and being deemed feeble. What men consider bitter experiences are that their bodies do not get rest and ease, that their mouths do not get food of rich flavour, that their persons are not finely clothed, that their eyes do not see beautiful colours, and that their ears do not listen to pleasant music. If they do not got these things, they are very sorrowful, and go on to be troubled with fears.

passages.zh: 其為形也亦愚哉！
passages.en: Their thoughts are all about the body - are they not silly?

passages.zh: 夫富者，苦身疾作，多積財而不得盡用，其為形也亦外矣。
passages.en: Now the rich embitter their lives by their incessant labours; they accumulate more wealth than they can use: while they act thus for the body, they make it external to themselves.

passages.zh: 夫貴者，夜以繼日，思慮善否，其為形也亦疏矣。
passages.en: Those who seek for honours carry their pursuit of them from the day into the night, full of anxiety about their methods whether they are skilful or not: while they act thus for the body they treat it as if it were indifferent to them.

passages.zh: 人之生也，與憂俱生，壽者惛惛，久憂不死，何苦也！
passages.en: The birth of man is at the same time the birth of his sorrow; and if he live long he becomes more and more stupid, and the longer is his anxiety that he may not die; how great is his bitterness!

passages.zh: 其為形也亦遠矣。
passages.en: -- while he thus acts for his body, it is for a distant result.

passages.zh: 烈士為天下見善矣，未足以活身。
passages.en: Meritorious officers are regarded by the world as good; but (their goodness) is not sufficient to keep their persons alive.

passages.zh: 吾未知善之誠善邪，誠不善邪？
passages.en: I do not know whether the goodness ascribed to them be really good or really not good.

passages.zh: 若以為善矣，不足活身；以為不善矣，足以活人。
passages.en: If indeed it be considered good, it is not sufficient to preserve their persons alive; if it be deemed not good, it is sufficient to preserve other men alive.

passages.zh: 故曰：「忠諫不聽，蹲循勿爭。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'When faithful remonstrances are not listened to, (the remonstrant) should sit still, let (his ruler) take his course, and not strive with him.'

passages.zh: 故夫子胥爭之以殘其形，不爭，名亦不成。
passages.en: Therefore when Zi-xu strove with (his ruler), he brought on himself the mutilation of his body. If he had not so striven, he would not have acquired his fame.

passages.zh: 誠有善無有哉？
passages.en: Was such (goodness) really good or was it not?

passages.zh: 今俗之所為與其所樂，吾又未知樂之果樂邪，果不樂邪？
passages.en: As to what the common people now do, and what they find their enjoyment in, I do not know whether the enjoyment be really enjoyment or really not.

passages.zh: 吾觀夫俗之所樂，舉群趣者，誙誙然如將不得已，而皆曰樂者，吾未之樂也，亦未之不樂也。
passages.en: I see them in their pursuit of it following after all their aims as if with the determination of death, and as if they could not stop in their course; but what they call enjoyment would not be so to me, while yet I do not say that there is no enjoyment in it.

passages.zh: 果有樂無有哉？
passages.en: Is there indeed such enjoyment, or is there not?

passages.zh: 吾以無為誠樂矣，又俗之所大苦也。
passages.en: I consider doing nothing (to obtain it) to be the great enjoyment, while ordinarily people consider it to be a great evil.

passages.zh: 故曰：「至樂無樂，至譽無譽。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'Perfect enjoyment is to be without enjoyment; the highest praise is to be without praise.'

passages.zh: 天下是非果未可定也。
passages.en: The right and the wrong (on this point of enjoyment) cannot indeed be determined according to (the view of) the world.

passages.zh: 雖然，無為可以定是非。
passages.en: Nevertheless, this doing nothing (to obtain it) may determine the right and the wrong.

passages.zh: 至樂活身，唯無為幾存。
passages.en: Since perfect enjoyment is (held to be) the keeping the body alive, it is only by this doing nothing that that end is likely to be secured.

passages.zh: 請嘗試言之。
passages.en: Allow me to try and explain this (more fully).

passages.zh: 天無為以之清，地無為以之寧，故兩無為相合，萬物皆化。
passages.en: Heaven does nothing, and thence comes its serenity; Earth does nothing, and thence comes its rest. By the union of these two inactivities, all things are produced.

passages.zh: 芒乎芴乎，而無從出乎！
passages.en: How vast and imperceptible is the process!-- they seem to come from nowhere!

passages.zh: 芴乎芒乎，而無有象乎！
passages.en: How imperceptible and vast!-- there is no visible image of it!

passages.zh: 萬物職職，皆從無為殖。
passages.en: All things in all their variety grow from this Inaction.

passages.zh: 故曰：「天地無為也，而無不為也。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'Heaven and Earth do nothing, and yet there is nothing that they do not do.'

passages.zh: 人也，孰能得無為哉！
passages.en: But what man is there that can attain to this inaction?

passages.zh: 莊子妻死，惠子弔之，莊子則方箕踞鼓盆而歌。
passages.en: When Zhuangzi's wife died, Huizi went to condole with him, and, finding him squatted on the ground, drumming on the basin, and singing.

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「與人居長子，老身死，不哭亦足矣，又鼓盆而歌，不亦甚乎！」
passages.en: Huizi said to him, 'When a wife has lived with her husband, and brought up children, and then dies in her old age, not to wail for her is enough. When you go on to drum on this basin and sing, is it not an excessive (and strange) demonstration?'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「不然。
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'It is not so.

passages.zh: 是其始死也，我獨何能無概然！
passages.en: When she first died, was it possible for me to be singular and not affected by the event?

passages.zh: 察其始而本無生，非徒無生也，而本無形，非徒無形也，而本無氣。
passages.en: But I reflected on the commencement of her being. She had not yet been born to life; not only had she no life, but she had no bodily form; not only had she no bodily form, but she had no breath.

passages.zh: 雜乎芒芴之間，變而有氣，氣變而有形，形變而有生，今又變而之死，是相與為春秋冬夏四時行也。
passages.en: During the intermingling of the waste and dark chaos, there ensued a change, and there was breath; another change, and there was the bodily form; another change, and there came birth and life. There is now a change again, and she is dead. The relation between these things is like the procession of the four seasons from spring to autumn, from winter to summer.

passages.zh: 人且偃然寢於巨室，而我噭噭然隨而哭之，自以為不通乎命，故止也。」
passages.en: There now she lies with her face up, sleeping in the Great Chamber; and if I were to fall sobbing and going on to wall for her, I should think that I did not understand what was appointed (for all). I therefore restrained myself!'

passages.zh: 支離叔與滑介叔觀於冥伯之丘，崑崙之虛，黃帝之所休。
passages.en: Mr. Deformed and Mr. One-foot were looking at the mound-graves of the departed in the wild of Kun-lun, where Huang-Di had entered into his rest.

passages.zh: 俄而柳生其左肘，其意蹶蹶然惡之。
passages.en: Suddenly a tumour began to grow on their left wrists, which made them look distressed as if they disliked it.

passages.zh: 支離叔曰：「子惡之乎？」
passages.en: The former said to the other, 'Do you dread it?'

passages.zh: 滑介叔曰：「亡。
passages.en: 'No,' replied he, 'why should I dread it?

passages.zh: 予何惡？
生者，假借也；假之而生生者，塵垢也。
passages.en: Life is a borrowed thing. The living frame thus borrowed is but so much dust.

passages.zh: 死生為晝夜。
passages.en: Life and death are like day and night.

passages.zh: 且吾與子觀化而化及我，我又何惡焉？」
passages.en: And you and I were looking at (the graves of) those who have undergone their change. If my change is coming to me, why should I dislike it?'

passages.zh: 莊子之楚，見空髑髏，髐然有形，撽以馬捶，因而問之曰：「夫子貪生失理，而為此乎？
passages.en: When Zhuangzi went to Chu, he saw an empty skull, bleached indeed, but still retaining its shape. Tapping it with his horse-switch, he asked it, saying, 'Did you, Sir, in your greed of life, fail in the lessons of reason, and come to this?

passages.zh: 將子有亡國之事，斧鉞之誅，而為此乎？
passages.en: Or did you do so, in the service of a perishing state, by the punishment of the axe?

passages.zh: 將子有不善之行，愧遺父母妻子之醜，而為此乎？
passages.en: Or was it through your evil conduct, reflecting disgrace on your parents and on your wife and children?

passages.zh: 將子有凍餒之患，而為此乎？
passages.en: Or was it through your hard endurances of cold and hunger?

passages.zh: 將子之春秋故及此乎？」
passages.en: Or was it that you had completed your term of life?'

passages.zh: 於是語卒，援髑髏枕而臥。
passages.en: Having given expression to these questions, he took up the skull, and made a pillow of it when he went to sleep.

passages.zh: 夜半，髑髏見夢曰：「子之談者似辯士。
passages.en: At midnight the skull appeared to him in a dream, and said, 'What you said to me was after the fashion of an orator.

passages.zh: 視子所言，皆生人之累也，死則無此矣。
passages.en: All your words were about the entanglements of men in their lifetime. There are none of those things after death.

passages.zh: 子欲聞死之說乎？」
passages.en: Would you like to hear me, Sir, tell you about death?'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「然。」
passages.en: 'I should,' said Zhuangzi.

passages.zh: 髑髏曰：「死，無君於上，無臣於下，亦無四時之事，從然以天地為春秋，雖南面王樂，不能過也。」
passages.en: The skull resumed: 'In death there are not (the distinctions of) ruler above and minister below. There are none of the phenomena of the four seasons. Tranquil and at ease, our years are those of heaven and earth. No king in his court has greater enjoyment than we have.'

passages.zh: 莊子不信，曰：「吾使司命復生子形，為子骨肉肌膚，反子父母妻子、閭里、知識，子欲之乎？」
passages.en: Zhuangzi did not believe it, and said, 'If I could get the Ruler of our Destiny to restore your body to life with its bones and flesh and skin, and to give you back your father and mother, your wife and children, and all your village acquaintances, would you wish me to do so?'

passages.zh: 髑髏深矉蹙頞曰：「吾安能棄南面王樂而復為人間之勞乎？」
passages.en: The skull stared fixedly at him, knitted its brows, and said, 'How should I cast away the enjoyment of my royal court, and undertake again the toils of life among mankind?'

passages.zh: 顏淵東之齊，孔子有憂色。
passages.en: When Yan Yuan went eastwards to Qi, Confucius wore a look of sorrow.

passages.zh: 子貢下席而問曰：「小子敢問：回東之齊，夫子有憂色，何邪？」
passages.en: Zi-gong left his mat, and asked him, saying, 'Your humble disciple ventures to ask how it is that the going eastwards of Hui to Qi has given you such a look of sadness.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「善哉汝問！
passages.en: Confucius said, 'Your question is good.

passages.zh: 昔者管子有言，丘甚善之，曰：『褚小者不可以懷大，綆短者不可以汲深。』
passages.en: Formerly Guanzi used words of which I very much approve. He said, "A small bag cannot be made to contain what is large; a short rope cannot be used to draw water from a deep well."

passages.zh: 夫若是者，以為命有所成而形有所適也，夫不可損益。
passages.en: So it is, and man's appointed lot is definitely determined, and his body is adapted for definite ends, so that neither the one nor the other can be augmented or diminished.

passages.zh: 吾恐回與齊侯言堯、舜、黃帝之道，而重以燧人、神農之言。
passages.en: I am afraid that Hui will talk with the marquis of Qi about the ways of Huang-Di, Yao, and Shun, and go on to relate the words of Sui-ren and Shen Nong.

passages.zh: 彼將內求於己而不得，不得則惑，人惑則死。
passages.en: The marquis will seek (for the correspondence of what he is told) in himself; and, not finding it there, will suspect the speaker; and that speaker, being suspected, will be put to death.

passages.zh: 且女獨不聞邪？
passages.en: And have you not heard this?

passages.zh: 昔者海鳥止於魯郊，魯侯御而觴之於廟，奏九韶以為樂，具太牢以為善。
passages.en: Formerly a sea-bird alighted in the suburban country of Lu. The marquis went out to meet it, (brought it) to the ancestral temple, and prepared to banquet it there. The Jiu-shao was performed to afford it music; an ox, a sheep, and a pig were killed to supply the food.

passages.zh: 鳥乃眩視憂悲，不敢食一臠，不敢飲一杯，三日而死。
passages.en: The bird, however, looked at everything with dim eyes, and was very sad. It did not venture to eat a single bit of flesh, nor to drink a single cupful; and in three days it died.

passages.zh: 此以己養養鳥也，非以鳥養養鳥也。
passages.en: The marquis was trying to nourish the bird with what he used for himself, and not with the nourishment proper for a bird.

passages.zh: 夫以鳥養養鳥者，宜栖之深林，遊之壇陸，浮之江湖，食之鰍鰷，隨行列而止，委蛇而處。
passages.en: They who would nourish birds as they ought to be nourished should let them perch in the deep forests, or roam over sandy plains; float on the rivers and lakes; feed on the eels and small fish; wing their flight in regular order and then stop; and be free and at ease in their resting-places.

passages.zh: 彼唯人言之惡聞，奚以夫譊譊為乎！
passages.en: It was a distress to that bird to hear men speak; what did it care for all the noise and hubbub made about it?

passages.zh: 咸池、九韶之樂，張之洞庭之野，鳥聞之而飛，獸聞之而走，魚聞之而下入，人卒聞之，相與還而觀之。
passages.en: If the music of the Jiu-shao or the Xian-chi were performed in the wild of the Dong-ting lake, birds would fly away, and beasts would run off when they heard it, and fishes would dive down to the bottom of the water; while men, when they hear it, would come all round together, and look on.

passages.zh: 魚處水而生，人處水而死，故必相與異，其好惡故異也。
passages.en: Fishes live and men die in the water. They are different in constitution, and therefore differ in their likes and dislikes.

passages.zh: 故先聖不一其能，不同其事。
passages.en: Hence it was that the ancient sages did not require (from all) the same ability, nor demand the same performances.

passages.zh: 名止於實，義設於適，是之謂條達而福持。」
passages.en: They gave names according to the reality of what was done, and gave their approbation where it was specially suitable. This was what was called the method of universal adaptation and of sure success.'

passages.zh: 列子行食於道，從見百歲髑髏，攓蓬而指之曰：「唯予與汝知而未嘗死，未嘗生也。
passages.en: Liezi (once) upon a journey took a meal by the road-side. There he saw a skull a hundred years old, and, pulling away the bush (under which it lay), he pointed to it and said, 'It is only you and I who know that you are not dead, and that (aforetime) you were not alive.

passages.zh: 若果養乎？
passages.en: Do you indeed really find (in death) the nourishment (which you like)?

passages.zh: 予果歡乎？」
passages.en: Do I really find (in life my proper) enjoyment?

passages.zh: 種有幾，得水則為㡭，得水土之際則為蛙蠙之衣，生於陵屯則為陵舄，陵舄得鬱棲則為烏足，烏足之根為蠐螬，其葉為蝴蝶。
passages.en: The seeds (of things) are multitudinous and minute. On the surface of the water they form a membranous texture. When they reach to where the land and water join they become the (lichens which we call the) clothes of frogs and oysters. Coming to life on mounds and heights, they become the plantain; and, receiving manure, appear as crows' feet. The roots of the crow's foot become grubs, and its leaves, butterflies.

passages.zh: 胡蝶，胥也化而為蟲，生於灶下，其狀若脫，其名為鴝掇。
passages.en: This butterfly, known by the name of xu, is changed into an insect, and comes to life under a furnace. Then it has the form of a moth, and is named the Qu-duo.

passages.zh: 鴝掇千日為鳥，其名曰乾餘骨。
passages.en: The Qu-duo after a thousand days becomes a bird, called the gan-yu-gu.

passages.zh: 乾餘骨之沬為斯彌，斯彌為食醯。
passages.en: Its saliva becomes the si-mi, and this again the shi-xi (or pickle-eater).

passages.zh: 頤輅生乎食醯，黃軦生乎九猷，瞀芮生乎腐蠸。
passages.en: The yi-lu is produced from the pickle-eater; the huang-kuang from the jiu-you; the mou-rui from the fu-quan.

passages.zh: 羊奚比乎不筍，久竹生青寧，青寧生程，程生馬，馬生人，人又反入於機。
passages.en: The yang-xi uniting with a bamboo, which has long ceased to put forth sprouts, produces the qing-ning; the qing-ning, the panther; the panther, the horse; and the horse, the man.

passages.zh: 萬物皆出於機，皆入於機。
passages.en: Man then again enters into the great Machinery (of Evolution), from which all things come forth (at birth), and which they enter at death.

passages.zh: 達生之情者，不務生之所無以為；達命之情者，不務知之所無奈何。
passages.en: He who understands the conditions of Life does not strive after what is of no use to life; and he who understands the conditions of Destiny does not strive after what is beyond the reach of knowledge.

passages.zh: 養形必先之以物，物有餘而形不養者有之矣；有生必先無離形，形不離而生亡者有之矣。
passages.en: In nourishing the body it is necessary to have beforehand the things (appropriate to its support); but there are cases where there is a superabundance of such things, and yet the body is not nourished. In order to have life it is necessary that it do not have left the body; but there are cases when the body has not been left by it, and yet the life has perished.

passages.zh: 生之來不能卻，其去不能止。
passages.en: When life comes, it cannot be declined; when it goes, it cannot be detained.

passages.zh: 悲夫！
passages.en: Alas!

passages.zh: 世之人以為養形足以存生，而養形果不足以存生，則世奚足為哉！
passages.en: The men of the world think that to nourish the body is sufficient to preserve life; and when such nourishment is not sufficient to preserve the life, what can be done in the world that will be sufficient?

passages.zh: 雖不足為而不可不為者，其為不免矣。
passages.en: Though (all that men can do) will be insufficient, yet there are things which they feel they ought to do, and they do not try to avoid doing them.

passages.zh: 夫欲免為形者，莫如棄世。
passages.en: For those who wish to avoid caring for the body, their best plan is to abandon the world.

passages.zh: 棄世則無累，無累則正平，正平則與彼更生，更生則幾矣。
passages.en: Abandoning the world, they are free from its entanglements. Free from its entanglements, their (minds) are correct and their (temperament) is equable. Thus correct and equable, they succeed in securing a renewal of life, as some have done. In securing a renewal of life, they are not far from the True (Secret of their being).

passages.zh: 事奚足棄而生奚足遺？
passages.en: But how is it sufficient to abandon worldly affairs? and how is it sufficient to forget the (business of) life?

passages.zh: 棄事則形不勞，遺生則精不虧。
passages.en: Through the renouncing of (worldly) affairs, the body has no more toil; through forgetting the (business of) life, the vital power suffers no diminution.

passages.zh: 夫形全精復，與天為一。
passages.en: When the body is completed and the vital power is restored (to its original vigour), the man is one with Heaven.

passages.zh: 天地者，萬物之父母也，合則成體，散則成始。
passages.en: Heaven and Earth are the father and mother of all things. It is by their union that the body is formed; it is by their separation that a (new) beginning is brought about.

passages.zh: 形精不虧，是謂能移；精而又精，反以相天。
passages.en: When the body and vital power suffer no diminution, we have what may be called the transference of power. From the vital force there comes another more vital, and man returns to be the assistant of Heaven.

passages.zh: 子列子問關尹曰：「至人潛行不窒，蹈火不熱，行乎萬物之上而不慄。
passages.en: My master Liezi asked Yin, (the warden) of the gate, saying, 'The perfect man walks under water without encountering any obstruction, treads on fire without being burned, and walks on high above all things without any fear.

passages.zh: 請問何以至於此？」
passages.en: Let me ask how he attains to do this?'

passages.zh: 關尹曰：「是純氣之守也，非知巧果敢之列。
passages.en: The warden Yin replied, 'It is by his keeping of the pure breath (of life); it is not to be described as an achievement of his skill or daring.

passages.zh: 居！
passages.en: Sit down, and I will explain it to you.

passages.zh: 吾語女。
凡有貌象聲色者，皆物也，物與物何以相遠？
passages.en: Whatever has form, semblance, sound, and colour is a thing; how can one thing come to be different from another?

passages.zh: 夫奚足以至乎先？
passages.en: But it is not competent for any of these things to reach to what preceded them all - they are but (form and) visibility.

passages.zh: 是色而已。
則物之造乎不形，而止乎無所化，夫得是而窮之者，物焉得而止焉！
passages.en: But (the perfect man) attains to be (as it were) without form, and beyond the capability of being transformed. Now when one attains to this and carries it out to the highest degree, how can other things come into his way to stop him?

passages.zh: 彼將處乎不淫之度，而藏乎無端之紀，遊乎萬物之所終始，壹其性，養其氣，合其德，以通乎物之所造。
passages.en: He will occupy the place assigned to him without going beyond it, and lie concealed in the clue which has no end. He will study with delight the process which gives their beginning and ending to all things. By gathering his nature into a unity, by nourishing his vital power, by concentrating his virtue, he will penetrate to the making of things.

passages.zh: 夫若是者，其天守全，其神無郤，物奚自入焉！
passages.en: In this condition, with his heavenly constitution kept entire, and with no crevice in his spirit, how can things enter (and disturb his serenity)?'

passages.zh: 夫醉者之墜車，雖疾不死。
passages.en: Take the case of a drunken man falling from his carriage - though he may suffer injury, he will not die.

passages.zh: 骨節與人同，而犯害與人異，其神全也，乘亦不知也，墜亦不知也，死生驚懼不入乎其胷中，是故遻物而不慴。
passages.en: His bones and joints are the same as those of other men, but the injury which he receives is different: his spirit is entire. He knew nothing about his getting into the carriage, and knew nothing about his falling from it. The thought of death or life, or of any alarm or affright, does not enter his breast; and therefore he encounters danger without any shrinking from it.

passages.zh: 彼得全於酒而猶若是，而況得全於天乎！
passages.en: Completely under the influence of the liquor he has drunk, it is thus with him - how much more would it be so, if he were under the influence of his Heavenly constitution!

passages.zh: 聖人藏於天，故莫之能傷也。」
passages.en: The sagely man is kept hid in his Heavenly constitution, and therefore nothing can injure him.'

passages.zh: 復讎者不折鏌、干，雖有忮心者不怨飄瓦，是以天下平均。
passages.en: A man in the pursuit of vengeance would not break the (sword) Mo-yu or Gan-jiang (which had done the deed); nor would one, however easily made wrathful, wreak his resentment on the fallen brick. In this way all under heaven there would be peace, without the disorder of assaults and fighting, without the punishments of death and slaughter: such would be the issue of the course (which I have described).

passages.zh: 故無攻戰之亂，無殺戮之刑者，由此道也。
不開人之天，而開天之天，開天者德生，開人者賊生。
passages.en: If the disposition that is of human origin be not developed, but that which is the gift of Heaven, the development of the latter will produce goodness, while that of the former would produce hurt.

passages.zh: 不厭其天，不忽於人，民幾乎以其真。
passages.en: If the latter were not wearied of, and the former not slighted, the people would be brought nearly to their True nature.'

passages.zh: 仲尼適楚，出於林中，見痀僂者承蜩，猶掇之也。
passages.en: When Zhongni was on his way to Chu, as he issued from a forest, he saw a hunchback receiving cicadas (on the point of a rod), as if he were picking them up with his hand.

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「子巧乎？
passages.en: 'You are clever!' said he to the man.

passages.zh: 有道邪？」
passages.en: 'Is there any method in it?'

passages.zh: 曰：「我有道也。
passages.en: The hunchback replied, 'There is.

passages.zh: 五六月累丸，二而不墜，則失者錙銖；累三而不墜，則失者十一；累五而不墜，猶掇之也。
