passages.en: For five or six months, I practised with two pellets, till they never fell down, and then I only failed with a small fraction of the cicadas (which I tried to catch). Having succeeded in the same way with three (pellets), I missed only one cicada in ten. Having succeeded with five, I caught the cicadas as if I were gathering them.

passages.zh: 吾處身也若厥株拘，吾執臂也若槁木之枝，雖天地之大，萬物之多，而唯蜩翼之知。
passages.en: My body is to me no more than the stump of a broken trunk, and my shoulder no more than the branch of a rotten tree. Great as heaven and earth are, and multitudinous as things are, I take no notice of them, but only of the wings of my cicadas.

passages.zh: 吾不反不側，不以萬物易蜩之翼，何為而不得！」
passages.en: Neither turning nor inclining to one side. I would not for them all exchange the wings of my cicadas - how should I not succeed in taking them?'

passages.zh: 孔子顧謂弟子曰：「用志不分，乃凝於神，其痀僂丈人之謂乎！」
passages.en: Confucius looked round, and said to his disciples, '"Where the will is not diverted from its object, the spirit is concentrated" - this might have been spoken of this hunchback gentleman.'

passages.zh: 顏淵問仲尼曰：「吾嘗濟乎觴深之淵，津人操舟若神。
passages.en: Yan Yuan asked Zhongni, saying, 'When I was crossing the gulf of Shang-shen, the ferryman handled the boat like a spirit.

passages.zh: 吾問焉，曰：『操舟可學邪？』
passages.en: I asked him whether such management of a boat could be learned.

passages.zh: 曰：『可。
passages.en: He replied, "It may.

passages.zh: 善游者數能。
passages.en: Good swimmers can learn it quickly.

passages.zh: 若乃夫沒人，則未嘗見舟而便操之也。』
passages.en: But as for divers, without having seen a boat, they can manage it at once."

passages.zh: 吾問焉而不吾告，敢問何謂也？」
passages.en: He did not directly tell me what I asked - I venture to ask you what he meant.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「善游者數能，忘水也。
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'Good swimmers acquire the ability quickly - they forget the water (and its dangers).

passages.zh: 若乃夫沒人之未嘗見舟而便操之也，彼視淵若陵，視舟之覆猶其車卻也。
passages.en: As to those who are able to dive, and without having seen a boat are able to manage it at once, they look on the watery gulf as if it were a hill-side, and the upsetting of a boat as the going back of a carriage.

passages.zh: 覆卻萬方陳乎前而不得入其舍，惡往而不暇！
passages.en: Such upsettings and goings back have occurred before them multitudes of times, and have not seriously affected their minds. Wherever they go, they feel at ease on their occurrence.

passages.zh: 以瓦注者巧，以鉤注者憚，以黃金注者殙。
passages.en: He who is contending for a piece of earthenware puts forth all his skill. If the prize be a buckle of brass, he shoots timorously; if it be for an article of gold, he shoots as if he were blind.

passages.zh: 其巧一也，而有所矜，則重外也。
passages.en: The skill of the archer is the same in all the cases; but (in the two latter cases) he is under the influence of solicitude, and looks on the external prize as most important.

passages.zh: 凡外重者內拙。」
passages.en: All who attach importance to what is external show stupidity in themselves.'

passages.zh: 田開之見周威公。
passages.en: Tian Kai-zhi was having an interview with duke Wei Of Zhou.

passages.zh: 威公曰：「吾聞祝腎學生。
passages.en: The duke said to him, 'I have heard that (your master) Zhu Shen has studied the subject of Life.

passages.zh: 吾子與祝腎游，亦何聞焉？」
passages.en: What have you, good Sir, heard from him about it in your intercourse with him?'

passages.zh: 田開之曰：「開之操拔篲以倚門庭，亦何聞於夫子！」
passages.en: Tian Kai-zhi replied, 'In my waiting on him in the courtyard with my broom, what should I have heard from my master?'

passages.zh: 威公曰：「田子無讓！
passages.en: Duke Wei said, 'Do not put the question off, Mr. Tian; I wish to hear what you have to say.'

passages.zh: 寡人願聞之。」
開之曰：「聞之夫子曰：『善養生者，若牧羊然，視其後者而鞭之。』」
passages.en: Kai-zhi then replied, 'I have heard my master say that they who skilfully nourish their life are like shepherds, who whip up the sheep that they see lagging behind.'

passages.zh: 威公曰：「何謂也？」
passages.en: 'What did he mean?' asked the duke.

passages.zh: 田開之曰：「魯有單豹者，巖居而水飲，不與民共利，行年七十而猶有嬰兒之色，不幸遇餓虎，餓虎殺而食之。
passages.en: The reply was, 'In Lu there was a Shan Bao, who lived among the rocks, and drank only water. He would not share with the people in their toils and the benefits springing from them; and though he was now in his seventieth year, he had still the complexion of a child. Unfortunately he encountered a hungry tiger, which killed and ate him.

passages.zh: 有張毅者，高門、懸薄，無不走也，行年四十而有內熱之病以死。
passages.en: There was also a Zhang Yi, who hung up a screen at his lofty door, and to whom all the people hurried (to pay their respects). In his fortieth year, he fell ill of a fever and died.

passages.zh: 豹養其內而虎食其外，毅養其外而病攻其內，此二子者，皆不鞭其後者也。」
passages.en: (Of these two men), Bao nourished his inner man, and a tiger ate his outer; while Yi nourished his outer man, and disease attacked his inner. Both of them neglected whipping up their lagging sheep.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「無入而藏，無出而陽，柴立其中央。
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'A man should not retire and hide himself; he should not push forward and display himself; he should be like the decayed tree which stands in the centre of the ground.

passages.zh: 三者若得，其名必極。
passages.en: Where these three conditions are fulfilled, the name will reach its greatest height.

passages.zh: 夫畏塗者，十殺一人，則父子兄弟相戒也，必盛卒徒而後敢出焉，不亦知乎！
passages.en: When people fear the dangers of a path, if one man in ten be killed, then fathers and sons, elder brothers and younger, warn one another that they must not go out on a journey without a large number of retainers - and is it not a mark of wisdom to do so?

passages.zh: 人之所取畏者，衽席之上，飲食之間，而不知為之戒者，過也。」
passages.en: But there are dangers which men incur on the mats of their beds, and in eating and drinking; and when no warning is given against them - is it not a mark of error?'

passages.zh: 祝宗人玄端以臨牢筴，說彘曰：「汝奚惡死？
passages.en: The officer of Prayer in his dark and squarecut robes goes to the pig-pen, and thus counsels the pigs, 'Why should you shrink from dying?

passages.zh: 吾將三月豢汝，十日戒，三日齊，藉白茅，加汝肩尻乎彫俎之上，則汝為之乎？」
passages.en: I will for three months feed you on grain. Then for ten days I will fast, and keep vigil for three days, after which I will put down the mats of white grass, and lay your shoulders and rumps on the carved stand; will not this suit you?'

passages.zh: 為彘謀曰：「不如食以糠糟，而錯之牢筴之中。」
passages.en: If he had spoken from the standpoint of the pigs, he would have said, 'The better plan will be to feed us with our bran and chaff, and leave us in our pen.'

passages.zh: 自為謀，則苟生有軒冕之尊，死得於腞、楯之上，聚僂之中，則為之。
passages.en: When consulting for himself, he preferred to enjoy, while he lived, his carriage and cap of office, and after death to be borne to the grave on the ornamented carriage, with the canopy over his coffin.

passages.zh: 為彘謀則去之，自為謀則取之，所異彘者何也？
passages.en: Consulting for the pigs, he did not think of these things, but for himself he would have chosen them. Why did he think so differently (for himself and) for the pigs?

passages.zh: 桓公田於澤，管仲御，見鬼焉。
passages.en: (Once), when duke Huan was hunting by a marsh, with Guan Zhong driving the carriage, he saw a ghost.

passages.zh: 公撫管仲之手曰：「仲父何見？」
passages.en: Laying his hand on that of Guan Zhong, he said to him, 'Do you see anything, Father Zhong?'

passages.zh: 對曰：「臣無所見。」
passages.en: 'Your servant sees nothing,' was the reply.

passages.zh: 公反，誒詒為病，數日不出。
passages.en: The duke then returned, talking incoherently and becoming ill, so that for several days he did not go out.

passages.zh: 齊士有皇子告敖者曰：「公則自傷，鬼惡能傷公！
passages.en: Among the officers of Qi there was a Huang-zi Gao-ao, who said to the duke, 'Your Grace is injuring yourself; how could a ghost injure you?

passages.zh: 夫忿滀之氣，散而不反，則為不足；上而不下，則使人善怒；下而不上，則使人善忘；不上不下，中身當心，則為病。」
passages.en: When a paroxysm of irritation is dispersed, and the breath does not return (to the body), what remains in the body is not sufficient for its wants. When it ascends and does not descend, the patient becomes accessible to gusts of anger. When it descends and does not ascend, he loses his memory of things. When it neither ascends nor descends, but remains about the heart in the centre of the body, it makes him ill.'

passages.zh: 桓公曰：「然則有鬼乎？」
passages.en: The duke said, 'Yes, but are there ghostly sprites?'

passages.zh: 曰：「有。
passages.en: The officer replied, 'There are.

passages.zh: 沈有履，灶有髻。
passages.en: About mountain tarns there is the lu; about furnaces, the Jie.

passages.zh: 戶內之煩壤，雷霆處之；東北方之下者，倍阿、鮭蠪躍之；西北方之下者，則泆陽處之。
passages.en: About the dust-heaps inside the door, the Lei-ting. In low-lying places in the north-east, the Bei-a and Wa-long leap about, and in similar places in the north-west there dwells the Yi-yang.

passages.zh: 水有罔象，丘有峷，山有夔，野有彷徨，澤有委蛇。」
passages.en: About rivers there is the Wang-xiang; about mounds, the Shen; about hills, the Kui; about wilds, the Fang-huang; about marshes, the Wei-tuo.'

passages.zh: 公曰：「請問委蛇之狀何如？」
passages.en: 'Let me ask what is the Wei-tuo like?' asked the duke.

passages.zh: 皇子曰：「委蛇，其大如轂，其長如轅，紫衣而朱冠。
passages.en: Huang-zi said, 'It is the size of the nave of a chariot wheel, and the length of the shaft. It wears a purple robe and a red cap.

passages.zh: 其為物也惡，聞雷車之聲，則捧其首而立。
passages.en: It dislikes the rumbling noise of chariot wheels, and, when it hears it, it puts both its hands to its head and stands up.

passages.zh: 見之者殆乎霸。」
passages.en: He who sees it is likely to become the leader of all the other princes.'

passages.zh: 桓公囅然而笑曰：「此寡人之所見者也。」
passages.en: Duke Huan burst out laughing and said, 'This was what I saw.'

passages.zh: 於是正衣冠與之坐，不終日而不知病之去也。
passages.en: On this he put his robes and cap to rights, and made Huang-zi sit with him. Before the day was done, his illness was quite gone, he knew not how.

passages.zh: 紀渻子為王養鬥雞。
passages.en: Ji Xing-zi was rearing a fighting-cock for the king.

passages.zh: 十日而問：「雞已乎？」
passages.en: Being asked after ten days if the bird were ready, he said, 'Not yet; he is still vain and quarrelsome, and relies on his own vigour.'

passages.zh: 曰：「未也。
方虛憍而恃氣。」
十日又問。
passages.en: Being asked the same after other ten days, he said, 'Not yet; he still responds to the crow and the appearance of another bird.'

passages.zh: 曰：「未也。
猶應嚮景。」
十日又問。
passages.en: After ten days more, he replied, 'Not yet. He still looks angrily, and is full of spirit.'

passages.zh: 曰：「未也。
猶疾視而盛氣。」
十日又問。
passages.en: When a fourth ten days had passed, he replied to the question, 'Nearly so.

passages.zh: 曰：「幾矣。
雞雖有鳴者，已無變矣，望之似木雞矣，其德全矣，異雞無敢應者，反走矣。」
passages.en: Though another cock crows, it makes no change in him. To look at him, you would say he was a cock of wood. His quality is complete. No other cock will dare to meet him, but will run from him.'

passages.zh: 孔子觀於呂梁，縣水三十仞，流沫四十里，黿鼉魚龞之所不能游也。
passages.en: Confucius was looking at the cataract near the gorge of Lu, which fell a height of 240 cubits, and the spray of which floated a distance of forty li, (producing a turbulence) in which no tortoise, gavial, fish, or turtle could play.

passages.zh: 見一丈夫游之，以為有苦而欲死也，使弟子並流而拯之。
passages.en: He saw, however, an old man swimming about in it, as if he had sustained some great calamity, and wished to end his life. Confucius made his disciples hasten along the stream to rescue the man.

passages.zh: 數百步而出，被髮行歌而游於塘下。
passages.en: And by the time they had gone several hundred paces, he was walking along singing, with his hair dishevelled, and enjoying himself at the foot of the embankment.

passages.zh: 孔子從而問焉，曰：「吾以子為鬼，察子則人也。
passages.en: Confucius followed and asked him, saying, 'I thought you were a sprite; but, when I look closely at you, I see that you are a man.

passages.zh: 請問蹈水有道乎？」
passages.en: Let me ask if you have any particular way of treading the water.'

passages.zh: 曰：「亡，吾無道。
passages.en: The man said, 'No, I have no particular way.

passages.zh: 吾始乎故，長乎性，成乎命。
passages.en: I began (to learn the art) at the very earliest time; as I grew up, it became my nature to practise it; and my success in it now is as sure as fate.

passages.zh: 與齊俱入，與汩偕出，從水之道而不為私焉。
passages.en: I enter and go down with the water in the very centre of its whirl, and come up again with it when it whirls the other way. I follow the way of the water, and do nothing contrary to it of myself - this is how I tread it.'

passages.zh: 此吾所以蹈之也。」
孔子曰：「何謂始乎故，長乎性，成乎命？」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'What do you mean by saying that you began to learn the art at the very earliest time; that as you grew up, it became your nature to practise it, and that your success in it now is as sure as fate?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾生於陵而安於陵，故也；長於水而安於水，性也；不知吾所以然而然，命也。」
passages.en: The man replied, 'I was born among these hills and lived contented among them - that was why I say that I have trod this water from my earliest time. I grew up by it, and have been happy treading it - that is why I said that to tread it had become natural to me. I know not how I do it, and yet I do it - that is why I say that my success is as sure as fate.'

passages.zh: 梓慶削木為鐻，鐻成，見者驚猶鬼神。
passages.en: Qing, the Worker in Rottlera wood, carved a bell-stand, and when it was completed, all who saw it were astonished as if it were the work of spirits.

passages.zh: 魯侯見而問焉，曰：「子何術以為焉？」
passages.en: The marquis of Lu went to see it, and asked by what art he had succeeded in producing it.

passages.zh: 對曰：「臣工人，何術之有！
passages.en: 'Your subject is but a mechanic,' was the reply; 'what art should I be possessed of?

passages.zh: 雖然，有一焉。
passages.en: Nevertheless, there is one thing (which I will mention).

passages.zh: 臣將為鐻，未嘗敢以耗氣也，必齊以靜心。
passages.en: When your servant had undertaken to make the bell-stand, I did not venture to waste any of my power, and felt it necessary to fast in order to compose my mind.

passages.zh: 齊三日，而不敢懷慶賞爵祿；齊五日，不敢懷非譽巧拙；齊七日，輒然忘吾有四枝形體也。
passages.en: After fasting for three days, I did not presume to think of any congratulation, reward, rank, or emolument (which I might obtain by the execution of my task); after fasting five days, I did not presume to think of the condemnation or commendation (which it would produce), or of the skill or want of skill (which it might display). At the end of the seven days, I had forgotten all about myself - my four limbs and my whole person.

passages.zh: 當是時也，無公朝，其巧專而外骨消；然後入山林，觀天性；形軀至矣，然後成見鐻，然後加手焉；不然則已。
passages.en: By this time the thought of your Grace's court (for which I was to make the thing) had passed away; everything that could divert my mind from exclusive devotion to the exercise of my skill had disappeared. Then I went into the forest, and looked at the natural forms of the trees. When I saw one of a perfect form, then the figure of the bell-stand rose up to my view, and I applied my hand to the work. Had I not met with such a tree, I must have abandoned the object.

passages.zh: 則以天合天，器之所以疑神者，其是與？」
passages.en: But my Heaven-given faculty and the Heaven-given qualities of the wood were concentrated on it. So it was that my spirit was thus engaged in the production of the bell-stand.'

passages.zh: 東野稷以御見莊公，進退中繩，左右旋中規。
passages.en: Dong-ye Ji was introduced to duke Zhuang to exhibit his driving. His horses went forwards and backwards with the straightness of a line, and wheeled to the right and the left with the exactness of a circle.

passages.zh: 莊公以為文弗過也，使之鉤百而反。
passages.en: The duke thought that the lines and circles could not be surpassed if they were woven with silken strings, and told him to make a hundred circuits on the same lines.

passages.zh: 顏闔遇之，入見曰：「稷之馬將敗。」
passages.en: On the road Yan He met the equipage, and on entering (the palace), and seeing the duke, he said, 'Ji's horses will break down,' but the duke was silent, and gave him no reply.

passages.zh: 公密而不應。
少焉，果敗而反。
passages.en: After a little the horses did come back, having broken down.

passages.zh: 公曰：「子何以知之？」
passages.en: The duke then said, 'How did you know that it would be so?'

passages.zh: 曰：「其馬力竭矣，而猶求焉，故曰敗。」
passages.en: Yan He said, 'The horses were exhausted, and he was still urging them on. It was this which made me say that they would break down.'

passages.zh: 工倕旋而蓋規矩，指與物化，而不以心稽，故其靈臺一而不桎。
passages.en: The artisan Chui made things round (and square) more exactly than if he had used the circle and square. The operation of his fingers on (the forms of) things was like the transformations of them (in nature), and required no application of his mind; and so his Intelligence was entire and encountered no resistance.

passages.zh: 忘足，履之適也；忘要，帶之適也；知忘是非，心之適也；不內變，不外從，事會之適也。
passages.en: To be unthought of by the foot that wears it is the fitness of a shoe; to be unthought of by the waist is the fitness of a girdle. When one's wisdom does not think of the right or the wrong (of a question under discussion), that shows the suitability of the mind (for the question); when one is conscious of no inward change, or outward attraction, that shows the mastery of affairs.

passages.zh: 始乎適而未嘗不適者，忘適之適也。
passages.en: He who perceives at once the fitness, and never loses the sense of it, has the fitness that forgets all about what is fitting.

passages.zh: 有孫休者，踵門而詫子扁慶子曰：「休居鄉不見謂不修，臨難不見謂不勇，然而田原不遇歲，事君不遇世，賓於鄉里，逐於州部，則胡罪乎天哉？
passages.en: There was a Sun Xiu who went to the door of Zi-bian Qing-zi, and said to him in a strange perturbed way, 'When I lived in my village, no one took notice of me, but all said that I did not cultivate (my fields); in a time of trouble and attack, no one took notice of me, but all said that I had no courage. But that I did not cultivate my fields, was really because I never met with a good year; and that I did not do service for our ruler, was because I did not meet with the suitable opportunity to do so. I have been sent about my business by the villagers, and am driven away by the registrars of the district - what is my crime? 0 Heaven! how is it that I have met with such a fate?'

passages.zh: 休惡遇此命也？」
扁子曰：「子獨不聞夫至人之自行邪？
passages.en: Bian-zi said to him, 'Have you not heard how the perfect man deals with himself?

passages.zh: 忘其肝膽，遺其耳目，芒然彷徨乎塵垢之外，逍遙乎無事之業，是謂『為而不恃，長而不宰』。
passages.en: He forgets that he has a liver and gall. He takes no thought of his ears and eyes. He seems lost and aimless beyond the dust and dirt of the world, and enjoys himself at ease in occupations untroubled by the affairs of business. He may be described as acting and yet not relying on what he does, as being superior and yet not using his superiority to exercise any control.

passages.zh: 今汝飾知以驚愚，修身以明汙，昭昭乎若揭日月而行也。
passages.en: But now you would make a display of your wisdom to astonish the ignorant; you would cultivate your person to make the inferiority of others more apparent; you seek to shine as if you were carrying the sun and moon in your hands.

passages.zh: 汝得全而形軀，具而九竅，無中道夭於聾盲跛蹇而比於人數，亦幸矣，又何暇乎天之怨哉！
passages.en: That you are complete in your bodily frame, and possess all its nine openings; that you have not met with any calamity in the middle of your course, such as deafness, blindness, or lameness, and can still take your place as a man among other men - in all this you are fortunate. What leisure have you to murmur against Heaven?

passages.zh: 子往矣！」
passages.en: Go away, Sir.'

passages.zh: 孫子出。
passages.en: Sun-zi on this went out, and Bian-zi went inside.

passages.zh: 扁子入坐，有間，仰天而歎。
passages.en: Having sitten down, after a little time he looked up to heaven, and sighed.

passages.zh: 弟子問曰：「先生何為歎乎？」
passages.en: His disciples asked him why he sighed.

passages.zh: 扁子曰：「向者休來，吾告之以至人之德，吾恐其驚而遂至於惑也。」
passages.en: He said to them, 'Xiu came to me a little while ago, and I told him the characteristics of the perfect man. I am afraid he will be frightened, and get into a state of perplexity.'

passages.zh: 弟子曰：「不然。
passages.en: His disciples said, 'Not so.

passages.zh: 孫子之所言是邪，先生之所言非邪，非固不能惑是。
passages.en: If what he said was right, and what you said was wrong, the wrong will certainly not be able to perplex the right.

passages.zh: 孫子所言非邪，先生所言是邪，彼固惑而來矣，又奚罪焉？」
passages.en: If what he said was wrong, and what you said was right, it was just because he was perplexed that he came to you. What was your fault in dealing with him as you did?'

passages.zh: 扁子曰：「不然。
passages.en: Bian-zi said, 'Not so.

passages.zh: 昔者有鳥止於魯郊，魯君說之，為具太牢以饗之，奏九韶以樂之，鳥乃始憂悲眩視，不敢飲食。
passages.en: Formerly a bird came, and took up its seat in the suburbs of Lu. The ruler of Lu was pleased with it, and provided an ox, a sheep, and a pig to feast it, causing also the Jiu-shao to be performed to delight it. But the bird began to be sad, looked dazed, and did not venture to eat or drink.

passages.zh: 此之謂以己養養鳥也。
passages.en: This was what is called "Nourishing a bird, as you would nourish yourself."

passages.zh: 若夫以鳥養養鳥者，宜棲之深林，浮之江湖，食之以委蛇，則平陸而已矣。
passages.en: He who would nourish a bird as a bird should be nourished should let it perch in a deep forest, or let it float on a river or lake, or let it find its food naturally and undisturbed on the level dry ground.

passages.zh: 今休，款啟寡聞之民也，吾告以至人之德，譬之若載鼷以車馬，樂鴳以鐘鼓也。
passages.en: Now Xiu (came to me), a man of slender intelligence, and slight information, and I told him of the characteristics of the perfect man, it was like using a carriage and horses to convey a mouse, or trying to delight a quail with the music of bells and drums - could the creatures help being frightened?'

passages.zh: 彼又奚能無驚乎哉？」
莊子行於山中，見大木，枝葉盛茂，伐木者止其旁而不取也。
passages.en: Zhuangzi was walking on a mountain, when he saw a great tree with huge branches and luxuriant foliage. A wood-cutter was resting by its side, but he would not touch it.

passages.zh: 問其故。
passages.en: When asked the reason, he said, that it was of no use for anything.

passages.zh: 曰：「無所可用。」
莊子曰：「此木以不材得終其天年。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi then said to his disciples, 'This tree, because its wood is good for nothing, will succeed in living out its natural term of years.'

passages.zh: 夫子出於山，舍於故人之家。
passages.en: Having left the mountain, the Master lodged in the house of an old friend, who was glad to see him, and ordered his waiting-lad to kill a goose and boil it.

passages.zh: 故人喜，命豎子殺鴈而烹之。
豎子請曰：「其一能鳴，其一不能鳴，請奚殺？」
passages.en: The lad said, 'One of our geese can cackle, and the other cannot - which of them shall I kill?'

passages.zh: 主人曰：「殺不能鳴者。」
passages.en: The host said, 'Kill the one that cannot cackle.'

passages.zh: 明日，弟子問於莊子曰：「昨日山中之木，以不材得終其天年；今主人之鴈，以不材死。
passages.en: Next day, his disciples asked Zhuangzi, saying, 'Yesterday the tree on the mountain (you said) would live out its years because of the uselessness of its wood, and now our host's goose has died because of its want of power (to cackle).

passages.zh: 先生將何處？」
passages.en: Which of these conditions, Master, would you prefer to be in?'

passages.zh: 莊子笑曰：「周將處夫材與不材之間。
passages.en: Zhuangzi laughed and said, '(If I said that) I would prefer to be in a position between being fit to be useful and wanting that fitness, that would seem to be the right position, but it would not be so, for it would not put me beyond being involved in trouble.

passages.zh: 材與不材之間，似之而非也，故未免乎累。
若夫乘道德而浮游則不然。
passages.en: Whereas one who takes his seat on the Dao and its Attributes, and there finds his ease and enjoyment, is not exposed to such a contingency.

passages.zh: 無譽無訾，一龍一蛇，與時俱化，而無肯專為；一上一下，以和為量，浮游乎萬物之祖；物物而不物於物，則胡可得而累邪！
passages.en: He is above the reach both of praise and of detraction; now he (mounts aloft) like a dragon, now he (keeps beneath) like a snake; he is transformed with the (changing) character of the time, and is not willing to addict himself to any one thing; now in a high position and now in a low, he is in harmony with all his surroundings; he enjoys himself at ease with the Author of all things; he treats things as things, and is not a thing to them: where is his liability to be involved in trouble?

passages.zh: 此黃帝、神農之法則也。
passages.en: This was the method of Shen Nong and Huang-Di.

passages.zh: 若夫萬物之情，人倫之傳，則不然。
passages.en: As to those who occupy themselves with the qualities of things, and with the teaching and practice of the human relations, it is not so with them.

passages.zh: 合則離，成則毀，廉則挫，尊則議，有為則虧，賢則謀，不肖則欺，胡可得而必乎哉？
passages.en: Union brings on separation; success, overthrow; sharp corners, the use of the file; honour, critical remarks; active exertion, failure; wisdom, scheming; inferiority, being despised: where is the possibility of unchangeableness in any of these conditions?

passages.zh: 悲夫！
passages.en: Remember this, my disciples.

passages.zh: 弟子志之，其唯道德之鄉乎！」
passages.en: Let your abode be here - in the Dao and its Attributes.'

passages.zh: 市南宜僚見魯侯，魯侯有憂色。
passages.en: Yi-liao, an officer of Shi-nan, having an interview with the marquis of Lu, found him looking sad.

passages.zh: 市南子曰：「君有憂色，何也？」
passages.en: He asked him why he was so.

passages.zh: 魯侯曰：「吾學先王之道，修先君之業，吾敬鬼尊賢，親而行之，無須臾離居，然不免於患，吾是以憂。」
passages.en: The marquis said, 'I have studied the ways of the former kings, and cultivated the inheritance left me by my predecessors. I reverence the spirits of the departed and honour the men of worth, doing this with personal devotion, and without the slightest intermission. Notwithstanding, I do not avoid meeting with calamity, and this it is which makes me sad.'

passages.zh: 市南子曰：「君之除患之術淺矣。
passages.en: The officer said, 'The arts by which you try to remove calamity are shallow.

passages.zh: 夫豐狐文豹，棲於山林，伏於巖穴，靜也；夜行晝居，戒也；雖飢渴隱約，猶旦胥疏於江湖之上而求食焉，定也。
passages.en: Think of the close-furred fox and of the elegantly-spotted leopard. They lodge in the forests on the hills, and lurk in their holes among the rocks - keeping still. At night they go about, and during day remain in their lairs - so cautious are they. Even if they are suffering from hunger, thirst, and other distresses, they still keep aloof from men, seeking their food about the Jiang and the Hu - so resolute are they.

passages.zh: 然且不免於罔羅機辟之患，是何罪之有哉？
passages.en: Still they are not able to escape the danger of the net or the trap; and what fault is it of theirs?

passages.zh: 其皮為之災也。
passages.en: It is their skins which occasion them the calamity.

passages.zh: 今魯國獨非君之皮邪？
passages.en: And is not the state of Lu your lordship's skin?

passages.zh: 吾願君刳形去皮，洒心去欲，而遊於無人之野。
passages.en: I wish your lordship to rip your skin from your body, to cleanse your heart, to put away your desires, and to enjoy yourself where you will be without the presence of any one.

passages.zh: 南越有邑焉，名為建德之國。
passages.en: In the southern state of Yue, there is a district called "the State of Established Virtue."

passages.zh: 其民愚而朴，少私而寡欲；知作而不知藏，與而不求其報；不知義之所適，不知禮之所將；猖狂妄行，乃蹈乎大方；其生可樂，其死可葬。
passages.en: The people are ignorant and simple; their object is to minimise the thought of self and make their desires few; they labour but do not lay up their gains; they give but do not seek for any return; they do not know what righteousness is required of them in any particular case, nor by what ceremonies their performances should be signalised; acting in a wild and eccentric way as if they were mad, they yet keep to the grand rules of conduct. Their birth is an occasion for joy; their death is followed by the rites of burial.

passages.zh: 吾願君去國捐俗，與道相輔而行。」
passages.en: I should wish your lordship to leave your state; to give up your ordinary ways, and to proceed to that country by the directest course.'

passages.zh: 君曰：「彼其道遠而險，又有江山，我無舟車，奈何？」
passages.en: The ruler said, 'The way to it is distant and difficult; there are rivers and hills; and as I have neither boat nor carriage, how am I to go?'

passages.zh: 市南子曰：「君無形倨，無留居，以為舟車。」
passages.en: The officer from Shi-nan rejoined, 'If your lordship abjure your personal state, and give up your wish to remain here, that will serve you for a carriage.'

passages.zh: 君曰：「彼其道幽遠而無人，吾誰與為鄰？
passages.en: The ruler rejoined, 'The way to it is solitary and distant, and there are no people on it - whom shall I have as my companions?

passages.zh: 吾無糧，我無食，安得而至焉？」
passages.en: I have no provisions prepared, and how shall I get food? How shall I be able to get (to the country)?'

passages.zh: 市南子曰：「少君之費，寡君之欲，雖無糧而乃足。
passages.en: The officer said, 'Minimise your lordship's expenditure, and make your wants few, and though you have no provisions prepared, you will find you have enough.

passages.zh: 君其涉於江而浮於海，望之而不見其崖，愈往而不知其所窮。
passages.en: Wade through the rivers and float along on the sea, where however you look, you see not the shore, and, the farther you go, you do not see where your journey is to end.

passages.zh: 送君者皆自崖而反，君自此遠矣。
passages.en: Those who escorted you to the shore will return, and after that you will feel yourself far away.

passages.zh: 故有人者累，見有於人者憂。
passages.en: Thus it is that he who owns men (as their ruler) is involved in troubles, and he who is owned by men (as their ruler) suffers from sadness.

passages.zh: 故堯非有人，非見有於人也。
passages.en: Hence Yao would neither own men, nor be owned by them.

passages.zh: 吾願去君之累，除君之憂，而獨與道遊於大莫之國。
passages.en: I wish to remove your trouble, and take away your sadness, and it is only (to be done by inducing you) to enjoy yourself with the Dao in the land of Great Vacuity.

passages.zh: 方舟而濟於河，有虛船來觸舟，雖有惼心之人不怒；有一人在其上，則呼張歙之；一呼而不聞，再呼而不聞，於是三呼邪，則必以惡聲隨之。
passages.en: If a man is crossing a river in a boat, and another empty vessel comes into collision with it, even though he be a man of a choleric temper, he will not be angry with it. If there be a person, however, in that boat, he will bawl out to him to haul out of the way. If his shout be not heard, he will repeat it; and if the other do not then hear, he will call out a third time, following up the shout with abusive terms.

passages.zh: 向也不怒而今也怒，向也虛而今也實。
passages.en: Formerly he was not angry, but now he is; formerly (he thought) the boat was empty, but now there is a person in it.

passages.zh: 人能虛己以遊世，其孰能害之！」
passages.en: If a man can empty himself of himself, during his time in the world, who can harm him?'

passages.zh: 北宮奢為衛靈公賦斂以為鐘，為壇乎國門之外，三月而成上下之縣。
passages.en: Bei-gong She was collecting taxes for duke Ling of Wei, to be employed in making (a peal of) bells. (In connexion with the work) he built an altar outside the gate of the suburban wall; and in three months the bells were completed, even to the suspending of the upper and lower (tiers).

passages.zh: 王子慶忌見而問焉，曰：「子何術之設？」
passages.en: The king's son Qing-ji saw them, and asked what arts he had employed in the making of them.

passages.zh: 奢曰：「一之間，無敢設也。
passages.en: She replied, 'Besides my undivided attention to them, I did not venture to use any arts.

passages.zh: 奢聞之：『既彫既琢，復歸於朴。』
passages.en: I have heard the saying, "After all the carving and the chiselling, let the object be to return to simplicity."

passages.zh: 侗乎其無識，儻乎其怠疑；萃乎芒乎，其送往而迎來；來者勿禁，往者勿止；從其彊梁，隨其曲傅，因其自窮。
passages.en: I was as a child who has no knowledge; I was extraordinarily slow and hesitating; they grew like the springing plants of themselves. In escorting those who went and meeting those who came, my object was neither to hinder the comers nor detain the goers. I suffered those who strongly opposed to take their way, and accepted those who did their best to come to terms. I allowed them all to do the utmost they could.

passages.zh: 故朝夕賦斂而毫毛不挫，而況有大塗者乎！」
passages.en: And in this way morning and evening I collected the taxes. I did not have the slightest trouble, and how much more will this be the case with those who pursue the Great Way (on a grand scale)!'

passages.zh: 孔子圍於陳、蔡之間，七日不火食。
passages.en: Confucius was kept (by his enemies) in a state of siege between Chen and Cai, and for seven days had no food cooked with fire to eat.

passages.zh: 大公任往弔之，曰：「子幾死乎？」
passages.en: The Da-gong Ren went to condole with him, and said, 'You had nearly met with your death.'
'Yes,' was the reply.

passages.zh: 「子惡死乎？」
passages.en: 'Do you dislike death?'
'I do.'

passages.zh: 任曰：「予嘗言不死之道。
passages.en: Then Ren continued, 'Let me try and describe a way by which (such a) death may be avoided.

passages.zh: 東海有鳥焉，其名曰意怠。
passages.en: In the eastern sea there are birds which go by the name of yi-dai.

passages.zh: 其為鳥也，翂翂翐翐，而似無能；引援而飛，迫脅而棲；進不敢為前，退不敢為後；食不敢先嘗，必取其緒。
passages.en: They fly low and slowly as if they were deficient in power. They fly as if they were leading and assisting one another, and they press on one another when they roost. No one ventures to take the lead in going forward, or to be the last in going backwards. In eating no one ventures to take the first mouthful, but prefers the fragments left by others.

passages.zh: 是故其行列不斥，而外人卒不得害，是以免於患。
passages.en: In this way (the breaks in) their line are not many, and men outside them cannot harm them, so that they escape injury.

passages.zh: 直木先伐，甘井先竭。
passages.en: The straight tree is the first to be cut down; the well of sweet water is the first to be exhausted.

passages.zh: 子其意者飾知以驚愚，修身以明汙，昭昭乎若揭日月而行，故不免也。
passages.en: Your aim is to embellish your wisdom so as to startle the ignorant, and to cultivate your person to show the unsightliness of others. A light shines around you as if you were carrying with you the sun and moon, and thus it is that you do not escape such calamity.

passages.zh: 昔吾聞之大成之人曰：『自伐者無功，功成者墮，名成者虧。』
passages.en: Formerly I heard a highly accomplished man say, "Those who boast have no merit. The merit which is deemed complete will begin to decay. The fame which is deemed complete will begin to wane."

passages.zh: 孰能去功與名而還與眾人！
passages.en: Who can rid himself of (the ideas of) merit and fame, and return and put himself on the level of the masses of men?

passages.zh: 道流而不明居，得行而不名處；純純常常，乃比於狂；削跡捐勢，不為功名。
passages.en: The practice of the Dao flows abroad, but its master does not care to dwell where it can be seen; his attainments in it hold their course, but he does not wish to appear in its display. Always simple and commonplace, he may seem to be bereft of reason. He obliterates the traces of his action, gives up position and power, and aims not at merit and fame.

passages.zh: 是故無責於人，人亦無責焉。
passages.en: Therefore he does not censure men, and men do not censure him.

passages.zh: 至人不聞，子何喜哉？」
passages.en: The perfect man does not seek to be heard of; how is it that you delight in doing so?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「善哉！」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'Excellent.'

passages.zh: 辭其交遊，去其弟子，逃於大澤；衣裘褐，食杼栗；入獸不亂群，入鳥不亂行。
passages.en: And thereupon he took leave of his associates, forsook his disciples, retired to the neighbourhood of a great marsh, wore skins and hair cloth, and ate acorns and chestnuts. He went among animals without causing any confusion among their herds, and among birds without troubling their movements.

passages.zh: 鳥獸不惡，而況人乎！
passages.en: Birds and beasts did not dislike him; how much less would men do so!

passages.zh: 孔子問子桑雽曰：「吾再逐於魯，伐樹於宋，削跡於衛，窮於商、周，圍於陳、蔡之間。
passages.en: Confucius asked Zi-sang Hu, saying, 'I was twice driven from Lu; the tree was felled over me in Song; I was obliged to disappear from Wei; I was reduced to extreme distress in Shang and Zhou; and I was kept in a state of siege between Chen and Cai.

passages.zh: 吾犯此數患，親交益疏，徒友益散，何與？」
passages.en: I have encountered these various calamities; my intimate associates are removed from me more and more; my followers and friends are more and more dispersed - why have all these things befallen me?'

passages.zh: 子桑雽曰：「子獨不聞假人之亡與？
passages.en: Zi-sang Hu replied, 'Have you not heard of the flight of Lin Hui of Jia.

passages.zh: 林回棄千金之璧，負赤子而趨。
passages.en: He abandoned his round jade symbol of rank, worth a thousand pieces of silver, and hurried away with his infant son on his back.

passages.zh: 或曰：『為其布與？
passages.en: If it be asked, "Was it because of the market value of the child?"

passages.zh: 赤子之布寡矣。
passages.en: But that value was small (compared with the value of the jade token).

passages.zh: 為其累與？
passages.en: If it be asked again, "Was it because of the troubles (of his office)?"

passages.zh: 赤子之累多矣。
passages.en: But the child would occasion him much more trouble.

passages.zh: 棄千金之璧，負赤子而趨，何也？』
passages.en: Why was it then that, abandoning the jade token, worth a thousand pieces of silver, he hurried away with the child on his back?

passages.zh: 林回曰：『彼以利合，此以天屬也。』
passages.en: Lin Hui (himself) said, "The union between me and the token rested on the ground of gain; that between me and the child was of Heaven's appointment."

passages.zh: 夫以利合者，迫窮禍患害相棄也；以天屬者，迫窮禍患害相收也。
passages.en: Where the bond of union is its profitableness, when the pressure of poverty, calamity, distress, and injury come, the parties abandon one another; when it is of Heaven's appointment, they hold in the same circumstances to one another.

passages.zh: 夫相收之與相棄亦遠矣。
passages.en: Now between abandoning one another, and holding to one another, the difference is great.

passages.zh: 且君子之交淡若水，小人之交甘若醴；君子淡以親，小人甘以絕。
passages.en: Moreover, the intercourse of superior men is tasteless as water, while that of mean men is sweet as new wine. But the tastelessness of the superior men leads on to affection, and the sweetness of the mean men to aversion.

passages.zh: 彼無故以合者，則無故以離。」
passages.en: The union which originates without any cause will end in separation without any cause.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「敬聞命矣。」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'I have reverently received your instructions.'

passages.zh: 徐行翔佯而歸，絕學捐書，弟子無挹於前，其愛益加進。
passages.en: And hereupon, with a slow step and an assumed air of ease, he returned to his own house. There he made an end of studying and put away his books. His disciples came no more to make their bow to him (and be taught), but their affection for him increased the more.

passages.zh: 異日，桑雽又曰：「舜之將死，真泠禹曰：『汝戒之哉！
passages.en: Another day Sang Hu said further to him, 'When Shun was about to die, he charged Yu, saying, 'Be upon your guard.

passages.zh: 形莫若緣，情莫若率。
passages.en: (The attraction of) the person is not like that of sympathy; the (power of) affection is not like the leading (of example).

passages.zh: 緣則不離，率則不勞；不離不勞，則不求文以待形；不求文以待形，固不待物。』」
passages.en: Where there is sympathy, there will not be separation; where there is (the leading of) example, there will be no toil. Where there is neither separation nor toil, you will not have to seek the decoration of forms to make the person attractive, and where there is no such need of those forms, there will certainly be none for external things.'

passages.zh: 莊子衣大布而補之，正緳係履而過魏王。
passages.en: Zhuangzi in a patched dress of coarse cloth, and having his shoes tied together with strings, was passing by the king of Wei.

passages.zh: 魏王曰：「何先生之憊邪？」
passages.en: The king said to him, 'How great, Master, is your distress?'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「貧也，非憊也。
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'It is poverty, not distress!

passages.zh: 士有道德不能行，憊也。
passages.en: While a scholar possesses the Dao and its Attributes, he cannot be going about in distress.

passages.zh: 衣弊履穿，貧也，非憊也，此所謂非遭時也。
passages.en: Tattered clothes and shoes tied on the feet are the sign of poverty, and not of distress. This is what we call not meeting with the right time.

passages.zh: 王獨不見夫騰猿乎？
passages.en: Has your majesty not seen the climbing monkey?

passages.zh: 其得柟、梓、豫、章也，攬蔓其枝，而王長其間，雖羿、蓬蒙不能眄睨也。
passages.en: When he is among the plane trees, rottleras, oaks, and camphor trees, he grasps and twists their branches (into a screen), where he reigns quite at his ease, so that not even Yi or Peng Meng could spy him out.

passages.zh: 及其得柘、棘、枳、枸之閒也，危行側視，振動悼慄，此筋骨非有加急而不柔也，處勢不便，未足以逞其能也。
passages.en: When, however, he finds himself among the prickly mulberry and date trees, and other thorns, he goes cautiously, casts sidelong glances, and takes every trembling movement with apprehension - it is not that his sinews and bones are straitened, and have lost their suppleness, but the situation is unsuitable for him, and he cannot display his agility.

passages.zh: 今處昏上亂相之間，而欲無憊，奚可得邪？
passages.en: And now when I dwell under a benighted ruler, and seditious ministers, how is it possible for me not to be in distress?

passages.zh: 此比干之見剖心，徵也夫！」
passages.en: My case might afford an illustration of the cutting out the heart of Bi-gan!'

passages.zh: 孔子窮於陳、蔡之間，七日不火食，左據槁木，右擊槁枝，而歌猋氏之風，有其具而無其數，有其聲而無宮角，木聲與人聲，犁然有當於人心。
passages.en: When Confucius was reduced to great distress between Chen and Cai, and for seven days he had no cooked food to eat, he laid hold of a decayed tree with his left hand, and with his right hand tapped it with a decayed branch, singing all the while the ode of Biao-shi. He had his instrument, but the notes were not marked on it. There was a noise, but no blended melody. The sound of the wood and the voice of the man came together like the noise of the plough through the ground, yet suitably to the feelings of the disciples around.

passages.zh: 顏回端拱還目而窺之。
passages.en: Yan Hui, who was standing upright, with his hands crossed on his breast, rolled his eyes round to observe him.

passages.zh: 仲尼恐其廣己而造大也，愛己而造哀也，曰：「回！
passages.en: Zhongni, fearing that Hui would go to excess in manifesting how he honoured himself, or be plunged in sorrow through his love for him, said to him, 'Hui.

passages.zh: 無受天損易，無受人益難。
passages.en: Not to receive (as evils) the inflictions of Heaven is easy; not to receive (as benefits) the favours of men is difficult.

passages.zh: 無始而非卒也，人與天一也。
passages.en: There is no beginning which was not an end. The Human and the Heavenly may be one and the same.

passages.zh: 夫今之歌者其誰乎？」
passages.en: Who, for instance, is it that is now singing?'

passages.zh: 回曰：「敢問無受天損易。」
passages.en: Hui said, 'I venture to ask how not to receive (as evils) the inflictions of Heaven is easy.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「飢溺寒暑，窮桎不行，天地之行也，運物之泄也，言與之偕逝之謂也。
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'Hunger, thirst, cold, and heat, and having one's progress entirely blocked up - these are the doings of Heaven and Earth, necessary incidents in the revolutions of things. They are occurrences of which we say that we will pass on (composedly) along with them.

passages.zh: 為人臣者，不敢去之。
passages.en: The minister of another does not dare to refuse his commands.

passages.zh: 執臣之道猶若是，而況乎所以待天乎！」
passages.en: And if he who is discharging the duty of a minister feels it necessary to act thus, how much more should we wait with ease on the commands of Heaven!'

passages.zh: 「何謂無受人益難？」
passages.en: 'What do you mean by saying that not to receive (as benefits) the favours of men is difficult?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「始用四達，爵祿並至而不窮，物之所利，乃非己也，吾命有在外者也。
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'As soon as one is employed in office, he gets forward in all directions; rank and emolument come to him together, and without end. But these advantages do not come from one's self - it is my appointed lot to have such external good.

passages.zh: 君子不為盜，賢人不為竊。
passages.en: The superior man is not a robber; the man of worth is no filcher.

passages.zh: 吾若取之，何哉？
passages.en: If I prefer such things, what am I?

passages.zh: 故曰：鳥莫知於鷾鴯，目之所不宜處，不給視，雖落其實，棄之而走。
passages.en: Hence it is said, "There is no bird wiser than the swallow." Where its eye lights on a place that is not suitable for it, it does not give it a second glance. Though it may drop the food from its mouth, it abandons it, and hurries off.

passages.zh: 其畏人也，而襲諸人間，社稷存焉爾。」
passages.en: It is afraid of men, and yet it stealthily takes up its dwelling by his; finding its protection in the altars of the Land and Grain.'

passages.zh: 「何謂無始而非卒？」
passages.en: 'What do you mean by saying that there is no beginning which was not an end?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「化其萬物而不知其禪之者，焉知其所終？
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'The change-- rise and dissolution-- of all things (continually) goes on, but we do not know who it is that maintains and continues the process. How do we know when any one begins?

passages.zh: 焉知其所始？
passages.en: How do we know when he will end?

passages.zh: 正而待之而已耳。」
passages.en: We have simply to wait for it, and nothing more.'

passages.zh: 「何謂天與人一邪？」
passages.en: 'And what do you mean by saying that the Human and the Heavenly are one and the same?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「有人，天也；有天，亦天也。
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'Given man, and you have Heaven; given Heaven, and you still have Heaven (and nothing more).

passages.zh: 人之不能有天，性也，聖人晏然體逝而終矣。」
passages.en: That man can not have Heaven is owing to the limitation of his nature. The sagely man quietly passes away with his body, and there is an end of it.'

passages.zh: 莊周遊乎雕陵之樊，睹一異鵲自南方來者，翼廣七尺，目大運寸，感周之顙而集於栗林。
passages.en: As Zhuang Zhou was rambling in the park of Diao-ling he saw a strange bird which came from the south. Its wings were seven cubits in width, and its eyes were large, an inch in circuit. It touched the forehead of Zhou as it passed him, and lighted in a grove of chestnut trees.

passages.zh: 莊周曰：「此何鳥哉？
passages.en: 'What bird is this?' said he, 'with such great wings not to go on! and with such large eyes not to see me!'

passages.zh: 翼殷不逝，目大不覩。」
蹇裳躩步，執彈而留之。
passages.en: He lifted up his skirts, and hurried with his cross-bow, waiting for (an opportunity to shoot) it.

passages.zh: 睹一蟬方得美蔭而忘其身；螳蜋執翳而搏之，見得而忘其形；異鵲從而利之，見利而忘其真。
passages.en: (Meanwhile) he saw a cicada, which had just alighted in a beautiful shady spot, and forgot its (care for its) body. (Just then), a preying mantis raised its feelers, and pounced on the cicada, in its eagerness for its prey, (also) forgetting (its care for) its body; while the strange bird took advantage of its opportunity to secure them both, in view of that gain forgetting its true (instinct of preservation).

passages.zh: 莊周怵然曰：「噫！
passages.en: Zhuang Zhou with an emotion of pity, said, 'Ah!

passages.zh: 物固相累，二類相召也。」
passages.en: So it is that things bring evil on one another, each of these creatures invited its own calamity.'

passages.zh: 捐彈而反走，虞人逐而誶之。
passages.en: (With this) he put away his cross-bow, and was hurrying away back, when the forester pursued him with terms of reproach.

passages.zh: 莊周反入，三月不庭。
passages.en: When he returned and went into his house, he did not appear in his courtyard for three months.

passages.zh: 藺且從而問之：「夫子何為頃間甚不庭乎？」
passages.en: (When he came out), Lin Qie (his disciple) asked him, saying, 'Master, why have you for this some time avoided the courtyard so much?'

passages.zh: 莊周曰：「吾守形而忘身，觀於濁水而迷於清淵。
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'I was guarding my person, and forgot myself; I was looking at turbid water, till I mistook the clear pool.

passages.zh: 且吾聞諸夫子曰：『入其俗，從其俗。』
passages.en: And moreover I have heard the Master say, "Going where certain customs prevail, you should follow those customs."

passages.zh: 今吾遊於雕陵而忘吾身，異鵲感吾顙，遊於栗林而忘真，栗林虞人以吾為戮，吾所以不庭也。」
passages.en: I was walking about in the park of Diao-ling, and forgot myself. A strange bird brushed past my forehead, and went flying about in the grove of chestnuts, where it forgot the true (art of preserving itself). The forester of the chestnut grove thought that I was a fitting object for his reproach. These are the reasons why I have avoided the courtyard.'

passages.zh: 陽子之宋，宿於逆旅。
passages.en: Yang-zi, having gone to Song, passed the night in a lodging-house.

passages.zh: 逆旅有妾二人，其一人美，其一人惡，惡者貴而美者賤。
passages.en: The master of the house had two concubines - one beautiful, the other ugly. The ugly one was honoured, however, and the beautiful one contemned.

passages.zh: 陽子問其故，逆旅小子對曰：「其美者自美，吾不知其美也；其惡者自惡，吾不知其惡也。」
passages.en: Yang-zi asked the reason, and a little boy of the house replied, 'The beauty knows her beauty, and we do not recognise it. The ugly one knows her ugliness, and we do not recognise it.'

passages.zh: 陽子曰：「弟子記之！
passages.en: Yang-zi said, 'Remember it, my disciples.

passages.zh: 行賢而去自賢之行，安往而不愛哉？」
passages.en: Act virtuously, and put away the practice of priding yourselves on your virtue. If you do this, where can you go to that you will not be loved?'

passages.zh: 田子方侍坐於魏文侯，數稱谿工。
passages.en: Tian Zi-fang, sitting in attendance on the marquis Wen of Wei, often quoted (with approbation) the words of Qi Gong.

passages.zh: 文侯曰：「谿工，子之師邪？」
passages.en: The marquis said, 'Is Qi Gong your preceptor?'

passages.zh: 子方曰：「非也。無擇之里人也，稱道數當，故無擇稱之。」
passages.en: Zi-fang replied, 'No. He only belongs to the same neighbourhood. In speaking about the Dao, his views are often correct, and therefore I quote them as I do.'

passages.zh: 文侯曰：「然則子無師邪？」
passages.en: The marquis went on, 'Then have you no preceptor?'

passages.zh: 子方曰：「有。」曰：「子之師誰邪？」子方曰：「東郭順子。」
passages.en: 'I have.' 'And who is he?' 'He is Dong-guo Shun-zi.'

passages.zh: 文侯曰：「然則夫子何故未嘗稱之？」
passages.en: 'And why, my Master, have I never heard you quote his words?'

passages.zh: 子方曰：「其為人也真，人貌而天虛，緣而葆真，清而容物。
passages.en: Zi-fang replied, 'He is a man who satisfies the true (ideal of humanity); a man in appearance, but (having the mind of) Heaven. Void of any thought of himself, he accommodates himself to others, and nourishes the true ideal that belongs to him. With all his purity, he is forbearing to others.

passages.zh: 物無道，正容以悟之，使人之意也消。
passages.en: Where they are without the Dao, he rectifies his demeanour, so that they understand it, and in consequence their own ideas melt away and disappear.

passages.zh: 無擇何足以稱之！」
passages.en: How should one like me be fit to quote his words?'

passages.zh: 子方出，文侯儻然終日不言，召前立臣，而語之曰：「遠矣全德之君子！
passages.en: When Zi-fang went out, the marquis Wen continued in a state of dumb amazement all the day. He then called Long Li-chen, and said to him, 'How far removed from us is the superior man of complete virtue!

passages.zh: 始吾以聖知之言、仁義之行為至矣，吾聞子方之師，吾形解而不欲動，口鉗而不欲言。
passages.en: Formerly I thought the words of the sages and wise men, and the practice of benevolence and righteousness, to be the utmost we could reach to. Since I have heard about the preceptor of Zi-fang, my body is all unstrung, and I do not wish to move, and my mouth is closed up, and I do not wish to speak.

passages.zh: 吾所學者直土梗耳，夫魏真為我累耳！」
passages.en: What I have learned has been only a counterfeit of the truth. Yes, (the possession of Wei) has been an entanglement to me.'

passages.zh: 溫伯雪子適齊，舍於魯。
passages.en: Wen-bo Xue-zi, on his way to Qi, stayed some time in Lu, where some persons of the state begged to have an interview with him.

passages.zh: 魯人有請見之者，溫伯雪子曰：「不可。吾聞中國之君子，明乎禮義而陋於知人心，吾不欲見也。」
passages.en: He refused them, saying, 'I have heard that the superior men of these Middle States understand the (subjects of) ceremony and righteousness, but are deplorably ignorant of the minds of men. I do not wish to see them.'

passages.zh: 至於齊，反舍於魯，是人也又請見。
passages.en: He went on to Qi; and on his way back (to the south), he again stayed in Lu, when the same persons begged as before for an interview.

passages.zh: 溫伯雪子曰：「往也蘄見我，今也又蘄見我，是必有以振我也。」
passages.en: He then said, 'Formerly they asked to see me, and now again they seek an interview. They will afford me some opportunity of bringing out my sentiments.'

passages.zh: 出而見客，入而歎。明日見客，又入而歎。
passages.en: He went out accordingly and saw the visitors, and came in again with a sigh. The next day again he saw the visitors, and again came in again with a sigh.

passages.zh: 其僕曰：「每見之客也，必入而歎，何邪？」
passages.en: His servant said to him, 'Whenever you see those visitors, you are sure to come in again sighing - Why is this?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾固告子矣：『中國之民，明乎禮義而陋乎知人心。』
passages.en: 'I told you before,' was the reply, 'that the people of these Middle States understand (the subjects of) ceremony and righteousness, but are deplorably ignorant of the minds of men.

passages.zh: 昔之見我者，進退一成規，一成矩；從容一若龍，一若虎；其諫我也似子，其道我也似父。是以歎也。」
passages.en: Those men who have just seen me, as they came in and went out would describe, one a circle and another a square, and in their easy carriage would be like, one a dragon and another a tiger. They remonstrated with me as sons (with their fathers), and laid down the way for me as fathers (for their sons). It was this which made me sigh.'

passages.zh: 仲尼見之而不言。
passages.en: Zhongni saw the man, but did not speak a word to him.

passages.zh: 子路曰：「吾子欲見溫伯雪子久矣，見之而不言，何邪？」
passages.en: Zi-lu said, 'You have wished, Sir, to see this Wen-bo Xue-zi for a long time; what is the reason that when you have seen him, you have not spoken a word?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「若夫人者，目擊而道存矣，亦不可以容聲矣。」
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'As soon as my eyes lighted on that man, the Dao in him was apparent. The situation did not admit of a word being spoken.'

passages.zh: 顏淵問於仲尼曰：「夫子步亦步，夫子趨亦趨，夫子馳亦馳，夫子奔逸絕塵，而回瞠若乎後矣。」
passages.en: Yan Yuan asked Zhongni, saying, 'Master, when you pace quietly along, I also pace along; when you go more quickly, I also do the same; when you gallop, I also gallop; but when you race along and spurn the dust, then I can only stand and look, and keep behind you.'

passages.zh: 夫子曰：「回，何謂邪？」
passages.en: The Master said, 'Hui, what do you mean?'

passages.zh: 曰：「夫子步亦步也，夫子言亦言也，夫子趨亦趨也，夫子辯亦辯也，夫子馳亦馳也，夫子言道，回亦言道也。
passages.en: The reply was, 'In saying that "when you, Master, pace quietly along, I also pace along," I mean that when you speak, I also speak. By saying, "When you go more quickly, I also do the same," I mean that when you reason, I also reason. By saying, "When you gallop, I also gallop," I mean that when you speak of the Way, I also speak of the Way.

passages.zh: 及奔逸絕塵，而回瞠若乎後者，夫子不言而信，不比而周，無器而民滔乎前，而不知所以然而已矣。」
passages.en: But by saying, "When you race along and spurn the dust, then I can only stare, and keep behind you," I am thinking how though you do not speak, yet all men believe you; though you are no partisan, yet all parties approve your catholicity; and though you sound no instrument, yet people all move on harmoniously before you, while (all the while) I do not know how all this comes about; and this is all which my words are intended to express.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「惡！可不察與！
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'But you must try and search the matter out.

passages.zh: 夫哀莫大於心死，而人死亦次之。
passages.en: Of all causes for sorrow there is none so great as the death of the mind - the death of man's (body) is only next to it.

passages.zh: 日出東方而入於西極，萬物莫不比方。
passages.en: The sun comes forth in the east, and sets in the extreme west - all things have their position determined by these two points.

passages.zh: 有目有趾者，待是而後成功，待晝而作。是出則存，是入則亡。
passages.en: All that have eyes and feet wait for this (sun), and then proceed to do what they have to do. When this comes forth, they appear in their places; when it sets, they disappear.

passages.zh: 萬物亦然，有待也而死，有待也而生。
passages.en: It is so with all things. They have that for which they wait, and (on its arrival) they die; they have that for which they wait, and then (again) they live.

passages.zh: 吾一受其成形，而不化以待盡，效物而動，日夜無隙，而不知其所終，薰然其成形，知命不能規乎其前，丘以是日徂。
passages.en: When once I receive my frame thus completed, I remain unchanged, awaiting the consummation of my course. I move as acted on by things, day and night without cessation, and I do not know when I will come to an end. Clearly I am here a completed frame, and even one who (fancies that he) knows what is appointed cannot determine it beforehand. I am in this way daily passing on.

passages.zh: 吾終身與汝交一臂而失之，可不哀與！
passages.en: But all day long I am communicating my views to you; and now, as we are shoulder to shoulder you fail (to understand me) - is it not matter for lamentation?

passages.zh: 女殆著乎吾所以著也。彼已盡矣，而女求之以為有，是求馬於唐肆也。
passages.en: You are able in a measure to set forth what I more clearly set forth; but that is passed away, and you look for it, as if it were still existing, just as if you were looking for a horse in the now empty place where it was formerly exhibited for sale.

passages.zh: 吾服女也甚忘，女服吾也亦甚忘。
passages.en: You have very much forgotten my service to you, and I have very much forgotten wherein I served you.

passages.zh: 雖然，女奚患焉！雖忘乎故吾，吾有不忘者存。」
passages.en: But nevertheless why should you account this such an evil? What you forget is but my old self; that which cannot be forgotten remains with me.'

passages.zh: 孔子見老聃，老聃新沐，方將被髮而乾，慹然似非人。
passages.en: Confucius went to see Lao Dan, and arrived just as he had completed the bathing of his head, and was letting his dishevelled hair get dry. There he was, motionless, and as if there were not another man in the world.

passages.zh: 孔子便而待之，少焉見曰：「丘也眩與？其信然與？向者先生形體掘若槁木，似遺物離人而立於獨也。」
passages.en: Confucius waited quietly; and, when in a little time he was introduced, he said, 'Were my eyes dazed? Is it really you? Just now, your body, Sir, was like the stump of a rotten tree. You looked as if you had no thought of anything, as if you had left the society of men, and were standing in the solitude (of yourself).'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「吾遊心於物之初。」
passages.en: Lao Dan replied, 'I was enjoying myself in thinking about the commencement of things.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「何謂邪？」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'What do you mean?'

passages.zh: 曰：「心困焉而不能知，口辟焉而不能言，嘗為汝議乎其將。
passages.en: Lao Dan replied, 'My mind is so cramped, that I hardly know it; my tongue is so tied that I cannot tell it; but I will try to describe it to you as nearly as I can.

passages.zh: 至陰肅肅，至陽赫赫；肅肅出乎天，赫赫發乎地；兩者交通成和而物生焉，或為之紀而莫見其形。
passages.en: When the state of Yin was perfect, all was cold and severe; when the state of Yang was perfect, all was turbulent and agitated. The coldness and severity came forth from Heaven; the turbulence and agitation issued from Earth. The two states communicating together, a harmony ensued and things were produced. Some one regulated and controlled this, but no one has seen his form.

passages.zh: 消息滿虛，一晦一明，日改月化，日有所為，而莫見其功。
passages.en: Decay and growth; fulness and emptiness; darkness and light; the changes of the sun and the transformations of the moon: these are brought about from day to day; but no one sees the process of production.

passages.zh: 生有所乎萌，死有所乎歸，始終相反乎無端，而莫知其所窮。
passages.en: Life has its origin from which it springs, and death has its place from which it returns. Beginning and ending go on in mutual contrariety without any determinable commencement, and no one knows how either comes to an end.

passages.zh: 非是也，且孰為之宗！」
passages.en: If we disallow all this, who originates and presides over all these phenomena?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「請問遊是。」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'I beg to ask about your enjoyment in these thoughts.'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「夫得是，至美至樂也。得至美而遊乎至樂，謂之至人。」
passages.en: Lao Dan replied, 'The comprehension of this is the most admirable and the most enjoyable (of all acquisitions). The getting of the most admirable and the exercise of the thoughts in what is the most enjoyable, constitutes what we call the Perfect man.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「願聞其方。」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'I should like to hear the method of attaining to it.'

passages.zh: 曰：「草食之獸不疾易藪，水生之蟲不疾易水，行小變而不失其大常也，喜怒哀樂不入於胸次。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Grass-eating animals do not dislike to change their pastures; creatures born in the water do not dislike to change their waters. They make a small change, but do not lose what is the great and regular requirement (of their nature); joy, anger, sadness, and delight do not enter into their breasts (in connexion with such events).

passages.zh: 夫天下也者，萬物之所一也。得其所一而同焉，則四支百體將為塵垢，而死生終始將為晝夜而莫之能滑，而況得喪禍福之所介乎！
passages.en: Now the space under the sky is occupied by all things in their unity. When they possess that unity and equally share it, then the four limbs and hundred members of their body are but so much dust and dirt, while death and life, their ending and beginning, are but as the succession of day and night, which cannot disturb their enjoyment; and how much less will they be troubled by gains and losses, by calamity and happiness!

passages.zh: 棄隸者若棄泥塗，知身貴於隸也，貴在於我而不失於變。
passages.en: Those who renounce the paraphernalia of rank do it as if they were casting away so much mud - they know that they are themselves more honourable than those paraphernalia. The honour belonging to one's self is not lost by any change (of condition).

passages.zh: 且萬化而未始有極也，夫孰足以患心！已為道者解乎此。」
passages.en: Moreover, a myriad transformations may take place before the end of them is reached. What is there in all this sufficient to trouble the mind? Those who have attained to the Dao understand the subject.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「夫子德配天地，而猶假至言以修心，古之君子，孰能脫焉？」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'O Master, your virtue is equal to that of Heaven and Earth, and still I must borrow (some of your) perfect words (to aid me) in the cultivation of my mind. Who among the superior men of antiquity could give such expression to them?'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「不然。夫水之於汋也，無為而才自然矣。
passages.en: Lao Dan replied, 'Not so. Look at the spring, the water of which rises and overflows - it does nothing, but it naturally acts so.

passages.zh: 至人之於德也，不修而物不能離焉，若天之自高，地之自厚，日月之自明，夫何修焉！」
passages.en: So with the perfect man and his virtue - he does not cultivate it, and nothing evades its influence. He is like heaven which is high of itself, like earth which is solid of itself, like the sun and moon which shine of themselves - what need is there to cultivate it?'

passages.zh: 孔子出，以告顏回曰：「丘之於道也，其猶醯雞與！
passages.en: Confucius went out and reported the conversation to Yan Hui, saying, 'In the (knowledge of the) Dao am I any better than an animalcule in vinegar?

passages.zh: 微夫子之發吾覆也，吾不知天地之大全也。」
passages.en: But for the Master's lifting the veil from me, I should not have known the grand perfection of Heaven and Earth.'

passages.zh: 莊子見魯哀公。
passages.en: At an interview of Zhuangzi with duke Ai of Lu, the duke said, 'There are many of the Learned class in Lu; but few of them can be compared with you, Sir.'

passages.zh: 哀公曰：「魯多儒士，少為先生方者。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'There are few Learned men in Lu.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「魯少儒。」
passages.en: 'Everywhere in Lu,' rejoined the duke, 'you see men wearing the dress of the Learned - how can you say that they are few?'

passages.zh: 哀公曰：「舉魯國而儒服，何謂少乎？」
passages.en: 'I have heard,' said Zhuangzi, 'that those of them who wear round caps know the times of heaven; that those who wear square shoes know the contour of the ground; and that those who saunter about with semicircular stones at their girdle-pendents settle matters in dispute as they come before them.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「周聞之：儒者冠圜冠者，知天時；履句屨者，知地形；緩佩玦者，事至而斷。
passages.en: But superior men who are possessed of such knowledge will not be found wearing the dress, and it does not follow that those who wear the dress possess the knowledge.

passages.zh: 君子有其道者，未必為其服也；為其服者，未必知其道也。
passages.en: If your Grace think otherwise, why not issue a notification through the state, that it shall be a capital offence to wear the dress without possessing the knowledge.'

passages.zh: 公固以為不然，何不號於國中曰『無此道而為此服者，其罪死』？」
passages.en: On this the duke issued such a notification, and in five days, throughout all Lu, there was no one who dared to wear the dress of the Learned.

passages.zh: 於是哀公號之五日，而魯國無敢儒服者。
passages.en: There was only one old man who came and stood in it at the duke's gate.

passages.zh: 獨有一丈夫儒服而立乎公門，公即召而問以國事，千轉萬變而不窮。
passages.en: The duke instantly called him in, and questioned him about the affairs of the state, when he talked about a thousand points and ten thousand divergences from them.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「以魯國而儒者一人耳，可謂多乎？」
passages.en: Zhuangzi said, 'When the state of Lu can thus produce but one man of the Learned class, can he be said to be many?'

passages.zh: 百里奚爵祿不入於心，故飯牛而牛肥，使秦穆公忘其賤，與之政也。
passages.en: The ideas of rank and emolument did not enter the mind of Bai-li Xi, and so he became a cattle-feeder, and his cattle were all in fine condition. This made duke Mu of Qin forget the meanness of his position, and put the government (of his state) into his hands.

passages.zh: 有虞氏死生不入於心，故足以動人。
passages.en: Neither life nor death entered into the mind of (Shun), the Lord of Yu, and therefore he was able to influence others.

passages.zh: 宋元君將畫圖。眾史皆至，受揖而立；舐筆和墨，在外者半。
passages.en: The ruler Yuan of Song wishing to have a map drawn, the masters of the pencil all came (to undertake the task). Having received his instructions and made their bows, they stood, licking their pencils and preparing their ink. Half their number, however, remained outside.

passages.zh: 有一史後至者，儃儃然不趨，受揖不立，因之舍。
passages.en: There was one who came late, with an air of indifference, and did not hurry forward. When he had received his instructions and made his bow, he did not keep standing, but proceeded to his shed.

passages.zh: 公使人視之，則解衣般礡，臝。
passages.en: The duke sent a man to see him, and there he was, with his upper garment off, sitting cross-legged, and nearly naked.

passages.zh: 君曰：「可矣，是真畫者也。」
passages.en: The ruler said, 'He is the man; he is a true draughtsman.'

passages.zh: 文王觀於臧，見一丈夫釣，而其釣莫釣，非持其釣，有釣者也，常釣也。
passages.en: King Wen was (once) looking about him at Zang, when he saw an old man fishing. But his fishing was no fishing. It was not the fishing of one whose business is fishing. He was always fishing (as if he had no object in the occupation).

passages.zh: 文王欲舉而授之政，而恐大臣父兄之弗安也；欲終而釋之，而不忍百姓之無天也。
passages.en: The king wished to raise him to office, and put the government into his hands, but was afraid that such a step would give dissatisfaction to his great ministers, his uncles, and cousins. He then wished to dismiss the man altogether from his mind, but he could not bear the thought that his people should be without (such a) Heaven (as their Protector).

passages.zh: 於是旦而屬之夫夫曰：「昔者寡人夢，見良人黑色而髯，乘駁馬而偏朱蹄，號曰：『寓而政於臧丈人，庶幾乎民有瘳乎！』」
passages.en: On this, (next) morning, he called together his great officers, and said to them, 'Last night, I dreamt that I saw a good man, with a dark complexion and a beard, riding on a piebald horse, one half of whose hoofs were red, who commanded me, saying, "Lodge your government in the hands of the old man of Zang; and perhaps the evils of your people will be cured."'

passages.zh: 諸大夫蹴然曰：「先君王也。」
passages.en: The great officers said eagerly, 'It was the king, your father.'

passages.zh: 文王曰：「然則卜之。」
passages.en: King Wen said, 'Let us then submit the proposal to the tortoise-shell.'

passages.zh: 諸大夫曰：「先君之命王，其無它，又何卜焉！」
passages.en: They replied, 'It is the order of your father. Let not your majesty think of any other. Why divine about it?'

passages.zh: 遂迎臧丈人而授之政。
passages.en: (The king) then met the old man of Zang, and committed the government to him.

passages.zh: 典洗無更，偏令無出。
passages.en: The statutes and laws were not changed by him; not a one-sided order (of his own) was issued.

passages.zh: 三年，文王觀於國，則列士壞植散群，長官者不成德，斔斛不敢入於四竟。
passages.en: But when the king made a survey of the kingdom after three years, he found that the officers had destroyed the plantations (which harboured banditti), and dispersed their occupiers, that the superintendents of the official departments did not plume themselves on their successes, and that no unusual grain measures were allowed within the different states.

passages.zh: 列士壞植散群，則尚同也；長官者不成德，則同務也；斔斛不敢入於四竟，則諸侯無二心也。
passages.en: When the officers had destroyed the dangerous plantations and dispersed their occupants, the highest value was set on the common interests; when the chiefs of departments did not plume themselves on their successes, the highest value was set on the common business; when unusual grain measures did not enter the different states, the different princes had no jealousies.

passages.zh: 文王於是焉以為大師，北面而問曰：「政可以及天下乎？」
passages.en: On this King Wen made the old man his Grand Preceptor, and asked him, with his own face to the north, whether his government might be extended to all the kingdom.

passages.zh: 臧丈人昧然而不應，泛然而辭，朝令而夜遁，終身無聞。
passages.en: The old man looked perplexed and gave no reply, but with aimless look took his leave. In the morning he had issued his orders, and at night he had gone his way; nor was he heard of again all his life.

passages.zh: 顏淵問於仲尼曰：「文王其猶未邪？又何以夢為乎？」
passages.en: Yan Yuan questioned Confucius, saying, 'Was even King Wen unequal to determine his course? What had he to do with resorting to a dream?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「默！汝無言！夫文王盡之也，而又何論刺焉！彼直以循斯須也。」
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'Be silent and do not say a word! King Wen was complete in everything. What have you to do with criticising him? He only had recourse (to the dream) to meet a moment's difficulty.'

passages.zh: 列御寇為伯昏無人射，引之盈貫，措杯水其肘上，發之，適矢復沓，方矢復寓。當是時，猶象人也。
passages.en: Lie Yu-Kou was exhibiting his archery to Bo-hun Wu-ren. Having drawn the bow to its full extent, with a cup of water placed on his elbow, he let fly. As the arrow was discharged, another was put in its place; and as that was sent off, a third was ready on the string. All the while he stood like a statue.

passages.zh: 伯昏無人曰：「是射之射，非不射之射也。嘗與汝登高山，履危石，臨百仞之淵，若能射乎？」
passages.en: Bo-hun Wu-ren said, 'That is the shooting of an archer, but not of one who shoots without thinking about his shooting. Let me go up with you to the top of a high mountain, treading with you among the tottering rocks, till we arrive at the brink of a precipice, 800 cubits deep, and (I will then see) if you can shoot.'

passages.zh: 於是無人遂登高山，履危石，臨百仞之淵，背逡巡，足二分垂在外，揖御寇而進之。
passages.en: On this they went up a high mountain, making their way among the tottering rocks, till they came to the brink of a precipice 800 cubits deep. Then Wu-ren turned round and walked backwards, till his feet were two-thirds of their length outside the edge, and beckoned Yu-kou to come forward.

passages.zh: 御寇伏地，汗流至踵。
passages.en: He, however, had fallen prostrate on the ground, with the sweat pouring down to his heels.

passages.zh: 伯昏無人曰：「夫至人者，上闚青天，下潛黃泉，揮斥八極，神氣不變。今汝怵然有恂目之志，爾於中也殆矣夫！」
passages.en: Then the other said, 'The Perfect man looks up to the azure sky above, or dives down to the yellow springs beneath, or soars away to the eight ends of the universe, without any change coming over his spirit or his breath. But now the trepidation of your mind appears in your dazed eyes; your inward feeling of peril is extreme!'

passages.zh: 肩吾問於孫叔敖曰：「子三為令尹而不榮華，三去之而無憂色。吾始也疑子，今視子之鼻間栩栩然，子之用心獨奈何？」
passages.en: Jian Wu asked Sun-shu Ao, saying, 'You, Sir, were thrice chief minister, and did not feel elated; you were thrice dismissed from that position, without manifesting any sorrow. At first I was in doubt about you, (but I am not now, since) I see how regularly and quietly the breath comes through your nostrils. How is it that you exercise your mind?'

passages.zh: 孫叔敖曰：「吾何以過人哉！吾以其來不可卻也，其去不可止也，吾以為得失之非我也，而無憂色而已矣。我何以過人哉！
passages.en: Sun-shu Ao replied, 'In what do I surpass other men? When the position came to me, I thought it should not be rejected; when it was taken away, I thought it could not be retained. I considered that the getting or losing it did not make me what I was, and was no occasion for any manifestation of sorrow - that was all. In what did I surpass other men?

passages.zh: 且不知其在彼乎，其在我乎？其在彼邪，亡乎我；在我邪，亡乎彼。方將躊躇，方將四顧，何暇至乎人貴人賤哉！」
passages.en: And moreover, I did not know whether the honour of it belonged to the dignity, or to myself. If it belonged to the dignity, it was nothing to me; if it belonged to me, it had nothing to do with the dignity. While occupied with these uncertainties, and looking round in all directions, what leisure had I to take knowledge of whether men honoured me or thought me mean?'

passages.zh: 仲尼聞之曰：「古之真人，知者不得說，美人不得濫，盜人不得劫，伏戲、黃帝不得友。
passages.en: Zhongni heard of all this, and said, 'The True men of old could not be fully described by the wisest, nor be led into excess by the most beautiful, nor be forced by the most violent robber. Neither Fu-xi nor Huang-Di could compel them to be their friends.

passages.zh: 死生亦大矣，而無變乎己，況爵祿乎！
passages.en: Death and life are indeed great considerations, but they could make no change in their (true) self; and how much less could rank and emolument do so?

passages.zh: 若然者，其神經乎大山而無介，入乎淵泉而不濡，處卑細而不憊，充滿天地，既以與人，己愈有。」
passages.en: Being such, their spirits might pass over the Tai mountain and find it no obstacle to them they might enter the greatest gulphs, and not be wet by them; they might occupy the lowest and smallest positions without being distressed by them. Theirs was the fulness of heaven and earth; the more that they gave to others, the more they had.'

passages.zh: 楚王與凡君坐，少焉，楚王左右曰「凡亡」者三。
passages.en: The king of Chu and the ruler of Fan were sitting together. After a little while, the attendants of the king said, 'Fan has been destroyed three times.'

passages.zh: 凡君曰：「凡之亡也，不足以喪吾存。夫『凡之亡也，不足以喪吾存』，則楚之存不足以存存。由是觀之，則凡未始亡而楚未始存也。」
passages.en: The ruler of Fan rejoined, 'The destruction of Fan has not been sufficient to destroy what we had that was most deserving to be preserved.' Now, if the destruction of Fan had not been sufficient to destroy that which it had most deserving to be preserved, the preservation of Chu had not been sufficient to preserve that in it most deserving to be preserved. Looking at the matter from this point of view, Fan had not begun to be destroyed, and Chu had not begun to be preserved.

passages.zh: 知北遊於玄水之上，登隱弅之丘，而適遭無為謂焉。
passages.en: Knowledge had rambled northwards to the region of the Dark Water, where he ascended the height of Imperceptible Slope, when it happened that he met with Dumb Inaction.

passages.zh: 知謂無為謂曰：「予欲有問乎若：何思何慮則知道？何處何服則安道？何從何道則得道？」
passages.en: Knowledge addressed him, saying, 'I wish to ask you some questions: By what process of thought and anxious consideration do we get to know the Dao? Where should we dwell and what should we do to find our rest in the Dao? From what point should we start and what path should we pursue to make the Dao our own?'

passages.zh: 三問而無為謂不答也，非不答，不知答也。
passages.en: He asked these three questions, but Dumb Inaction gave him no reply. Not only did he not answer, but he did not know how to answer.

passages.zh: 知不得問，反於白水之南，登狐闋之丘，而睹狂屈焉。
passages.en: Knowledge, disappointed by the fruitlessness of his questions, returned to the south of the Bright Water, and ascended the height of the End of Doubt, where he saw Heedless Blurter, to whom he put the same questions.

passages.zh: 知以之言也問乎狂屈。狂屈曰：「唉！予知之，將語若，中欲言而忘其所欲言。」
passages.en: Heedless Blurter replied, 'Ah! I know, and will tell you.' But while he was about to speak, he forgot what he wanted to say.

passages.zh: 知不得問，反於帝宮，見黃帝而問焉。
passages.en: Knowledge, (again) receiving no answer to his questions, returned to the palace of the Di, where he saw Huang-Di, and put the questions to him.

passages.zh: 黃帝曰：「無思無慮始知道，無處無服始安道，無從無道始得道。」
passages.en: Huang-Di said, 'To exercise no thought and no anxious consideration is the first step towards knowing the Dao; to dwell nowhere and do nothing is the first step towards resting in the Dao; to start from nowhere and pursue no path is the first step towards making the Dao your own.'

passages.zh: 知問黃帝曰：「我與若知之，彼與彼不知也，其孰是邪？」
passages.en: Knowledge then asked Huang-Di, saying, 'I and you know this; those two did not know it; which of us is right?'

passages.zh: 黃帝曰：「彼無為謂真是也，狂屈似之，我與汝終不近也。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Dumb Inaction is truly right; Heedless Blurter has an appearance of being so; I and you are not near being so.

passages.zh: 夫知者不言，言者不知，故聖人行不言之教。
passages.en: (As it is said), "Those who know (the Dao) do not speak of it; those who speak of it do not know it;" and "Hence the sage conveys his instructions without the use of speech."

passages.zh: 道不可致，德不可至。仁可為也，義可虧也，禮相偽也。
passages.en: The Dao cannot be made ours by constraint; its characteristics will not come to us (at our call). Benevolence may be practised; Righteousness may be partially attended to; by Ceremonies men impose on one another.

passages.zh: 故曰：『失道而後德，失德而後仁，失仁而後義，失義而後禮。禮者，道之華而亂之首也。』
passages.en: Hence it is said, "When the Dao was lost, its Characteristics appeared. When its Characteristics were lost, Benevolence appeared. When Benevolence was lost, Righteousness appeared. When Righteousness was lost, Ceremonies appeared. Ceremonies are but (the unsubstantial) flowers of the Dao, and the commencement of disorder."

passages.zh: 故曰：『為道者日損，損之又損之，以至於無為，無為而無不為也。』
passages.en: Hence (also it is further said), "He who practises the Dao, daily diminishes his doing. He diminishes it and again diminishes it, till he arrives at doing nothing. Having arrived at this non-inaction, there is nothing that he does not do."

passages.zh: 今已為物也，欲復歸根，不亦難乎！其易也，其唯大人乎！
passages.en: Here now there is something, a regularly fashioned utensil - if you wanted to make it return to the original condition of its materials, would it not be difficult to make it do so? Could any but the Great Man accomplish this easily?

passages.zh: 生也死之徒，死也生之始，孰知其紀！
passages.en: Life is the follower of death, and death is the predecessor of life; but who knows the Arranger (of this connexion between them)?

passages.zh: 人之生，氣之聚也，聚則為生，散則為死。若死生為徒，吾又何患！
passages.en: The life is due to the collecting of the breath. When that is collected, there is life; when it is dispersed, there is death. Since death and life thus attend on each other, why should I account (either of) them an evil?

passages.zh: 故萬物一也，是其所美者為神奇，其所惡者為臭腐；臭腐復化為神奇，神奇復化為臭腐。
passages.en: Therefore all things go through one and the same experience. (Life) is accounted beautiful because it is spirit-like and wonderful, and death is accounted ugly because of its foetor and putridity. But the foetid and putrid is transformed again into the spirit-like and wonderful, and the spirit-like and wonderful is transformed again into the foetid and putrid.

passages.zh: 故曰：『通天下一氣耳。』聖人故貴一。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, "All under the sky there is one breath of life, and therefore the sages prized that unity."

passages.zh: 知謂黃帝曰：「吾問無為謂，無為謂不應我，非不我應，不知應我也。
passages.en: Knowledge said to Huang-Di, 'I asked Dumb Inaction, and he did not answer me. Not only did he not answer me, but he did not know how to answer me.

passages.zh: 吾問狂屈，狂屈中欲告我而不我告，非不我告，中欲告而忘之也。
passages.en: I asked Heedless Blurter, and while he wanted to tell me, he yet did not do so. Not only did he not tell me, but while he wanted to tell me, he forgot all about my questions.

passages.zh: 今予問乎若，若知之，奚故不近？」
passages.en: Now I have asked you, and you knew (all about them) - why (do you say that) you are not near doing so?'

passages.zh: 黃帝曰：「彼其真是也，以其不知也；此其似之也，以其忘之也；予與若終不近也，以其知之也。」
passages.en: Huang-Di replied, 'Dumb Inaction was truly right, because he did not know the thing. Heedless Blurter was nearly right, because he forgot it. I and you are not nearly right, because we know it.'

passages.zh: 狂屈聞之，以黃帝為知言。
passages.en: Heedless Blurter heard of (all this), and considered that Huang-Di knew how to express himself (on the subject).

passages.zh: 天地有大美而不言，四時有明法而不議，萬物有成理而不說。
passages.en: (The operations of) Heaven and Earth proceed in the most admirable way, but they say nothing about them; the four seasons observe the clearest laws, but they do not discuss them; all things have their complete and distinctive constitutions, but they say nothing about them.

passages.zh: 聖人者，原天地之美而達萬物之理。是故至人無為，大聖不作，觀於天地之謂也。
passages.en: The sages trace out the admirable operations of Heaven and Earth, and reach to and understand the distinctive constitutions of all things; and thus it is that the Perfect Man (is said to) do nothing and the Greatest Sage to originate nothing, such language showing that they look to Heaven and Earth as their model.

passages.zh: 今彼神明至精，與彼百化，物已死生方圓，莫知其根也，扁然而萬物自古以固存。
passages.en: Even they, with their spirit-like and most exquisite intelligence, as well as all the tribes that undergo their transformations, the dead and the living, the square and the round, do not understand their root and origin, but nevertheless they all from the oldest time by it preserve their being.

passages.zh: 六合為巨，未離其內；秋豪為小，待之成體。
passages.en: Vast as is the space included within the six cardinal points, it all (and all that it contains) lies within (this twofold root of Heaven and Earth); small as is an autumn hair, it is indebted to this for the completion of its form.

passages.zh: 天下莫不沈浮，終身不故；陰陽四時運行，各得其序。
passages.en: All things beneath the sky, now rising, now descending, ever continue the same through this. The Yin and Yang, and the four seasons revolve and move by it, each in its proper order.

passages.zh: 惛然若亡而存，油然不形而神，萬物畜而不知。此之謂本根，可以觀於天矣。
passages.en: Now it seems to be lost in obscurity, but it continues; now it seems to glide away, and have no form, but it is still spirit-like.
