passages.en: Of the grasping and crooked we have an example in Shun. Mutton has no craving for ants, but ants have a craving for mutton, for it is rank. There was a rankness about the conduct of Shun, and the people were pleased with him. Hence when he thrice changed his residence, every one of them became a capital city. When he came to the wild of Tang, he had 100,000 families about him.

passages.zh: 堯聞舜之賢，舉之童土之地，曰冀得其來之澤。舜舉乎童土之地，年齒長矣，聰明衰矣，而不得休歸，所謂卷婁者也。
passages.en: Yao having heard of the virtue and ability of Shun, appointed him to a new and uncultivated territory, saying, 'I look forward to the benefit of his coming here.' When Shun was appointed to this new territory, his years were advanced, and his intelligence was decayed - and yet he could not find a place of rest or a home. This is an example of being grasping and wayward.

passages.zh: 是以神人惡眾至，眾至則不比，不比則不利也。故無所甚親，無所甚疏，抱德煬和，以順天下，此謂真人。
passages.en: Therefore (in opposition to such) the spirit-like man dislikes the flocking of the multitudes to him. When the multitudes come, they do not agree; and when they do not agree, no benefit results from their coming. Hence there are none whom he brings very near to himself, and none whom he keeps at a great distance. He keeps his virtue in close embrace, and warmly nourishes (the spirit of) harmony, so as to be in accordance with all men. This is called the True man.

passages.zh: 於蟻棄知，於魚得計，於羊棄意。以目視目，以耳聽耳，以心復心，若然者，其平也繩，其變也循。古之真人，以天待之，不以人入天。
passages.en: Even the knowledge of the ant he puts away; his plans are simply those of the fishes; even the notions of the sheep he discards. His seeing is simply that of the eye; his hearing that of the ear; his mind is governed by its general exercises. Being such, his course is straight and level as if marked out by a line, and its every change is in accordance (with the circumstances of the case). The True men of old waited for the issues of events as the arrangements of Heaven, and did not by their human efforts try to take the place of Heaven.

passages.zh: 古之真人，得之也生，失之也死；得之也死，失之也生。藥也，其實堇也。桔梗也，雞壅也，豕零也，是時為帝者也，何可勝言！
passages.en: The True men of old (now) looked on success as life and on failure as death; and (now) on success as death and on failure as life. The operation of medicines will illustrate this: there are monk's-bane, the Jie-geng, the tribulus fruit, and china-root; each of these has the time and case for which it is supremely suitable; and all such plants and their suitabilities cannot be mentioned particularly.

passages.zh: 句踐也以甲楯三千，棲於會稽。唯種也能知亡之所以存，唯種也不知身之所以愁。
passages.en: Gou-jian took his station on (the hill of) Gui-ji with 3,000 men with their buff-coats and shields: (his minister) Zhong knew how the ruined (Yue) might still be preserved, but the same man did not know the sad fate in store for himself.

passages.zh: 故曰：鴟目有所適，鶴脛有所節，解之也悲。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'The eye of the owl has its proper fitness; the leg of the crane has its proper limit, and to cut off any of it would distress (the bird).'

passages.zh: 故曰：風之過河也有損焉，日之過河也有損焉。請只風與日相與守河，而河以為未始其攖也，恃源而往者也。
passages.en: Hence (also) it is (further) said, 'When the wind passes over it, the volume of the river is diminished, and so it is when the sun passes over it. But let the wind and sun keep a watch together on the river, and it will not begin to feel that they are doing it any injury: it relies on its springs and flows on.'

passages.zh: 故水之守土也審，影之守人也審，物之守物也審。
passages.en: Thus, water does its part to the ground with undeviating exactness; and so does the shadow to the substance; and one thing to another.

passages.zh: 故目之於明也殆，耳之於聰也殆，心之於殉也殆。凡能其於府也殆，殆之成也不給改。
passages.en: Therefore there is danger from the power of vision in the eyes, of hearing in the ears, and of the inordinate thinking of the mind; yea, there is danger from the exercise of every power of which man's constitution is the depository. When the danger has come to a head, it cannot be averted, and the calamity is perpetuated, and goes on increasing.

passages.zh: 禍之長也茲萃，其反也緣功，其果也待久。而人以為己寶，不亦悲乎！故有亡國戮民無已，不知問是也。
passages.en: The return from this (to a state of security) is the result of (great) effort, and success can be attained only after a long time; and yet men consider (their power of self-determination) as their precious possession: is it not sad? It is in this way that we have the ruin of states and the slaughtering of the people without end; while no one knows how to ask how it comes about.

passages.zh: 故足之於地也踐，雖踐，恃其所不蹍而後善博也；人之於知也少，雖少，恃其所不知而後知天之所謂也。
passages.en: Therefore, the feet of man on the earth tread but on a small space, but going on to where he has not trod before, he traverses a great distance easily; so his knowledge is but small, but going on to what he does not already know, he comes to know what is meant by Heaven.

passages.zh: 知大一，知大陰，知大目，知大均，知大方，知大信，知大定，至矣。大一通之，大陰解之，大目視之，大均緣之，大方體之，大信稽之，大定持之。
passages.en: He knows it as The Great Unity; The Great Mystery; The Great Illuminator; The Great Framer; The Great Boundlessness; The Great Truth; The Great Determiner. This makes his knowledge complete. As The Great Unity, he comprehends it; as The Great Mystery, he unfolds it; as the Great Illuminator, he contemplates it; as the Great Framer, it is to him the Cause of all; as the Great Boundlessness, all is to him its embodiment; as The Great Truth, he examines it; as The Great Determiner, he holds it fast.

passages.zh: 盡有天，循有照，冥有樞，始有彼。則其解之也似不解之者，其知之也似不知之也，不知而後知之。
passages.en: Thus Heaven is to him all; accordance with it is the brightest intelligence. Obscurity has in this its pivot; in this is the beginning. Such being the case, the explanation of it is as if it were no explanation; the knowledge of it is as if it were no knowledge. (At first) he does not know it, but afterwards he comes to know it.

passages.zh: 其問之也，不可以有崖，而不可以無崖。頡滑有實，古今不代，而不可以虧，則可不謂有大揚搉乎！闔不亦問是已，奚惑然為！以不惑解惑，復於不惑，是尚大不惑。
passages.en: In his inquiries, he must not set to himself any limits, and yet he cannot be without a limit. Now ascending, now descending, then slipping from the grasp, (the Dao) is yet a reality, unchanged now as in antiquity, and always without defect: may it not be called what is capable of the greatest display and expansion? Why should we not inquire into it? Why should we be perplexed about it? With what does not perplex let us explain what perplexes, till we cease to be perplexed. So may we arrive at a great freedom from all perplexity!

passages.zh: 則陽游於楚，夷節言之於王，王未之見，夷節歸。
passages.en: Ze-yang having travelled to Chu, Yi Jie spoke of him to the king, and then, before the king had granted him an interview, (left him, and) returned home.

passages.zh: 彭陽見王果曰：「夫子何不譚我於王？」
passages.en: Ze-yang went to see Wang Guo, and said to him, 'Master, why do you not mention me to the king?'

passages.zh: 王果曰：「我不若公閱休。」
passages.en: Wang Guo replied, 'I am not so good a person to do that as Gong-yue Xiu.'

passages.zh: 彭陽曰：「公閱休奚為者邪？」
passages.en: 'What sort of man is he?' asked the other.

passages.zh: 曰：「冬則擉鱉於江，夏則休乎山樊。
passages.en: And the reply was, 'In winter he spears turtles in the Jiang, and in summer he rests in shady places on the mountain.

passages.zh: 有過而問者，曰：『此予宅也。』
passages.en: When passers-by ask him (what he is doing there), he says, "This is my abode."

passages.zh: 夫夷節已不能，而況我乎！
passages.en: Since Yi Jie was not able to induce the king to see you, how much less should I, who am not equal to him, be able to do so!

passages.zh: 吾又不若夷節。
passages.en: I am not equal to Yi Jie.

passages.zh: 夫夷節之為人也，無德而有知，不自許，以之神其交，固顛冥乎富貴之地，非相助以德，相助消也。
passages.en: Yi Jie's character is this: he has no (real) virtue, but he has knowledge. If you do not freely yield yourself to him, but employ him to carry on his spirit-like influence (with you), you will certainly get upset and benighted in the region of riches and honours. His help will not be of a Virtuous character, but will go to make your virtue less.

passages.zh: 夫凍者假衣於春，暍者反冬乎冷風。
passages.en: It will be like heaping on clothes in spring as a protection against cold, or bringing back the cold winds of winter as a protection against heat (in summer).

passages.zh: 夫楚王之為人也，形尊而嚴，其於罪也，無赦如虎，非夫佞人、正德，其孰能橈焉！
passages.en: Now the king of Chu is of a domineering presence and stern. He has no forgiveness for offenders, but is merciless as a tiger. It is only a man of subtle speech, or one of correct virtue, who can bend him from his purpose.

passages.zh: 故聖人，其窮也使家人忘其貧，其達也使王公忘其爵祿而化卑。
passages.en: But the sagely man, when he is left in obscurity, causes the members of his family to forget their poverty; and, when he gets forward to a position of influence, causes kings and dukes to forget their rank and emoluments, and transforms them to be humble.

passages.zh: 其於物也，與之為娛矣；其於人也，樂物之通而保己焉。
passages.en: With the inferior creatures, he shares their pleasures, and they enjoy themselves the more; with other men, he rejoices in the fellowship of the Dao, and preserves it in himself.

passages.zh: 故或不言而飲人以和，與人並立而使人化。
passages.en: Therefore though he may not speak, he gives them to drink of the harmony (of his spirit). Standing in association with them, he transforms them till they become in their feeling towards him as sons with a father.

passages.zh: 父子之宜，彼其乎歸居，而一閒其所施。
passages.en: His wish is to return to the solitude of his own mind, and this is the effect of his occasional intercourse with them.

passages.zh: 其於人心者，若是其遠也。
passages.en: So far-reaching is his influence on the minds of men.

passages.zh: 故曰待公閱休。」
passages.en: And therefore I said to you. "Wait for Gong-yue Xi?."

passages.zh: 聖人達綢繆，周盡一體矣，而不知其然，性也。
passages.en: The sage comprehends the connexions between himself and others, and how they all go to constitute him of one body with them, and he does not know how it is so - he naturally does so.

passages.zh: 復命搖作而以天為師，人則從而命之也。
passages.en: In fulfilling his constitution, as acted on and acting, he (simply) follows the direction of Heaven; and it is in consequence of this that men style him (a sage).

passages.zh: 憂乎知而所行恆無幾時，其有止也若之何？
passages.en: If he were troubled about (the insufficiency of) his knowledge, what he did would always be but small, and sometimes would be arrested altogether - how would he in this case be (the sage)?

passages.zh: 生而美者，人與之鑑，不告則不知其美於人也。
passages.en: When (the sage) is born with all his excellence, it is other men who see it for him. If they did not tell him, he would not know that he was more excellent than others.

passages.zh: 若知之，若不知之，若聞之，若不聞之，其可喜也終無已，人之好之亦無已，性也。
passages.en: And when he knows it, he is as if he did not know it; when he hears it, he is as if he did not hear it. His source of joy in it has no end, and men's admiration of him has no end - all this takes place naturally.

passages.zh: 聖人之愛人也，人與之名，不告則不知其愛人也。
passages.en: The love of the sage for others receives its name from them. If they did not tell him of it, he would not know that he loved them.

passages.zh: 若知之，若不知之，若聞之，若不聞之，其愛人也終無已，人之安之亦無已，性也。
passages.en: And when he knows it, he is as if he knew it not; when he hears it, he is as if he heard it not. His love of others never has an end, and their rest in him has also no end: all this takes place naturally.

passages.zh: 舊國舊都，望之暢然；雖使丘陵草木之緡，入之者十九，猶之暢然。
passages.en: When one sees at a distance his old country and old city, he feels a joyous satisfaction. Though it be full of mounds and an overgrowth of trees and grass, and when he enters it he finds but a tenth part remaining, still he feels that satisfaction.

passages.zh: 況見見聞聞者也？
passages.en: How much more when he sees what he saw, and hears what he heard before!

passages.zh: 以十仞之臺縣眾閒者也！
passages.en: All this is to him like a tower eighty cubits high exhibited in the sight of all men.

passages.zh: 冉相氏得其環中以隨成，與物無終無始，無幾無時日。
passages.en: (The sovereign) Ran-xiang was possessed of that central principle round which all things revolve, and by it he could follow them to their completion. His accompanying them had neither ending nor beginning, and was independent of impulse or time.

passages.zh: 與物化者，一不化者也，闔嘗舍之！
passages.en: Daily he witnessed their changes, and himself underwent no change; and why should he not have rested in this?

passages.zh: 夫師天而不得師天，與物皆殉，其以為事也若之何？
passages.en: If we (try to) adopt Heaven as our Master, we incapacitate ourselves from doing so. Such endeavour brings us under the power of things. If one acts in this way, what is to be said of him?

passages.zh: 夫聖人未始有天，未始有人，未始有始，未始有物，與世偕行而不替，所行之備而不洫，其合之也若之何？
passages.en: The sage never thinks of Heaven nor of men. He does not think of taking the initiative, nor of anything external to himself. He moves along with his age, and does not vary or fail. Amid all the completeness of his doings, he is never exhausted. For those who wish to be in accord with him, what other course is there to pursue?

passages.zh: 湯得其司御門尹登恆為之傅之，從師而不囿，得其隨成；為之司其名之名，嬴法得其兩見。
passages.en: When Tang got one to hold for him the reins of government, namely, Men-yin Deng-heng, he employed him as his teacher. He followed his master, but did not allow himself to be hampered by him, and so he succeeded in following things to their completion. The master had the name; but that name was a superfluous addition to his laws, and the twofold character of his government was made apparent.

passages.zh: 仲尼之盡慮，為之傅之。
passages.en: Zhongni's 'Task your thoughts to the utmost' was his expression of the duties of a master.

passages.zh: 容成氏曰：「除日無歲，無內無外。」
passages.en: Rong-cheng said, 'Take the days away and there will be no year; without what is internal there will be nothing external.'

passages.zh: 魏瑩與田侯牟約，田侯牟背之。
passages.en: (King) Ying of Wei made a treaty with the marquis Tian Mou (of Qi), which the latter violated.

passages.zh: 魏瑩怒，將使人刺之。
passages.en: The king was enraged, and intended to send a man to assassinate him.

passages.zh: 犀首聞而恥之，曰：「君為萬乘之君也，而以匹夫從讎！
passages.en: When the Minister of War heard of it, he was ashamed, and said (to the king), 'You are a ruler of 10,000 chariots, and by means of a common man would avenge yourself on your enemy.

passages.zh: 衍請受甲二十萬，為君攻之，虜其人民，係其牛馬，使其君內熱發於背，然後拔其國。
passages.en: I beg you to give me, Yan, the command of 200,000 soldiers to attack him for you. I will take captive his people and officers, halter (and lead off) his oxen and horses, kindling a fire within him that shall burn to his backbone. I will then storm his capital.

passages.zh: 忌也出走，然後抶其背，折其脊。」
passages.en: And when he shall run away in terror, I will flog his back and break his spine.'

passages.zh: 季子聞而恥之，曰：「築十仞之城，城者既十仞矣，則又壞之，此胥靡之所苦也。
passages.en: Ji-zi heard of this advice, and was ashamed of it, and said (to the king), 'We have been raising the wall (of our capital) to a height of eighty cubits, and the work has been completed. If we now get it thrown down, it will be a painful toil to the convict builders.

passages.zh: 今兵不起七年矣，此王之基也。
passages.en: It is now seven years since our troops were called out, and this is the foundation of the royal sway.

passages.zh: 衍亂人，不可聽也。」
passages.en: Yen would introduce disorder - he should not be listened to.'

passages.zh: 華子聞而醜之，曰：「善言伐齊者，亂人也；善言勿伐者，亦亂人也；謂伐之與不伐亂人也者，又亂人也。」
passages.en: Hua-zi heard of this advice, and, greatly disapproving of it, said (to the king), 'He who shows his skill in saying "Attack Qi!" would produce disorder; and he who shows his skill in saying "Do not attack it" would also produce disorder. And one who should (merely) say, "The counsellors to attack Qi and not to attack it would both produce disorder," would himself also lead to the same result.'

passages.zh: 王曰：「然則若何？」
passages.en: The king said, 'Yes, but what am I to do?'

passages.zh: 曰：「君求其道而已矣。」
passages.en: The reply was, 'You have only to seek for (the rule of) the Dao (on the subject).'

passages.zh: 惠子聞之而見戴晉人。
passages.en: Huizi, having heard of this counsel, introduced to the king Dai Jin-ren.

passages.zh: 戴晉人曰：「有所謂蝸者，君知之乎？」
passages.en: Dai Jin-ren said, 'There is the creature called a snail; does your majesty know it?'
'I do.'

passages.zh: 「有國於蝸之左角者曰觸氏，有國於蝸之右角者曰蠻氏，時相與爭地而戰，伏尸數萬，逐北旬有五日而後反。」
passages.en: 'On the left horn of the snail there is a kingdom which is called Provocation, and on the right horn another which is called Stupidity. These two kingdoms are continually striving about their territories and fighting. The corpses that lie on the ground amount to several myriads. The army of one may be defeated and put to flight, but in fifteen days it will return.'

passages.zh: 君曰：「噫！其虛言與？」
passages.en: The king said, 'Pooh! that is empty talk!'

passages.zh: 曰：「臣請為君實之。
passages.en: The other rejoined, 'Your servant begs to show your majesty its real significance.

passages.zh: 君以意在四方上下有窮乎？」
passages.en: When your majesty thinks of space - east, west, north, and south, above and beneath - can you set any limit to it?'

passages.zh: 君曰：「無窮。」
passages.en: 'It is illimitable,' said the king.

passages.zh: 曰：「知遊心於無窮，而反在通達之國，若存若亡乎？」
passages.en: And his visitor went on, 'Your majesty knows how to let your mind thus travel through the illimitable, and yet (as compared with this) does it not seem insignificant whether the kingdoms that communicate one with another exist or not?'

passages.zh: 君曰：「然。」
passages.en: The king replies, 'It does so.'

passages.zh: 曰：「通達之中有魏，於魏中有梁，於梁中有王。
passages.en: And Dai Jin-ren said, finally, 'Among those kingdoms, stretching one after another, there is this Wei; in Wei there is this (city of) Liang; and in Liang there is your majesty.

passages.zh: 王與蠻氏，有辯乎？」
passages.en: Can you make any distinction between yourself, and (the king of that kingdom of) Stupidity?'

passages.zh: 君曰：「無辯。」
passages.en: To this the king answered, 'There is no distinction.'

passages.zh: 客出而君惝然若有亡也。
passages.en: And his visitor went out, while the king remained disconcerted and seemed to have lost himself.

passages.zh: 客出，惠子見。
passages.en: When the visitor was gone, Huizi came in and saw the king.

passages.zh: 君曰：「客，大人也，聖人不足以當之。」
passages.en: The king said, 'That stranger is a Great man. An (ordinary) sage is not equal to him.'

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「夫吹筦也，猶有嗃也；吹劍首者，吷而已矣。
passages.en: Huizi replied, 'If you blow into a flute, there come out its pleasant notes; if you blow into a sword-hilt, there is nothing but a wheezing sound.

passages.zh: 堯、舜，人之所譽也；道堯、舜於戴晉人之前，譬猶一吷也。」
passages.en: Yao and Shun are the subjects of men's praises, but if you speak of them before Dai Jin-ran, there will be but the wheezing sound.'

passages.zh: 孔子之楚，舍於蟻丘之漿。
passages.en: Confucius, having gone to Chu, was lodging in the house of a seller of Congee at Ant-hill.

passages.zh: 其鄰有夫妻臣妾登極者，子路曰：「是稯稯何為者邪？」
passages.en: On the roof of a neighbouring house there appeared the husband and his wife, with their servants, male and female. Zi-lu said, 'What are those people doing, collected there as we see them?'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「是聖人僕也。
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'The man is a disciple of the sages.

passages.zh: 是自埋於民，自藏於畔。
passages.en: He is burying himself among the people, and hiding among the fields.

passages.zh: 其聲銷，其志無窮，其口雖言，其心未嘗言，方且與世違而心不屑與之俱。
passages.en: Reputation has become little in his eyes, but there is no bound to his cherished aims. Though he may speak with his mouth, he never tells what is in his mind. Moreover, he is at variance with the age, and his mind disdains to associate with it.

passages.zh: 是陸沈者也，是其市南宜僚邪？」
passages.en: He is one who may be said to lie hid at the bottom of the water on the dry land. Is he not a sort of Yi Liao of Shi-nan?'

passages.zh: 子路請往召之。
passages.en: Zi-lu asked leave to go and call him.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「已矣！
passages.en: But Confucius said, 'Stop.

passages.zh: 彼知丘之著於己也，知丘之適楚也，以丘為必使楚王之召己也，彼且以丘為佞人也。
passages.en: He knows that I understand him well. He knows that I am come to Chu, and thinks that I am sure to try and get the king to invite him (to court). He also thinks that I am a man swift to speak.

passages.zh: 夫若然者，其於佞人也羞聞其言，而況親見其身乎！
passages.en: Being such a man, he would feel ashamed to listen to the words of one of voluble and flattering tongue, and how much more to come himself and see his person!

passages.zh: 而何以為存？」
passages.en: And why should we think that he will remain here?'

passages.zh: 子路往視之，其室虛矣。
passages.en: Zi-lu, however, went to see how it was, but found the house empty.

passages.zh: 長梧封人問子牢曰：「君為政焉勿鹵莽，治民焉勿滅裂。
passages.en: The Border-warden of Chang-wu, in questioning Zi-lao, said, 'Let not a ruler in the exercise of his government be (like the farmer) who leaves the clods unbroken, nor, in regulating his people, (like one) who recklessly plucks up the shoots.

passages.zh: 昔予為禾，耕而鹵莽之，則其實亦鹵莽而報予；芸而滅裂之，其實亦滅裂而報予。
passages.en: Formerly, in ploughing my corn-fields, I left the clods unbroken, and my recompense was in the rough unsatisfactory crops; and in weeding, I destroyed and tore up (many good plants), and my recompense was in the scantiness of my harvests.

passages.zh: 予來年變齊，深其耕而熟耰之，其禾蘩以滋，予終年厭飧。」
passages.en: In subsequent years I changed my methods, ploughing deeply and carefully covering up the seed; and my harvests were rich and abundant, so that all the year I had more than I could eat.'

passages.zh: 莊子聞之曰：「今人之治其形，理其心，多有似封人之所謂：遁其天，離其性，滅其情，亡其神，以眾為。
passages.en: When Zhuangzi heard of his remarks, he said, 'Now-a-days, most men, in attending to their bodies and regulating their minds, correspond to the description of the Border-warden. They hide from themselves their Heaven(-given being); they leave (all care of) their (proper) nature; they extinguish their (proper) feelings; and they leave their spirit to die: abandoning themselves to what is the general practice.

passages.zh: 故鹵莽其性者，欲惡之孽，為性萑葦蒹葭，始萌以扶吾形，尋擢吾性，並潰漏發，不擇所出，漂疽疥癕，內熱溲膏是也。」
passages.en: Thus dealing with their nature like the farmer who is negligent of the clods in his soil, the illegitimate results of their likings and dislikings become their nature. The bushy sedges, reeds, and rushes, which seem at first to spring up to support our bodies, gradually eradicate our nature, and it becomes like a mass of running sores, ever liable to flow out, with scabs and ulcers, discharging in flowing matter from the internal heat. So indeed it is!'

passages.zh: 柏矩學於老聃，曰：「請之天下遊。」
passages.en: Bo Ju was studying with Lao Dan, and asked his leave to go and travel everywhere.

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「已矣！天下猶是也。」
passages.en: Lao Dan said, 'Nay - elsewhere it is just as here.'

passages.zh: 又請之，老聃曰：「汝將何始？」
passages.en: He repeated his request, and then Lao Dan said, 'Where would you go first?'

passages.zh: 曰：「始於齊。」
passages.en: 'I would begin with Qi,' replied the disciple.

passages.zh: 至齊，見辜人焉，推而強之，解朝服而幕之，號天而哭之曰：「子乎子乎！天下有大菑，子獨先離之！」
passages.en: 'Having got there, I would go to look at the criminals (who had been executed). With my arms I would raise (one of) them up and set him on his feet, and, taking off my court robes, I would cover him with them, appealing at the same time to Heaven and bewailing his lot, while I said, "My son, my son, you have been one of the first to suffer from the great calamities that afflict the world."'

passages.zh: 曰：「莫為盜！莫為殺人！
passages.en: (Lao Dan) said, '(It is said), "Do not rob. Do not kill."

passages.zh: 榮辱立，然後睹所病；貨財聚，然後睹所爭。
passages.en: (But) in the setting up of (the ideas of) glory and disgrace, we see the cause of those evils; in the accumulation of property and wealth, we see the causes of strife and contention.

passages.zh: 今立人之所病，聚人之所爭，窮困人之身，使無休時，欲無至此，得乎！
passages.en: If now you set up the things against which men fret; if you accumulate what produces strife and contention among them; if you put their persons in such a state of distress, that they have no rest or ease, although you may wish that they should not come to the end of those (criminals), can your wish be realised?

passages.zh: 古之君人者，以得為在民，以失為在己；以正為在民，以枉為在己。
passages.en: The superior men (and rulers) of old considered that the success (of their government) was to be found in (the state of) the people, and its failure to be sought in themselves; that the right might be with the people, and the wrong in themselves.

passages.zh: 故一形有失其形者，退而自責。
passages.en: Thus it was that if but a single person lost his life, they retired and blamed themselves.

passages.zh: 今則不然。
passages.en: Now, however, it is not so.

passages.zh: 匿為物而愚不識，大為難而罪不敢，重為任而罰不勝，遠其塗而誅不至。
passages.en: (Rulers) conceal what they want done, and hold those who do not know it to be stupid; they require what is very difficult, and condemn those who do not dare to undertake it; they impose heavy burdens, and punish those who are unequal to them; they require men to go far, and put them to death when they cannot accomplish the distance.

passages.zh: 民知力竭，則以偽繼之，日出多偽，士民安得不偽！
passages.en: When the people know that the utmost of their strength will be insufficient, they follow it up with deceit. When (the rulers) daily exhibit much hypocrisy, how can the officers and people not be hypocritical?

passages.zh: 夫力不足則偽，知不足則欺，財不足則盜。
passages.en: Insufficiency of strength produces hypocrisy; insufficiency of knowledge produces deception; insufficiency of means produces robbery.

passages.zh: 盜竊之行，於誰責而可乎？」
passages.en: But in this case against whom ought the robbery and theft to be charged?'

passages.zh: 蘧伯玉行年六十而六十化，未嘗不始於是之而卒詘之以非也，未知今之所謂是之非五十九年非也。
passages.en: When Qu Bo-yu was in his sixtieth year, his views became changed in the course of it. He had never before done anything but consider the views which he held to be right, but now he came to condemn them as wrong; he did not know that what he now called right was not what for fifty-nine years he had been calling wrong.

passages.zh: 萬物有乎生而莫見其根，有乎出而莫見其門。
passages.en: All things have the life (which we know), but we do not see its root; they have their goings forth, but we do not know the door by which they depart.

passages.zh: 人皆尊其知之所知，而莫知恃其知之所不知而後知，可不謂大疑乎！
passages.en: Men all honour that which lies within the sphere of their knowledge, but they do not know their dependence on what lies without that sphere which would be their (true) knowledge: may we not call their case one of great perplexity?

passages.zh: 已乎已乎！且無所逃。
passages.en: Ah! Ah! there is no escaping from this dilemma.

passages.zh: 此所謂然與，然乎？
passages.en: So it is! So it is!

passages.zh: 仲尼問於大史大弢、伯常騫、狶韋曰：「夫衛靈公飲酒湛樂，不聽國家之政；田獵畢弋，不應諸侯之際。
passages.en: Zhongni asked the Grand Historiographer Da Tao, (along with) Bo Chang-qian and Xi-wei, saying, 'Duke Ling of Wei was so addicted to drink, and abandoned to sensuality, that he did not attend to the government of his state. Occupied in his pursuit of hunting with his nets and bows, he kept aloof from the meetings of the princes.

passages.zh: 其所以為靈公者何邪？」
passages.en: In what was it that he showed his title to the epithet of Ling?'

passages.zh: 大弢曰：「是因是也。」
passages.en: Da Tao said, 'It was on account of those very things.'

passages.zh: 伯常騫曰：「夫靈公有妻三人，同濫而浴。
passages.en: Bo Chang-qian said, 'Duke Ling had three mistresses with whom he used to bathe in the same tub.

passages.zh: 史鰌奉御而進所，搏幣而扶翼。
passages.en: (Once, however), when Shi-qiu came to him with presents from the imperial court, he made his servants support the messenger in bearing the gifts.

passages.zh: 其慢若彼之甚也，見賢人若此其肅也，是其所以為靈公也。」
passages.en: So dissolute was he in the former case, and when he saw a man of worth, thus reverent was he to him. It was on this account that he was styled "Duke Ling."'

passages.zh: 狶韋曰：「夫靈公也死，卜葬於故墓不吉，卜葬於沙丘而吉。
passages.en: Xi-wei said, 'When duke Ling died, and they divined about burying him in the old tomb of his House, the answer was unfavourable; when they divined about burying him on Sha-qiu, the answer was favourable.

passages.zh: 掘之數仞，得石槨焉，洗而視之，有銘焉，曰：『不馮其子，靈公奪而里之。』
passages.en: Accordingly they dug there to the depth of several fathoms, and found a stone coffin. Having washed and inspected it, they discovered an inscription, which said, "This grave will not be available for your posterity; Duke Ling will appropriate it for himself."

passages.zh: 夫靈公之為靈也久矣，之二人何足以識之？」
passages.en: Thus that epithet of Ling had long been settled for the duke. But how should those two be able to know this?'

passages.zh: 少知問於大公調曰：「何謂丘里之言？」
passages.en: Shao Zhi asked Da-gong Diao, saying, 'What do we mean by "The Talk of the Hamlets and Villages?"'

passages.zh: 大公調曰：「丘里者，合十姓百名而以為風俗也。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Hamlets and Villages are formed by the union - say of ten surnames and a hundred names, and are considered to be (the source of) manners and customs.

passages.zh: 合異以為同，散同以為異。
passages.en: The differences between them are united to form their common character, and what is common to them is separately apportioned to form the differences.

passages.zh: 今指馬之百體而不得馬，而馬係於前者，立其百體而謂之馬也。
passages.en: If you point to the various parts which make up the body of a horse, you do not have the horse; but when the horse is before you, and all its various parts stand forth (as forming the animal), you speak of "the horse."

passages.zh: 是故丘山積卑而為高，江河合水而為大，大人合并而為公。
passages.en: So it is that the mounds and hills are made to be the elevations that they are by accumulations of earth which individually are but low. (So also rivers like) the Jiang and the He obtain their greatness by the union of (other smaller) waters with them. And (in the same way) the Great man exhibits the common sentiment of humanity by the union in himself of all its individualities.

passages.zh: 是以自外入者，有主而不執；由中出者，有正而不距。
passages.en: Hence when ideas come to him from without, though he has his own decided view, he does not hold it with bigotry; and when he gives out his own decisions, which are correct, the views of others do not oppose them.

passages.zh: 四時殊氣，天不賜，故歲成；五官殊職，君不私，故國治；文武大人不賜，故德備；萬物殊理，道不私，故無名。
passages.en: The four seasons have their different elemental characters, but they are not the partial gifts of Heaven, and so the year completes its course. The five official departments have their different duties, but the ruler does not partially employ any one of them, and so the kingdom is governed. (The gifts of) peace and war (are different), but the Great man does not employ the one to the prejudice of the other, and so the character (of his administration) is perfect. All things have their different constitutions and modes of actions, but the Dao (which directs them) is free from all partiality, and therefore it has no name.

passages.zh: 無名故無為，無為而無不為。
passages.en: Having no name, it therefore does nothing. Doing nothing, there is nothing which it does not do.

passages.zh: 時有終始，世有變化，禍福淳淳，至有所拂者而有所宜；自殉殊面，有所正者有所差。
passages.en: Each season has its ending and beginning; each age has its changes and transformations; misery and happiness regularly alternate. Here our views are thwarted, and yet the result may afterwards have our approval; there we insist on our own views, and looking at things differently from others, try to correct them, while we are in error ourselves.

passages.zh: 比於大澤，百材皆度；觀於大山，木石同壇。
passages.en: The case may be compared to that of a great marsh, in which all its various vegetation finds a place, or we may look at it as a great hill, where trees and rocks are found on the same terrace.

passages.zh: 此之謂丘里之言。」
passages.en: Such may be a description of what is intended by "The Talk of the Hamlets and Villages."'

passages.zh: 少知曰：「然則謂之道，足乎？」
passages.en: Shao Zhi said, 'Well, is it sufficient to call it (an expression of) the Dao?'

passages.zh: 大公調曰：「不然。
passages.en: Da-gong Diao said, 'It is not so.

passages.zh: 今計物之數，不止於萬，而期曰『萬物』者，以數之多者號而讀之也。
passages.en: If we reckon up the number of things, they are not 10,000 merely. When we speak of them as "the Myriad Things," we simply use that large number by way of accommodation to denominate them.

passages.zh: 是故天地者，形之大者也；陰陽者，氣之大者也；道者為之公。
passages.en: In this way Heaven and Earth are the greatest of all things that have form; the Yin and Yang are the greatest of all elemental forces. But the Dao is common to them.

passages.zh: 因其大而號以讀之，則可也。
passages.en: Because of their greatness to use the Dao or (Course) as a title and call it "the Great Dao" is allowable.

passages.zh: 已有之矣，乃將得比哉！
passages.en: But what comparison can be drawn between it and "the Talk of the Hamlets and Villages?"

passages.zh: 則若以斯辯，譬猶狗馬，其不及遠矣。」
passages.en: To argue from this that it is a sufficient expression of the Dao, is like calling a dog and a horse by the same name, while the difference between them is so great.'

passages.zh: 少知曰：「四方之內，六合之裏，萬物之所生惡起？」
passages.en: Shao Zhi said, 'Within the limits of the four cardinal points, and the six boundaries of space, how was it that there commenced the production of all things?'

passages.zh: 太公調曰：「陰陽相照、相蓋、相治，四時相代、相生、相殺，欲惡去就於是橋起，雌雄片合於是庸有。
passages.en: Da-gong Diao replied, 'The Yin and Yang reflected light on each other, covered each other, and regulated each the other; the four seasons gave place to one another, produced one another, and brought one another to an end. Likings and dislikings, the avoidings of this and movements towards that, then arose (in the things thus produced), in their definite distinctness; and from this came the separation and union of the male and female.

passages.zh: 安危相易，禍福相生，緩急相摩，聚散以成。
passages.en: Then were seen now security and now insecurity, in mutual change; misery and happiness produced each other; gentleness and urgency pressed on each other; the movements of collection and dispersion were established.

passages.zh: 此名實之可紀，精微之可志也。
passages.en: These names and processes can be examined, and, however minute, can be recorded.

passages.zh: 隨序之相理，橋運之相使，窮則反，終則始。
passages.en: The rules determining the order in which they follow one another, their mutual influence now acting directly and now revolving, how, when they are exhausted, they revive, and how they end and begin again.

passages.zh: 此物之所有，言之所盡，知之所至，極物而已。
passages.en: These are the properties belonging to things. Words can describe them and knowledge can reach to them; but with this ends all that can be said of things.

passages.zh: 覩道之人，不隨其所廢，不原其所起，此議之所止。」
passages.en: Men who study the Dao do not follow on when these operations end, nor try to search out how they began: with this all discussion of them stops.'

passages.zh: 少知曰：「季真之莫為，接子之或使，二家之議，孰正於其情？孰偏於其理？」
passages.en: Shao Zhi said, 'Ji Zhen holds that (the Dao) forbids all action, and Jie-zi holds that it may perhaps allow of influence. Which of the two is correct in his statements, and which is one-sided in his ruling?'

passages.zh: 太公調曰：「雞鳴狗吠，是人之所知，雖有大知，不能以言讀其所自化，又不能以意其所將為。
passages.en: Da-gong Diao replied, 'Cocks crow and dogs bark - this is what all men know. But men with the greatest wisdom cannot describe in words whence it is that they are formed (with such different voices), nor can they find out by thinking what they wish to do.

passages.zh: 斯而析之，精至於無倫，大至於不可圍，或之使，莫之為，未免於物而終以為過。
passages.en: We may refine on this small point; till it is so minute that there is no point to operate on, or it may become so great that there is no embracing it. "Some one caused it;" "No one did it;" but we are thus debating about things; and the end is that we shall find we are in error.

passages.zh: 或使則實，莫為則虛。
passages.en: "Some one caused it" - then there was a real Being. "No one did it" - then there was mere vacancy.

passages.zh: 有名有實，是物之居；無名無實，在物之虛。
passages.en: To have a name and a real existence - that is the condition of a thing. Not to have a name, and not to have real being - that is vacancy and no thing.

passages.zh: 可言可意，言而愈疏。
passages.en: We may speak and we may think about it, but the more we speak, the wider shall we be of the mark.

passages.zh: 未生不可忌，已死不可阻。
passages.en: Birth, before it comes, cannot be prevented; death, when it has happened, cannot be traced farther.

passages.zh: 死生非遠也，理不可睹。
passages.en: Death and life are not far apart; but why they have taken place cannot be seen.

passages.zh: 或之使，莫之為，疑之所假。
passages.en: That some one has caused them, or that there has been no action in the case are but speculations of doubt.

passages.zh: 吾觀之本，其往無窮；吾求之末，其來無止。
passages.en: When I look for their origin, it goes back into infinity; when I look for their end, it proceeds without termination.

passages.zh: 無窮、無止，言之無也，與物同理；或使、莫為，言之本也，與物終始。
passages.en: Infinite, unceasing, there is no room for words about (the Dao). To regard it as in the category of things is the origin of the language that it is caused or that it is the result of doing nothing; but it would end as it began with things.

passages.zh: 道不可有，有不可無。
passages.en: The Dao cannot have a (real) existence; if it has, it cannot be made to appear as if it had not.

passages.zh: 道之為名，所假而行。
passages.en: The name Dao is a metaphor, used for the purpose of description.

passages.zh: 或使莫為，在物一曲，夫胡為於大方？
passages.en: To say that it causes or does nothing is but to speak of one phase of things, and has nothing to do with the Great Subject.

passages.zh: 言而足，則終日言而盡道；言而不足，則終日言而盡物。
passages.en: If words were sufficient for the purpose, in a day's time we might exhaust it; since they are not sufficient, we may speak all day, and only exhaust (the subject of) things.

passages.zh: 道、物之極，言、默不足以載；非言非默，議其有極。」
passages.en: The Dao is the extreme to which things conduct us. Neither speech nor silence is sufficient to convey the notion of it. Neither by speech nor by silence can our thoughts about it have their highest expression.

passages.zh: 外物不可必，故龍逢誅，比干戮，箕子狂，惡來死，桀、紂亡。
passages.en: What comes from without cannot be determined beforehand. So it was that Long-feng was killed; Bi-gan immolated; and the count of Ji (made to feign himself) mad, (while) Wu-lai died, and Jie and Zhou both perished.

passages.zh: 人主莫不欲其臣之忠，而忠未必信，故伍員流於江，萇弘死於蜀，藏其血三年，化而為碧。
passages.en: Rulers all wish their ministers to be faithful, but that faithfulness may not secure their confidence; hence Wu Yuan became a wanderer along the Jiang, and Chang Hong died in Shu, where (the people) preserved his blood for three years, when it became changed into green jade.

passages.zh: 人親莫不欲其子之孝，而孝未必愛，故孝己憂而曾參悲。
passages.en: Parents all wish their sons to be filial, but that filial duty may not secure their love; hence Xiao-ji had to endure his sorrow, and Zeng Shen his grief.

passages.zh: 木與木相摩則然，金與火相守則流。
passages.en: When wood is rubbed against wood, it begins to burn; when metal is subjected to fire, it (melts and) flows.

passages.zh: 陰陽錯行，則天地大絯，於是乎有雷有霆，水中有火，乃焚大槐。
passages.en: When the Yin and Yang act awry, heaven and earth are greatly perturbed; and on this comes the crash of thunder, and from the rain comes fire, which consumes great locust trees.

passages.zh: 有甚憂兩陷而無所逃，螴蜳不得成，心若縣於天地之間，慰睯沈屯，利害相摩，生火甚多，眾人焚和。
passages.en: (The case of men) is still worse. They are troubled between two pitfalls, from which they cannot escape. Chrysalis-like, they can accomplish nothing. Their minds are as if hung up between heaven and earth. Now comforted, now pitied, they are plunged in difficulties. The ideas of profit and of injury rub against each other, and produce in them a very great fire. The harmony (of the mind) is consumed in the mass of men.

passages.zh: 月固不勝火，於是乎有僓然而道盡。
passages.en: Their moonlike intelligence cannot overcome the (inward) fire. They thereupon fall away more and more, and the Course (which they should pursue) is altogether lost.

passages.zh: 莊周家貧，故往貸粟於監河侯。
passages.en: The family of Zhuang Zhou being poor, he went to ask the loan of some rice from the Marquis Superintendent of the He.

passages.zh: 監河侯曰：「諾。我將得邑金，將貸子三百金，可乎？」
passages.en: The Marquis said, 'Yes, I shall be getting the (tax-) money from the people (soon), and I will then lend you three hundred ounces of silver - will that do?'

passages.zh: 莊周忿然作色曰：「周昨來，有中道而呼者。
passages.en: Zhuang Zhou flushed with anger, and said, 'On the road yesterday, as I was coming here, I heard some one calling out.

passages.zh: 周顧視車轍中，有鮒魚焉。
passages.en: On looking round, I saw a goby in the carriage rut.

passages.zh: 周問之曰：『鮒魚來！子何為者邪？』
passages.en: I said to it, "Goby fish, what has brought you here?"

passages.zh: 對曰：『我，東海之波臣也。君豈有斗升之水而活我哉？』
passages.en: The goby said, "I am Minister of Waves in the Eastern Sea. Have you, Sir, a gallon or a pint of water to keep me alive?"

passages.zh: 周曰：『諾。我且南遊吳、越之王，激西江之水而迎子，可乎？』
passages.en: I replied, "Yes, I am going south to see the kings of Wu and Yue, and I will then lead a stream from the Western Kiang to meet you - will that do?"

passages.zh: 鮒魚忿然作色曰：『吾失我常與，我無所處。吾得斗升之水然活耳，君乃言此，曾不如早索我於枯魚之肆！』」
passages.en: The goby flushed with anger, and said, "I have lost my proper element, and I can here do nothing for myself; but if I could get a gallon or a pint of water, I should keep alive. Than do what you propose, you had better soon look for me in a stall of dry fish."'

passages.zh: 任公子為大鉤巨緇，五十犗以為餌，蹲乎會稽，投竿東海，旦旦而釣，期年不得魚。
passages.en: A son of the duke of Ren, having provided himself with a great hook, a powerful black line, and fifty steers to be used as bait, squatted down on (mount) Gui Ji, and threw the line into the Eastern Sea. Morning after morning he angled thus, and for a whole year caught nothing.

passages.zh: 已而大魚食之，牽巨鉤錎沒而下，騖揚而奮鬐，白波若山，海水震蕩，聲侔鬼神，憚赫千里。
passages.en: At the end of that time, a great fish swallowed the bait, and dived down, dragging the great hook with him. Then it rose to the surface in a flurry, and flapped with its fins, till the white waves rose like hills, and the waters were lashed into fury. The noise was like that of imps and spirits, and spread terror for a thousand li.

passages.zh: 任公子得若魚，離而腊之，自制河以東，蒼梧以北，莫不厭若魚者。
passages.en: The prince having got such a fish, cut it in slices and dried them. From the Zhi river to the east, and from Cang-wu to the north, there was not one who did not eat his full from that fish.

passages.zh: 已而後世輇才諷說之徒，皆驚而相告也。
passages.en: In subsequent generations, story-tellers of small abilities have all repeated the story to one another with astonishment.

passages.zh: 夫揭竿累，趣灌瀆，守鯢鮒，其於得大魚難矣；飾小說以干縣令，其於大達亦遠矣。
passages.en: (But) if the prince had taken his rod, with a fine line, and gone to pools and ditches, and watched for minnows and gobies, it would have been difficult for him to get a large fish. Those who dress up their small tales to obtain favour with the magistrates are far from being men of great understanding.

passages.zh: 是以未嘗聞任氏之風俗，其不可與經於世亦遠矣。
passages.en: And therefore one who has not heard the story of this scion of Ren is not fit to take any part in the government of the world - far is he from being so.

passages.zh: 儒以《詩》、《禮》發冢。
passages.en: Some literati, students of the Odes and Ceremonies, were breaking open a mound over a grave.

passages.zh: 大儒臚傳曰：「東方作矣，事之何若？」
passages.en: The superior among them spoke down to the others, 'Day is breaking in the east; how is the thing going on?'

passages.zh: 小儒曰：「未解裙襦，口中有珠。
passages.en: The younger men replied, 'We have not yet opened his jacket and skirt, but there is a pearl in the mouth.

passages.zh: 《詩》固有之曰：『青青之麥，生於陵陂。生不布施，死何含珠為？』
passages.en: As it is said in the Ode, "The bright, green grain is growing on the sides of the mound. While living, he gave nothing away; why, when dead, should he hold a pearl in his mouth?"

passages.zh: 接其鬢，壓其顪，儒以金椎控其頤，徐別其頰，無傷口中珠！」
passages.en: Thereupon they took hold of the whiskers and pulled at the beard, while the superior introduced a piece of fine steel into the chin, and gradually separated the jaws, so as not to injure the pearl in the mouth.

passages.zh: 老萊子之弟子出薪，遇仲尼，反以告曰：「有人於彼，修上而趨下，末僂而後耳，視若營四海，不知其誰氏之子。」
passages.en: A disciple of Lao Lai-zi, while he was out gathering firewood, met with Zhongni. On his return, he told (his master), saying, 'There is a man there, the upper part of whose body is long and the lower part short. He is slightly hump-backed, and his ears are far back. When you look at him, he seems occupied with the cares of all within the four seas; I do not know whose son he is.'

passages.zh: 老萊子曰：「是丘也，召而來！」
passages.en: Lao Lai-zi said, 'It is Qiu - call him here.'

passages.zh: 仲尼至。曰：「丘！去汝躬矜與汝容知，斯為君子矣。」
passages.en: And when Zhongni came, he said to him, 'Qiu, put away your personal conceit, and airs of wisdom, and show yourself to be indeed a superior man.'

passages.zh: 仲尼揖而退，蹙然改容而問曰：「業可得進乎？」
passages.en: Zhongni bowed and was retiring, when he abruptly changed his manner, and asked, 'Will the object I am pursuing be thereby advanced?'

passages.zh: 老萊子曰：「夫不忍一世之傷，而驁萬世之患，抑固窶邪？亡其略弗及邪？
passages.en: Lao Lai-zi replied, 'You cannot bear the sufferings of this one age, and are stubbornly regardless of the evils of a myriad ages: is it that you purposely make yourself thus unhappy? or is it that you have not the ability to comprehend the case?

passages.zh: 惠以歡為驁，終身之醜，中民之行進焉耳，相引以名，相結以隱。
passages.en: Your obstinate purpose to make men rejoice in a participation of your joy is your life-long shame, the procedure of a mediocre man. You would lead men by your fame; you would bind them to you by your secret art.

passages.zh: 與其譽堯而非桀，不如兩忘而閉其所譽。
passages.en: Than be praising Yao and condemning Jie, you had better forget them both, and shut up your tendency to praise.

passages.zh: 反無非傷也，動無非邪也。
passages.en: If you reflect on it, it does nothing but injury; your action in it is entirely wrong.

passages.zh: 聖人躊躇以興事，以每成功。
passages.en: The sage is full of anxiety and indecision in undertaking anything, and so he is always successful.

passages.zh: 奈何哉其載焉終矜爾！」
passages.en: But what shall I say of your conduct? To the end it is all affectation.'

passages.zh: 宋元君夜半而夢人被髮闚阿門，曰：「予自宰路之淵，予為清江使河伯之所，漁者余且得予。」
passages.en: The ruler Yuan of Song (once) dreamt at midnight that a man with dishevelled hair peeped in on him at a side door and said, 'I was coming from the abyss of Zai-lu, commissioned by the Clear Jiang to go to the place of the Earl of the He; but the fisherman Yu Qie has caught me.'

passages.zh: 元君覺，使人占之，曰：「此神龜也。」
passages.en: When the ruler Yuan awoke, he caused a diviner to divine the meaning (of the dream), and was told, 'This is a marvellous tortoise.'

passages.zh: 君曰：「漁者有余且乎？」
passages.en: The ruler asked if among the fishermen there was one called Yu Qie.

passages.zh: 左右曰：「有。」
passages.en: Being told by his attendants that there was, he gave orders that he should be summoned to court.

passages.zh: 君曰：「令余且會朝。」
passages.en: Accordingly the man next day appeared at court.

passages.zh: 明日，余且朝。君曰：「漁何得？」
passages.en: The ruler said, 'What have you caught (lately) in fishing?'

passages.zh: 對曰：「且之網，得白龜焉，其圓五尺。」
passages.en: The reply was, 'I have caught in my net a white tortoise, sievelike, and five cubits round.'

passages.zh: 君曰：「獻若之龜。」
passages.en: 'Present the prodigy here,' said the ruler.

passages.zh: 龜至，君再欲殺之，再欲活之，心疑，卜之，曰：「殺龜以卜，吉。」
passages.en: When it came, once and again he wished to kill it, once and again he wished to keep it alive. Doubting in his mind (what to do), he had recourse to divination, and obtained the answer, 'To kill the tortoise for use in divining will be fortunate.'

passages.zh: 乃刳龜，七十二鑽而無遺筴。
passages.en: Accordingly they cut the creature open, and perforated its shell in seventy-two places, and there was not a single divining slip which failed.

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「神龜能見夢於元君而不能避余且之網；知能七十二鑽而無遺筴，不能避刳腸之患。
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'The spirit-like tortoise could show itself in a dream to the ruler Yuan, and yet it could not avoid the net of Yu Qie. Its wisdom could respond on seventy-two perforations without failing in a single divination, and yet it could not avoid the agony of having its bowels all scooped out.

passages.zh: 如是，則知有所困，神有所不及也。
passages.en: We see from this that wisdom is not without its perils, and spirit-like intelligence does not reach to everything.

passages.zh: 雖有至知，萬人謀之。
passages.en: A man may have the greatest wisdom, but there are a myriad men scheming against him.

passages.zh: 魚不畏網而畏鵜鶘。
passages.en: Fishes do not fear the net, though they fear the pelican.

passages.zh: 去小知而大知明，去善而自善矣。」
passages.en: Put away your small wisdom, and your great wisdom will be bright; discard your skilfulness, and you will become naturally skilful.

passages.zh: 嬰兒生無石師而能言，與能言者處也。
passages.en: A child when it is born needs no great master, and yet it becomes able to speak, living (as it does) among those who are able to speak.'

passages.zh: 惠子謂莊子曰：「子言無用。」
passages.en: Huizi said to Zhuangzi, 'You speak, Sir, of what is of no use.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「知無用而始可與言用矣。
passages.en: The reply was, 'When a man knows what is not useful, you can then begin to speak to him of what is useful.

passages.zh: 夫地非不廣且大也，人之所用容足耳。
passages.en: The earth for instance is certainly spacious and great; but what a man uses of it is only sufficient ground for his feet.

passages.zh: 然則廁足而墊之，致黃泉，人尚有用乎？」
passages.en: If, however, a rent were made by the side of his feet, down to the yellow springs, could the man still make use of it?'

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「無用。」
passages.en: Huizi said, 'He could not use it.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「然則無用之為用也亦明矣。」
passages.en: And Zhuangzi rejoined, 'Then the usefulness of what is of no use is clear.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「人有能遊，且得不遊乎？人而不能遊，且得遊乎？
passages.en: Zhuangzi said, 'If a man have the power to enjoy himself (in any pursuit), can he be kept from doing so? If he have not the power, can he so enjoy himself?

passages.zh: 夫流遁之志，決絕之行，噫！其非至知厚德之任與！
passages.en: There are those whose aim is bent on concealing themselves, and those who are determined that their doings shall leave no trace. Alas! they both shirk the obligations of perfect knowledge and great virtue.

passages.zh: 覆墜而不反，火馳而不顧，雖相與為君臣，時也，易世而無以相賤。
passages.en: The (latter) fall, and cannot recover themselves; the (former) rush on like fire, and do not consider (what they are doing). Though men may stand to each other in the relation of ruler and minister, that is but for a time. In a changed age, the one of them would not be able to look down on the other.

passages.zh: 故曰：至人不留行焉。
passages.en: Hence it is said, "The Perfect man leaves no traces of his conduct."

passages.zh: 夫尊古而卑今，學者之流也。
passages.en: To honour antiquity and despise the present time is the characteristic of learners.

passages.zh: 且以豨韋氏之流觀今之世，夫孰能不波？
passages.en: But even the disciples of Khih-wei have to look at the present age; and who can avoid being carried along by its course?

passages.zh: 唯至人乃能遊於世而不僻，順人而不失己，彼教不學，承意不彼。
passages.en: It is only the Perfect man who is able to enjoy himself in the world, and not be deflected from the right, to accommodate himself to others and not lose himself. He does not learn their lessons; he only takes their ideas into consideration, and does not discard them as different from his own.

passages.zh: 目徹為明，耳徹為聰，鼻徹為顫，口徹為甘，心徹為知，知徹為德。
passages.en: It is the penetrating eye that gives clear vision, the acute ear that gives quick hearing, the discriminating nose that gives discernment of odours, the practised mouth that gives the enjoyment of flavours, the active mind that acquires knowledge, and the far-reaching knowledge that constitutes virtue.

passages.zh: 凡道不欲壅，壅則哽，哽而不止則跈，跈則眾害生。
passages.en: In no case does the connexion with what is without like to be obstructed; obstruction produces stoppage; stoppage, continuing without intermission, arrests all progress; and with this all injurious effects spring up.

passages.zh: 物之有知者恃息，其不殷，非天之罪。
passages.en: The knowledge of all creatures depends on their breathing. But if their breath be not abundant, it is not the fault of Heaven, which tries to penetrate them with it, day and night without ceasing.

passages.zh: 天之穿之，日夜無降，人則顧塞其竇。
passages.en: But men notwithstanding shut their pores against it.

passages.zh: 胞有重閬，心有天遊。
passages.en: The womb encloses a large and empty space; the heart has its spontaneous and enjoyable movements.

passages.zh: 室無空虛，則婦姑勃谿；心無天遊，則六鑿相攘。
passages.en: If their apartment be not roomy, wife and mother-in-law will be bickering; if the heart have not its spontaneous and enjoyable movements, the six faculties of perception will be in mutual collision.

passages.zh: 大林丘山之善於人也，亦神者不勝。
passages.en: That the great forests, the heights and hills, are pleasant to men, is because their spirits cannot overcome (those distracting influences).

passages.zh: 德溢乎名，名溢乎暴，謀稽乎誸，知出乎爭，柴生乎守，官事果乎眾宜。
passages.en: Virtue overflows into (the love of) fame; (the love of) fame overflows into violence; schemes originate in the urgency (of circumstances); (the show of) wisdom comes from rivalry; the fuel (of strife) is produced from the obstinate maintenance (of one's own views); the business of offices should be apportioned in accordance with the approval of all.

passages.zh: 春雨日時，草木怒生，銚鎒於是乎始修，草木之到植者過半，而不知其然。
passages.en: In spring, when the rain and the sunshine come seasonably, vegetation grows luxuriantly, and sickles and hoes begin to be prepared. More than half of what had fallen down becomes straight, and we do not know how.

passages.zh: 靜然可以補病，眥搣可以休老，寧可以止遽。
passages.en: Stillness and silence are helpful to those who are ill; rubbing the corners of the eyes is helpful to the aged; rest serves to calm agitation.

passages.zh: 雖然，若是，勞者之務也，非佚者之所未嘗過而問焉。
passages.en: But they are the toiled and troubled who have recourse to these things. Those who are at ease, and have not had such experiences, do not care to ask about them.

passages.zh: 聖人之所以駴天下，神人未嘗過而問焉；賢人所以駴世，聖人未嘗過而問焉；君子所以駴國，賢人未嘗過而問焉；小人所以合時，君子未嘗過而問焉。
passages.en: The spirit-like man has had no experience of how it is that the sagely man keeps the world in awe, and so he does not inquire about it; the sagely man has had no experience of how it is that the man of ability and virtue keeps his age in awe, and so he does not inquire about it; the man of ability and virtue has had no experience of how it is that the superior man keeps his state in awe, and so he does not inquire about it. The superior man has had no experience of how it is that the small man keeps himself in agreement with his times that he should inquire about it.'

passages.zh: 演門有親死者，以善毀，爵為官師，其黨人毀而死者半。
passages.en: The keeper of the Yan Gate, on the death of his father, showed so much skill in emaciating his person that he received the rank of 'Pattern for Officers.' Half the people of his neighbourhood (in consequence) carried their emaciation to such a point that they died.

passages.zh: 堯與許由天下，許由逃之；湯與務光天下，務光怒之。
passages.en: When Yao wished to resign the throne to Xu You, the latter ran away. When Thang offered his to Wu Guang, Wu Guang became angry.

passages.zh: 紀他聞之，帥弟子而踆於窾水，諸侯弔之三年，申徒狄因以踣河。
passages.en: When Ji Ta heard it, he led his disciples, and withdrew to the river Kuan, where the feudal princes came and condoled with him, and after three years, Shen Tu-di threw himself into the water.

passages.zh: 荃者所以在魚，得魚而忘荃；蹄者所以在兔，得兔而忘蹄；言者所以在意，得意而忘言。
passages.en: Fishing-stakes are employed to catch fish; but when the fish are got, the men forget the stakes. Snares are employed to catch hares, but when the hares are got, men forget the snares. Words are employed to convey ideas; but when the ideas are apprehended, men forget the words.

passages.zh: 吾安得忘言之人而與之言哉？」
passages.en: Fain would I talk with such a man who has forgot the words!

passages.zh: 寓言十九，重言十七，卮言日出，和以天倪。
passages.en: Of my sentences nine in ten are metaphorical; of my illustrations seven in ten are from valued writers. The rest of my words are like the water that daily fills the cup, tempered and harmonised by the Heavenly element in our nature.

passages.zh: 寓言十九，藉外論之。
passages.en: The nine sentences in ten which are metaphorical are borrowed from extraneous things to assist (the comprehension of) my argument.

passages.zh: 親父不為其子媒。
passages.en: (When it is said, for instance), 'A father does not act the part of matchmaker for his own son.'

passages.zh: 親父譽之，不若非其父者也；非吾罪也，人之罪也。
passages.en: (The meaning is that) 'it is better for another man to praise the son than for his father to do so.' The use of such metaphorical language is not my fault, but the fault of men (who would not otherwise readily understand me).

passages.zh: 與己同則應，不與己同則反，同於己為是之，異於己為非之。
passages.en: Men assent to views which agree with their own, and oppose those which do not so agree. Those which agree with their own they hold to be right, and those which do not so agree they hold to be wrong.

passages.zh: 重言十七，所以已言也，是為耆艾。
passages.en: The seven out of ten illustrations taken from valued writers are designed to put an end to disputations. Those writers are the men of hoary eld, my predecessors in time.

passages.zh: 年先矣，而無經緯本末以期年耆者，是非先也。
passages.en: But such as are unversed in the warp and woof, the beginning and end of the subject, cannot be set down as of venerable eld, and regarded as the predecessors of others.

passages.zh: 人而無以先人，無人道也；人而無人道，是之謂陳人。
passages.en: If men have not that in them which fits them to precede others, they are without the way proper to man, and they who are without the way proper to man can only be pronounced defunct monuments of antiquity.

passages.zh: 卮言日出，和以天倪，因以曼衍，所以窮年。
passages.en: Words like the water that daily issues from the cup, and are harmonised by the Heavenly Element (of our nature), may be carried on into the region of the unlimited, and employed to the end of our years.

passages.zh: 不言則齊，齊與言不齊，言與齊不齊也，故曰無言。
passages.en: But without words there is an agreement (in principle). That agreement is not effected by words, and an agreement in words is not effected by it. Hence it is said, 'Let there be no words.'

passages.zh: 言無言，終身言，未嘗言；終身不言，未嘗不言。
passages.en: Speech does not need words. One may speak all his life, and not have spoken a (right) word; and one may not have spoken all his life, and yet all his life been giving utterance to the (right) words.

passages.zh: 有自也而可，有自也而不可；有自也而然，有自也而不然。
passages.en: There is that which makes a thing allowable, and that which makes a thing not allowable. There is that which makes a thing right, and that which makes a thing not right.

passages.zh: 惡乎然？然於然。惡乎不然？不然於不然。惡乎可？可於可。惡乎不可？不可於不可。
passages.en: How is a thing right? It is right because it is right. How is a thing wrong? It is wrong because it is wrong. How is a thing allowable? It is allowable because it is so. How is a thing not allowable? It is not allowable because it is not so.

passages.zh: 物固有所然，物固有所可，無物不然，無物不可。
passages.en: Things indeed have what makes them right, and what makes them allowable. There is nothing which has not its condition of right; nothing which has not its condition of allowability.

passages.zh: 非卮言日出，和以天倪，孰得其久！
passages.en: But without the words of the (water-) cup in daily use, and harmonised by the Heavenly Element (in our nature), what one can continue long in the possession of these characteristics?

passages.zh: 萬物皆種也，以不同形相禪，始卒若環，莫得其倫，是謂天均。
passages.en: All things are divided into their several classes, and succeed to one another in the same way, though of different bodily forms. They begin and end as in an unbroken ring, though how it is they do so be not apprehended. This is what is called the Lathe of Heaven.

passages.zh: 天均者，天倪也。
passages.en: And the Lathe of Heaven is the Heavenly Element in our nature.

passages.zh: 莊子謂惠子曰：「孔子行年六十而六十化，始時所是，卒而非之，未知今之所謂是之非五十九年非也。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi said to Huizi, 'When Confucius was in his sixtieth year, in that year his views changed. What he had before held to be right, he now ended by holding to be wrong; and he did not know whether the things which he now pronounced to be right were not those which he had for fifty-nine years held to be wrong.'

passages.zh: 惠子曰：「孔子勤志服知也。」
passages.en: Huizi replied, 'Confucius with an earnest will pursued the acquisition of knowledge, and acted accordingly.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「孔子謝之矣，而其未之嘗言。
passages.en: Zhuangzi rejoined, 'Confucius disowned such a course, and never said that it was his.

passages.zh: 孔子云：『夫受才乎大本，復靈以生。』
passages.en: He said, "Man receives his powers from the Great Source (of his being), and he should restore them to their (original) intelligence in his life.

passages.zh: 鳴而當律，言而當法，利義陳乎前，而好惡是非直服人之口而已矣。
passages.en: His singing should be in accordance with the musical tubes, and his speech a model for imitation. When profit and righteousness are set before him, and his liking (for the latter) and dislike (of the former), his approval and disapproval, are manifested, that only serves to direct the speech of men (about him).

passages.zh: 使人乃以心服而不敢蘁立，定天下之定。
passages.en: To make men in heart submit, and not dare to stand up in opposition to him; to establish the fixed law for all under heaven.

passages.zh: 已乎已乎！吾且不得及彼乎！」
passages.en: Ah! ah! I have not attained to that."'

passages.zh: 曾子再仕而心再化，曰：「吾及親仕，三釜而心樂；後仕，三千鍾而不洎，吾心悲。」
passages.en: Zeng-zi twice took office, and on the two occasions his state of mind was different. He said, 'While my parents were alive I took office, and though my emolument was only three fu (of grain), my mind was happy. Afterwards when I took office, my emolument was three thousand zhong; but I could not share it with my parents, and my mind was sad.'

passages.zh: 弟子問於仲尼曰：「若參者，可謂無所縣其罪乎？」
passages.en: The other disciples asked Zhongni, saying, 'Such an one as Shan may be pronounced free from all entanglement: is he to be blamed for feeling as he did?'

passages.zh: 曰：「既已縣矣。夫無所縣者，可以有哀乎？彼視三釜、三千鍾，如觀雀蚊虻相過乎前也。」
passages.en: The reply was, 'But he was subject to entanglement. If he had been free from it, could he have had that sadness? He would have looked on his three fu and three thousand zhong no more than on a heron or a mosquito passing before him.'

passages.zh: 顏成子游謂東郭子綦曰：自吾聞子之言，一年而野，二年而從，三年而通，四年而物，五年而來，六年而鬼入，七年而天成，八年而不知死、不知生，九年而大妙。
passages.en: Yan Cheng Zi-you said to Dong-guo Zi-qi, 'When I (had begun to) hear your instructions, the first year, I continued a simple rustic; the second year, I became docile; the third year, I comprehended (your teaching); the fourth year, I was (plastic) as a thing; the fifth year, I made advances; the sixth year, the spirit entered (and dwelt in me); the seventh year, (my nature as designed by) Heaven was perfected; the eighth year, I knew no difference between death and life; the ninth year, I attained to the Great Mystery.'

passages.zh: 生有為，死也。
passages.en: Life has its work to do, and death ensues, (as if) the common character of each were a thing prescribed.

passages.zh: 勸公：以其死也，有自也；而生陽也，無自也。
passages.en: Men consider that their death has its cause; but that life from (the operation of) the Yang has no cause. But is it really so?

passages.zh: 而果然乎？惡乎其所適？惡乎其所不適？
passages.en: How does (the Yang) operate in this direction? Why does it not operate there?

passages.zh: 天有曆數，地有人據，吾惡乎求之？
passages.en: Heaven has its places and spaces which can be calculated; (the divisions of) the earth can be assigned by men. But how shall we search for and find out (the conditions of the Great Mystery)?

passages.zh: 莫知其所終，若之何其無命也？莫知其所始，若之何其有命也？
passages.en: We do not know when and how (life) will end, but how shall we conclude that it is not determined (from without)? And as we do not know when and how it begins, how should we conclude that it is not (so) determined?

passages.zh: 有以相應也，若之何其無鬼邪？無以相應也，若之何其有鬼邪？」
passages.en: In regard to the issues of conduct which we deem appropriate, how should we conclude that there are no spirits presiding over them; and where those issues seem inappropriate, how should we conclude that there are spirits presiding over them?'

passages.zh: 眾罔兩問於景曰：「若向也俯而今也仰，向也括而今被髮，向也坐而今也起，向也行而今也止，何也？」
passages.en: The penumbrae (once) asked the shadow, saying, 'Formerly you were looking down, and now you are looking up; formerly you had your hair tied up, and now it is dishevelled; formerly you were sitting, and now you have risen up; formerly you were walking, and now you have stopped: how is all this?'

passages.zh: 景曰：「搜搜也，奚稍問也？
passages.en: The shadow said, 'Venerable Sirs, how do you ask me about such small matters?

passages.zh: 予有而不知其所以。
passages.en: These things all belong to me, but I do not know how they do so.

passages.zh: 予，蜩甲也，蛇蛻也，似之而非也。
passages.en: I am (like) the shell of a cicada or the cast-off skin of a snake - like them, and yet not like them.

passages.zh: 火與日，吾屯也；陰與夜，吾代也。
passages.en: With light and the sun I make my appearance; with darkness and the night I fade away.

passages.zh: 彼，吾所以有待邪？而況乎以有待者乎！
passages.en: Am not I dependent on the substance from which I am thrown? And that substance is itself dependent on something else!

passages.zh: 彼來則我與之來，彼往則我與之往，彼強陽則我與之強陽。
passages.en: When it comes, I come with it; when it goes, I go with it. When it comes under the influence of the strong Yang, I come under the same.

passages.zh: 強陽者，又何以有問乎！」
passages.en: Since we are both produced by that strong Yang, what occasion is there for you to question me?'

passages.zh: 陽子居南之沛，老聃西遊於秦，邀於郊，至於梁而遇老子。
passages.en: Yang Zi-ju had gone South to Pei, while Lao Dan was travelling in the west in Qin. (He thereupon) asked (Laozi) to come to the border (of Pei), and went himself to Liang, where he met him.

passages.zh: 老子中道仰天而歎曰：「始以汝為可教，今不可也。」
passages.en: Laozi stood in the middle of the way, and, looking up to heaven, said with a sigh, 'At first I thought that you might be taught, but now I see that you cannot be.'

passages.zh: 陽子居不答。
passages.en: Yang Zi-ju made no reply.

passages.zh: 至舍，進盥漱巾櫛，脫屨戶外，膝行而前曰：「向者弟子欲請夫子，夫子行不閒，是以不敢。今閒矣，請問其過。」
passages.en: When they came to their lodging-house, he brought in water for the master to wash his hands and rinse his mouth, along with a towel and comb. He then took off his shoes outside the door, went forward on his knees, and said, 'Formerly, your disciple wished to ask you, Master, (the reason of what you said); but you were walking, and there was no opportunity, and therefore I did not presume to speak. Now there is an opportunity, and I beg to ask why you spoke as you did.'

passages.zh: 老子曰：「而睢睢盱盱，而誰與居？大白若辱，盛德若不足。」
passages.en: Laozi replied, 'Your eyes are lofty, and you stare - who would live with you? The purest carries himself as if he were soiled; the most virtuous seems to feel himself defective.'

passages.zh: 陽子居蹴然變容曰：「敬聞命矣。」
passages.en: Yang Zi-ju looked abashed and changed countenance, saying, 'I receive your commands with reverence.'

passages.zh: 其往也，舍者迎將其家，公執席，妻執巾櫛，舍者避席，煬者避灶。
passages.en: When he first went to the lodging-house, the people of it met him and went before him. The master of it carried his mat for him, and the mistress brought the towel and comb. The lodgers left their mats, and the cook his fire-place (as he passed them).

passages.zh: 其反也，舍者與之爭席矣。
passages.en: When he went away, the others in the house would have striven with him about (the places for) their mats.

chapters.title: Kings Who Have Wished To Resign

passages.zh: 堯以天下讓許由，許由不受。
passages.en: Yao proposed to resign the throne to Xu You, who would not accept it.

passages.zh: 又讓於子州支父，子州支父曰：「以為我天子，猶之可也。
passages.en: He then offered it to Zi-zhou Zhi-fu, but he said, 'It is not unreasonable to propose that I should occupy the throne.

passages.zh: 雖然，我適有幽憂之病，方且治之，未暇治天下也。」
passages.en: But I happen to be suffering under a painful sorrow and illness. While I am engaged in dealing with it, I have not leisure to govern the kingdom.'

passages.zh: 夫天下至重也，而不以害其生，又況他物乎！
passages.en: Now the throne is the most important of all positions, and yet this man would not occupy it to the injury of his life; how much less would he have allowed any other thing to do so!

passages.zh: 唯無以天下為者，可以託天下也。
passages.en: But only he who does not care to rule the kingdom is fit to be entrusted with it.

passages.zh: 舜讓天下於子州支伯，子州支伯曰：「予適有幽憂之病，方且治之，未暇治天下也。」
passages.en: Shun proposed to resign the throne to Zi-zhou Zhi-bo, who (likewise) said, 'I happen to be suffering under a painful sorrow and illness. While I am engaged in dealing with it, I have not leisure to govern the kingdom.'

passages.zh: 故天下大器也，而不以易生，此有道者之所以異乎俗者也。
passages.en: Now the kingdom is the greatest of all concerns, and yet this man would not give his life in exchange for the throne. This shows how they who possess the Dao differ from common men.

passages.zh: 舜以天下讓善卷，善卷曰：「余立於宇宙之中，冬日衣皮毛，夏日衣葛絺；春耕種，形足以勞動；秋收斂，身足以休息；日出而作，日入而息，逍遙於天地之間而心意自得。
passages.en: Shun proposed to resign the throne to Shan Juan, who said, 'I am a unit in the midst of space and time. In winter I wear skins and furs; in summer, grass-cloth and linen; in spring I plough and sow, my strength being equal to the toil; in autumn I gather in my harvest, and am prepared to cease from labour and eat. At sunrise I get up and work; at sunset I rest. So do I enjoy myself between heaven and earth, and my mind is content.

passages.zh: 吾何以天下為哉？悲夫！子之不知余也！」
passages.en: Why should I have anything to do with the throne? Alas! that you, Sir, do not know me better!'

passages.zh: 遂不受。
passages.en: Thereupon he declined the proffer.

passages.zh: 於是去而入深山，莫知其處。
passages.en: And went away, deep among the hills, no man knew where.

passages.zh: 舜以天下讓其友石戶之農，石戶之農曰：「捲捲乎后之為人，葆力之士也。」
passages.en: Shun proposed to resign the throne to his friend, a farmer of Shi-hu. The farmer, however, said (to himself), 'How full of vigor does our lord show himself, and how exuberant is his strength!'

passages.zh: 以舜之德為未至也，於是夫負妻戴，攜子以入於海，終身不反也。
passages.en: 'If Shun with all his powers be not equal (to the task of government, how should I be so?)' On this he took his wife on his back, led his son by the hand, and went away to the sea-coast, from which to the end of his life he did not come back.

passages.zh: 大王亶父居邠，狄人攻之。
passages.en: When Dai-wang Dan-fu was dwelling in Bin, the wild tribes of the North attacked him.

passages.zh: 事之以皮帛而不受，事之以犬馬而不受，事之以珠玉而不受，狄人之所求者土地也。
passages.en: He tried to serve them with skins and silks, but they were not satisfied. He tried to serve them with dogs and horses, but they were not satisfied, and then with pearls and jade, but they were not satisfied. What they sought was his territory.

passages.zh: 大王亶父曰：「與人之兄居而殺其弟，與人之父居而殺其子，吾不忍也。
passages.en: Dai-wang Dan-fu said (to his people), 'To dwell with the elder brother and cause the younger brother to be killed, or with the father and cause the son to be killed - this is what I cannot bear to do.

passages.zh: 子皆勉居矣！為吾臣與為狄人臣，奚以異？
passages.en: Make an effort, my children, to remain here. What difference is there between being my subjects, or the subjects of those wild people?

passages.zh: 且吾聞之，不以所用養害所養。」
passages.en: And I have heard that a man does not use that which he employs for nourishing his people to injure them.'

passages.zh: 因杖筴而去之。民相連而從之，遂成國於岐山之下。
passages.en: Thereupon he took his staff and switch and left, but the people followed him in an unbroken train, and he established a (new) state at the foot of mount Qi.

passages.zh: 夫大王亶父可謂能尊生矣。
passages.en: Thus Dai-wang Dan-fu might be pronounced one who could give its (due) honour to life.

passages.zh: 能尊生者，雖貴富不以養傷身，雖貧賤不以利累形。
passages.en: Those who are able to do so, though they may be rich and noble, will not, for that which nourishes them, injure their persons; and though they may be poor and mean, will not, for the sake of gain, involve their bodies (in danger).

passages.zh: 今世之人，居高官尊爵者，皆重失之，見利輕亡其身，豈不惑哉！
passages.en: The men of the present age who occupy high offices and are of honourable rank all lose these (advantages) again, and in the prospect of gain lightly expose their persons to ruin: is it not a case of delusion?

passages.zh: 越人三世弒其君，王子搜患之，逃乎丹穴。
passages.en: The people of Yue three times in succession killed their ruler, and the prince Sou, distressed by it, made his escape to the caves of Dan, so that Yue was left without a ruler.

passages.zh: 而越國無君，求王子搜不得，從之丹穴。
passages.en: The people sought for the prince, but could not find him, till (at last) they followed him to the cave of Dan.

passages.zh: 王子搜不肯出，越人薰之以艾，乘以王輿。
passages.en: The prince was not willing to come out to them, but they smoked him out with moxa, and made him mount the royal chariot.

passages.zh: 王子搜援綏登車，仰天而呼曰：「君乎君乎！獨不可以舍我乎！」
passages.en: As he took hold of the strap, and mounted the carriage, he looked up to heaven, and called out, 'O Ruler, O Ruler, could you not have spared me this?'

passages.zh: 王子搜非惡為君也，惡為君之患也。
passages.en: Prince Sou did not dislike being ruler - he disliked the evil inseparable from being so.

passages.zh: 若王子搜者，可謂不以國傷生矣，此固越人之所欲得為君也。
passages.en: It may be said of him that he would not for the sake of a kingdom endanger his life; and this indeed was the reason why the people of Yue wanted to get him for their ruler.

passages.zh: 韓、魏相與爭侵地。
passages.en: Han and Wei were contending about some territory which one of them had wrested from the other.

passages.zh: 子華子見昭僖侯，昭僖侯有憂色。
passages.en: Zi-hua Zi went to see the marquis Zhao-xi (of Han), and, finding him looking sorrowful.

passages.zh: 子華子曰：「今使天下書銘於君之前，書之言曰：『左手攫之則右手廢，右手攫之則左手廢，然而攫之者必有天下。』君能攫之乎？」
passages.en: He said, 'Suppose now that all the states were to sign an agreement before you to the effect that "Whoever should with his left hand carry off (the territory in dispute) should lose his right hand, and whoever should do so with his right hand should lose his left hand, but that, nevertheless, he who should carry it off was sure to obtain the whole kingdom;" would your lordship feel yourself able to carry it off?'

passages.zh: 昭僖侯曰：「寡人不攫也。」
passages.en: The marquis said, 'I would not carry it off.'

passages.zh: 子華子曰：「甚善！自是觀之，兩臂重於天下也，身亦重於兩臂。
passages.en: Zi-hua rejoined, 'Very good. Looking at the thing from this point of view, your two arms are of more value to you than the whole kingdom. But your body is of more value than your two arms.

passages.zh: 韓之輕於天下亦遠矣，今之所爭者，其輕於韓又遠。
passages.en: And Han is of much less value than the whole kingdom. The territory for which you are now contending is further much less important than Han.

passages.zh: 君固愁身傷生以憂戚不得也！」
passages.en: Your lordship, since you feel so much concern for your body, should not be endangering your life by indulging your sorrow.'

passages.zh: 僖侯曰：「善哉！教寡人者眾矣，未嘗得聞此言也。」
passages.en: The marquis Zhao-xi said, 'Good! Many have given me their counsel about this matter; but I never heard what you have said.'

passages.zh: 子華子可謂知輕重矣。
passages.en: Zi-hua Zi may be said to have known well what was of great importance and what was of little.

passages.zh: 魯君聞顏闔得道之人也，使人以幣先焉。
passages.en: The ruler of Lu, having heard that Yan He had attained to the Dao, sent a messenger, with a gift of silks, to prepare the way for further communication with him.

passages.zh: 顏闔守陋閭，苴布之衣而自飯牛。
passages.en: Yan He was waiting at the door of a mean house, in a dress of coarse hempen cloth, and himself feeding a cow.

passages.zh: 魯君之使者至，顏闔自對之。
passages.en: When the messenger arrived, Yan He himself confronted him.

passages.zh: 使者曰：「此顏闔之家與？」
passages.en: The messenger asked, 'Is this the house of Yan He?'

passages.zh: 顏闔對曰：「此闔之家也。」
passages.en: 'It is,' was the reply.

passages.zh: 使者致幣，顏闔曰：「恐聽者謬而遺使者罪，不若審之。」
passages.en: The other was presenting the silks to him, when he said, 'I am afraid you heard (your instructions) wrongly, and that he who sent you will blame you. You had better make sure.'

passages.zh: 使者還，反審之，復來求之，則不得已。
passages.en: The messenger on this returned, and made sure that he was right; but when he came back, and sought for Yan He, he was not to be found.

passages.zh: 故若顏闔者，真惡富貴也。
passages.en: Yes; men like Yan He do of a truth dislike riches and honours.

passages.zh: 故曰：道之真以治身，其緒餘以為國家，其土苴以治天下。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'The true object of the Dao is the regulation of the person. Quite subordinate to this is its use in the management of the state and the clan; while the government of the kingdom is but the dust and refuse of it.'

passages.zh: 由此觀之，帝王之功，聖人之餘事也，非所以完身養生也。
passages.en: From this we may see that the services of the Dis and Kings are but a surplusage of the work of the sages, and do not contribute to complete the person or nourish the life.

passages.zh: 今世俗之君子，多為身棄生以殉物，豈不悲哉！
passages.en: Yet the superior men of the present age will, most of them, throw away their lives for the sake of their persons, in pursuing their (material) objects - is it not cause for grief?

passages.zh: 凡聖人之動作也，必察其所以之，與其所以為。
passages.en: Whenever a sage is initiating any movement, he is sure to examine the motive which influences him, and what he is about to do.

passages.zh: 今且有人於此，以隨侯之珠彈千仞之雀，世必笑之。是何也？則其所用者重而所要者輕也。
passages.en: Here, however, is a man, who uses a pearl like that of the marquis of Sui to shoot a bird at a distance of 10,000 feet. All men will laugh at him; and why? Because the thing which he uses is of great value, and what he wishes to get is of little.

passages.zh: 夫生者，豈特隨侯之重哉！
passages.en: And is not life of more value than the pearl of the marquis of Sui?

passages.zh: 子列子窮，容貌有飢色。
passages.en: Zi Liezi was reduced to extreme poverty, and his person had a hungry look.

passages.zh: 客有言之於鄭子陽者曰：「列御寇，蓋有道之士也，居君之國而窮，君無乃為不好士乎？」
passages.en: A visitor mentioned the case to Zi-yang, (the premier) of Kang, saying, 'Lie Yu-kou, I believe, is a scholar who has attained to the Dao. Is it because our ruler does not love (such) scholars, that he should be living in his state in such poverty?'

passages.zh: 鄭子陽即令官遺之粟。
passages.en: Zi-yang immediately ordered an officer to send to him a supply of grain.

passages.zh: 子列子見使者，再拜而辭。
passages.en: When Liezi saw the messenger, he bowed to him twice, and declined the gift.

passages.zh: 使者去，子列子入，其妻望之而拊心曰：「妾聞為有道者之妻子，皆得佚樂，今有飢色。
passages.en: On Liezi's going into the house, his wife looked to him and beat her breast, saying, 'I have heard that the wife and children of a possessor of the Dao all enjoy plenty and ease, but now we look starved.

passages.zh: 君過而遺先生食，先生不受，豈不命邪！」
passages.en: The ruler has seen his error, and sent you a present of food, but you would not receive it - is it appointed (for us to suffer thus)?'

passages.zh: 子列子笑謂之曰：「君非自知我也。以人之言而遺我粟，至其罪我也，又且以人之言。此吾所以不受也。」
passages.en: Zi Liezi laughed and said to her, 'The ruler does not himself know me. Because of what some one said to him, he sent me the grain; but if another speak (differently) of me to him, he may look on me as a criminal. This was why I did not receive the grain.'

passages.zh: 其卒，民果作難而殺子陽。
passages.en: In the end it did come about, that the people, on an occasion of trouble and disorder, put Zi-yang to death.

passages.zh: 楚昭王失國，屠羊說走而從於昭王。
passages.en: When king Zhao of Chu lost his kingdom, the sheep-butcher Yue followed him in his flight.

passages.zh: 昭王反國，將賞從者，及屠羊說。
passages.en: When the king (recovered) his kingdom and returned to it, and was going to reward those who had followed him, on coming to the sheep-butcher Yue.

passages.zh: 屠羊說曰：「大王失國，說失屠羊；大王反國，說亦反屠羊。臣之爵祿已復矣，又何賞之言？」
passages.en: That personage said, 'When our Great King lost his kingdom, I lost my sheep-killing. When his majesty got back his kingdom, I also got back my sheep-killing. My income and rank have been recovered; why speak further of rewarding me?'

passages.zh: 王曰：「強之！」
passages.en: The king, (on hearing of this reply), said, 'Force him (to take the reward).'

passages.zh: 屠羊說曰：「大王失國，非臣之罪，故不敢伏其誅；大王反國，非臣之功，故不敢當其賞。」
passages.en: But Yue said, 'It was not through any crime of mine that the king lost his kingdom, and therefore I did not dare to submit to the death (which would have been mine if I had remained in the capital). And it was not through any service of mine that he recovered his kingdom, and therefore I do not dare to count myself worthy of any reward from him.'

passages.zh: 王曰：「見之！」
passages.en: The king (now) asked that the butcher should be introduced to him.

passages.zh: 屠羊說曰：「楚國之法，必有重賞大功而後得見。
passages.en: But Yue said, 'According to the law of Chu, great reward ought to be given to great service, and the recipient then be introduced to the king.

passages.zh: 今臣之知不足以存國，而勇不足以死寇。
passages.en: But now my wisdom was not sufficient to preserve the kingdom, nor my courage sufficient to die at the hands of the invaders.

passages.zh: 吳軍入郢，說畏難而避寇，非故隨大王也。
