passages.en: When the army of Wu entered, I was afraid of the danger, and got out of the way of the thieves - it was not with a distinct purpose (of loyalty) that I followed the king.

passages.zh: 今大王欲廢法毀約而見說，此非臣之所以聞於天下也。」
passages.en: And now he wishes, in disregard of the law, and violations of the conditions of our social compact, to see me in court - this is not what I would like to be talked of through the kingdom.'

passages.zh: 王謂司馬子綦曰：「屠羊說居處卑賤而陳義甚高，子綦為我延之以三旌之位。」
passages.en: The king said to Zi-qi, the Minister of War, 'The position of the sheep-butcher Yue is low and mean, but his setting forth of what is right is very high; do you ask him for me to accept the place of one of my three most distinguished nobles.'

passages.zh: 屠羊說曰：「夫三旌之位，吾知其貴於屠羊之肆也；萬鍾之祿，吾知其富於屠羊之利也。
passages.en: (This being communicated to Yue), he said, 'I know that the place of such a distinguished noble is nobler than a sheep-butcher's stall, and that the salary of 10,000 zhong is more than its profits.

passages.zh: 然豈可以食爵祿而使吾君有妄施之名乎！說不敢當，願復反吾屠羊之肆。」遂不受也。
passages.en: But how should I, through my greed of rank and emolument, bring on our ruler the name of an unlawful dispensation of his gifts? I dare not respond to your wishes, but desire to return to my stall as the sheep-butcher.' Accordingly he did not accept (the proffered reward).

passages.zh: 原憲居魯，環堵之室，茨以生草，蓬戶不完，桑以為樞而甕牖，二室，褐以為塞，上漏下溼，匡坐而弦。
passages.en: Yuan Xian was living in Lu. His house, whose walls were only a few paces round, looked as if it were thatched with a crop of growing grass; its door of brushwood was incomplete, with branches of a mulberry tree for its side-posts; the window of each of its two apartments was formed by an earthenware jar (in the wall), which was stuffed with some coarse serge. It leaked above, and was damp on the ground beneath; but there he sat composedly, playing on his guitar.

passages.zh: 子貢乘大馬，中紺而表素，軒車不容巷，往見原憲。
passages.en: Zi-gong, in an inner robe of purple and an outer one of pure white, riding in a carriage drawn by two large horses, the hood of which was too high to get into the lane (leading to the house), went to see him.

passages.zh: 原憲華冠縰履，杖藜而應門。
passages.en: Yuan Xian, in a cap made of bark, and slippers without heels, and with a stalk of hellebore for a staff, met him at the door.

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「嘻！先生何病？」
passages.en: 'Alas! Master,' said Zi-gong, 'that you should be in such distress!'

passages.zh: 原憲應之曰：「憲聞之：『無財謂之貧，學而不能行謂之病。』今憲，貧也，非病也。」
passages.en: Yuan Xian answered him, 'I have heard that to have no money is to be poor, and that not to be able to carry one's learning into practice is to be distressed. I am poor but not in distress.'

passages.zh: 子貢逡巡而有愧色。
passages.en: Zi-gong shrank back, and looked ashamed.

passages.zh: 原憲笑曰：「夫希世而行，比周而友，學以為人，教以為己，仁義之慝，輿馬之飾，憲不忍為也。」
passages.en: The other laughed and said, 'To act with a view to the world's (praise); to pretend to be public-spirited and yet be a partisan; to learn in order to please men; to teach for the sake of one's own gain; to conceal one's wickedness under the garb of benevolence and righteousness; and to be fond of the show of chariots and horses: these are things which Xian cannot bear to do.'

passages.zh: 曾子居衛，縕袍無表，顏色腫噲，手足胼胝。
passages.en: Zeng-zi was residing in Wei. He wore a robe quilted with hemp, and had no outer garment; his countenance looked rough and emaciated; his hands and feet were horny and callous.

passages.zh: 三日不舉火，十年不製衣，正冠而纓絕，捉衿而肘見，納履而踵決。
passages.en: He would be three days without lighting a fire; in ten years he did not have a new suit; if he put his cap on straight, the strings would break; if he drew tight the overlap of his robe, his elbow would be seen; in putting on his shoes, the heels would burst them.

passages.zh: 曳縰而歌商頌，聲滿天地，若出金石。
passages.en: Yet dragging his shoes along, he sang the 'Sacrificial Odes of Shang' with a voice that filled heaven and earth as if it came from a bell or a sounding stone.

passages.zh: 天子不得臣，諸侯不得友。
passages.en: The Son of Heaven could not get him to be a minister; no feudal prince could get him for his friend.

passages.zh: 故養志者忘形，養形者忘利，致道者忘心矣。
passages.en: So it is that he who is nourishing his mind's aim forgets his body, and he who is nourishing his body discards all thoughts of gain, and he who is carrying out the Dao forgets his own mind.

passages.zh: 孔子謂顏回曰：「回來！家貧居卑，胡不仕乎？」
passages.en: Confucius said to Yan Hui, 'Come here, Hui. Your family is poor, and your position is low; why should you not take office?'

passages.zh: 顏回對曰：「不願仕。回有郭外之田五十畝，足以給饘粥；郭內之田十畝，足以為絲麻；鼓琴足以自娛；所學夫子之道者足以自樂也。回不願仕。」
passages.en: Hui replied, 'I have no wish to be in office. Outside the suburban district I possess fields to the extent of fifty acres, which are sufficient to supply me with congee; and inside it I have ten acres, which are sufficient to supply me with silk and flax. I find my pleasure in playing on my lute, and your doctrines, Master, which I study, are sufficient for my enjoyment; I do not wish to take office.'

passages.zh: 孔子愀然變容曰：「善哉回之意！
passages.en: Confucius looked sad, changed countenance, and said, 'How good is the mind of Hui!

passages.zh: 丘聞之：『知足者不以利自累也，審自得者失之而不懼，行修於內者無位而不怍。』
passages.en: I have heard that he who is contented will not entangle himself with the pursuit of gain, that he who is conscious of having gained (the truth) in himself is not afraid of losing other things, and that he who cultivates the path of inward rectification is not ashamed though he may have no official position.

passages.zh: 丘誦之久矣，今於回而後見之，是丘之得也。」
passages.en: I have long been preaching this; but to-day I see it realised in Hui: this is what I have gained.'

passages.zh: 中山公子牟謂瞻子曰：「身在江海之上，心居乎魏闕之下，奈何？」
passages.en: Prince Mou of Gong-shan spoke to Zhan-zi, saying, 'My body has its place by the streams and near the sea, but my mind dwells at the court of Wei - what have you to say to me in the circumstances?'

passages.zh: 瞻子曰：「重生。重生則利輕。」
passages.en: Zhan-zi replied, 'Set the proper value on your life. When one sets the proper value on his life, gain seems to him unimportant.'

passages.zh: 中山公子牟曰：「雖知之，未能自勝也。」
passages.en: The prince rejoined, 'I know that, but I am not able to overcome (my wishes).'

passages.zh: 瞻子曰：「不能自勝則從，神無惡乎？不能自勝而強不從者，此之謂重傷。重傷之人，無壽類矣。」
passages.en: The reply was, 'If you cannot master yourself (in the matter), follow (your inclinations so that) your spirit may not be dissatisfied. When you cannot master yourself, and try to force yourself where your spirit does not follow, this is what is called doing yourself a double injury; and those who so injure themselves are not among the long-lived.'

passages.zh: 魏牟，萬乘之公子也，其隱巖穴也，難為於布衣之士，雖未至乎道，可謂有其意矣。
passages.en: Mou of Wei was the son of a lord of ten thousand chariots. For him to live in retirement among crags and caves was more difficult than for a scholar who had not worn the dress of office. Although he had not attained to the Dao, he may be said to have had some idea of it.

passages.zh: 孔子窮於陳、蔡之間，七日不火食，藜羹不糝，顏色甚憊，而弦歌於室。
passages.en: When Confucius was reduced to extreme distress between Zhan and Cai, for seven days he had no cooked meat to eat, but only some soup of coarse vegetables without any rice in it. His countenance wore the appearance of great exhaustion, and yet he kept playing on his lute and singing inside the house.

passages.zh: 顏回擇菜，子路、子貢相與言曰：「夫子再逐於魯，削迹於衛，伐樹於宋，窮於商、周，圍於陳、蔡，殺夫子者無罪，藉夫子者無禁。弦歌鼓琴，未嘗絕音，君子之無恥也若此乎？」
passages.en: Yan Hui (was outside), selecting the vegetables, while Zi-lu and Zi-gong were talking together, and said to him, 'The Master has twice been driven from Lu; he had to flee from Wei; the tree (beneath which he rested) was cut down in Sung; he was reduced to extreme distress in Shang and Zhou; he is held in a state of siege here between Zhan and Cai; any one who kills him will be held guiltless; there is no prohibition against making him a prisoner. And yet he keeps playing and singing, thrumming his lute without ceasing. Can a superior man be without the feeling of shame to such an extent as this?'

passages.zh: 顏回無以應，入告孔子。
passages.en: Yan Hui gave them no reply, but went in and told (their words) to Confucius.

passages.zh: 孔子推琴喟然而歎曰：「由與賜，細人也。召而來！吾語之。」
passages.en: Confucius pushed aside his lute, and said, 'You and Ci are small men. Call them here, and I will explain the thing to them.'

passages.zh: 子路、子貢入。子路曰：「如此者可謂窮矣。」
passages.en: When they came in, Zi-lu said, 'Your present condition may be called one of extreme distress.'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「是何言也！君子通於道之謂通，窮於道之謂窮。今丘抱仁義之道，以遭亂世之患，其何窮之為？
passages.en: Confucius replied, 'What words are these! When the Superior man has free course with his principles, that is what we call his success; when such course is denied, that is what we call his failure. Now I hold in my embrace the principles of benevolence and righteousness, and with them meet the evils of a disordered age - where is the proof of my being in extreme distress?

passages.zh: 故內省而不窮於道，臨難而不失其德，天寒既至，霜露既降，吾是以知松柏之茂也。
passages.en: Therefore looking inwards and examining myself, I have no difficulties about my principles; though I encounter such difficulties (as the present), I do not lose my virtue. It is when winter's cold is come, and the hoar-frost and snow are falling, that we know the vegetative power of the pine and cypress.

passages.zh: 陳、蔡之隘，於丘其幸乎！」
passages.en: This strait between Zhan and Cai is fortunate for me.'

passages.zh: 孔子削然反琴而弦歌，子路扢然執干而舞。
passages.en: He then took back his lute so that it emitted a twanging sound, and began to play and sing. (At the same time) Zi-lu, hurriedly, seized a shield, and began to dance.

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「吾不知天之高也，地之下也。」
passages.en: While Zi-gong said, 'I did not know (before) the height of heaven nor the depth of the earth.'

passages.zh: 古之得道者，窮亦樂，通亦樂。所樂非窮通也，道德於此，則窮通為寒暑風雨之序矣。
passages.en: The ancients who had got the Dao were happy when reduced to extremity, and happy when having free course. Their happiness was independent of both these conditions. The Dao, and its characteristics - let them have these and distress and success come to them as cold and heat, as wind and rain in the natural order of things.

passages.zh: 故許由娛於潁陽，而共伯得乎共首。
passages.en: Thus it was that Xu You found pleasure on the north of the river Ying, and that the earl of Gong enjoyed himself on the top of mount (Gong).

passages.zh: 舜以天下讓其友北人無擇，北人無擇曰：「異哉！后之為人也，居於甽畝之中，而遊堯之門。
passages.en: Shun proposed to resign the throne to his friend, the Northerner Wu-zhai, who said, 'A strange man you are, O sovereign! You (first) lived among the channeled fields, and then your place was in the palace of Yao.

passages.zh: 不若是而已，又欲以其辱行漫我。吾羞見之。」
passages.en: And not only so: you now further wish to extend to me the stain of your disgraceful doings. I am ashamed to see you.'

passages.zh: 因自投清泠之淵。
passages.en: And on this he threw himself into the abyss of Qing-ling.

passages.zh: 湯將伐桀，因卞隨而謀，卞隨曰：「非吾事也。」
passages.en: When Tang was about to attack Jie, he took counsel with Bian Sui, who said, 'It is no business of mine.'

passages.zh: 湯曰：「孰可？」曰：「吾不知也。」
passages.en: Tang then said, 'To whom should I apply?' And the other said, 'I do not know.'

passages.zh: 湯又因瞀光而謀，瞀光曰：「非吾事也。」
passages.en: Tang then took counsel with Wu Guang, who gave the same answer as Bian Sui.

passages.zh: 湯曰：「孰可？」曰：「吾不知也。」
passages.en: And when asked to whom he should apply, said in the same way, 'I do not know.'

passages.zh: 湯曰：「伊尹何如？」曰：「強力忍垢，吾不知其他也。」
passages.en: 'Suppose,' Tang then said, 'I apply to Yi Yin, what do you say about him?' The reply was, 'He has a wonderful power in doing what is disgraceful, and I know nothing more about him!'

passages.zh: 湯遂與伊尹謀伐桀。
passages.en: Tang thereupon took counsel with Yi Yin and attacked Jie.

passages.zh: 剋之，以讓卞隨。
passages.en: Tang overcame him, after which he proposed to resign the throne to Bian Sui.

passages.zh: 卞隨辭曰：「后之伐桀也謀乎我，必以我為賊也；勝桀而讓我，必以我為貪也。
passages.en: Bian Sui declined it, saying, 'When you were about to attack Jie, and sought counsel from me, you must have supposed me to be prepared to be a robber. Now that you have conquered Jie, and propose to resign the throne to me, you must consider me to be greedy.

passages.zh: 吾生乎亂世，而無道之人再來漫我以其辱行，吾不忍數聞也。」
passages.en: I have been born in an age of disorder, and a man without principle twice comes, and tries to extend to me the stain of his disgraceful proceedings - I cannot bear to hear the repetition of his proposals.'

passages.zh: 乃自投稠水而死。
passages.en: With this he threw himself into the Zhou water and died.

passages.zh: 湯又讓瞀光曰：「知者謀之，武者遂之，仁者居之，古之道也。吾子胡不立乎？」
passages.en: Tang further made proffer of the throne to Wu Guang, saying, 'The wise man has planned it; the martial man has carried it through; and the benevolent man should occupy it: this was the method of antiquity. Why should you, Sir, not take the position?'

passages.zh: 瞀光辭曰：「廢上，非義也；殺民，非仁也；人犯其難，我享其利，非廉也。
passages.en: Wu Guang refused the proffer, saying, 'To depose the sovereign is contrary to right; to kill the people is contrary to benevolence. When another has encountered the risks, if I should accept the gain of his adventure, I should violate my disinterestedness.

passages.zh: 吾聞之曰：『非其義者，不受其祿；無道之世，不踐其土。』
passages.en: I have heard it said, "If it be not right for him to do so, one should not accept the emolument; in an age of unprincipled (government), one should not put foot on the soil (of the) country."

passages.zh: 況尊我乎！吾不忍久見也。」
passages.en: How much less should I accept this position of honour! I cannot bear to see you any longer.'

passages.zh: 乃負石而自沈於廬水。
passages.en: And with this he took a stone on his back, and drowned himself in the Lu water.

passages.zh: 昔周之興，有士二人處於孤竹，曰伯夷、叔齊。
passages.en: Formerly, at the rise of the Zhou dynasty, there were two brothers who lived in Gu-zhu, and were named Bo-yi and Shu-Qi.

passages.zh: 二人相謂曰：「吾聞西方有人，似有道者，試往觀焉。」
passages.en: They spoke together and said, 'We have heard that in the west there is one who seems to rule according to the Right Way; let us go and see.'

passages.zh: 至於岐陽，武王聞之，使叔旦往見之，與盟曰：「加富二等，就官一列。」
passages.en: (Accordingly) they came to the south of (mount) Qi; and when king Wu heard of them, he sent (his brother) Shu Dan to see them, and make a covenant with them, engaging that their wealth should be second (only to that of the king), and that their offices should be of the first rank.

passages.zh: 血牲而埋之。
passages.en: And instructing him to bury the covenant with the blood of the victim after they had smeared the corners of their mouths with it.

passages.zh: 二人相視而笑曰：「嘻！異哉！此非吾所謂道也。
passages.en: The brothers looked at each other and laughed, saying, 'Ah! How strange! This is not what we call the Right Way.

passages.zh: 昔者神農之有天下也，時祀盡敬而不祈喜；其於人也，忠信盡治而無求焉。
passages.en: Formerly, when Shen Nong had the kingdom, he offered his sacrifices at the proper seasons and with the utmost reverence, but without praying for any blessing. Towards men he was leal-hearted and sincere, doing his utmost in governing them, but without seeking anything for himself.

passages.zh: 樂與政為政，樂與治為治，不以人之壞自成也，不以人之卑自高也，不以遭時自利也。
passages.en: When it was his pleasure to use administrative measures, he did so; and a sterner rule when he thought that would be better. He did not by the ruin of others establish his own power; he did not exalt himself by bringing others low; he did not, when the time was opportune, seek his own profit.

passages.zh: 今周見殷之亂而遽為政，上謀而下行貨，阻兵而保威，割牲而盟以為信，揚行以說眾，殺伐以要利，是推亂以易暴也。
passages.en: But now Zhou, seeing the disorder of Yin, has suddenly taken the government into its hands; with the high it has taken counsel, and with those below employed bribes; it relies on its troops to maintain the terror of its might; it makes covenants over victims to prove its good faith; it vaunts its proceedings to please the masses; it kills and attacks for the sake of gain: this is simply overthrowing disorder and changing it for tyranny.

passages.zh: 吾聞古之士遭治世不避其任，遇亂世不為苟存。
passages.en: We have heard that the officers of old, in an age of good government, did not shrink from their duties, and in an age of disorder did not recklessly seek to remain in office.

passages.zh: 今天下闇，周德衰，其並乎周以塗吾身也，不如避之以絜吾行。」
passages.en: Now the kingdom is in a state of darkness; the virtue of Zhou is decayed. Than to join with it and lay our persons in the dust, it is better for us to abandon it, and maintain the purity of our conduct.'

passages.zh: 二子北至於首陽之山，遂餓而死焉。
passages.en: The two princes then went north to the hill of Shou-yang, where they died of starvation.

passages.zh: 若伯夷、叔齊者，其於富貴也，苟可得已，則必不賴。
passages.en: If men such as Bo-yi and Shu-Qi, in the matter of riches and honours, can manage to avoid them, (let them do so).

passages.zh: 高節戾行，獨樂其志，不事於世，此二士之節也。
passages.en: But they must not depend on their lofty virtue to pursue any perverse course, only gratifying their own tendencies, and not doing service in their time: this was the style of these two princes.

passages.zh: 孔子與柳下季為友。
passages.en: Confucius was on terms of friendship with Liu-xia Ji, who had a brother named Dao Zhi.

passages.zh: 柳下季之弟名曰盜跖。
passages.en: This Dao Zhi had 9,000 followers, who marched at their will through the kingdom, assailing and oppressing the different princes.

passages.zh: 盜跖從卒九千人，橫行天下，侵暴諸侯，穴室樞戶，驅人牛馬，取人婦女，貪得忘親，不顧父母兄弟，不祭先祖。
passages.en: They dug through walls and broke into houses; they drove away people's cattle and horses; they carried off people's wives and daughters. In their greed to get, they forgot the claims of kinship, and paid no regard to their parents and brethren. They did not sacrifice to their ancestors.

passages.zh: 所過之邑，大國守城，小國入保，萬民苦之。
passages.en: Wherever they passed through the country, in the larger states the people guarded their city walls, and in the smaller the people took to their strongholds. All were distressed by them.

passages.zh: 孔子謂柳下季曰：「夫為人父者，必能詔其子；為人兄者，必能教其弟。
passages.en: Confucius spoke to Liu-xia Ji, saying, 'Fathers should be able to lay down the law to their sons, and elder to instruct their younger brothers.

passages.zh: 若父不能詔其子，兄不能教其弟，則無貴父子兄弟之親矣。
passages.en: If they are unable to do so, they do not fulfil the duties of the relationships which they sustain.

passages.zh: 今先生，世之才士也，弟為盜跖，為天下害，而弗能教也，丘竊為先生羞之。
passages.en: You, Sir, are one of the most talented officers of the age, and your younger brother is this Robber Zhi. He is a pest in the kingdom, and you are not able to instruct him better; I cannot but be ashamed of you, and I beg to go for you and give him counsel.

passages.zh: 丘請為先生往說之。」
passages.en: Liu-xia Ji replied, 'You say, Sir, that fathers must be able to lay down the law to their sons, and elder to instruct their younger brothers, but if sons will not listen to the orders of their fathers, nor the younger receive the lessons of their elder brothers, though one may have your powers of persuasion, what is to be done?

passages.zh: 柳下季曰：「先生言『為人父者必能詔其子，為人兄者必能教其弟』，若子不聽父之詔，弟不受兄之教，雖今先生之辯，將奈之何哉？
passages.en: And, moreover, Zhi is a man whose mind is like a gushing fountain, and his will like a whirlwind; he is strong enough to resist all enemies, and clever enough to gloss over his wrong-doings.

passages.zh: 且跖之為人也，心如涌泉，意如飄風，強足以距敵，辯足以飾非，順其心則喜，逆其心則怒，易辱人以言。
passages.en: If you agree with him, he is glad; if you oppose him, he is enraged; and he readily meets men with the language of abuse.

passages.zh: 先生必無往。」
passages.en: You must not go to him.'

passages.zh: 孔子不聽，顏回為御，子貢為右，往見盜跖。
passages.en: Confucius, however, did not attend to this advice. With Yan Hui as his charioteer, and Zi-gong seated on the right, he went to see Dao Zhi, whom he found with his followers halted on the south of Tai-shan, and mincing men's livers, which he gave them to eat.

passages.zh: 盜跖乃方休卒徒太山之陽，膾人肝而餔之。
passages.en: Confucius alighted from his carriage, and went forward, till he saw the usher, to whom he said, 'I, Kong Qiu of Lu, have heard of the general's lofty righteousness,' bowing twice respectfully to the man as he said so.

passages.zh: 孔子下車而前，見謁者曰：「魯人孔丘，聞將軍高義，敬再拜謁者。」
passages.en: The usher went in and announced the visitor.

passages.zh: 謁者入通，盜跖聞之大怒，目如明星，髮上指冠，曰：「此夫魯國之巧偽人孔丘非邪？
passages.en: But when Dao Zhi heard of the arrival, he flew into a great rage; his eyes became like blazing stars, and his hair rose up and touched his cap. 'Is not this fellow,' said he, 'Kong Qiu, that artful hypocrite of Lu?

passages.zh: 為我告之：『爾作言造語，妄稱文、武，冠枝木之冠，帶死牛之脅，多辭繆說，不耕而食，不織而衣，搖脣鼓舌，擅生是非，以迷天下之主，使天下學士不反其本，妄作孝弟而儌倖於封侯富貴者也。
passages.en: Tell him from me, "You invent speeches and babble away, appealing without ground to (the examples of) Wen and Wu. The ornaments on your cap are as many as the branches of a tree, and your girdle is (a piece of skin) from the ribs of a dead ox, The more you talk, the more nonsense you utter. You get your food without (the labour of) ploughing, and your clothes without (that of) weaving. You wag your lips and make your tongue a drum-stick. You arbitrarily decide what is right and what is wrong, thereby leading astray the princes throughout the kingdom, and making its learned scholars not occupy their thoughts with their proper business. You recklessly set up your filial piety and fraternal duty, and curry favour with the feudal princes, the wealthy and the noble.

passages.zh: 子之罪大極重，疾走歸！
passages.en: Your offence is great; your crime is very heavy. Take yourself off home at once.

passages.zh: 不然，我將以子肝益晝餔之膳。』」
passages.en: If you do not do so, I will take your liver, and add it to the provision for to-day's food."

passages.zh: 孔子復通曰：「丘得幸於季，願望履幕下。」
passages.en: But Confucius sent in another message, saying, 'I enjoy the good will of (your brother) Ji, and I wish and hope to tread the ground beneath your tent.'

passages.zh: 謁者復通，盜跖曰：「使來前！」
passages.en: When the usher had communicated this message, Dao Zhi said, 'Make him come forward.'

passages.zh: 孔子趨而進，避席反走，再拜盜跖。
passages.en: On this Confucius hastened forwards. Declining to take a mat, he drew hastily back, and bowed twice to Dao Zhi, who in a great rage stretched his legs apart, laid his hand on his sword, and with glaring eyes and a voice like the growl of a nursing tigress, said, 'Come forwards, Zhi.

passages.zh: 盜跖大怒，兩展其足，案劍瞋目，聲如乳虎，曰：「丘來前！
passages.en: If what you say be in accordance with my mind, you shall live; but, if it be contrary to it, you shall die.'

passages.zh: 若所言，順吾意則生，逆吾心則死。」
passages.en: Confucius replied, 'I have heard that everywhere under the sky there are three (most excellent) qualities.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「丘聞之，凡天下有三德：生而長大，美好無雙，少長貴賤見而皆說之，此上德也；知維天地，能辯諸物，此中德也；勇悍果敢，聚眾率兵，此下德也。
passages.en: To be naturally tall and large, to be elegant and handsome without a peer, so that young and old, noble and mean, are pleased to look upon him - this is the highest of those qualities. To comprehend both heaven and earth in his wisdom, and to be able to speak eloquently on all subjects - this is the middle one of them. To be brave and courageous, resolute and daring, gathering the multitudes round him, and leading on his troops - this is the lowest of them.

passages.zh: 凡人有此一德者，足以南面稱孤矣。
passages.en: Whoever possesses one of these qualities is fit to stand with his face to the south, and style himself a Prince.

passages.zh: 今將軍兼此三者，身長八尺二寸，面目有光，脣如激丹，齒如齊貝，音中黃鐘，而名曰盜跖，丘竊為將軍恥不取焉。
passages.en: But you, General, unite in yourself all the three. Your person is eight cubits and two inches in height; there is a brightness about your face and a light in your eyes; your lips look as if stained with vermilion; your teeth are like rows of precious shells; your voice is attuned to the musical tubes, and yet you are named "The Robber Zhi." I am ashamed of you, General, and cannot approve of you.

passages.zh: 將軍有意聽臣，臣請南使吳、越，北使齊、魯，東使宋、衛，西使晉、楚，使為將軍造大城數百里，立數十萬戶之邑，尊將軍為諸侯，與天下更始，罷兵休卒，收養昆弟，共祭先祖。
passages.en: If you are inclined to listen to me, I should like to go as your commissioner to Wu and Yue in the south; to Qi and Lu in the north; to Sung and Wei in the cast; and to Jin and Chu in the west. I will get them to build for you a great city several hundred li in size, to establish under it towns containing several hundred thousands of inhabitants, and honour you there as a feudal lord. The kingdom will see you begin your career afresh; you will cease from your wars and disband your soldiers; you will collect and nourish your brethren, and along with them offer the sacrifices to your ancestors: this will be a course befitting a sage and an officer of ability, and will fulfil the wishes of the whole kingdom.'

passages.zh: 此聖人才士之行，而天下之願也。」
passages.en: 'Come forward, Qiu,' said Dao Zhi, greatly enraged.

passages.zh: 盜跖大怒曰：「丘來前！
passages.en: 'Those who can be persuaded by considerations of gain, and to whom remonstrances may be addressed with success, are all ignorant, low, and ordinary people.

passages.zh: 夫可規以利而可諫以言者，皆愚陋恆民之謂耳。
passages.en: That I am tall and large, elegant and handsome, so that all who see me are pleased with me - this is an effect of the body left me by my parents.

passages.zh: 今長大美好，人見而悅之者，此吾父母之遺德也。
passages.en: Though you were not to praise me for it, do I not know it myself?

passages.zh: 丘雖不吾譽，吾獨不自知邪？
passages.en: And I have heard that he who likes to praise men to their face will also like to speak ill of them behind their back.

passages.zh: 且吾聞之：『好面譽人者，亦好背而毀之。』
passages.en: And when you tell me of a great wall and a multitudinous people, this is to try to persuade me by considerations of gain, and to cocker me as one of the ordinary people.

passages.zh: 今丘告我以大城眾民，是欲規我以利而恆民畜我也，安可久長也？
passages.en: But how could such advantages last for long?

passages.zh: 城之大者，莫大乎天下矣。
passages.en: Of all great cities there is none so great as the whole kingdom, which was possessed by Yao and Shun, while their descendants (now) have not so much territory as would admit an awl.

passages.zh: 堯、舜有天下，子孫無置錐之地，湯、武立為天子而後世絕滅，非以其利大故邪？
passages.en: Tang and Wu were both set up as the Sons of Heaven, but in after ages (their posterity) were cut off and extinguished - was not this because the gain of their position was so great a prize?

passages.zh: 且吾聞之：古者禽獸多而人少，於是民皆巢居以避之，晝拾橡栗，暮栖木上，故命之曰有巢氏之民。
passages.en: 'And moreover I have heard that anciently birds and beasts were numerous, and men were few, so that they lived in nests in order to avoid the animals. In the daytime they gathered acorns and chestnuts, and in the night they roosted on the trees; and on account of this they are called the people of the Nest-builder.

passages.zh: 古者民不知衣服，夏多積薪，冬則煬之，故命之曰知生之民。
passages.en: Anciently the people did not know the use of clothes. In summer they collected great stores of faggots, and in winter kept themselves warm by means of them; and on account of this they are called the people who knew how to take care of their lives.

passages.zh: 神農之世，臥則居居，起則于于，民知其母，不知其父，與麋鹿共處，耕而食，織而衣，無有相害之心，此至德之隆也。
passages.en: In the age of Shen Nong, the people lay down in simple innocence, and rose up in quiet security. They knew their mothers, but did not know their fathers. They dwelt along with the elks and deer. They ploughed and ate; they wove and made clothes; they had no idea of injuring one another: this was the grand time of Perfect virtue.

passages.zh: 然而黃帝不能致德，與蚩尤戰於涿鹿之野，流血百里。
passages.en: Huang-Di, however, was not able to perpetuate this virtuous state. He fought with Chi-you in the wild ofZhuo-lu till the blood flowed over a hundred li.

passages.zh: 堯、舜作，立群臣，湯放其主，武王殺紂。
passages.en: When Yao and Shun arose, they instituted their crowd of ministers. Tang banished his lord. King Wu killed Zhou.

passages.zh: 自是之後，以強陵弱，以眾暴寡。
passages.en: Since that time the strong have oppressed the weak, and the many tyrannised over the few.

passages.zh: 湯、武以來，皆亂人之徒也。
passages.en: From Tang and Wu downwards, (the rulers) have all been promoters of disorder and confusion.

passages.zh: 今子修文、武之道，掌天下之辯，以教後世，縫衣淺帶，矯言偽行，以迷惑天下之主，而欲求富貴焉，盜莫大於子。
passages.en: 'You yourself now cultivate and inculcate the ways of Wen and Wu; you handle whatever subjects are anywhere discussed for the instruction of future ages. With your peculiar robe and narrow girdle, with your deceitful speech and hypocritical conduct, you delude the lords of the different states, and are seeking for riches and honours. There is no greater robber than you are - why does not all the world call you the Robber Zhi, instead of styling me the Robber Zhi?

passages.zh: 天下何故不謂子為盜丘而乃謂我為盜跖？
passages.en: You prevailed by your sweet speeches on Zi-lu, and made him your follower; you made him put away his high cap, lay aside his long sword, and receive your instructions, so that all the world said, "Kong Qiu is able to arrest violence and repress the wrong-doer;" but in the end, when Zi-lu wished to slay the ruler of Wei, and the affair proved unsuccessful, his body was exhibited in pickle over the eastern gate of the capital - so did your teaching of him come to nothing.

passages.zh: 子以甘辭說子路而使從之，使子路去其危冠，解其長劍，而受教於子，天下皆曰『孔丘能止暴禁非』。
passages.en: Do you call yourself a scholar of talent, a sage?

passages.zh: 其卒之也，子路欲殺衛君而事不成，身菹於衛東門之上，是子教之不至也。
passages.en: Why, you were twice driven out of Lu; you had to run away from Wei; you were reduced to extremity in Qi; you were held in a state of siege between Chen and Cai; there is no resting-place for your person in the kingdom; your instructions brought Zi-lu to pickle.

passages.zh: 子自謂才士聖人邪！
passages.en: Such have been the misfortunes (attending your course).

passages.zh: 則再逐於魯，削跡於衛，窮於齊，圍於陳、蔡，不容身於天下。
passages.en: You have done no good either for yourself or for others - how can your doctrines be worth being thought much of?

passages.zh: 子教子路菹此患，上無以為身，下無以為人，子之道豈足貴邪？
passages.en: 'There is no one whom the world exalts so much as it does Huang-Di, and still he was not able to perfect his virtue, but fought in the wilderness of Zhuo-lu, till the blood flowed over a hundred li.

passages.zh: 世之所高，莫若黃帝，黃帝尚不能全德，而戰涿鹿之野，流血百里。
passages.en: Yao was not kind to his son. Shun was not filial.

passages.zh: 堯不慈，舜不孝，禹偏枯，湯放其主，武王伐紂，文王拘羑里。
passages.en: Yu was paralysed on one side. Tang banished his sovereign. King Wu smote Zhou. King Wen was imprisoned in You-li.

passages.zh: 此六子者，世之所高也，孰論之，皆以利惑其真而強反其情性，其行乃甚可羞也！
passages.en: These are the six men of whom the world thinks the most highly, yet when we accurately consider their history, we see that for the sake of gain they all disallowed their true (nature), and did violence to its proper qualities and tendencies: their conduct cannot be thought of but with deep shame.

passages.zh: 世之所謂賢士，伯夷、叔齊，伯夷、叔齊辭孤竹之君，而餓死於首陽之山，骨肉不葬。
passages.en: 'Among those whom the world calls men of ability and virtue were (the brothers) Bo-yi and Shu-Qi. They declined the rule of Gu-zhu, and died of starvation on the hill of Shou-yang, leaving their bones and flesh unburied.

passages.zh: 鮑焦飾行非世，抱木而死。
passages.en: Bao Qiao vaunted his conduct, and condemned the world, but he died with his arms round a tree.

passages.zh: 申徒狄諫而不聽，負石自投於河，為魚鱉所食。
passages.en: When Shen-tu Di's remonstrances were not listened to, he fastened a stone on his back, and threw himself into the He, where he was eaten by the fishes and turtles.

passages.zh: 介子推至忠也，自割其股以食文公，文公後背之，子推怒而去，抱木而燔死。
passages.en: Jie Zi-tui was the most devoted (of followers), and cut a piece from his thigh as food for duke Wen. But when the duke afterwards overlooked him (in his distribution of favours), he was angry, and went away, and was burned to death with a tree in his arms.

passages.zh: 尾生與女子期於梁下，女子不來，水至不去，抱梁柱而死。
passages.en: Wei Sheng had made an appointment with a girl to meet him under a bridge; but when she did not come, and the water rose around him, he would not go away, and died with his arms round one of the pillars.

passages.zh: 此六子者，無異於磔犬、流豕、操瓢而乞者，皆離名輕死，不念本養壽命者也。
passages.en: (The deaths of) these four men were not different from those of the dog that is torn in pieces, the pig that is borne away by a current, or the beggar (drowned in a ditch) with his alms-gourd in his hand. They were all caught as in a net by their (desire for) fame, not caring to nourish their life to its end, as they were bound to do.

passages.zh: 世之所謂忠臣者，莫若王子比干、伍子胥，子胥沈江，比干剖心。
passages.en: 'Among those whom the world calls faithful ministers there have been none like the prince Bi-gan and Wu Zi-xu. But Zi-xu's (dead) body was cast into the Jiang, and the heart of Bi-gan was cut out.

passages.zh: 此二子者，世謂忠臣也，然卒為天下笑。
passages.en: These two were what the world calls loyal ministers, but the end has been that everybody laughs at them.

passages.zh: 自上觀之，至於子胥、比干，皆不足貴也。
passages.en: Looking at all the above cases, down to those of Zi-xu and Bi-gan, there is not one worthy to be honoured.

passages.zh: 丘之所以說我者，若告我以鬼事，則我不能知也；若告我以人事者，不過此矣，皆吾所聞知也。
passages.en: 'And as to the admonitions which you, Qiu, wish to impress on me, if you tell me about the state of the dead, I am unable to know anything about it; if you tell me about the things of men (alive), they are only such as I have stated, what I have heard and know all about.

passages.zh: 今吾告子以人之情：目欲視色，耳欲聽聲，口欲察味，志氣欲盈。
passages.en: I will now tell you, Sir, my views about the condition of man. The eyes wish to look on beauty; the ears to hear music; the mouth to enjoy flavours; the will to be gratified.

passages.zh: 人上壽百歲，中壽八十，下壽六十，除病瘦、死喪、憂患，其中開口而笑者，一月之中不過四五日而已矣。
passages.en: The greatest longevity man can reach is a hundred years; a medium longevity is eighty years; the lowest longevity is sixty. Take away sickness, pining, bereavement, mourning, anxieties, and calamities, the times when, in any of these, one can open his mouth and laugh, are only four or five days in a month.

passages.zh: 天與地無窮，人死者有時，操有時之具而託於無窮之間，忽然無異騏驥之馳過隙也。
passages.en: Heaven and earth have no limit of duration, but the death of man has its (appointed) time. Take the longest amount of a limited time, and compare it with what is unlimited, its brief existence is not different from the passing of a crevice by one of king Mu's horses.

passages.zh: 不能說其志意，養其壽命者，皆非通道者也。
passages.en: Those who cannot gratify their will and natural aims, and nourish their appointed longevity, are all unacquainted with the (right) Way (of life).

passages.zh: 丘之所言，皆吾之所棄也，亟去走歸，無復言之！
passages.en: I cast from me, Zhi, all that you say. Be quick and go. Hurry back and say not a word more.

passages.zh: 子之道，狂狂汲汲，詐巧虛偽事也，非可以全真也，奚足論哉！」
passages.en: Your Way is only a wild recklessness, deceitful, artful, vain, and hypocritical. It is not available to complete the true (nature of man); it is not worth talking about!'

passages.zh: 孔子再拜趨走，出門上車，執轡三失，目芒然無見，色若死灰，據軾低頭，不能出氣。
passages.en: Confucius bowed twice, and hurried away. He went out at the door, and mounted his carriage. Thrice he missed the reins as he tried to take hold of them. His eyes were dazed, and he could not see; and his colour was that of slaked lime. He laid hold of the cross-bar, holding his head down, and unable to draw his breath.

passages.zh: 歸到魯東門外，適遇柳下季。
passages.en: When he got back, outside the east gate of (the capital of) Lu, he encountered Liu-xia Ji, who said to him, 'Here you are, right in the gate.

passages.zh: 柳下季曰：「今者闕然數日不見，車馬有行色，得微往見跖邪？」
passages.en: For some days I have not seen you. Your carriage and horses are travel-stained - have you not been to see Dao Zhi?'

passages.zh: 孔子仰天而歎曰：「然。」
passages.en: Confucius looked up to heaven, sighed, and said, 'Yes.'

passages.zh: 柳下季曰：「跖得無逆汝意若前乎？」
passages.en: The other went on, 'And did he not set himself in opposition to all your views, as I said he would do?'

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「然。
passages.en: 'He did.

passages.zh: 丘所謂無病而自灸也，疾走料虎頭，編虎須，幾不免虎口哉！」
passages.en: My case has been that of the man who cauterised himself without being ill. I rushed away, stroked the tiger's head, played with his whiskers, and narrowly escaped his mouth.'

passages.zh: 子張問於滿苟得曰：「盍不為行？
passages.en: Zi-zhang asked Man Gou-de, saying, 'Why do you not pursue a (righteous) course?

passages.zh: 無行則不信，不信則不任，不任則不利。
passages.en: Without such a course you will not be believed in; unless you are believed in, you will not be employed in office; and if not employed in office, you will not acquire gain.

passages.zh: 故觀之名，計之利，而義真是也。
passages.en: Thus, if you look at the matter from the point of reputation, or estimate it from the point of gain, a righteous course is truly the right thing.

passages.zh: 若棄名利，反之於心，則夫士之為行，不可一日不為乎？」
passages.en: If you discard the thought of reputation and gain, yet when you think over the thing in your own mind, you will see that the scholar should not be a single day without pursuing a (righteous) course.'

passages.zh: 滿苟得曰：「無恥者富，多信者顯。
passages.en: Man Gou-de said, 'He who has no shame becomes rich, and he in whom many believe becomes illustrious.

passages.zh: 夫名利之大者，幾在無恥而信。
passages.en: Thus the greatest fame and gain would seem to spring from being without shame and being believed in.

passages.zh: 故觀之名，計之利，而信真是也。
passages.en: Therefore if you look at the matter from the point of reputation, or estimate it from the point of gain, to be believed in is the right thing.

passages.zh: 若棄名利，反之於心，則夫士之為行，抱其天乎！」
passages.en: If you discard the thought of fame and gain, and think over the thing in your own mind, you will see that the scholar in the course which he pursues is (simply) holding fast his Heavenly (nature, and gaining nothing).'

passages.zh: 子張曰：「昔者桀、紂貴為天子，富有天下，今謂臧聚曰『汝行如桀、紂』，則有怍色，有不服之心者，小人所賤也。
passages.en: Zi-zhang said, 'Formerly Jie and Zhou each enjoyed the honour of being the sovereign, and all the wealth of the kingdom was his; but if you now say to a (mere) money-grabber, "Your conduct is like that of Jie or Zhou," he will look ashamed, and resent the imputation: (these two sovereigns) are despised by the smallest men.

passages.zh: 仲尼、墨翟，窮為匹夫，今謂宰相曰『子行如仲尼、墨翟』，則變容易色稱不足者，士誠貴也。
passages.en: Zhongni and Mo Di (on the other hand) were poor, and common men; but if you say to a Prime Minister that his conduct is like that of Zhongni or Mo Di, then he will be put out and change countenance, and protest that he is not worthy (to be so spoken of): (these two philosophers) are held to be truly noble by (all) scholars.

passages.zh: 故勢為天子，未必貴也；窮為匹夫，未必賤也。
passages.en: Thus it is that the position of sovereign does not necessarily connect with being thought noble, nor the condition of being poor and of common rank with being thought mean.

passages.zh: 貴賤之分，在行之美惡。」
passages.en: The difference of being thought noble or mean arises from the conduct being good or bad.'

passages.zh: 滿苟得曰：「小盜者拘，大盜者為諸侯，諸侯之門，義士存焉。
passages.en: Man Gou-de replied, 'Small robbers are put in prison; a great robber becomes a feudal lord; and in the gate of the feudal lord your righteous scholars will be found.

passages.zh: 昔者桓公小白殺兄入嫂而管仲為臣，田成子常殺君竊國而孔子受幣。
passages.en: For instance, Xi-bo, the duke Huan, killed his elder brother, and took his sister-in-law to himself, and yet Guan Zhong became his minister; and Tian Cheng, styled Cheng-zi, killed his ruler, and usurped the state, and yet Confucius received a present of silks from him.

passages.zh: 論則賤之，行則下之，則是言行之情悖戰於胸中也，不亦拂乎！
passages.en: In their discussions they would condemn the men, but in their conduct they abased themselves before them. In this way their words and actions must have been at war together in their breasts - was it not a contradiction and perversity?

passages.zh: 故《書》曰：『孰惡孰美？
passages.en: As it is said in a book, "Who is bad?

passages.zh: 成者為首，不成者為尾。』」
passages.en: and who is good? The successful is regarded as the Head, and the unsuccessful as the Tail."'

passages.zh: 子張曰：「子不為行，即將疏戚無倫，貴賤無義，長幼無序，五紀六位將何以為別乎？」
passages.en: Zi-zhang said, 'If you do not follow the usual course of what is held to be right, but observe no distinction between the near and remote degrees of kin, no difference between the noble and the mean, no order between the old and the young, then how shall a separation be made of the fivefold arrangement (of the virtues), and the six parties (in the social organisation)?'

passages.zh: 滿苟得曰：「堯殺長子，舜流母弟，疏戚有倫乎？
passages.en: Man Gou-de replied, 'Yao killed his eldest son, and Shun banished his half-brother': did they observe the rules about the different degrees of kin?

passages.zh: 湯放桀，武王伐紂，貴賤有義乎？
passages.en: Tang deposed Jie; king Wu overthrew Zhou: did they observe the righteousness that should obtain between the noble and the mean?

passages.zh: 王季為適，周公殺兄，長幼有序乎？
passages.en: King Ji took the place of his elder brother, and the duke of Zhou killed his: did they observe the order that should obtain between the elder and the younger?

passages.zh: 儒者偽辭，墨者兼愛，五紀六位將有別乎？
passages.en: The Literati make hypocritical speeches; the followers of Mo hold that all should be loved equally: do we find in them the separation of the fivefold arrangement (of the virtues), and the six parties (in the social organisation)?

passages.zh: 且子正為名，我正為利。
passages.en: And further, you, Sir, are all for reputation, and I am all for gain; but where the actual search for reputation and gain may not be in accordance with principle and will not bear to be examined in the light of the right way, let me and you refer the matter to-morrow to the decision of Wu-yue.'

passages.zh: 名利之實，不順於理，不監於道。
passages.en: (This Wu-yue) said, 'The small man pursues after wealth; the superior man pursues after reputation.

passages.zh: 吾日與子訟於無約，曰：『小人殉財，君子殉名。
passages.en: The way in which they change their feelings and alter their nature is different; but if they were to cast away what they do, and replace it with doing nothing, they would be the same.

passages.zh: 其所以變其情，易其性，則異矣；乃至於棄其所為而殉其所不為，則一也。』
passages.en: Hence it is said, "Do not be a small man - return and pursue after the Heavenly in you.

passages.zh: 故曰：無為小人，反殉而天；無為君子，從天之理。
passages.en: Do not be a superior man - follow the rule of the Heavenly in you.

passages.zh: 若枉若直，相而天極，面觀四方，與時消息。
passages.en: Be it crooked, be it straight, view the thing in the light of Heaven as revealed in you. Look all round on every side of it, and as the time indicates, cease your endeavours.

passages.zh: 若是若非，執而圓機，獨成而意，與道徘徊。
passages.en: Be it right, be it wrong, hold fast the ring in yourself in which all conditions converge. Alone by yourself, carry out your idea; ponder over the right way.

passages.zh: 無轉而行，無成而義，將失而所為。
passages.en: Do not turn your course; do not try to complete your righteousness. You will fail in what you do.

passages.zh: 無赴而富，無殉而成，將棄而天。
passages.en: Do not haste to be rich; do not follow after your perfection. If you do, you will lose the heavenly in you."

passages.zh: 比干剖心，子胥抉眼，忠之禍也；直躬證父，尾生溺死，信之患也；鮑子立乾，申子不自理，廉之害也；孔子不見母，匡子不見父，義之失也。
passages.en: Bi-gan had his heart cut out; Zi-xu had his eyes gouged out: such were the evil consequences of their loyalty. The upright person bore witness against his father; Wei Sheng was drowned: such were the misfortunes of good faith. Bao-zi stood till he was dried up; Shan-zi would not defend himself: such were the injuries brought on by disinterestedness. Confucius did not see his mother; Kuang-zi did not see his father: such were the failures of the righteous.

passages.zh: 此上世之所傳，下世之所語，以為士者正其言，必其行，故服其殃，離其患也。」
passages.en: These are instances handed down from former ages, and talked about in these later times. They show us how superior men, in their determination to be correct in their words and resolute in their conduct, paid the penalty of these misfortunes, and were involved in these distresses.'

passages.zh: 無足問於知和曰：「人卒未有不興名就利者。
passages.en: Mr. Dissatisfied asked Mr. Know-the-Mean, saying, 'There is no man after all who does not strive for reputation and pursue after gain.

passages.zh: 彼富則人歸之，歸則下之，下則貴之。
passages.en: When men are rich, then others go to them. Going to them, they put themselves beneath them. In that position they do honour to them as nobler than themselves.

passages.zh: 夫見下貴者，所以長生、安體、樂意之道也。
passages.en: But to see others taking that position and doing honour to us is the way to prolong life, and to secure the rest of the body and the satisfaction of the mind.

passages.zh: 今子獨無意焉，知不足邪？
passages.en: You alone, Sir, however, have no idea of this. Is it that your knowledge is deficient?

passages.zh: 意知而力不能行邪？
passages.en: Is it that you have the knowledge, but want the strength to carry it into practice?

passages.zh: 故推正不忘邪？」
passages.en: Or is it that your mind is made up to do what you consider right, and never allow yourself to forget it?'

passages.zh: 知和曰：「今夫此人以為與己同時而生、同鄉而處者，以為夫絕俗過世之士焉，是專無主正，所以覽古今之時，是非之分也，與俗化世。
passages.en: Know-the-Mean replied, 'Here now is this man judging of us, his contemporaries, and living in the same neighbourhood as himself, that we consider ourselves scholars who have abjured all vulgar ways and risen above the world. He is entirely without the thought of submitting to the rule of what is right. He therefore studies ancient times and the present, and the differing questions about the right and wrong, and agrees with the vulgar ideas and influences of the age, abandoning what is most important and discarding what is most honourable, in order to be free to act as he does.

passages.zh: 去至重，棄至尊，以為其所為也，此其所以論長生、安體、樂意之道，不亦遠乎！
passages.en: But is he not wide of the mark when he thinks that this is the way to promote long life, and to secure the rest of the body and the satisfaction of the mind?

passages.zh: 慘怛之疾，恬愉之安，不監於體；怵惕之恐，欣懽之喜，不監於心。
passages.en: He has his painful afflictions and his quiet repose, but he does not inquire how his body is so variously affected; he has his apprehensive terrors, and his happy joys, but he does not inquire how his mind has such different experiences.

passages.zh: 知為為而不知所以為，是以貴為天子，富有天下，而不免於患也。」
passages.en: He knows how to pursue his course, but he does not know why he does so. Even if he had the dignity of the Son of Heaven, and all the wealth of the kingdom were his, he would not be beyond the reach of misfortunes and evils.'

passages.zh: 無足曰：「夫富之於人，無所不利，窮美究埶，至人之所不得逮，賢人之所不能及，俠人之勇力而不為威強，秉人之知謀以為明察，因人之德以為賢良，非享國而嚴若君父。
passages.en: Dissatisfied rejoined, 'But riches are in every way advantageous to man. With them his attainment of the beautiful and mastery of every art become what the perfect man cannot obtain nor the sagely man reach to; his appropriation of the bravery and strength of others enables him to exercise a powerful sway; his availing himself of the wisdom and plans of others makes him be accounted intelligent and discriminating; his taking advantage of the virtues of others makes him be esteemed able and good. Though he may not be the holder of a state, he is looked to with awe as a ruler and father.

passages.zh: 且夫聲色、滋味、權勢之於人，心不待學而樂之，體不待象而安之。
passages.en: Moreover, music, beauty, with the pleasures of the taste and of power, are appreciated by men's minds and rejoiced in without any previous learning of them; the body reposes in them without waiting for the example of others.

passages.zh: 夫欲惡避就，固不待師，此人之性也。
passages.en: Desire and dislike, avoidance and pursuit, do not require any master - this is the nature of man.

passages.zh: 天下雖非我，孰能辭之！」
passages.en: Though the world may condemn one's indulgence of them, who can refrain from it?'

passages.zh: 知和曰：「知者之為，故動以百姓，不違其度，是以足而不爭，無以為故不求。
passages.en: Know-the-Mean replied, 'The action of the wise is directed for the good of the people, but they do not go against the (proper) rule and degree. Therefore when they have enough, they do not strive (for more); they have no further object, and so they do not seek for one.

passages.zh: 不足故求之，爭四處而不自以為貪；有餘故辭之，棄天下而不自以為廉。
passages.en: When they have not enough, they will seek for it; they will strive for it in every quarter, and yet not think of themselves as greedy. If they have (already) a superfluity, they will decline (any more); they will decline the throne, and yet not think of themselves as disinterested: the conditions of disinterestedness and greediness are (with them) not from the constraint of anything external.

passages.zh: 廉貪之實，非以迫外也，反監之度。
passages.en: Through their exercise of introspection, their power may be that of the sovereign, but they will not in their nobility be arrogant to others; their wealth may be that of the whole kingdom, but they will not in their possession of it make a mock of others.

passages.zh: 勢為天子而不以貴驕人，富有天下而不以財戲人。
passages.en: They estimate the evils to which they are exposed, and are anxious about the reverses which they may experience.

passages.zh: 計其患，慮其反，以為害於性，故辭而不受也，非以要名譽也。
passages.en: They think how their possessions may be injurious to their nature, and therefore they will decline and not accept them - but not because they seek for reputation and praise.

passages.zh: 堯、舜為帝而雍，非仁天下也，不以美害生也；善卷、許由得帝而不受，非虛辭讓也，不以事害己。
passages.en: Yao and Shun were the sovereigns, and harmony prevailed. It did so, not because of their benevolence towards the people - they would not, for what was (deemed) admirable, injure their lives. Shan Juan and Xu You might have been the sovereigns, but they would not receive the throne - not that they declined it without purpose, but they would not by its occupancy injure themselves.

passages.zh: 此皆就其利，辭其害，而天下稱賢焉，則可以有之，彼非以興名譽也。」
passages.en: These all followed after what was advantageous to them, and declined what was injurious, and all the world celebrates their superiority. Thus, though they enjoy the distinction, they did what they did, not for the sake of the reputation and praise.'

passages.zh: 無足曰：「必持其名，苦體絕甘，約養以持生，則亦久病長阨而不死者也。」
passages.en: Dissatisfied (continued his argument), saying, 'In thus thinking it necessary for their reputation, they bitterly distressed their bodies, denied themselves what was pleasant, and restricted themselves to a bare sustenance in order to sustain their life; but so they had life-long distress, and long-continued pressure till their death arrived.'

passages.zh: 知和曰：「平為福，有餘為害者，物莫不然，而財其甚者也。
passages.en: Know-the-Mean replied, 'Tranquil ease is happiness; a superfluity is injurious: so it is with all things, and especially it is so, where the superfluity is of wealth.

passages.zh: 今富人耳營鐘鼓筦籥之聲，口嗛於芻豢醪醴之味，以感其意，遺忘其業，可謂亂矣；侅溺於馮氣，若負重行而上也，可謂苦矣；貪財而取慰，貪權而取竭，靜居則溺，體澤則馮，可謂疾矣；為欲富就利，故滿若堵耳而不知避，且馮而不舍，可謂辱矣；財積而無用，服膺而不舍，滿心戚醮，求益而不止，可謂憂矣；內則疑劫請之賊，外則畏寇盜之害，內周樓疏，外不敢獨行，可謂畏矣。
passages.en: The ears of the rich are provided with the music of bells, drums, flageolets and flutes; and their mouths are stuffed with the flesh of fed beasts and with wine of the richest flavour; so are their desires satisfied, till they forget their proper business: theirs may be pronounced a condition of disorder. Sunk deeply in their self-sufficiency, they resemble individuals ascending a height with a heavy burden on their backs: their condition may be pronounced one of bitter suffering. They covet riches, thinking to derive comfort from them; they covet power, and would fain monopolise it; when quiet and retired, they are drowned in luxurious indulgence; their persons seem to shine, and they are full of boasting: they may be said to be in a state of disease. In their desire to be rich and striving for gain, they fill their stores, and, deaf to all admonition, refuse to desist from their course. They are even more elated, and hold on their way: their conduct may be pronounced disgraceful. When their wealth is amassed till they cannot use it, they clasp it to their breasts and will not part with it; when their hearts are distressed with their very fulness, they still seek for more and will not desist: their condition may be said to be sad. In-doors they are apprehensive of pilfering and begging thieves, and out-of-doors they are afraid of being injured by plundering robbers; in-doors they have many chambers and partitions, and out-of-doors they do not dare to go alone: they may be said to be in a state of (constant) alarm.

passages.zh: 此六者，天下之至害也，皆遺忘而不知察，及其患至，求盡性竭財，單以反一日之無故而不可得也。
passages.en: These six conditions are the most deplorable in the world, but they forget them all, and have lost their faculty of judgment. When the evil comes, though they begged it with all the powers of their nature, and by the sacrifice of all their wealth, they could not bring back one day of untroubled peace.

passages.zh: 故觀之名則不見，求之利則不得，繚意體而爭此，不亦惑乎！」
passages.en: When they look for their reputation, it is not to be seen; when they seek for their wealth, it is not to be got. To task their thoughts, and destroy their bodies, striving for (such an end as) this - is it not a case of great delusion?'

passages.zh: 昔趙文王喜劍，劍士夾門而客三千餘人，日夜相擊於前，死傷者歲百餘人，好之不厭。
passages.en: Formerly, King Wen of Zhao delighted in the sword-fight. More than three thousand men, masters of the weapon, appeared as his guests, lining the way on either side of his gate, and fighting together before him day and night. Over a hundred of them would die or be (severely) wounded in the course of a year, but he was never weary of looking on (at their engagements), so fond was he of them.

passages.zh: 如是三年，國衰，諸侯謀之。
passages.en: The thing continued for three years, when the kingdom began to decay, and other states to plan measures against it.

passages.zh: 太子悝患之，募左右曰：「孰能說王之意止劍士者，賜之千金。」
passages.en: The crown-prince Kui was distressed, and laid the case before his attendants, saying, 'If any one can persuade the king, and put an end to these swordsmen, I will give him a thousand ounces of silver.'

passages.zh: 左右曰：「莊子當能。」
passages.en: His attendants said, '(Only) Zhuangzi is able to do this.'

passages.zh: 太子乃使人以千金奉莊子。
passages.en: Thereupon the prince sent men with a thousand ounces of silver to offer to Zhuangzi, who, however, would not accept them, but went with the messengers.

passages.zh: 莊子弗受，與使者俱往見太子曰：「太子何以教周，賜周千金？」
passages.en: When he saw the prince, he said, '0 prince, what have you to say to Zhou, and why would you give me the silver?'

passages.zh: 太子曰：「聞夫子明聖，謹奉千金以幣從者。
passages.en: The prince replied, 'I have heard that you, master, are sagacious and sage. I sent you respectfully the thousand ounces of silver, as a prelude to the silks and other gifts.

passages.zh: 夫子弗受，悝尚何敢言！」
passages.en: But as you decline to receive them, how dare I now tell you (what I wished from you)?'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「聞太子所欲用周者，欲絕王之喜好也。
passages.en: Zhuangzi rejoined, 'I have heard, 0 prince, that what you wanted me for was to wean the king from what is his delight.

passages.zh: 使臣上說大王而逆王意，下不當太子，則身刑而死，周尚安所事金乎！
passages.en: Suppose that in trying to persuade his Majesty I should offend him, and not fulfil your expectation, I shall be punished with death; and could I then enjoy this silver?

passages.zh: 使臣上說大王，下當太子，趙國何求而不得也？」
passages.en: Or suppose that I shall succeed in persuading his Majesty, and accomplish what you desire, what is there in the kingdom of Zhao that I might ask for which I would not get?'

passages.zh: 太子曰：「然。
passages.en: The crown-prince said, 'Yes; but my (father), the king, will see none but swordsmen.'

passages.zh: 吾王所見，唯劍士也。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'I know; but I am expert in the use of the sword.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「諾。
passages.en: 'That is well,' observed the prince; 'but the swordsmen whom his Majesty sees all have their hair in a tangle, with whiskers projecting out.

passages.zh: 周善為劍。」
passages.en: They wear slouching caps with coarse and unornamented tassels, and their coats are cut short behind.

passages.zh: 太子曰：「然吾王所見劍士，皆蓬頭、突鬢、垂冠，曼胡之纓，短後之衣，嗔目而語難，王乃說之。
passages.en: They have staring eyes, and talk about the hazards of their game. The king is delighted with all this; but now you are sure to present yourself to him in your scholar's dress, and this will stand greatly in the way of your success.'

passages.zh: 今夫子必儒服而見王，事必大逆。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi said, 'I will then, with your leave, get me a swordsman's dress.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「請治劍服。」
passages.en: This was ready in three days, and when he appeared in it before the prince, the latter went with him to introduce him to the king, who then drew his sword from its scabbard and waited for him.

passages.zh: 治劍服三日，乃見太子。
passages.en: When Zhuangzi entered the door of the hall, he did not hurry forward, nor, when he saw the king, did he bow.

passages.zh: 太子乃與見王，王脫白刃待之。
passages.en: The king asked him, 'What do you want to teach me, Sir, that you have got the prince to mention you beforehand?'

passages.zh: 莊子入殿門不趨，見王不拜。
passages.en: The reply was, 'I have heard that your Majesty is fond of the sword-fight, and therefore I have sought an interview with you on the ground of (my skill in the use of) the sword.'

passages.zh: 王曰：「子欲何以教寡人，使太子先？」
passages.en: 'What can you do with your sword against an opponent?'

passages.zh: 曰：「臣聞大王喜劍，故以劍見王。」
passages.en: 'Let me meet with an opponent every ten paces, my sword would deal with him, so that I should not be stopped in a march of a thousand li.'

passages.zh: 王曰：「子之劍何能禁制？」
passages.en: The king was delighted with him, and said, 'You have not your match in the kingdom.'

passages.zh: 曰：「臣之劍，十步一人，千里不留行。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'A good swordsman first makes a feint (against his opponent), then seems to give him an advantage, and finally gives his thrust, reaching him before he can return the blow.

passages.zh: 王大悅之，曰：「天下無敵矣。」
passages.en: I should like to have an opportunity to show you my skill.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「夫為劍者，示之以虛，開之以利，後之以發，先之以至。
passages.en: The king said, 'Stop (for a little), Master. Go to your lodging, and wait for my orders.

passages.zh: 願得試之。」
passages.en: I will make arrangements for the play, and then call you.'

passages.zh: 王曰：「夫子休就舍，待命令設戲請夫子。」
passages.en: The king accordingly made trial of his swordsmen for seven days, till more than sixty of them were killed, or (severely) wounded.

passages.zh: 王乃校劍士七日，死傷者六十餘人，得五六人，使奉劍於殿下，乃召莊子。
passages.en: He then selected five or six men, and made them bring their swords and take their places beneath the hall, after which he called Zhuangzi, and said to him, 'To-day I am going to make (you and) these men show what you can do with your swords.'

passages.zh: 王曰：「今日試使士敦劍。」
passages.en: 'I have long been looking for the opportunity,' replied Zhuangzi.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「望之久矣。」
passages.en: The king then asked him what would be the length of the sword which he would use; and he said, 'Any length will suit me, but I have three swords, any one of which I will use, as may please your Majesty.

passages.zh: 王曰：「夫子所御杖，長短何如？」
passages.en: Let me first tell you of them, and then go to the arena.'

passages.zh: 曰：「臣之所奉皆可。
passages.en: 'I should like to hear about the three swords,' said the king; and Zhuangzi went on, 'There is the sword of the Son of Heaven; the sword of a feudal prince; and the sword of a common man.'

passages.zh: 然臣有三劍，唯王所用，請先言而後試。」
passages.en: 'What about the sword of the Son of Heaven?'

passages.zh: 王曰：「願聞三劍。」
passages.en: 'This sword has Yan-qi and Shi-cheng for its point; Qi and (Mount) Dai for its edge; Jin and Wei for its back; Zhou and Song for its hilt; Han and Wei for its sheath.

passages.zh: 曰：「有天子劍，有諸侯劍，有庶人劍。」
passages.en: It is embraced by the wild tribes all around; it is wrapped up in the four seasons; it is bound round by the Sea of Bo; and its girdle is the enduring hills.

passages.zh: 王曰：「天子之劍何如？」
passages.en: It is regulated by the five elements; its wielding is by means of Punish ments and Kindness; its unsheathing is like that of the Yin and Yang; it is held fast in the spring and summer; it is put in action in the autumn and winter.

passages.zh: 曰：「天子之劍，以燕谿、石城為鋒，齊、岱為鍔，晉、魏為脊，周、宋為鐔，韓、魏為夾，包以四夷，裹以四時，繞以渤海，帶以常山，制以五行，論以刑德，開以陰陽，持以春夏，行以秋冬。
passages.en: When it is thrust forward, there is nothing in front of it; when lifted up, there is nothing above it; when laid down, there is nothing below it; when wheeled round, there is nothing left on any side of it; above, it cleaves the floating clouds; and below, it penetrates to every division of the earth.

passages.zh: 此劍直之無前，舉之無上，案之無下，運之無旁，上決浮雲，下絕地紀。
passages.en: Let this sword be once used, and the princes are all reformed, and the whole kingdom submits.

passages.zh: 此劍一用，匡諸侯，天下服矣。
passages.en: This is the sword of the Son of Heaven.'

passages.zh: 此天子之劍也。」
passages.en: King Wen looked lost in amazement, and said again, 'And what about the sword of a feudal lord?'

passages.zh: 文王芒然自失，曰：「諸侯之劍何如？」
passages.en: (Zhuangzi) replied, 'This sword has wise and brave officers for its point; pure and disinterested officers for its edge; able and honourable officers for its back; loyal and sage officers for its hilt; valiant and eminent officers for its sheath.

passages.zh: 曰：「諸侯之劍，以知勇士為鋒，以清廉士為鍔，以賢良士為脊，以忠聖士為鐔，以豪桀士為夾。
passages.en: When this sword is thrust directly forward, as in the former case, there is nothing in front of it; when directed upwards, there is nothing above it; when laid down, there is nothing below it; when wheeled round, there is nothing on any side of it.

passages.zh: 此劍值之亦無前，舉之亦無上，案之亦無下，運之亦無旁，上法圓天以順三光，下法方地以順四時，中和民意以安四鄉。
passages.en: Above, its law is taken from the round heaven, and is in accordance with the three luminaries; below, its law is taken from the square earth, and is in accordance with the four seasons; between, it is in harmony with the minds of the people, and in all the parts of the state there is peace.

passages.zh: 此劍一用，如雷霆之震也，四封之內，無不賓服而聽從君命者矣。
passages.en: Let this sword be once used, and you seem to hear the crash of the thunder-peal. Within the four borders there are none who do not respectfully submit, and obey the orders of the ruler.

passages.zh: 此諸侯之劍也。」
passages.en: This is the sword of the feudal lord.'

passages.zh: 王曰：「庶人之劍何如？」
passages.en: 'And what about the sword of the common man?' asked the king (once more).

passages.zh: 曰：「庶人之劍，蓬頭、突鬢、垂冠，曼胡之纓，短後之衣，瞋目而語難，相擊於前，上斬頸領，下決肝肺。
passages.en: (Zhuangzi) replied, 'The sword of the common man (is wielded by) those who have their hair in a tangle, with whiskers projecting out; who wear slouching caps with coarse and unornamented tassels, and have their coats cut short behind; who have staring eyes, and talk (only) about the hazards (of their game). They hit at one another before you. Above, the sword slashes through the neck; and below, it scoops out the liver and lungs.

passages.zh: 此庶人之劍，無異於鬥雞，一旦命已絕矣，無所用於國事。
passages.en: This is the sword of the common man. (The users of it) are not different from fighting cocks; any morning their lives are brought to an end; they are of no use in the affairs of the state.

passages.zh: 今大王有天子之位，而好庶人之劍，臣竊為大王薄之。」
passages.en: Your Majesty occupies the seat of the Son of Heaven, and that you should be so fond of the swordsmanship of such common men, is unworthy, as I venture to think, of your Majesty.'

passages.zh: 王乃牽而上殿，宰人上食，王三環之。
passages.en: On this the king drew Zhuangzi with him, and went up to the top of the hall, where the cook set forth a meal, which the king walked round three times (unable to sit down to it).

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「大王安坐定氣，劍事已畢奏矣。」
passages.en: Zhuangzi said to him, 'Sit down quietly, Great King, and calm yourself. I have said all I wished to say about swords.'

passages.zh: 於是文王不出宮三月，劍士皆服斃其處也。
passages.en: King Wen, thereafter, did not quit the palace for three months, and the swordsmen all killed themselves in their own rooms.

passages.zh: 孔子遊乎緇帷之林，休坐乎杏壇之上。
passages.en: Confucius, rambling in the forest of Zi-wei, stopped and sat down by the Apricot altar.

passages.zh: 弟子讀書，孔子絃歌鼓琴，奏曲未半。
passages.en: The disciples began to read their books, while he proceeded to play on his lute, singing as he did so. He had not half finished his ditty when an old fisherman stepped down from his boat, and came towards them.

passages.zh: 有漁父者下船而來，須眉交白，被髮揄袂，行原以上，距陸而止，左手據膝，右手持頤以聽。
passages.en: His beard and eyebrows were turning white; his hair was all uncombed; and his sleeves hunc, idly down. He walked thus up from the bank, till he got to the dry ground, when he stopped, and, with his left hand holding one of his knees, and the right hand at his chin, listened.

passages.zh: 曲終而招子貢、子路，二人俱對。
passages.en: When the ditty was finished, he beckoned to Zi-gong and Zi-lu, who both responded and went to him.

passages.zh: 客指孔子曰：「彼何為者也？」
passages.en: Pointing to Confucius, he said, 'Who is he?'

passages.zh: 子路對曰：「魯之君子也。」
passages.en: Zi-lu replied, 'He is the Superior Man of Lu.'

passages.zh: 客問其族。
passages.en: 'And of what family is he?'

passages.zh: 子路對曰：「族孔氏。」
passages.en: 'He is of the Kong family.'

passages.zh: 客曰：「孔氏者何治也？」
passages.en: 'And what is the occupation of this Mr. Kong?'

passages.zh: 子路未應，子貢對曰：「孔氏者，性服忠信，身行仁義，飾禮樂，選人倫，上以忠於世主，下以化於齊民，將以利天下。
passages.en: To this question Zi-lu gave no reply, but Zi-gong replied, 'This scion of the Kong family devotes himself in his own nature to leal-heartedness and sincerity; in his conduct he manifests benevolence and righteousness; he cultivates the ornaments of ceremonies and music; he pays special attention to the relationships of society; above, he would promote loyalty to the hereditary lords; below, he seeks the transformation of all classes of the people; his object being to benefit the kingdom: this is what Mr. Kong devotes himself to.'

passages.zh: 此孔氏之所治也。」
passages.en: The stranger further asked, 'Is he a ruler possessed of territory?'

passages.zh: 又問曰：「有土之君與？」
passages.en: 'No,' was Zi-gong's reply.

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「非也。」
passages.en: 'Is he the assistant of any prince or king?'

passages.zh: 「侯王之佐與？」
passages.en: 'No;' and on this the other began to laugh and to retrace his steps, saying as he went, 'Yes, benevolence is benevolence!

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「非也。」
passages.en: But I am afraid he will not escape (the evils incident to humanity).

passages.zh: 客乃笑而還行，言曰：「仁則仁矣，恐不免其身，苦心勞形以危其真。
passages.en: By embittering his mind and toiling his body, he is imperilling his true (nature)!

passages.zh: 嗚乎，遠哉其分於道也。」
passages.en: Alas! how far removed is he from the proper way (of life)!'

passages.zh: 子貢還，報孔子。
passages.en: Zi-gong returned, and reported (what the man had said) to Confucius, who pushed his lute aside, and arose, saying, 'Is he not a sage?'

passages.zh: 孔子推琴而起曰：「其聖人與！」
passages.en: and down the slope he went in search of him.

passages.zh: 乃下求之，至於澤畔，方將杖拏而引其船，顧見孔子，還鄉而立。
passages.en: When he reached the edge of the lake, there was the fisherman with his pole, dragging the boat towards him. Turning round and seeing Confucius, he came back towards him and stood up.

passages.zh: 孔子反走，再拜而進。
passages.en: Confucius then drew back, bowed to him twice, and went forward.

passages.zh: 客曰：「子將何求？」
passages.en: 'What do you want with me, Sir?' asked the stranger.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「曩者先生有緒言而去，丘不肖，未知所謂，竊待於下風，幸聞咳唾之音，以卒相丘也！」
passages.en: The reply was, 'A little while ago, my Master, you broke off the thread of your remarks and went away. Inferior to you, I do not know what you wished to say, and have ventured here to wait for your instructions, fortunate if I may but hear the sound of your words to complete the assistance that you can give me!'

passages.zh: 客曰：「嘻！
passages.en: 'Ah!' responded the stranger, 'how great is your love of learning!'

passages.zh: 甚矣子之好學也！」
passages.en: Confucius bowed twice, and then rose up, and said, 'Since I was young, I have cultivated learning till I am now sixty-nine years old; but I have not had an opportunity of hearing the perfect teaching; dare I but listen to you with a humble and unprejudiced mind?'

passages.zh: 孔子再拜而起曰：「丘少而修學，以至於今，六十九歲矣，無所得聞至教，敢不虛心！」
passages.en: The stranger replied, 'Like seeks to like, and (birds) of the same note respond to one another - this is a rule of Heaven.

passages.zh: 客曰：「同類相從，同聲相應，固天之理也。
passages.en: Allow me to explain what I am in possession of, and to pass over (from its standpoint) to the things which occupy you.

passages.zh: 吾請釋吾之所有而經子之所以。
passages.en: What you occupy yourself with are the affairs of men.

passages.zh: 子之所以者，人事也。
passages.en: When the sovereign, the feudal lords, the great officers, and the common people, these four classes, do what is correct (in their several positions), we have the beauty of good order; and when they leave their proper duties, there ensues the greatest disorder.

passages.zh: 天子、諸侯、大夫、庶人，此四者自正，治之美也，四者離位而亂莫大焉。
passages.en: When the officials attend to their duties, and the common people are anxiously concerned about their business, there is no encroachment on one another's rights.

passages.zh: 官治其職，人憂其事，乃無所陵。
passages.en: Fields running to waste; leaking rooms; insufficiency of food and clothing; taxes unprovided for; want of harmony among wives and concubines; and want of order between old and young - these are the troubles of the common people.

passages.zh: 故田荒室露，衣食不足，徵賦不屬，妻妾不和，長少無序，庶人之憂也；能不勝任，官事不治，行不清白，群下荒怠，功美不有，爵祿不持，大夫之憂也；廷無忠臣，國家昏亂，工技不巧，貢職不美，春秋後倫，不順天子，諸侯之憂也；陰陽不和，寒暑不時，以傷庶物，諸侯暴亂，擅相攘伐，以殘民人，禮樂不節，財用窮匱，人倫不飭，百姓淫亂，天子有司之憂也。
passages.en: Incompetency for their charges; inattention to their official business; want of probity in conduct; carelessness and idleness in subordinates; failure of merit and excellence; and uncertainty of rank and emolument: these are the troubles of great officers. No loyal ministers at their courts; the clans in their states rebellious; want of skill in their mechanics; articles of tribute of bad quality; late appearances at court in spring and autumn; and the dissatisfaction of the sovereign: these are the troubles of the feudal lords. Want of harmony between the Yin and Yang; unseasonableness of cold and heat, affecting all things injuriously; oppression and disorder among the feudal princes, their presuming to plunder and attack one another, to the injury of the people; ceremonies and music ill-regulated; the resources for expenditure exhausted or deficient; the social relationships uncared for; and the people abandoned to licentious disorder: these are the troubles of the Son of Heaven and his ministers.

passages.zh: 今子既上無君侯有司之勢，而下無大臣職事之官，而擅飭禮樂，選人倫，以化齊民，不泰多事乎？
passages.en: Now, Sir, you have not the high rank of a ruler, a feudal lord, or a minister of the royal court, nor are you in the inferior position of a great minister, with his departments of business, and yet you take it on you to regulate ceremonies and music, and to give special attention to the relationships of society, with a view to transform the various classes of the people: is it not an excessive multiplication of your business?

passages.zh: 且人有八疵，事有四患，不可不察也。
passages.en: And moreover men are liable to eight defects, and (the conduct of) affairs to four evils; of which we must by all means take account.

passages.zh: 非其事而事之，謂之摠；莫之顧而進之，謂之佞；希意道言，謂之諂；不擇是非而言，謂之諛；好言人之惡，謂之讒；析交離親，謂之賊；稱譽詐偽以敗惡人，謂之慝；不擇善否，兩容頰適，偷拔其所欲，謂之險。
passages.en: To take the management of affairs which do not concern him is called monopolising. To bring forward a subject which no one regards is called loquacity. To lead men on by speeches made to please them is called sycophancy. To praise men without regard to right or wrong is called flattery. To be fond of speaking of men's wickedness is called calumny. To part friends and separate relatives is called mischievousness. To praise a man deceitfully, or in the same way fix on him the character of being bad, is called depravity. Without reference to their being good or bad, to agree with men with double face, in order to steal a knowledge of what they wish, is called being dangerous.

passages.zh: 此八疵者，外以亂人，內以傷身，君子不友，明君不臣。
passages.en: Those eight defects produce disorder among other men and injury to one's self. A superior man will not make a friend of one who has them, nor will an intelligent ruler make him his minister.

passages.zh: 所謂四患者，好經大事，變更易常，以挂功名，謂之叨；專知擅事，侵人自用，謂之貪；見過不更，聞諫愈甚，謂之很；人同於己則可，不同於己，雖善不善，謂之矜。
passages.en: To speak of what I called the four evils: To be fond of conducting great affairs, changing and altering what is of long-standing, to obtain for one's self the reputation of meritorious service, is called ambition; to claim all wisdom and intrude into affairs, encroaching on the work of others, and representing it as one's own, is called greediness; to see his errors without changing them, and to go on more resolutely in his own way when remonstrated with, is called obstinacy; when another agrees with himself, to approve of him, and, however good he may be, when he disagrees, to disapprove of him, is called boastful conceit.

passages.zh: 此四患也。
passages.en: These are the four evils.

passages.zh: 能去八疵，無行四患，而始可教已。」
passages.en: When one can put away the eight defects, and allow no course to the four evils, he begins to be capable of being taught.'

passages.zh: 孔子愀然而歎，再拜而起曰：「丘再逐於魯，削跡於衛，伐樹於宋，圍於陳、蔡。
passages.en: Confucius looked sorrowful and sighed. (Again) he bowed twice, and then rose up and said, 'I was twice driven from Lu. I had to flee from Wei; the tree under which I rested was cut down in Song; I was kept in a state of siege between Chen and Cai.

passages.zh: 丘不知所失，而離此四謗者何也？」
passages.en: I do not know what errors I had committed that I came to be misrepresented on these four occasions (and suffered as I did).'

passages.zh: 客悽然變容曰：「甚矣子之難悟也！
passages.en: The stranger looked grieved (at these words), changed countenance, and said, 'Very difficult it is, Sir, to make you understand.

passages.zh: 人有畏影惡跡而去之走者，舉足愈數而跡愈多，走愈疾而影不離身，自以為尚遲，疾走不休，絕力而死。
passages.en: There was a man who was frightened at his shadow and disliked to see his footsteps, so that he ran to escape from them. But the more frequently he lifted his feet, the more numerous his footprints were; and however fast he ran, his shadow did not leave him. He thought he was going too slow, and ran on with all his speed without stopping, till his strength was exhausted and he died.

passages.zh: 不知處陰以休影，處靜以息跡，愚亦甚矣！
passages.en: He did not know that, if he had stayed in a shady place, his shadow would have disappeared, and that if he had remained still, he would have lost his footprints: his stupidity was excessive!

passages.zh: 子審仁義之間，察同異之際，觀動靜之變，適受與之度，理好惡之情，和喜怒之節，而幾於不免矣。
passages.en: And you, Sir, exercise your judgment on the questions about benevolence and righteousness; you investigate the points where agreement and difference touch; you look at the changes from movement to rest and from rest to movement; you have mastered the rules of receiving and giving; you have defined the feelings of liking and disliking; you have harmonised the limits of joy and anger: and yet you have hardly been able to escape (the troubles of which you speak).

passages.zh: 謹修而身，慎守其真，還以物與人，則無所累矣。
passages.en: If you earnestly cultivated your own person, and carefully guarded your (proper) truth, simply rendering to others what was due to them, then you would have escaped such entanglements.

passages.zh: 今不修之身而求之人，不亦外乎！」
passages.en: But now, when you do not cultivate your own person, and make the cultivation of others your object, are you not occupying yourself with what is external?'

passages.zh: 孔子愀然曰：「請問何謂真？」
passages.en: Confucius with an air of sadness said, 'Allow me to ask what it is that you call my proper Truth.'

passages.zh: 客曰：「真者，精誠之至也。
passages.en: The stranger replied, 'A man's proper Truth is pure sincerity in its highest degree - without this pure sincerity one cannot move others.

passages.zh: 不精不誠，不能動人。
passages.en: Hence if one (only) forces himself to wail, however sadly he may do so, it is not (real) sorrow; if he forces himself to be angry, however he may seem to be severe, he excites no awe; if he forces himself to show affection, however he may smile, he awakens no harmonious reciprocation.

passages.zh: 故強哭者雖悲不哀，強怒者雖嚴不威，強親者雖笑不和。
passages.en: True grief, without a sound, is yet sorrowful; true anger, without any demonstration, yet awakens awe; true affection, without a smile, yet produces a harmonious reciprocation.

passages.zh: 真悲無聲而哀，真怒未發而威，真親未笑而和。
passages.en: Given this truth within, it exercises a spiritual efficacy without, and this is why we count it so valuable.

passages.zh: 真在內者，神動於外，是所以貴真也。
passages.en: In our relations with others, it appears according to the requirements of each case: in the service of parents, as gentle, filial duty; in the service of rulers, as loyalty and integrity; in festive drinking, as pleasant enjoyment; in the performance of the mourning rites, as sadness and sorrow.

passages.zh: 其用於人理也，事親則慈孝，事君則忠貞，飲酒則歡樂，處喪則悲哀。
passages.en: In loyalty and integrity, good service is the principal thing; in festive drinking, the enjoyment; in the mourning rites, the sorrow; in the service of parents, the giving them pleasure.

passages.zh: 忠貞以功為主，飲酒以樂為主，處喪以哀為主，事親以適為主，功成之美，無一其跡矣。
passages.en: The beauty of the service rendered (to a ruler) does not require that it always be performed in one way; the service of parents so as to give them pleasure takes no account of how it is done; the festive drinking which ministers enjoyment does not depend on the appliances for it; the observance of the mourning rites with the proper sorrow asks no questions about the rites themselves.

passages.zh: 事親以適，不論所以矣；飲酒以樂，不選其具矣；處喪以哀，無問其禮矣。
passages.en: Rites are prescribed for the practice of the common people; man's proper Truth is what he has received from Heaven, operating spontaneously, and unchangeable.

passages.zh: 禮者，世俗之所為也；真者，所以受於天也，自然不可易也。
passages.en: Therefore the sages take their law from Heaven, and prize their (proper) Truth, without submitting to the restrictions of custom.

passages.zh: 故聖人法天貴真，不拘於俗。
passages.en: The stupid do the reverse of this.

passages.zh: 愚者反此，不能法天而恤於人，不知貴真，祿祿而受變於俗，故不足。
passages.en: They are unable to take their law from Heaven, and are influenced by other men; they do not know how to prize the proper Truth (of their nature), but are under the dominion of ordinary things, and change according to the customs (around them): always, consequently, incomplete.

passages.zh: 惜哉！
passages.en: Alas for you, Sir, that you were early steeped in the hypocrisies of men, and have been so late in hearing about the Great Way!'

passages.zh: 子之早湛於人偽，而晚聞大道也！」
passages.en: (Once more), Confucius bowed twice (to the fisherman), then rose again, and said, 'That I have met you to-day is as if I had the happiness of getting to heaven.

passages.zh: 孔子又再拜而起曰：「今者丘得遇也，若天幸然。
passages.en: If you, Master, are not ashamed, but will let me be as your servant, and continue to teach me, let me venture to ask where your dwelling is.

passages.zh: 先生不羞而比之服役，而身教之。
passages.en: I will then beg to receive your instructions there, and finish my learning of the Great Way.'

passages.zh: 敢問舍所在，請因受業而卒學大道。」
passages.en: The stranger replied, 'I have heard the saying, "If it be one with whom you can walk together, go with him to the subtlest mysteries of the Dao.

passages.zh: 客曰：「吾聞之：可與往者與之，至於妙道；不可與往者，不知其道，慎勿與之，身乃無咎。
passages.en: If it be one with whom you cannot walk together and he do not know the Dao, take care that you do not associate with him, and you will yourself incur no responsibility."

passages.zh: 子勉之！
passages.en: Do your utmost, Sir.

passages.zh: 吾去子矣，吾去子矣。」
passages.en: I must leave you, I must leave you!'

passages.zh: 乃刺船而去，延緣葦間。
passages.en: With this he shoved off his boat, and went away among the green reeds.

passages.zh: 顏淵還車，子路授綏，孔子不顧，待水波定，不聞拏音，而後敢乘。
passages.en: Yan Yuan (now) returned to the carriage, where Zi-lu handed to him the strap; but Confucius did not look round, (continuing where he was), till the wavelets were stilled, and he did not hear the sound of the pole, when at last he ventured to (return and) take his seat.

passages.zh: 子路旁車而問曰：「由得為役久矣，未嘗見夫子遇人如此其威也。
passages.en: Zi-lu, by his side in the carriage, asked him, saying, 'I have been your servant for a long time, but I have never seen you, Master, treat another with the awe and reverence which you have now shown.

passages.zh: 萬乘之主，千乘之君，見夫子未嘗不分庭伉禮，夫子猶有倨敖之容。
