passages.en: I have seen you in the presence of a Lord of ten thousand chariots or a Ruler of a thousand, and they have never received you in a different audience-room, or treated you but with the courtesies due to an equal, while you have still carried yourself with a reserved and haughty air; but to-day this old fisherman has stood erect in front of you with his pole in his hand, while you, bent from your loins in the form of a sounding-stone, would bow twice before you answered him - was not your reverence of him excessive?

passages.zh: 今漁者杖拏逆立，而夫子曲要磬折，言拜而應，得無太甚乎？
passages.en: Your disciples will all think it strange in you, Master.

passages.zh: 門人皆怪夫子矣，漁人何以得此乎？」
passages.en: Why did the old fisherman receive such homage from you?'

passages.zh: 孔子伏軾而歎曰：「甚矣由之難化也！
passages.en: Confucius leant forward on the cross-bar of the carriage, heaved a sigh, and said, 'Difficult indeed is it to change you, 0 You!

passages.zh: 湛於禮義有間矣，而樸鄙之心至今未去。
passages.en: You have been trained in propriety and righteousness for long, and yet your servile and mean heart has not been taken front you.

passages.zh: 進！
passages.en: Come nearer, that I may speak fully to you.

passages.zh: 吾語汝。
passages.en: If you meet one older than yourself, and do not show him respect, you fail in propriety.

passages.zh: 夫遇長不敬，失禮也；見賢不尊，不仁也。
passages.en: If you see a man of superior wisdom and goodness, and do not honour him, you want the great characteristic of humanity.

passages.zh: 彼非至人，不能下人，下人不精，不得其真，故長傷身。
passages.en: If that (fisherman) did not possess it in the highest degree, how could he make others submit to him? And if their submission to him be not sincere, they do not attain to the truth (of their nature), and inflict a lasting injury on their persons.

passages.zh: 惜哉！
passages.en: Alas!

passages.zh: 不仁之於人也，禍莫大焉，而由獨擅之。
passages.en: there is no greater calamity to man than the want of this characteristic; and you, 0 You, you alone, would take such want on yourself.

passages.zh: 且道者，萬物之所出也，庶物失之者死，得之者生；為事逆之則敗，順之則成。
passages.en: Moreover, the Dao is the course by which all things should proceed. For things to fail in this is death; to observe it, is life. To oppose it in practice is ruin; to conform it, is success.

passages.zh: 故道之所在，聖人尊之。
passages.en: Therefore wherever the sagely man finds the Dao, he honours it.

passages.zh: 今漁父之道，可謂有矣，吾敢不敬乎！」
passages.en: And that old fisherman to-day might be said to possess it - dared I presume not to show him reverence?'

passages.zh: 列御寇之齊，中道而反，遇伯昏瞀人。
passages.en: Lie Yu-kou had started to go to Qi, but came back when he was half-way to it. He met Bo-hun Wu-ren, who said, 'Why have you come back?'

passages.zh: 伯昏瞀人曰：「奚方而反？」
passages.en: His reply was, 'I was frightened.'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾驚焉。」
passages.en: 'What frightened you?'

passages.zh: 曰：「惡乎驚？」
passages.en: 'I went into ten soup-shops to get a meal, and in five of them the soup was set before me before (I had paid for it).'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾嘗食於十漿，而五漿先饋。」
passages.en: 'But what was there in that to frighten you?'

passages.zh: 伯昏瞀人曰：「若是，則汝何為驚已？」
passages.en: (Liezi) said, 'Though the inward and true purpose be not set forth, the body like a spy gives some bright display of it.

passages.zh: 曰：「夫內誠不解，形諜成光，以外鎮人心，使人輕乎貴老，而齏其所患。
passages.en: And this outward demonstration overawes men's minds, and makes men on light grounds treat one as noble or as aged, from which evil to him will be produced.

passages.zh: 夫漿特為食羹之貨，多餘之贏，其為利也薄，其為權也輕，而猶若是，而況於萬乘之主乎！
passages.en: Now vendors of soup supply their commodity simply as a matter of business, and however much they may dispose of, their profit is but little, and their power is but slight; and yet they treated me as I have said: how much more would the lord of ten thousand chariots do so!

passages.zh: 身勞於國而知盡於事，彼將任我以事而效我以功，吾是以驚。」
passages.en: His body burdened with (the cares of his) kingdom, and his knowledge overtasked by its affairs, he would entrust those affairs to me, and exact from me the successful conduct (of its government). It was this which frightened me.'

passages.zh: 伯昏瞀人曰：「善哉觀乎！
passages.en: Po-hwan Wu-zan replied, 'Admirable perspicacity!

passages.zh: 汝處已，人將保汝矣。」
passages.en: But if you carry yourself as you do, men will flock to you for protection.'

passages.zh: 無幾何而往，則戶外之屨滿矣。
passages.en: Not long after, Bo-hun Wu-ren went (to visit Liezi), and found the space outside his door full of shoes.

passages.zh: 伯昏瞀人北面而立，敦杖蹙之乎頤，立有間，不言而出。
passages.en: There he stood with his face to the north, holding his staff upright, and leaning his chin on it till the skin was wrinkled. After standing so for some time, and without saying a word, he was going away, when the door-keeper went in, and told Liezi.

passages.zh: 賓者以告列子，列子提屨，跣而走，暨乎門，曰：「先生既來，曾不發藥乎？」
passages.en: The latter (immediately) took up his shoes, and ran barefoot after the visitor. When he overtook him at the (outer) gate, he said, 'Since you, Sir, have come, are you going away without giving me some medicine?'

passages.zh: 曰：「已矣！
passages.en: The other replied, 'It is of no use.

passages.zh: 吾固告汝曰『人將保汝』，果保汝矣。
passages.en: I did tell you that men would flock to you, and they do indeed do so.

passages.zh: 非汝能使人保汝，而汝不能使人無保汝也，而焉用之感豫出異也！
passages.en: It is not that you can cause men to flock to you, but you cannot keep them from not so coming - of what use is (all my warning)?

passages.zh: 必且有感，搖而本才，又無謂也。
passages.en: What influences them and makes them glad is the display of your extraordinary (qualities); but you must also be influenced in your turn, and your proper nature be shaken, and no warning can be addressed to you.

passages.zh: 與汝遊者，又莫汝告也，彼所小言，盡人毒也。
passages.en: Those who associate with you do not admonish you of this. The small words which they speak are poison to a man.

passages.zh: 莫覺莫悟，何相孰也！
passages.en: You perceive it not; you understand it not - how can you separate yourself from them?

passages.zh: 巧者勞而知者憂，無能者無所求，飽食而敖遊，汎若不繫之舟，虛而敖遊者也。」
passages.en: The clever toil on, and the wise are sad. Those who are without ability seek for nothing. They eat to the full, and wander idly about. They drift like a vessel loosed from its moorings, and aimlessly wander about.'

passages.zh: 鄭人緩也呻吟裘氏之地。
passages.en: A man of Zheng, called Huan, learned his books in the neighbourhood of Qiu-shi, and in no longer time than three years became a Confucian scholar, benefiting the three classes of his kindred as the He extends its enriching influence for nine li.

passages.zh: 祗三年而緩為儒，潤河九里，澤及三族，使其弟墨。
passages.en: He made his younger brother study (the principles of) Mo, and then they two - the scholar and the Mohist - disputed together (about their respective systems), and the father took the side of the younger.

passages.zh: 儒、墨相與辯，其父助翟。
passages.en: After ten years Huan killed himself.

passages.zh: 十年而緩自殺。
passages.en: (By and by) he appeared to his father in a dream, saying, 'It was I who made your son become a Mohist; why did you not recognise that good service?

passages.zh: 其父夢之，曰：「使而子為墨者，予也。
passages.en: I am become (but) the fruit of a cypress in autumn.'

passages.zh: 闔胡嘗視其良，既為秋柏之實矣！」
passages.en: But the Creator, in apportioning the awards of men, does not recompense them for their own doings, but recompenses them for the (use of the) Heavenly in them.

passages.zh: 夫造物者之報人也，不報其人而報其人之天。
passages.en: It was thus that Huan's brother was led to learn Mohism.

passages.zh: 彼故使彼。
passages.en: When this Huan thought that it was he who had made his brother different from what he would have been, and proceeded to despise his father, he was like the people of Qi, who, while they drank from a well, tried to keep one another from it.

passages.zh: 夫人以己為有以異於人，以賤其親，齊人之井，飲者相捽也。
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'Now-a-days all men are Huans.'

passages.zh: 故曰：「今之世皆緩也。」
passages.en: From this we perceive that those who possess the characteristics (of the Dao) consider that they do not know them; how much more is it so with those who possess the Dao itself!

passages.zh: 自是，有德者以不知也，而況有道者乎！
passages.en: The ancients called such (as Huan) 'men who had escaped the punishment of Heaven.'

passages.zh: 古者謂之遁天之刑。
passages.en: The sagely man rests in what is his proper rest; he does not rest in what is not so - the multitude of men rest in what is not their proper rest; they do not rest in their proper rest.

passages.zh: 聖人安其所安，不安其所不安；眾人安其所不安，不安其所安。
passages.en: Zhuangzi said, 'To know the Dao is easy; not to say (that you know it) is difficult.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「知道易，勿言難。
passages.en: To know it and not to speak of it is the way to attain to the Heavenly; to know and to speak of it, is the way to show the Human.

passages.zh: 知而不言，所以之天也；知而言之，所以之人也。
passages.en: The ancients pursued the Heavenly (belonging to them), and not the Human.'

passages.zh: 古之人，天而不人。」
passages.en: Zhu Ping-man learned how to slaughter the dragon from Zhi-li Yi, expending (in doing so) all his wealth of a thousand ounces of silver.

passages.zh: 朱泙漫學屠龍於支離益，單千金之家，三年技成，而無所用其巧。
passages.en: In three years he became perfect in the art, but he never exercised his skill.

passages.zh: 聖人以必不必，故無兵；眾人以不必必之，故多兵。
passages.en: The sage looks on what is deemed necessary as unnecessary, and therefore is not at war (in himself). The mass of men deem what is unnecessary to be necessary, and therefore they are often at war (in themselves).

passages.zh: 順於兵，故行有求。
passages.en: Therefore those who pursue this method of (internal) war, resort to it in whatever they seek for.

passages.zh: 兵，恃之則亡。
passages.en: But reliance on such war leads to ruin.

passages.zh: 小夫之知，不離苞苴竿牘，敝精神乎蹇淺，而欲兼濟道物，太一形虛。
passages.en: The wisdom of the small man does not go beyond (the minutiae of) making presents and writing memoranda, wearying his spirits out in what is trivial and mean. But at the same time he wishes to aid in guiding to (the secret of) the Dao and of (all) things in the incorporeity of the Grand Unity.

passages.zh: 若是者，迷惑於宇宙，形累不知太初。
passages.en: In this way he goes all astray in regard to (the mysteries of) space and time. The fetters of embodied matter keep him from the knowledge of the Grand Beginning.

passages.zh: 彼至人者，歸精神乎無始，而甘冥乎無何有之鄉。
passages.en: (On the other hand), the perfect man directs the energy of his spirit to what was before the Beginning, and finds pleasure in the mysteriousness belonging to the region of nothingness.

passages.zh: 水流乎無形，發泄乎太清。
passages.en: He is like the water which flows on without the obstruction of matter, and expands into the Grand Purity.

passages.zh: 悲哉乎！
passages.en: Alas for what you do, (0 men)!

passages.zh: 汝為知在毫毛，而不知大寧！
passages.en: You occupy yourselves with things trivial as a hair, and remain ignorant of the Grand Rest!

passages.zh: 宋人有曹商者，為宋王使秦。
passages.en: There was a man of Song, called Cao Shang, who was sent by the king of Song on a mission to Qin.

passages.zh: 其往也，得車數乘；王說之，益車百乘。
passages.en: On setting out, he had several carriages with him; and the king (of Qin) was so pleased with him that he gave him another hundred.

passages.zh: 反於宋，見莊子曰：「夫處窮閭阨巷，困窘織屨，槁項黃馘者，商之所短也；一悟萬乘之主，而從車百乘者，商之所長也。」
passages.en: When he returned to Song, he saw Zhuangzi, and said to him, 'To live in a narrow lane of a poor mean hamlet, wearing sandals amid distress of poverty, with a weazen neck and yellow face - that is what I should find it difficult to do. But as soon as I come to an understanding with the Lord of a myriad carriages, to find myself with a retinue of a hundred carriages - that is wherein I excel.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「秦王有病召醫，破癰潰痤者得車一乘，舐痔者得車五乘，所治愈下，得車愈多。
passages.en: Zhuangzi replied, 'When the king of Qin is ill, the doctor whom he calls to open an ulcer or squeeze a boil receives a carriage; and he who licks his piles receives five.

passages.zh: 子豈治其痔邪？
passages.en: The lower the service, the more are the carriages given.

passages.zh: 何得車之多也？
passages.en: Did you, Sir, lick his piles?

passages.zh: 子行矣！」
passages.en: How else should you have got so many carriages? Begone!'

passages.zh: 魯哀公問於顏闔曰：「吾以仲尼為貞幹，國其有瘳乎？」
passages.en: Duke Ai of lu asked Yan He, saying, 'If I employ Zhongni as the support of my government, will the evils of the state be thereby cured?'

passages.zh: 曰：「殆哉圾乎！
passages.en: The reply was, '(Such a measure) would be perilous! It would be full of hazard!

passages.zh: 仲尼方且飾羽而畫，從事華辭，以支為旨，忍性以視民而不知不信，受乎心，宰乎神，夫何足以上民！
passages.en: Zhongni, moreover, will try to ornament a feather and paint it; in the conduct of affairs he uses flowery speeches. A (mere) branch is to him more admirable (than the root); he can bear to misrepresent their nature in instructing the people, and is not conscious of the unreality of his words. He receives (his inspiration) from his own mind, and rules his course from his own spirit: what fitness has he to be set over the people?

passages.zh: 彼宜女與？
passages.en: Is such a man suitable for you (as your minister)?

passages.zh: 予頤與？
passages.en: Could you give to him the nourishment (of the people)?

passages.zh: 誤而可矣。
passages.en: You would do so by mistake (but not on purpose, for a time, but not as a permanency).

passages.zh: 今使民離實學偽，非所以視民也。
passages.en: To make the people leave what is real, and learn what is hypocritical - that is not the proper thing to be shown to them; if you take thought for future ages, your better plan will be to give up (the idea of employing Confucius) - else governing will be difficult.

passages.zh: 為後世慮，不若休之，難治也。」
passages.en: Dealing with men without forgetting yourself is not according to the example of Heaven in diffusing its benefits.

passages.zh: 施於人而不忘，非天布也。
passages.en: Merchants and traffickers are not to be ranked (with administrative officers) if on an occasion you so rank them, the spirits (of the people) do not acquiesce in your doing so.

passages.zh: 商賈不齒，雖以事齒之，神者勿齒。
passages.en: The instruments of external punishment are made of metal and wood; those of internal punishment are agitation (of the mind) and (the sense of) transgression.

passages.zh: 為外刑者，金與木也；為內刑者，動與過也。
passages.en: When small men become subject to the external punishment, the (instruments of) metal and wood deal with them; when they become liable to the internal punishments, the Yin and Yang consume them.

passages.zh: 宵人之離外刑者，金木訊之；離內刑者，陰陽食之。
passages.en: It is only the true man who can escape both from the external and internal punishment.

passages.zh: 夫免乎外內之刑者，唯真人能之。
passages.en: Confucius said, 'The minds of men are more difficult of approach than (the position defended by) mountains and rivers, and more difficult to know than Heaven itself.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「凡人心險於山川，難於知天。
passages.en: Heaven has its periods of spring and autumn, of winter and summer, and of morning and evening; but man's exterior is thickly veiled, and his feelings lie deep.

passages.zh: 天猶有春秋冬夏旦暮之期，人者厚貌深情。
passages.en: Thus the demeanour of some is honest-like, and yet they go to excess (in what is mean); others are really gifted, and yet look to be without ability; some seem docile and impressible, but yet they have far-reaching schemes; others look firm, and yet may be twisted about; others look slow, and yet they are hasty.

passages.zh: 故有貌愿而益，有長若不肖，有順懁而達，有堅而縵，有緩而釬。
passages.en: In this way those who hasten to do what is right as if they were thirsty will anon hurry away from it as if it were fire.

passages.zh: 故其就義若渴者，其去義若熱。
passages.en: Hence the superior man looks at them when employed at a distance to test their fidelity, and when employed near at hand to test their reverence.

passages.zh: 故君子遠使之而觀其忠，近使之而觀其敬，煩使之而觀其能，卒然問焉而觀其知，急與之期而觀其信，委之以財而觀其仁，告之以危而觀其節，醉之以酒而觀其側，雜之以處而觀其色。
passages.en: By employing them on difficult services, he tests their ability; by questioning them suddenly, he tests their knowledge; by appointing them a fixed time, he tests their good faith; by entrusting them with wealth, he tests their benevolence; by telling them of danger, he tests their self-command in emergencies; by making them drunk, he tests their tendencies; by placing them in a variety of society, he tests their chastity: by these nine tests the inferior man is discovered.'

passages.zh: 九徵至，不肖人得矣。
passages.en: When Kao-fu, the Correct, received the first grade of official rank, he walked with head bowed down; on receiving the second, with bent back; on receiving the third, with body stooping, he ran and hurried along the wall: who would presume not to take him as a model?

passages.zh: 正考父一命而傴，再命而僂，三命而俯，循牆而走，孰敢不軌！
passages.en: But one of those ordinary men, on receiving his first appointment, goes along with a haughty stride; on receiving his second, he looks quite elated in his chariot; and on receiving the third, he calls his uncles by their personal names - how very different from Xu (You) in the time (of Yao of) Tang!

passages.zh: 如而夫者，一命而呂鉅，再命而於車上舞，三命而名諸父，孰協唐、許！
passages.en: Of all things that injure (men) there is none greater than the practising of virtue with the purpose of the mind, till the mind becomes supercilious.

passages.zh: 賊莫大乎德有心而心有眼，及其有眼也而內視，內視而敗矣。
passages.en: When it becomes so, the mind (only) looks inwards (on itself), and such looking into itself leads to its ruin.

passages.zh: 凶德有五，中德為首。
passages.en: This evil quality has five forms, and the chief of them is that which is the central.

passages.zh: 何謂中德？
passages.en: What do we mean by the central quality?

passages.zh: 中德也者，有以自好也而吡其所不為者也。
passages.en: It is that which appears in a man's loving (only) his own views, and reviling whatever he does not do (himself).

passages.zh: 窮有八極，達有三必，形有六府。
passages.en: Limiting (men's advance), there are eight extreme conditions; securing (that advance), there are three things necessary; and the person has its six repositories.

passages.zh: 美、髯、長、大、壯、麗、勇、敢，八者俱過人也，因以是窮。
passages.en: Elegance; a (fine) beard; tallness; size; strength; beauty; bravery; daring; and in all these excelling others: (these are the eight extreme conditions) by which advance is limited.

passages.zh: 緣循、偃佒、困畏不若人，三者俱通達。
passages.en: Depending on and copying others; stooping in order to rise; and being straitened by the fear of not equalling others: these are the three things that lead to advancing.

passages.zh: 知慧外通，勇動多怨，仁義多責。
passages.en: Knowledge seeking to reach to all that is external; bold movement producing many resentments; benevolence and righteousness leading to many requisitions; understanding the phenomena of life in an extraordinary degree; understanding all knowledge so as to possess an approach to it; understanding the great condition appointed for him, and following it, and the smaller conditions, and meeting them as they occur: (these are the six repositories of the person).

passages.zh: 達生之情者傀，達於知者肖；達大命者隨，達小命者遭。
passages.en: There was a man who, having had an interview with the king of Song, and been presented by him with ten carriages, showed them boastfully to Zhuangzi, as if the latter had been a boy.

passages.zh: 人有見宋王者，錫車十乘，以其十乘驕稚莊子。
passages.en: Zhuangzi said to him, 'Near the He there was a poor man who supported his family by weaving rushes (to form screens).

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「河上有家貧恃緯蕭而食者，其子沒於淵，得千金之珠。
passages.en: His son, when diving in a deep pool, found a pearl worth a thousand ounces of silver.

passages.zh: 其父謂其子曰『取石來鍛之！
passages.en: The father said, "Bring a stone, and break it in pieces.

passages.zh: 夫千金之珠，必在九重之淵而驪龍頷下，子能得珠者，必遭其睡也。
passages.en: A pearl of this value must have been in a pool nine Zhong deep, and under the chin of the Black Dragon. That you were able to get it must have been owing to your finding him asleep.

passages.zh: 使驪龍而寤，子尚奚微之有哉！』
passages.en: Let him awake, and the consequences to you will not be small!"

passages.zh: 今宋國之深，非直九重之淵也；宋王之猛，非直驪龍也。
passages.en: Now the kingdom of Song is deeper than any pool of nine Zhong, and its king is fiercer than the Black Dragon.

passages.zh: 子能得車者，必遭其睡也。
passages.en: That you were able to get the chariots must have been owing to your finding him asleep.

passages.zh: 使宋王而寤，子為齏粉夫！」
passages.en: Let him awake, and you will be ground to powder.'

passages.zh: 或聘於莊子，莊子應其使曰：「子見夫犧牛乎？
passages.en: Some (ruler) having sent a message of invitation to him, Zhuangzi replied to the messenger, 'Have you seen, Sir, a sacrificial ox?

passages.zh: 衣以文繡，食以芻叔，及其牽而入於太廟，雖欲為孤犢，其可得乎！」
passages.en: It is robed with ornamental embroidery, and feasted on fresh grass and beans. But when it is led into the grand ancestral temple, though it wished to be (again) a solitary calf, would that be possible for it?'

passages.zh: 莊子將死，弟子欲厚葬之。
passages.en: When Zhuangzi was about to die, his disciples signified their wish to give him a grand burial.

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「吾以天地為棺槨，以日月為連璧，星辰為珠璣，萬物為齎送。
passages.en: 'I shall have heaven and earth,' said he, 'for my coffin and its shell; the sun and moon for my two round symbols of jade; the stars and constellations for my pearls and jewels; and all things assisting as the mourners.

passages.zh: 吾葬具豈不備邪？
passages.en: Will not the provisions for my burial be complete?

passages.zh: 何以加此！」
passages.en: What could you add to them?'

passages.zh: 弟子曰：「吾恐烏鳶之食夫子也。」
passages.en: The disciples replied, 'We are afraid that the crows and kites will eat our master.'

passages.zh: 莊子曰：「在上為烏鳶食，在下為螻蟻食，奪彼與此，何其偏也！」
passages.en: Zhuangzi rejoined, 'Above, the crows and kites will eat me; below, the mole-crickets and ants will eat me: to take from those and give to these would only show your partiality.'

passages.zh: 以不平平，其平也不平；以不徵徵，其徵也不徵。
passages.en: The attempt, with what is not even, to produce what is even will only produce an uneven result; the attempt, with what is uncertain, to make the uncertain certain will leave the uncertainty as it was.

passages.zh: 明者唯為之使，神者徵之。
passages.en: He who uses only the sight of his eyes is acted on by what he sees; it is the (intuition of the) spirit, that gives the assurance of certainty.

passages.zh: 夫明之不勝神也久矣，而愚者恃其所見入於人，其功外也，不亦悲乎！
passages.en: That the sight of the eyes is not equal to that intuition of the spirit is a thing long acknowledged. And yet stupid people rely on what they see, and will have it to be the sentiment of all men - all their success being with what is external: is it not sad?

passages.zh: 天下之治方術者多矣，皆以其有為不可加矣。
passages.en: The methods employed in the regulation of the world are many; and (the employers of them) think each that the efficiency of his own method leaves nothing to be added to it.

passages.zh: 古之所謂道術者，果惡乎在？
passages.en: But where is what was called of old 'the method of the Dao?'

passages.zh: 曰：「無乎不在。」
passages.en: We must reply, 'It is everywhere.'

passages.zh: 曰：「神何由降？
passages.en: But then whence does the spiritual in it come down?

passages.zh: 明何由出？」
passages.en: and whence does the intelligence in it come forth?

passages.zh: 「聖有所生，王有所成，皆原於一。」
passages.en: There is that which gives birth to the Sage, and that which gives his perfection to the King: the origin of both is the One.

passages.zh: 不離於宗，謂之天人。
passages.en: Not to be separate from his primal source constitutes what we call the Heavenly man; not to be separate from the essential nature thereof constitutes what we call the Spirit-like man; not to be separate from its real truth constitutes what we call the Perfect man.

passages.zh: 不離於精，謂之神人。
passages.en: To regard Heaven as his primal Source, Its Attributes as the Root (of his nature), and the Dao as the Gate (by which he enters into this inheritance), (knowing also) the prognostics given in change and transformation, constitutes what we call the Sagely man.

passages.zh: 不離於真，謂之至人。
passages.en: To regard benevolence as (the source of all) kindness, righteousness as (the source of all) distinctions, propriety as (the rule of) all conduct, and music as (the idea of) all harmony, thus diffusing a fragrance of gentleness and goodness, constitutes what we call the Superior man.

passages.zh: 以天為宗，以德為本，以道為門，兆於變化，謂之聖人。
passages.en: To regard laws as assigning the different (social) conditions, their names as the outward expression (of the social duties), the comparison of subjects as supplying the grounds of evidence, investigation as conducting to certainty, so that things can be numbered as first, second, third, fourth (and so on): (this is the basis of government).

passages.zh: 以仁為恩，以義為理，以禮為行，以樂為和，薰然慈仁，謂之君子。
passages.en: Its hundred offices are thus arranged; business has its regular course; the great matters of clothes and food are provided for; cattle are fattened and looked after; the (government) stores are filled; the old and weak, orphans and solitaries, receive anxious consideration: in all these ways is provision made for the nourishment of the people.

passages.zh: 以法為分，以名為表，以參為驗，以稽為決，其數一二三四是也。
passages.en: How complete was (the operation of the Dao) in the men of old!

passages.zh: 百官以此相齒，以事為常，以衣食為主，蕃息畜藏，老弱孤寡為意，皆有以養，民之理也。
passages.en: It made them the equals of spiritual beings, and subtle and all-embracing as heaven and earth.

passages.zh: 古之人其備乎！
passages.en: They nourished all things, and produced harmony all under heaven.

passages.zh: 配神明，醇天地，育萬物，和天下，澤及百姓，明於本數，係於末度，六通四辟，小大精粗，其運無乎不在。
passages.en: Their beneficent influence reached to all classes of the people. They understood all fundamental principles, and followed them out to their graduated issues; in all the six directions went their penetration, and in the four quarters all things were open to them. Great and small, fine and coarse - all felt their presence and operation.

passages.zh: 其明而在數度者，舊法世傳之史尚多有之。
passages.en: Their intelligence, as seen in all their regulations, was handed down from age to age in their old laws, and much of it was still to be found in the Historians.

passages.zh: 其在於《詩》、《書》、《禮》、《樂》者，鄒、魯之士、搢紳先生多能明之。
passages.en: What of it was in the Shi, the Shu, the Li, and the Yue, might be learned from the scholars of Zou and Lu, and the girdled members of the various courts.

passages.zh: 《詩》以道志，《書》以道事，《禮》以道行，《樂》以道和，《易》以道陰陽，《春秋》以道名分。
passages.en: The Shi describes what should be the aim of the mind; the Shu, the course of events; the Li is intended to direct the conduct; the Yue, to set forth harmony; the Yi, to show the action of the Yin and Yang; and the Chun Qiu, to display names and the duties belonging to them.

passages.zh: 其數散於天下而設於中國者，百家之學時或稱而道之。
passages.en: Some of the regulations (of these men of old), scattered all under heaven, and established in our Middle states, are (also) occasionally mentioned and described in the writings of the different schools.

passages.zh: 天下大亂，賢聖不明，道德不一，天下多得一察焉以自好。
passages.en: There ensued great disorder in the world, and sages and worthies no longer shed their light on it. The Dao and its characteristics ceased to be regarded as uniform. Many in different places got one glimpse of it, and plumed themselves on possessing it as a whole.

passages.zh: 譬如耳目鼻口，皆有所明，不能相通。
passages.en: They might be compared to the ear, the eye, the nose, or the mouth. Each sense has its own faculty, but their different faculties cannot be interchanged.

passages.zh: 猶百家眾技也，皆有所長，時有所用。
passages.en: So it was with the many branches of the various schools. Each had its peculiar excellence, and there was the time for the use of it; but notwithstanding no one covered or extended over the whole (range of truth).

passages.zh: 雖然，不該不遍，一曲之士也。
passages.en: The case was that of the scholar of a corner who passes his judgment on all the beautiful in heaven and earth, discriminates the principles that underlie all things, and attempts to estimate the success arrived at by the ancients.

passages.zh: 判天地之美，析萬物之理，察古人之全，寡能備於天地之美，稱神明之容。
passages.en: Seldom is it that such an one can embrace all the beautiful in heaven and earth, or rightly estimate the ways of the spiritual and intelligent; and thus it was that the Dao, which inwardly forms the sage and externally the king, became obscured and lost its clearness, became repressed and lost its development.

passages.zh: 是故內聖外王之道，闇而不明，鬱而不發，天下之人各為其所欲焉以自為方。
passages.en: Every one in the world did whatever he wished, and was the rule to himself.

passages.zh: 悲夫！
passages.en: Alas!

passages.zh: 百家往而不反，必不合矣。
passages.en: the various schools held on their several ways, and could not come back to the same point, nor agree together.

passages.zh: 後世之學者，不幸不見天地之純，古人之大體，道術將為天下裂。
passages.en: The students of that later age unfortunately did not see the undivided purity of heaven and earth, and the great scheme of truth held by the ancients. The system of the Dao was about to be torn in fragments all under a the sky.

passages.zh: 不侈於後世，不靡於萬物，不暉於數度，以繩墨自矯，而備世之急，古之道術有在於是者。
passages.en: To leave no example of extravagance to future generations; to show no wastefulness in the use of anything; to make no display in the degree of their (ceremonial) observances; to keep themselves (in their expenditure) under the restraint of strict and exact rule, so as to be prepared for occurring emergencies - such regulations formed part of the system of the Dao in antiquity, and were appreciated by Mo Di, and (his disciple) Qin Hua-li.

passages.zh: 墨翟、禽滑釐聞其風而說之。
passages.en: When they heard of such ways, they were delighted with them; but they enjoined them in excess, and followed them themselves too strictly.

passages.zh: 為之大過，己之大循。
passages.en: (Mo) made the treatise 'Against Music,' and enjoined the subject of another, called 'Economy in Expenditure,' on his followers.

passages.zh: 作為《非樂》，命之曰《節用》，生不歌，死無服。
passages.en: He would have no singing in life, and no wearing of mourning on occasions of death.

passages.zh: 墨子汎愛兼利而非鬥，其道不怒；又好學而博，不異，不與先王同，毀古之禮樂。
passages.en: He inculcated Universal Love, and a Common Participation in all advantages, and condemned Fighting. His doctrine did not admit of Anger. He was fond also of Learning, and with it all strove not to appear different from others. Yet he did not agree with the former kings, but attacked the ceremonies and music of the ancients.

passages.zh: 黃帝有《咸池》，堯有《大章》，舜有《大韶》，禹有《大夏》，湯有《大濩》，文王有辟雍之樂，武王、周公作《武》。
passages.en: Huang-Di had his Xian-chi; Yao, his Da Zhang; Shun, his Da Shao; Yu, his Da Xia; Tang, his Da Hu; King Wen, his music of the Pi-yong; and king Wu and the duke of Zhou made the Wu.

passages.zh: 古之喪禮，貴賤有儀，上下有等，天子棺槨七重，諸侯五重，大夫三重，士再重。
passages.en: In the mourning rites of the ancients, the noble and mean had their several observances, the high and low their different degrees. The coffin of the Son of Heaven was sevenfold; of a feudal lord, fivefold; of a great officer, threefold; of other officers, twofold.

passages.zh: 今墨子獨生不歌，死不服，桐棺三寸而無槨，以為法式。
passages.en: But now Mo-zi alone, would have no singing during life, and no wearing of mourning after death. As the rule for all, he would have a coffin of elaeococca wood, three inches thick, and without any enclosing shell.

passages.zh: 以此教人，恐不愛人；以此自行，固不愛己。
passages.en: The teaching of such lessons cannot be regarded as affording a proof of his love for men; his practising them in his own case would certainly show that he did not love himself; but this has not been sufficient to overthrow the views of Mo-zi.

passages.zh: 未敗墨子道，雖然，歌而非歌，哭而非哭，樂而非樂，是果類乎？
passages.en: Notwithstanding, men will sing, and he condemns singing; men will wail, and he condemns wailing; men will express their joy, and he condemns such expression: is this truly in accordance with man's nature?

passages.zh: 其生也勤，其死也薄，其道大觳，使人憂，使人悲，其行難為也，恐其不可以為聖人之道，反天下之心，天下不堪。
passages.en: Through life toil, and at death niggardliness: his way is one of great unkindliness. Causing men sorrow and melancholy, and difficult to be carried into practice, I fear it cannot be regarded as the way of a sage. Contrary to the minds of men everywhere, men will not endure it.

passages.zh: 墨子雖能獨任，奈天下何！
passages.en: Though Mo-zi himself might be able to endure it, how can the aversion of the world to it be overcome?

passages.zh: 離於天下，其去王也遠矣。
passages.en: The world averse to it, it must be far from the way of the (ancient) kings.

passages.zh: 墨子稱道曰：「昔者禹之湮洪水，決江河而通四夷九州也，名山三百，支川三千，小者無數。
passages.en: Mo-zi, in praise of his views, said, 'Anciently, when Yu was draining off the waters of the flood, he set free the channels of the Jiang and the He, and opened communications with them from the regions of the four Yi and the nine provinces. The famous hills with which he dealt were 300, the branch streams were 3000, and the smaller ones innumerable.

passages.zh: 禹親自操稿耜而九雜天下之川，腓無胈，脛無毛，沐甚雨，櫛疾風，置萬國。
passages.en: With his own hands he carried the sack and wielded the spade, till he had united all the streams of the country (conducting them to the sea). There was no hair left on his legs from the knee to the ankle. He bathed his hair in the violent wind, and combed it in the pelting rain, thus marking out the myriad states.

passages.zh: 禹，大聖也，而形勞天下也如此。」
passages.en: Yu was a great sage, and thus he toiled in the service of the world.'

passages.zh: 使後世之墨者多以裘褐為衣，以跂蹻為服，日夜不休，以自苦為極，曰：「不能如此，非禹之道也，不足謂墨。」
passages.en: The effect of this is that in this later time most of the Mohists wear skins and dolychos cloth, with shoes of wood or twisted hemp, not stopping day or night, but considering such toiling on their part as their highest achievement. They say that he who cannot do this is acting contrary to the way of Yu, and not fit to be a Mohist.

passages.zh: 相里勤之弟子五侯之徒，南方之墨者苦獲、已齒、鄧陵子之屬，俱誦《墨經》，而倍譎不同，相謂別墨，以堅白、同異之辯相訾，以觭偶不仵之辭相應，以巨子為聖人，皆願為之尸，冀得為其後世，至今不決。
passages.en: The disciples of Qin of Xiang-li, the followers of the various feudal lords; and Mohists of the south, such as Ku Huo, Ji Chi, and Zheng Ling-zi, all repeated the texts of Mo, but they differed in the objections which they offered to them, and in their deceitful glosses they called one another Mohists of different schools. They had their disputations, turning on 'what was hard,' and 'what was white,' what constituted 'sameness' and what 'difference,' and their expressions about the difference between 'the odd' and 'the even,' with which they answered one another. They regarded their most distinguished member as a sage, and wished to make him their chief, hoping that he would be handed down as such to future ages. To the present day these controversies are not determined.

passages.zh: 墨翟、禽滑釐之意則是，其行則非也。
passages.en: The idea of Mo Di and Qin Hua-li was good, but their practice was wrong.

passages.zh: 將使後世之墨者必自苦以腓無胈、脛無毛，相進而已矣。
passages.en: They would have made the Mohists of future ages feel it necessary to toil themselves, till there was not a hair on their legs, and still be urging one another on; (thus producing a condition) superior indeed to disorder, but inferior to the result of good government.

passages.zh: 亂之上也，治之下也。
passages.en: Nevertheless, Mo-zi was indeed one of the best men in the world, which you may search without finding his equal.

passages.zh: 雖然，墨子真天下之好也，將求之不得也，雖枯槁不舍也，才士也！
passages.en: Decayed and worn (his person) might be, but he is not to be rejected - a scholar of ability indeed!

passages.zh: 夫不累於俗，不飾於物，不苟於人，不忮於眾，願天下之安寧以活民命，人我之養畢足而止，以此白心，古之道術有在於是者。
passages.en: To keep from being entangled by prevailing customs; to shun all ornamental attractions in one's self; not to be reckless in his conduct to others; not to set himself stubbornly against a multitude; to desire the peace and repose of the world in order to preserve the lives of the people; and to cease his action when enough had been obtained for the nourishment of others and himself, showing that this was the aim of his mind - such a scheme belonged to the system of the Dao in antiquity, and it was appreciated by Song Xing and Yin Wen.

passages.zh: 宋鈃、尹文聞其風而悅之。
passages.en: When they heard of such ways, they were delighted with them.

passages.zh: 作為華山之冠以自表，接萬物以別宥為始。
passages.en: They made the Hua-shan cap, and wore it as their distinguishing badge. In their intercourse with others, whatever their differences might be, they began by being indulgent to them.

passages.zh: 語心之容，命之曰心之行，以聏合驩，以調海內，請欲置之以為主。
passages.en: Their name for 'the Forbearance of the Mind' was 'the Action of the Mind.' By the warmth of affection they sought the harmony of joy, and to blend together all within the four seas; and their wish was to plant this everywhere as the chief thing to be pursued.

passages.zh: 見侮不辱，救民之鬥；禁攻寢兵，救世之戰。
passages.en: They endured insult without feeling it a disgrace; they sought to save the people from fighting; they forbade aggression and sought to hush the weapons of strife, to save their age from war.

passages.zh: 以此周行天下，上說下教，雖天下不取，強聒而不舍者也。
passages.en: In this way they went everywhere, counselling the high and instructing the low. Though the world might not receive them, they only insisted on their object the more strongly, and would not abandon it.

passages.zh: 故曰：「上下見厭而強見也。」
passages.en: Hence it is said, 'The high and the low might be weary of them, but they were strong to show themselves.'

passages.zh: 雖然，其為人太多，其自為太少，曰：「請欲固置五升之飯足矣，先生恐不得飽，弟子雖飢，不忘天下。」
passages.en: Notwithstanding all this, they acted too much out of regard to others, and too little for themselves. It was as if they said, 'What we request and wish is simply that there may be set down for us five pints of rice - that will be enough.' But I fear the Master would not get his fill from this; and the disciples, though famishing, would still have to be mindful of the world, and, never stopping day or night, have to say, 'Is it necessary I should preserve my life?

passages.zh: 日夜不休，曰：「我必得活哉！」
passages.en: Shall I scheme how to exalt myself above the master, the saviour of the age?'

passages.zh: 圖傲乎救世之士哉！
passages.en: It was moreover as if they said, 'The superior man does not censoriously scrutinize (the faults of others); he does not borrow from others to supersede his own endeavours; when any think that he is of no use to the world, he knows that their intelligence is inferior to his own; he considers the prohibition of aggression and causing the disuse of arms to be an external achievement, and the making his own desires to be few and slight to be the internal triumph.'

passages.zh: 曰：「君子不為苛察，不以身假物。」
passages.en: Such was their discrimination between the great and the small, the subtle and the coarse; and with the attainment of this they stopped.

passages.zh: 以為無益於天下者，明之不如已也。
passages.en: Public-spirited, and with nothing of the partizan; easy and compliant, without any selfish partialities; capable of being led, without any positive tendencies; following in the wake of others, without any double mind; not looking round because of anxious thoughts; not scheming in the exercise of their wisdom; not choosing between parties, but going along with all - all such courses belonged to the Daoists of antiquity, and they were appreciated by Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao.

passages.zh: 以禁攻寢兵為外，以情欲寡淺為內，其小大精粗，其行適至是而止。
passages.en: When they heard of such ways, they were delighted with them.

passages.zh: 公而不當，易而無私，決然無主，趣物而不兩，不顧於慮，不謀於知，於物無擇，與之俱往，古之道術有在於是者。
passages.en: They considered that the first thing for them to do was to adjust the controversies about different things.

passages.zh: 彭蒙、田駢、慎到聞其風而說之。
passages.en: They said, 'Heaven can cover, but it cannot sustain; Earth can contain, but it cannot cover.

passages.zh: 齊萬物以為首，曰：「天能覆之而不能載之，地能載之而不能覆之，大道能包之而不能辯之。」
passages.en: The Great Dao embraces all things, but It does not discriminate between them.'

passages.zh: 知萬物皆有所可，有所不可，故曰：「選則不遍，教則不至，道則無遺者矣。」
passages.en: They knew that all things have what they can do and what they cannot do. Hence it is said, 'If you select, you do not reach all; if you teach some things, you must omit the others; but the Dao neglects none.'

passages.zh: 是故慎到，棄知去己，而緣不得已，泠汰於物以為道理，曰：「知不知，將薄知而後鄰傷之者也。」
passages.en: Therefore Shen Dao discarded his knowledge and also all thought of himself, acting only where he had no alternative, and pursued it as his course to be indifferent and pure in his dealings with others. He said that the best knowledge was to have no knowledge, and that if we had a little knowledge it was likely to prove a dangerous thing.

passages.zh: 謑髁無任而笑天下之尚賢也，縱脫無行而非天下之大聖，椎拍輐斷，與物宛轉，舍是與非，苟可以免，不師知慮，不知前後，魏然而已矣。
passages.en: Conscious of his unfitness, he undertook no charge, and laughed at those who valued ability and virtue. Remiss and evasive, he did nothing, and disallowed the greatest sages which the world had known. Now with a hammer, now with his hand, smoothing all corners, and breaking all bonds, he accommodated himself to all conditions. He disregarded right and wrong, his only concern being to avoid trouble; he learned nothing from the wise and thoughtful, and took no note of the succession of events, thinking only of carrying himself with a lofty disregard of everything.

passages.zh: 推而後行，曳而後往，若飄風之還，若羽之旋，若磨石之隧，全而無非，動靜無過，未嘗有罪。
passages.en: He went where he was pushed, and followed where he was led, like a whirling wind, like a feather tossed about, like the revolutions of a grindstone. What was the reason that he appeared thus complete, doing nothing wrong? that, whether in motion or at rest, he committed no error, and could be charged with no transgression?

passages.zh: 是何故？
passages.en: Creatures that have no knowledge are free from the troubles that arise from self-assertion and the entanglements that spring from the use of knowledge.

passages.zh: 夫無知之物，無建己之患，無用知之累，動靜不離於理，是以終身無譽。
passages.en: Moving and at rest, they do not depart from their proper course, and all their life long they do not receive any praise.

passages.zh: 故曰：「至於若無知之物而已，無用賢聖，夫塊不失道。」
passages.en: Hence (Shen Dao) said, 'Let me come to be like a creature without knowledge. Of what use are the (teachings of the) sages and worthies?' But a clod of earth never fails in the course (proper for it), and men of spirit and eminence laughed together at him, and said, 'The way of Shen Dao does not describe the conduct of living men; that it should be predicable only of the dead is strange indeed!'

passages.zh: 豪桀相與笑之曰：「慎到之道，非生人之行而至死人之理，適得怪焉。」
passages.en: It was just the same with Tian Pian. He learned under Peng Meng, but it was as if he were not taught at all.

passages.zh: 田駢亦然，學於彭蒙，得不教焉。
passages.en: The master of Peng Meng said, 'The Daoist professors of old came no farther than to say that nothing was absolutely right and nothing absolutely wrong.'

passages.zh: 彭蒙之師曰：「古之道人，至於莫之是、莫之非而已矣。
passages.en: His spirit was like the breath of an opposing wind; how can it be described in words?

passages.zh: 其風窢然，惡可而言？」
passages.en: But he was always contrary to (the views of) other men, which he would not bring together to view, and he did not escape shaving the corners and bonds (of which I have spoken).

passages.zh: 常反人，不見觀，而不免於鯇斷。
passages.en: What he called the Dao was not the true Dao, and what he called the right was really the wrong.

passages.zh: 其所謂道非道，而所言之韙不免於非。
passages.en: Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not in fact know the Dao; but nevertheless they had heard in a general way about it.

passages.zh: 彭蒙、田駢、慎到不知道。
passages.en: To take the root (from which things spring) as the essential (part), and the things as its coarse (embodiment); to see deficiency in accumulation; and in the solitude of one's individuality to dwell with the spirit-like and intelligent - such a course belonged to the Dao of antiquity, and it was appreciated by Guan Yin and Lao Dan.

passages.zh: 雖然，概乎皆嘗有聞者也。
passages.en: When they heard of such ways, they were delighted with them.

passages.zh: 以本為精，以物為粗，以有積為不足，澹然獨與神明居，古之道術有在於是者。
passages.en: They built their system on the assumption of an eternal non-existence, and made the ruling idea in it that of the Grand Unity.

passages.zh: 關尹、老聃聞其風而悅之。
passages.en: They made weakness and humility their mark of distinction, and considered that by empty vacuity no injury could be sustained, but all things be preserved in their substantiality.

passages.zh: 建之以常無有，主之以太一，以濡弱謙下為表，以空虛不毀萬物為實。
passages.en: Guan Yin says, 'To him who does not dwell in himself the forms of things show themselves as they are.

passages.zh: 關尹曰：「在己無居，形物自著。
passages.en: His movement is like that of water; his stillness is like that of a mirror; his response is like that of the echo.

passages.zh: 其動若水，其靜若鏡，其應若響。
passages.en: His tenuity makes him seem to be disappearing altogether; he is still as a clear (lake), harmonious in his association with others, and he counts gain as loss.

passages.zh: 芴乎若亡，寂乎若清，同焉者和，得焉者失。
passages.en: He does not take precedence of others, but follows them.'

passages.zh: 未嘗先人而常隨人。」
passages.en: Lao Dan says, 'He knows his masculine power, but maintains his female weakness,-- becoming the channel into which all streams flow.

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「知其雄，守其雌，為天下谿；知其白，守其辱，為天下谷。」
passages.en: He knows his white purity, but keeps his disgrace, becoming the valley of the world.'

passages.zh: 人皆取先，己獨取後，曰：「受天下之垢。」
passages.en: Men all prefer to be first; he alone chooses to be last, saying, 'I will receive the offscourings of the world.'

passages.zh: 人皆取實，己獨取虛，無藏也故有餘，巋然而有餘。
passages.en: Men all choose fulness; he alone chooses emptiness. He does not store, and therefore he has a superabundance; he looks solitary, but has a multitude around him.

passages.zh: 其行身也，徐而不費，無為也而笑巧。
passages.en: In his conducting of himself he is easy and leisurely and wastes nothing. He does nothing, and laughs at the clever and ingenious.

passages.zh: 人皆求福，己獨曲全，曰：「苟免於咎。」
passages.en: Men all seek for happiness, but he feels complete in his imperfect condition, and says, 'Let me only escape blame.'

passages.zh: 以深為根，以約為紀，曰：「堅則毀矣，銳則拙矣。」
passages.en: He regards what is deepest as his root, and what is most restrictive as his rule; and says, 'The strong is broken; the sharp and pointed is blunted.'

passages.zh: 常寬容於物，不削於人，可謂至極。
passages.en: He is always generous and forbearing with others, and does not encroach on any man - this may be pronounced the height (of perfection).'

passages.zh: 關尹、老聃乎！
passages.en: O Guan Yin, and Lao Dan, ye were among the greatest men of antiquity; True men indeed!

passages.zh: 古之博大真人哉！
passages.en: That the shadowy and still is without bodily form; that change and transformation are ever proceeding, but incapable of being determined.

passages.zh: 芴漠無形，變化無常，死與生與！
passages.en: What is death? What is life?

passages.zh: 天地並與！
passages.en: What is meant by the union of Heaven and Earth?

passages.zh: 神明往與！
passages.en: Does the spiritual intelligence go away?

passages.zh: 芒乎何之？
passages.en: Shadowy, where does it go?

passages.zh: 忽乎何適？
passages.en: Subtle, whither does it proceed?

passages.zh: 萬物畢羅，莫足以歸，古之道術有在於是者。
passages.en: All things being arranged as they are, there is no one place which can be fitly ascribed to it. Such were the questions belonging to the scheme of Dao in antiquity, and they were appreciated by Zhuang Zhou.

passages.zh: 莊周聞其風而悅之。
passages.en: When he heard of such subjects, he was delighted with them.

passages.zh: 以謬悠之說，荒唐之言，無端崖之辭，時恣縱而不儻，不以觭見之也。
passages.en: (He discussed them), using strange and mystical expressions, wild and extravagant words, and phrases to which no definite meaning could be assigned. He constantly indulged his own wayward ideas, but did not make himself a partisan, nor look at them as peculiar to himself.

passages.zh: 以天下為沈濁，不可與莊語；以卮言為曼衍，以重言為真，以寓言為廣。
passages.en: Considering that men were sunk in stupidity and could not be talked to in dignified style, he employed the words of the cup of endless application, with important quotations to substantiate the truth, and an abundance of corroborative illustrations.

passages.zh: 獨與天地精神往來，而不敖倪於萬物，不譴是非，以與世俗處。
passages.en: He chiefly cared to occupy himself with the spirit-like operation of heaven and earth, and did not try to rise above the myriads of things. He did not condemn the agreements and differences of others, so that he might live in peace with the prevalent views.

passages.zh: 其書雖瑰瑋而連犿無傷也，其辭雖參差而諔詭可觀。
passages.en: Though his writings may seem to be sparkling trifles, there is no harm in amusing one's self with them; though his phraseology be ever-varying, its turns and changes are worth being looked at - the fulness and completeness of his ideas cannot be exhausted.

passages.zh: 彼其充實不可以已，上與造物者遊，而下與外死生、無終始者為友。
passages.en: Above he seeks delight in the Maker; below, he has a friendly regard to those who consider life and death as having neither beginning nor end.

passages.zh: 其於本也，宏大而辟，深閎而肆；其於宗也，可謂稠適而上遂矣。
passages.en: As regards his dealing with the Root (origin of all things), he is comprehensive and great, opening up new views, deep, vast, and free. As regards the Author and Master (the Great Dao Itself), be may be pronounced exact and correct, carrying our thoughts to range and play on high.

passages.zh: 雖然，其應於化而解於物也，其理不竭，其來不蛻，芒乎昧乎，未之盡者。
passages.en: Nevertheless on the subject of transformation, and the emancipation of that from (the thraldom of) things, his principles are inexhaustible, and are not derived from his predecessors. They are subtle and obscure, and cannot be fully explained.

passages.zh: 惠施多方，其書五車，其道舛駁，其言也不中。
passages.en: Hui Shi had many ingenious notions. His writings would fill five carriages; but his doctrines were erroneous and contradictory, and his words were wide of their mark.

passages.zh: 歷物之意，曰：「至大無外，謂之大一；至小無內，謂之小一。
passages.en: Taking up one thing after another, he would say: 'That which is so great that there is nothing outside it may be called the Great One; and that which is so small that there is nothing inside it maybe called the Small One.'

passages.zh: 無厚不可積也，其大千里。
passages.en: 'What has no thickness and will not admit of being repeated is 1000 li in size.'

passages.zh: 天與地卑，山與澤平。
passages.en: 'Heaven may be as low as the earth.' 'A mountain may be as level as a marsh.'

passages.zh: 日方中方睨，物方生方死。
passages.en: 'The sun in the meridian may be the sun declining.' 'A creature may be born to life and may die at the same time.'

passages.zh: 大同而與小同異，此之謂小同異；萬物畢同畢異，此之謂大同異。
passages.en: '(When it is said that) things greatly alike are different from things a little alike, this is what is called making little of agreements and differences; (when it is said that) all things are entirely alike or entirely different, this is what is called making much of agreements and differences.'

passages.zh: 南方無窮而有窮，今日適越而昔來。
passages.en: 'The south is unlimited and yet has a limit.' 'I proceed to Yue to-day and came to it yesterday.'

passages.zh: 連環可解也。
passages.en: 'Things which are joined together can be separated.'

passages.zh: 我知天下之中央，燕之北，越之南是也。
passages.en: 'I know the centre of the world - it is north of Yan or south of Yue.'

passages.zh: 氾愛萬物，天地一體也。」
passages.en: 'If all things be regarded with love, heaven and earth are of one body (with me).'

passages.zh: 惠施以此為大觀於天下而曉辯者，天下之辯者相與樂之。
passages.en: Hui Shi by such sayings as these made himself very conspicuous throughout the kingdom, and was considered an able debater. All other debaters vied with one another and delighted in similar exhibitions.

passages.zh: 卵有毛，雞三足，郢有天下，犬可以為羊，馬有卵，丁子有尾，火不熱，山出口，輪不蹍地，目不見，指不至，至不絕，龜長於蛇，矩不方，規不可以為圓，鑿不圍枘，飛鳥之景未嘗動也，鏃矢之疾而有不行不止之時，狗非犬，黃馬、驪牛三，白狗黑，孤駒未嘗有母，一尺之捶，日取其半，萬世不竭。
passages.en: (They would say), 'There are feathers in an egg.' 'A fowl has three feet.' 'The kingdom belongs to Ying.' 'A dog might have been (called) a sheep.' 'A horse has eggs.' 'A tadpole has a tail.' 'Fire is not hot.' 'A mountain gives forth a voice.' 'A wheel does not tread on the ground.' 'The eye does not see.' 'The finger indicates, but needs not touch, (the object).' 'Where you come to may not be the end.' 'The tortoise is longer than the snake.' 'The carpenter's square is not square.' 'A compass should not itself be round.' 'A chisel does not surround its handle.' 'The shadow of a flying bird does not (itself) move.' 'Swift as the arrowhead is, there is a time when it is neither fiying nor at rest.' 'A dog is not a hound.' 'A bay horse and a black ox are three.' 'A white dog is black.' 'A motherless colt never had a mother.' 'If from a stick a foot long you every day take the half of it, in a myriad ages it will not be exhausted.' - It was in this way that the debaters responded to Hui Shi, all their lifetime, without coming to an end.

passages.zh: 辯者以此與惠施相應，終身無窮。
passages.en: Huan Tuan and Gong-sun Long were true members of this class.

passages.zh: 桓團、公孫龍辯者之徒，飾人之心，易人之意，能勝人之口，不能服人之心，辯者之囿也。
passages.en: By their specious representations they threw a glamour over men's minds and altered their ideas. They vanquished men in argument, but could not subdue their minds, only keeping them in the enclosure of their sophistry.

passages.zh: 惠施日以其知，與人之辯，特與天下之辯者為怪，此其柢也。
passages.en: Hui Shi daily used his own knowledge and the arguments of others to propose strange theses to all debaters - such was his practice.

passages.zh: 然惠施之口談，自以為最賢，曰：「天地其壯乎！」
passages.en: At the same time he would talk freely of himself, thinking himself the ablest among them, and saying, 'In heaven or earth who is my match?'

passages.zh: 施存雄而無術。
passages.en: Shi maintained indeed his masculine energy, but he had not the art (of controversy).

passages.zh: 南方有倚人焉，曰黃繚，問天地所以不墜不陷，風雨雷霆之故。
passages.en: In the south there was a man of extraordinary views, named Huang Liao, who asked him how it was that the sky did not fall nor the earth sink, and what was the cause of wind, rain, and the thunder's roll and crash.

passages.zh: 惠施不辭而應，不慮而對，遍為萬物說；說而不休，多而無已，猶以為寡，益之以怪。
passages.en: Shi made no attempt to evade the questions, and answered him without any exercise of thought, talking about all things, without pause, on and on without end; yet still thinking that his words were few, and adding to them the strangest observations.

passages.zh: 以反人為實，而欲以勝人為名，是以與眾不適也。
passages.en: He thought that to contradict others was a real triumph, and wished to make himself famous by overcoming them; and on this account he was not liked by the multitude of debaters.

passages.zh: 弱於德，強於物，其塗隩矣。
passages.en: He was weak in real attainment, though he might seem strong in comparison with others, and his way was narrow and dark.

passages.zh: 由天地之道觀惠施之能，其猶一蚉一虻之勞者也，其於物也何庸！
passages.en: If we look at Hui Shi's ability from the standpoint of Heaven and Earth, it was only like the restless activity of a mosquito or gadfly; of what service was it to anything?

passages.zh: 夫充一尚可，曰愈貴，道幾矣！
passages.en: To give its full development to any one capacity is a good thing, and he who does so is in the way to a higher estimation of the Dao; but Hui Shi could find no rest for himself in doing this.

passages.zh: 惠施不能以此自寧，散於萬物而不厭，卒以善辯為名。
passages.en: He diffused himself over the world of things without satiety, till in the end he had only the reputation of being a skilful debater.

passages.zh: 惜乎！
passages.en: Alas!

passages.zh: 惠施之才，駘蕩而不得，逐萬物而不反，是窮響以聲，形與影競走也。
passages.en: Hui Shi, with all his talents, vast as they were, made nothing out; he pursued all subjects and never came back (with success). It was like silencing an echo by his shouting, or running a race with his shadow.

passages.zh: 悲夫！
passages.en: Alas!
